headline: MRS. BHUTTO ACCUSES U.S. OF DOUBLE STANDARD
abstract: The widow of Zulfikar Ali Bhutto, the former Pakistani Prime Minister who was executed in 1979, has accused the United States of using a double standard in its relations with the martial law Governments of Poland and Pakistan.   Nusrat Bhutto, whose husband was hanged by the Government of President Mohammad Zia ul-Haq for what officials said was complicity in a plot to kill a dissident member of Mr. Bhutto's political party, is in West Germany for treatment of what doctors believe may be lung cancer.   ''It is unfortunate,'' Mrs. Bhutto said in a conversation at a hotel here Saturday. ''On the one hand the Americans support Zia for five and a half years, giving wheat, giving arms, giving F-16's.'' General Zia came to power after toppling Mrs. Bhutto's husband in a bloodless coup in 1977.

headline: WARSAW IS BRACING FOR NEW PROTESTS
abstract: On the eve of a parliamentary session that is expected to outlaw the independent Solidarity union, the Polish Government has been seizing opposition activists and bracing itself for any flurry of demonstrations.   The Government's prize catch - a sharp blow to the fugitive union leadership - is Wladyslaw Frasyniuk, the Silesian labor chief and one of the organizers of the union's five-man underground coordinating committee.   Thus far, there has been no response from the Solidarity underground to the plans to enact the long-awaited trade union bill at the session of Parliament opening on Friday.   An attempt was made Wednesday to broadcast a clandestine Solidarity message over the radio, but the signal was so weak that it could not be made out.

headline: Mexico Shifts to Austerity to Win Loans
abstract: With a flurry of new laws, decrees and initiatives, Mexico's two-week-old Government has moved rapidly to impose a broad economic austerity program and to tackle the country's huge foreign debt problem.   Many of the new measures effectively reverse the policies of the administration of Jose Lopez Portillo, which bequeathed Mexico's worst economic crisis in 40 years to President Miguel de la Madrid Hurtado on Dec. 1.   Unlike his predecessor, who blamed external forces, such as the drop in oil prices and the rise in interest rates, for Mexico's troubles, Mr. de la Madrid has also stressed that the main answer to the crisis must be found at home, through a belt-tightening program to reduce the budget deficit. A lower deficit would reduce foreign borrowing to finance it. Postponement Asked of Banks   As a quid pro quo for the austerity measures that he has already enacted, Finance Minister Jesus Silva Herzog, in a telex message last weekend to Mexico's 1,400 foreign bank creditors, formally asked for a restructuring of $20 billion worth of Government debt due between August of this year and December 1984 and for $5 billion in new credits next year to ease the country's balance-of-payments crisis.  In effect, the banks were asked to postpone all repayment of debt principal through Dec. 31, 1984.

headline: ADVERTISING; Catalogue Assignment
abstract: Levine, Huntley, Schmidt, Plapler & Beaver has become the agency for Popular Services of Garfield, N.J., a 40-year-old company whose Popular Club Plan has saleswomen going door to door selling a variety of products from catalogues.

headline: BANK OF AMERICA OFFICER LEAVES TO BUY COMPANY
abstract: Lawrence E. Nerheim, an executive vice president of the Bank of America, has quit to buy an investment bank.   Mr. Nerheim, 47, resigned from the bank after announcing he had acquired European-American Securities Inc., a Los Angeles investment firm, for an undisclosed sum. Mr. Nerheim, who until last week headed Bank of America's private banking division for wealthy individuals, said he bought the ivestment firm on his own, with no outside money.   "Right now I am the sole owner," said Mr. Nerheim, who once was chief counsel for the Securities nad Exchange Commission. "I expect to invite other people onto my board, but for now it is a one-man show."

headline: Socal Deadlock
abstract: The Standard Oil Company of California said its directors met yesterday with President Suharto of Indonesia in Jakarta to try to break a deadlock in talks over renewal of a contract for production of Indonesian crude oil by P.T. Caltex Pacific Indonesia, a joint venture of Socal and Texaco Inc. Caltex hopes to extend its contract until the year 2001, and has a deadline of November 1983 to complete negotiations. The Indonesian Government now receives 85 percent of the crude oil Caltex produces, and at issue in the negotiations is its request to receive more.

headline: U.S. Steel Sells Stake in Building
abstract: The United States Steel Corporation said it had sold an 81 percent interest in its 64-story headquarters building here for $200 million and expects to sell the remaining interest by December. The purchaser was the California Public Employees Retirees System.

headline: SALVADOR AID: U.S. RESOLVE IS QUESTIONED
abstract: Mixed signals from Washington recently have reinforced the conviction among a number of conservative politicians and top military officials here that the United States will not take the drastic step of suspending aid to El Salvador as long as the guerrilla war goes on, Western diplomats here say.   The mixed signals involved the White House reaction to a speech by the United States Ambassador here, Deane R. Hinton, that was sharply critical of El Salvador's courts and security forces.   The text of the Ambassador's speech had been approved by Assistant Secretary of State Thomas O. Enders. But Administration officials said after its delivery that its candid and public nature - though not its content - did not have the specific approval of the White House or of President Reagan himself.

headline: A TOUGH SELL FOR MADISON AVENUE
abstract: LAST summer, Hal Shoup, president of the Carr Liggett advertising a gency, received a call from an industrial advertiser whose p atrongage he had been zealously seeking. ''Hal, I've got some good n ews and some bad news,'' the businessman said. ''Congratulations on w inning our account - but we're cutting the budget 50 percent.''  What seemed at the time to be a mixed blessing has been nothing but trouble for Carr Liggett, one of Cleveland's top agencies. At that reduced spending level, it hasn't made a dime on the account, and Mr. Shoup's rueful tone suggests that the shop may even have lost some money.  Ad agencies across the country have been enduring similar hardships all year - and 1983 isn't expected to be much better. The current recession has caused many advertisers to reduce spending from projected levels. And as the year progressed and the recovery became the subject of macabre jokes rather than strategic planning, the cutbacks accelerated. For some companies, such as Republic Steel, Phelps Dodge and Kenwood Electronics's home audio division, what was once a 1982 ad budget is now just a memory.

headline: ANDROPOV SAYS TALK WITH REAGAN COULD AID TIES
abstract: Yuri V. Andropov was quoted today as saying that a meeting with President Reagan could be a ''very effective'' way of improving relations between Moscow and Washington but that the success of any meeting would depend on ''good preparatory work.''   The press agency Tass also quoted Mr. Andropov, the Soviet party leader, as saying he believed that there was ''every possibility'' of the two nations' working out compromise agreements on nuclear arms issues because there were solutions available ''which do not prejudice the interests of either side.''   The remarks came in a Tass text of replies provided to written questions submitted through the Soviet Embassy in Washington by Joseph Kingsbury-Smith, an editor of the Hearst newspapers.   In the United States, Mr. Kingsbury-Smith said that the questions were submitted to the embassy on Dec. 22 and that Mr. Andropov's replies were delivered through the embassy Wednesday.

headline: AFRICAN ISLE'S STORY: SLAVERY AND A NEW SERVITUDE
abstract: There is a house in this sunstruck place that is called the House of Slaves and many Americans, both black and white, have stood before its somber dungeons in homage and quest, recalling the human traffic that once linked Africa to a cruel, new world across the Atlantic.   Here, too, there are cannon and ramparts, none of local origin, that chart a troubled history of slavers and traders and foreign forces that vied for dominance in this westernmost tip of Africa.  And, the visitor may find, there are signs of a newer subordination that has made Africans complain of economic bondage bequeathed along with political independence, a vulnerability to the vagaries of distant markets and uncontrollable climates at home and to continued influence by former colonial powers.   The visitor arrives on Goree Island, a 20-minute ferry ride from the Senegalese capital of Dakar, aboard a vessel that is the settlement's only means of support. It brings the foreign tourists who pay local youths a small sum for their services as guides and who patronize the Hostellerie du Chevalier de Boufflers, the island's sole restaurant, that sells wine and Perrier water from France, along with food of similar origin. Usually the guests are French too, from a community of 20,000 in Senegal that includes 1,200 French soldiers, stationed, as elsewhere in French-speaking Africa, as part of France's postcolonial presence.

headline: BRITONS PRESS COMPETITIVENESS
abstract: The Confederation of British Industries, Britain's ''bosses' union,'' wrapped up its closely watched convention at this seaside resort today, committed to improving the competitiveness of British business at home and abroad with a minimum of Government intervention.   The executives pressed for removal of a surcharge on an insurance tax that is paid for all employees, stronger negotiating stands with some trading partners, relief from local taxes and changes in energy pricing. They clearly wanted to play down disagreements with the Conservative administration of Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher as Britain heads into a year when she is expected to call a national election.   The generally temperate tone of the three-day meeting was typified by Sir Terrence Beckett, the organization's chief executive. This was in contrast to two years ago when he created a rift in the membership by advocating a ''bare-knuckled'' approach to the Government on issues over which it and the confederation were at odds. This year he said: ''The biggest job is for industry. On the side, we need some help from the Government.''

headline: CANADA'S GAS HURT BY ITS HIGH PRICE
abstract: Come winter, two of Canada's principal exports to the United States become more noticeable: Arctic cold and natural gas. Residents of northern states have long wished that Canadians would keep their cold to themselves, and they are beginning to feel the same way about Canada's exports of gas, much of which is used for domestic heating.   In the midst of a worldwide fuel surplus and deep stagnation in the Canadian economy, pressure is building on Ottawa to reduce gas prices, too.   According to 75 members of Congress, who expressed their sentiments in a recent letter to President Reagan, and to one of the Administration's own energy regulators, the price of Canadian gas is simply too high - $4.94 a thousand cubic feet, compared with an average price of gas produced in the United States of $2.27.

headline: GLEMP AND PRIESTS SAID TO CLASH
abstract: Priests in Archbishop Jozef Glemp's Warsaw archdiocese have accused the Roman Catholic Primate of not taking a stronger public line toward the Government, church sources said today.   The criticisms were made at a meeting Tuesday between the Archbishop and at least 200 Warsaw priests who wanted to discuss the church's role in Poland's political life.

headline: Travelers Income Down
abstract: The Travelers Corporation reported yesterday that its operating income in the third quarter dropped 18.5 percent, to $72.2 million, or 86 cents a share, from $88.6 million, or $1.04 a share, in the corresponding quarter a year earlier. The Hartford insurance company said its net income in the third quarter dropped 27.1 percent, to $64.4 million, or 76 cents a share, from $88.3 million, or $1.04 a share, in the 1981 quarter.

headline: Salvadoran Army Says It Killed 42 Rebels
abstract: The army killed 42 guerrillas and destroyed four rebel camps in eastern El Salvador in a three-day offensive, a Defense Ministry spokesman said today. Government troops reportedly suffered only two wounded.   Officials said the offensive, said to have included heavy mortar attacks and bombing runs by United States-s@upplied A-37 fighter bombers, ended Thursday and centered on an area 37 miles east of the capital.

headline: Mexico Plans 106 Closings
abstract: Mexico announced plans today to liquidate 106 of the 743 companies and agencies that are wholly or partly owned by the Government. The move was called part of a program to streamline public administration.

headline: I.M.F. Talks Set in Paris
abstract: Talks aimed at speeding up negotiations on an increase in resources for the International Monetary Fund will take place in Paris on Monday, European monetary sources said today.   Officials from the world's 10 biggest industrial nations, known as the Group of 10, hope to iron out differences between the United States and some European countries so that a final decision on an increase can be taken early next year, the sources said.

headline: DEFENDING DEFENSE
abstract: The military equipment industry has generally been thriving during the current economic downturn, but its top executives could hardly have been cheered by some of the talk at the recent Business Council meeting in Hot Springs, W. Va. At that meeting, the chairmen of several giant corporations urged the Reagan Administration to cut military spending in an effort to reduce the swelling Federal deficit.   Defense accounts for some 29 percent of the nation's total budget, or about $150 billion this fiscal year, and the pressures to pare or not to pare it are likely to mount as Election Day nears. Defense plans call for real growth rates in 1984 of 10 percent and for 7 percent each in 1985 and 1986.

headline: TROUBLE-SHOOTER GIVEN CHIEF'S POST AT MICRO Z
abstract: Things have not been going well at the Micro Z Corporation, and its board of directors has hired Joffe Marketing International in an attempt to turn the company around.   Louis H. Benzing, an executive vice president of Joffe, was named yesterday as president and chief executive officer of Micro Z. Mr.  Benzing, 55, succeeds Allan Klein, who has resigned as president but will remain the company's chief financial officer.   ''The company has gone through some hard times,'' said Mr. Benzing, who has been involved in a number of turnaround situations as a Joffe executive. Micro Z is seeking additional financing and plans to de-emphasize two of its products, he said.

headline: ICAHN DRAWN BY DAN RIVER'S BOOK VALUE
abstract: Dan River Inc. seems an unlikely company to be fighting a heated battle for control of its stock.  In the last decade, the large textile manufacturer has been a sluggish performer in an industry hit hard by rising imports, increasing competition and damaging price wars. Profits have tumbled since 1979, the company's best year, and long-term debt remains high.    The future does not appear much brighter. Analysts predict Dan River's performance will be in line with the struggling industry's norm, at best, and say it will be some time before the company sees substantial improvement. ''Obviously,'' said one analyst, ''they have problems.''

headline: Evans to Stop Homebuilding
abstract: The Evans Products Company, a construction and building supply company in Portland, Ore., said it would discontinue its homebuilding operations on Dec. 31, resulting in a pretax loss of about $20 million, in addition to $40 million in operating losses already projected for 1982.   Evans said the closings would affect 250 employees in Colorado Springs, Colo., Elk Grove, Calif., and Milesburg, Pa., plus 96 sales representatives and dealers in 38 states.   Monford A. Orloff, chairman, president and chief executive officer, said ''we have concluded that it is more prudent to concentrate our resources in the more predictable and highly profitable areas of our company,'' primarily making and leasing transportation and industrial equipment and the retailing of building materials.

headline: Not Guilty Plea on Stix
abstract: Thomas R. Brimberry, a former vice president of Stix & Company, pleaded not guilty yesterday in Federal District Courts in St. Louis, Mo., and in East St. Louis, Ill., to charges related to the bankruptcy of the brokerage firm more than a year ago.   A grand jury in St. Louis had indicted Mr. Brimberry on 10 counts of making false statements to the Securities and Exchange Commission and on one count of hiding Stix assets from the bankruptcy trustee.

headline: No Headline
abstract: REAGAN PRESSES SOVIET ON AFGHAN ACCORD   WASHINGTON, Dec. 26 (Reuters) - President Reagan, marking the third anniversary of the Soviet military intervention in Afghanistan, said today that the occupation was not a success and urged Moscow's new leaders to work toward a peaceful solution.   ''The United States does not intend to forget these brave people and their struggle,'' Mr. Reagan said in a statement, adding that ''we hope that the new leadership of the Soviet Union will take advantage of the opportunities the new year will no doubt offer to achieve a solution for Afghanistan.''   Mr. Reagan said if Soviet aggression was allowed to succeed in Afghanistan ''it will have a dangerous impact on the safety of free men everywhere.''   ''Afghanistan is important to the world because the Afghan people are resisting Soviet imperialism.'' Three years after the armed intervention, he said, the Soviet campaign ''is not a success.''

headline: Indian Army Seeking to Keep Order in a City After Violence
abstract: Indian Army units today moved into the curfew-bound city of Baroda, north of Bombay, to help maintain order after a second day of violence.   The police killed two people and wounded four when they opened fire on an angry crowd to disperse rioters, the Press Trust of India said.  Another person died of stab wounds in a hospital, raising the death toll to four since trouble, sparked by friction between Hindus and Moslems, flared on Monday.

headline: U.S.-ALLIED ACCORD ON SOVIET PIPELINE DESCRIBED AS NEAR
abstract: The United States and its key allies have reached virtual agreement on a policy that will enable President Reagan to revoke sanctions imposed on companies that take part in construction of the Soviet natural gas pipeline, Administration officials said today.   State Department officials said that some procedural details, such as the way the accord is made public, still have to be worked out and that this may take a few more days. But Larry Speakes, the White House spokesman, said he expected a public announcement ''soon'' on the agreement for East-West economic policy.   Secretary of State George P. Shultz reported on the state of the negotiations at a meeting with Mr. Reagan and the rest of the National Security Council late today.

headline: Harnischfeger Debt Discussions
abstract: The Harnischfeger Corporation, a heavy machinery company that lost $13.9 million in the third quarter, said it is beginning a costcutting plan but said the cuts will not help the company's fourth quarter, when it expects ''substantially greater losses.''

headline: Market Place; Money Fund Advantages
abstract: WILL bank liquid asset accounts draw away a substantial part of the money market funds' $200 billion asset base? A new law now ready for the President's signature would authorize such accounts for commercial banks and thrift institutions, and this prospect vexes some money funds.   But money funds offer the advantage of low-cost switching into stock and bond funds in the same family of funds. Their ''inherent'' safety may offset Federal insurance protection to be offered by the banks.   That's Charles B. Johnson's admittedly biased view. Mr. Johnson is president of the $2 billion Franklin Group of Funds in San Mateo, Calif.

headline: Your Money; Bond Swaps As Tax Aids
abstract: EVERY year around this time, tax swapping reaches a crescendo. For December is the month when thousands of holders of securities - generally bonds rather than stocks - use this device to create paper losses that will shelter part of their income from taxes.   In a typical tax swap, a portfolio is inspected to pull out fixedincome securities whose market prices are lower than their original cost. The investor's goal is to sell these bonds and then use the proceeds to buy securities - normally those with a similar maturity date, coupon value or credit rating - that have comparable or improved investment quality.

headline: Opposition Chief Asserts Guyana Regime Will Fall
abstract: Cheddi Jagan, Guyana's Marxist opposition leader, today predicted the imminent downfall of the Government of President Forbes Burnham.

headline: New Face at Marschalk
abstract: Going in as executive vice president and director of strategic planning at Marschalk is Stuart J. Agres, who since 1979 has been doing similar work for the Adolph Coors brewery. He succeeds Paula Drillman, who shifted over to McCann-Erickson, the big-sister company in the Interpublic Group of Companies. Mr. Agres, who has a Ph.D. in psychology, started in consumer research at the Leo Burnett Company in Chicago.

headline: Motorola Radios For G.M. Backed
abstract: Motorola Inc. said Delco Electronics had recommended that Motorola's AM stereo broadcasting system be used on radios in General Motors Corporation vehicles.

headline: 21 Colombian Rebels Yield
abstract: Twenty-one leftist guerrillas, 15 men and six women, surrendered over the weekend to the Roman Catholic Bishop of Florencia, Jose Luis Serna, and applied for amnesty, the Bishop said today.

headline: BRITAIN TO INCREASE ULSTER FORCES
abstract: Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher's Government will add 800 men to Northern Ireland's police forces and will increase security spending by $20 million a year in the province, Britain's Cabinet Minister for Northern Ireland announced today.   The Cabinet minister, James Prior, in his first speech to the new Northern Ireland Assembly, rejected hard-line Protestant demands for a drive against the guerrillas of the Irish Republican Army Provisionals.   ''It is natural that in our disgust and contempt for violent crimes we should be tempted to take short cuts,'' Mr. Prior said. ''We must, however, resist the temptation. We can only win by unremitting, patient and skilled activity on all fronts.''

headline: Italy Open to Increase In Beirut Peace Force
abstract: Foreign Minister Emilio Colombo of Italy said today that his Government would respond favorably to a Lebanese request to expand the multinational peacekeeping force if the conditions were acceptable to the other troop contributors, France and the United States.   Mr. Colombo suggested that an increase in the strength of the force might require the participation of other countries, but he declined to identify potential contributors.

headline: SATURDAY, OCTOBER 9, 1982; The Economy
abstract: The September jobless rate rose 0.3 of a percentage point, to 10.1 percent, force, the highest monthly rate since 1940. The Labor Department said that 11,260,000 people were out of work last month and that the total number of employed fell 119,000, to 99,720,000.  Officials noted more job losses in manufacturing and an unusual decline in wholesale and retail jobs. (Page 1.) New York City's jobless rate fell to 9.2 percent. (11.) In California, President Reagan warned the Democrats not to try to exploit the new data. (10.)    The heads of many big companies predicted only a tepid recovery next year. Nor did the executives, at a meeting of the Business Council, see much hope for improvement soon in unemployment or investment in industry. But the forecast, prepared by company economists, did say inflation will be kept at 6 percent in 1983.  (31.)

headline: What's New in Consumer Research; OF BELONGERS, ACHIEVERS, SURVIVORS ET AL.
abstract: Advertising executives will spend close to $15 billion on television commercials this year, even though they don't always understand the consumers they are trying to reach.   Madison Avenue has traditionally categorized the buying public into such amorphous groups as housewives (18 to 54 years of age), upscale working women (18 to 34), or urban men (34 to 55). But such divisions give advertisers little insight into people's life styles, personal values or goals -all of which affect the way they decide to spend their money.   Now, however, a newly developed research approach enables marketers to view consumers as something other than vague statistics. After years of in-depth interviews with consumers, the Stanford Research Institute created VALS - for Values and Life Styles -to provide Madison Avenue with an economic, social and emotional profile of American society. What a client gets is a series of reports based on extensive interviews with Americans, conducted by the Stanford institute. Clients can commission specific studies or they can get parts of a regular series of reports that can cover everything from religious views to attitudes about a hypothetical economic disaster.

headline: Transamerica Net Off
abstract: The Transamerica Corporation announced yesterday that its profits in the third quarter dropped 50.1 percent, to $39.8 million, or 64 cents a share, from $79.8 million, or $1.23 a share in the comparable period last year. The diversified financial services and manufacturing company said that total revenues in the third quarter rose to $1.12 billion, from $1.06 billion the year before. James R.  Harvey, president and chief executive officer, said that ''all our businesses have strong turnaround potential so that as the economy and insurance markets improve, our subsidiaries earnings should benefit substantially.''

headline: Pemex Files Suit
abstract: Mexico's national oil monopoly has filed suit in Federal court, charging that two Houston engineering companies conspired to fix prices on marine construction and service projects for 20 years. The suit filed by Petroleos Mexicanos, commonly known as Pemex, said its damages amounted to ''many millions of dollars'' because of what was termed the violation of antitrust laws by Brown & Root Inc., a subsidiary of the Halliburton Company, and McDermott Inc. Pemex said it had spent more than $50 million for marine projects between 1960 and 1980. Both Brown & Root and McDermott officials declined comment.

headline: Weekly Steel Output Up 10%
abstract: Steel production rose to 1.027 million tons in the week ended last Saturday, a 10 percent increase from the previous week's 934,000 tons, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday.

headline: Chrysler Profit Outlook
abstract: The Chrysler Corporation still has a good chance to be profitable for the year, despite a five-week Canadian strike that cost about $100 million, Robert Miller, executive vice president for finance, said today.

headline: Homes for Winter Are Found For Palestinians in Lebanon
abstract: About 95,000 Palestinians left homeless after Israel's invasion of Lebanon on June 6 have found housing for the winter, the chief of the United Nations Relief and Works Agency said.   ''Every refugee in Lebanon will have a roof over his head this winter,'' Olof Rydbeck, the official, said Friday.  He said about 183,000 of the 239,000 Palestinians in Lebanon are receiving some form of United Nations aid, most of it food.  Mr. Rydbeck told reporters here Friday that his agency spent about $20 million to house those made homeless by the war.

headline: REAGAN SAYS BASING SYSTEM FOR MX IS NOT AN ISSUE
abstract: President Reagan today disavowed any intent to make an issue of his MX missile-basing plan as he warned that Senate rejection of production funds for the missile would weaken the chance for peace.   ''The basing mode is not an issue,'' the President declared in what was perhaps his strongest attempt thus far to divorce the issue of producing the MX from the greater Congressional controversy over where and how to protect the missile's launching silos.   ''There's plenty of time to decide on that,'' he continued in his weekly radio address to the nation. ''What we need now is a clear, positive vote on the missile itself, to go forward on production of the missile.''

headline: U.S. AND SOVIET DELEGATES SEE U.N. CHIEF ON CURBING COSTS
abstract: Representatives of the United States, the Soviet Union and Britain met today with Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar for a 45-minute discussion on holding down the rising cost of the United Nations.   On her way into the Secretary General's office, Jeane J.  Kirkpatrick, the United States delegate, described the talks as ''an inquiry,'' and said, ''We have no specific proposals.''

headline: Bendix Net Falls 84.8%
abstract: The Bendix Corporation, citing the impact of the recession, reported yesterday that net income in its fiscal fourth quarter plunged 84.8 percent, while sales slipped 6.2 percent.   The company said net income in the three months ended Sept. 30 fell to $9.7 million, or 42 cents a share, from $63.7 million, or $2.78 a share, in the corresponding quarter a year earlier.

headline: People
abstract: * Richard Catania and Vernon Mackie have joined Sawdon & Bess Advertising, a subsidiary of Ted Bates, as senior vice presidents and creative group heads.   * Merle Schel has been promoted to senior vice president at Rosenfeld, Sirowitz & Lawson Inc.

headline: U.S. APPROVES MAJORITY OF BELL OPERATING AREAS
abstract: The Justice Department says it is willing to accept most of the proposals advanced by the American Telephone and Telegraph Company for staking out the operating areas of the Bell System companies once they are divested in 1984.   In a filing Wednesday with Federal District Court Judge Harold H.  Greene, the department said it was reserving judgment or opposing only 9 of the 161 operating areas proposed last month by A.T.& T. to meet the terms of its August antitrust settlement.

headline: RATES STABLE IN QUIET TRADING
abstract: Interest rates were little changed to slightly lower in quiet trading yesterday. Securities dealers said investors seemed to be taking a breather after the heavy buying in August and earlier this month.   Although yields now available on notes and bonds are at their lowest levels since 1980, many dealers and economists are optimistic that short-term interest rates will decline further, thereby encouraging investors to shift funds from short-term securities to higher-yielding notes and bonds.

headline: Talking Business with Zvi Porath of Elscint; CAT Scanner's New Rival
abstract: In advanced medical diagnostics, a new generation of technology is competing with the CAT scanner, which has revolutionized medical imaging. Nuclear magnetic resonance, or N.M.R., systems, producing pictures of the body based on the responses of atomic nuclei in a magnetic field, are considered by some experts to be safer and more effective than the CAT scanner. A half-dozen companies worldwide produce one or two of the systems. But only Elscint Ltd., an Israelbased company whose stock is traded on this country's over-thecounter exchange, derives almost all of its revenues from three imaging systems.   Zvi Porath, Elscint's chief economist, had been a consultant to the World Bank and his country's representative to the board of the International Monetary Fund. Here the 41-year-old executive discusses his company's prospects.

headline: LEBANESE TROOPS RESUME SEARCHES IN CAPITAL
abstract: The Lebanese Army resumed its searches of predominantly Moslem West Beirut for hidden weapons and illegal residents today, increasing concerns over when similar sweeps might be conducted in Christian-dominated East Beirut.   Twenty-seven people were reportedly seized in shantytown areas on the southern outskirts of West Beirut. About a thousand people have been taken into custody so far in the eight days of searches.

headline: MARINES TO START PATROLLING CHRISTIAN-DOMINATED EAST BEIRUT TODAY
abstract: The United States Marine contingent here said today that its first patrols would enter East Beirut on Wednesday to extend its presence to what has been the stronghold of Christian militiamen.   The first patrols will consist of armed infantrymen in four jeeps, according to Lieut. Col. Jonathan Abel, the spokesman of the Marine contingent, which is stationed at the international airport on the southern outskirts of Beirut.   The colonel spoke at a briefing a day after the State Department announced in Washington that the role of the marines in the multinational peacekeeping force was being expanded at the request of President Amin Gemayel.   A spokesman for the Lebanese Forces, as the Phalangist-dominated militias are known, said the entry of marines would present ''no problem whatsoever.'' He said the militiamen would stay in their barracks.

headline: Cellular Permit; For Boston
abstract: The Federal Communications Commission has issued its second construction permit for a cellular mobile telephone system, this time for the rights to operate in Boston.   The Boston permit, like the first permit issued in Chicago, went to a subsidiary of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company.

headline: Butler Filing
abstract: The Butler Communications Corporation, which bought radio stations WHLD-AM and WZIR-FM on suburban Grand Island in May 1980, has filed for reorganization under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Act. William M. Savino, lawyer for the company, said its debts total about $1.7 million. The company cited ''unexpectedly high start-up costs'' for creating a deficit before the stations switched last June to ''an album-oriented rock format.''

headline: U.S. NOW BACKING GUATEMALA LOANS
abstract: The State Department says that because of what it sees as improvements in the human rights situation in Guatemala, it has recommended that the United States no longer block development bank loans to that country, according to Administration officials.   On the basis of the State Department's recommendation, the Treasury Secretary, who directs the activities of the United States in the development banks, plans to support an $18 million loan request from Guatemala to the Inter-American Development Bank, according to a Treasury Department official. The loan is for a $30 million rural telephone project.   Without opposition from the United States, which provides about $1.1 billion, or roughly 42 percent, of the Development Bank's current capital funds, the loan is expected to be approved this month.

headline: DOW RISES BY 26.12, TO 1,019.22
abstract: The Dow Jones industrial average, surging ahead yesterday amid forecasts of further extended declines in interest rates, jumped 26.12 points, to 1,019.22, its highest level in nearly 18 months.   The sharp rise put the Dow average, for the second time in less than a month, within striking distance of its highest level in close to a decade.   Yesterday's finish was the highest since 1,024.05 on April 27, 1981, when the stock market still basked in the glow of President Reagan's election and budget cuts were the talk of Washington. That, in turn, marked the best finish since 1,026.19 on Jan. 19, 1973, when the Dow was receding from its record closing of 1,051.70 on Jan. 11 of the same year, when institutional purchases were concentrated in the ''favorite 50'' growth stocks.

headline: SOME INSIGHTS INTO ANDROPOV GLEANED FROM BUDAPEST ROLE
abstract: In a number of ways, the fortunes of Yuri V.  Andropov have been linked to those of Hungary. Mr. Andropov, the new Soviet party leader, served in the Soviet Embassy in Budapest from 1953 to 1957, initially as a second-rank official, then as Ambassador.   Those were troubled times, marked by growing unrest, by the 1956 uprising and by the installation of Janos Kadar as head of the Hungarian Communist Party.   So were the years that followed. Mr. Kadar began evolving his program of economic decentralization, and Mr. Andropov, by then back in Moscow, was largely responsible for allowing him to develop the program in his position overseeing the Central Committee's dealings with Eastern Europe. Hungarians Willing to Talk   Mr. Andropov's tenure in Hungary gives his background a special quality. No other top Soviet leader since Lenin has ever lived outside the Soviet Union. And it offers the West a chance to learn something about the man. The Hungarians know him well, and they are willing to talk; people in the Soviet Union have usually found it prudent to say nothing, or to hew to a prearranged line, in discussing the country's leaders.

headline: New Order for F-18A
abstract: Secretary of the Navy John Lehman announced a one-year agreement today with the McDonnell Douglas Corporation to build 63 F-18A fighter-attack planes for $1.14 billion. The agreement ended an effort by the Navy to reduce the price of the planes. Mr. Lehman said the contract represented a cost of $22.5 million a plane, the same as the present price, despite inflation. The Northrop Corporation is the prime F-18A subcontractor and the General Electric Company is the engine builder.

headline: BONN OPENS DOOR FOR ELECTIONS IN MARCH
abstract: Chancellor Helmut Kohl's conservative coalition intentionally lost a confidence vote in Parliament today, opening the way for general elections in three months.   ''All the parties represented in the German Bundestag want new elections,'' said Mr. Kohl, defending his unusual recourse to the confidence vote. ''The great majority of our citizens also want new elections.''   The opposition Social Democratic Party voted no to the confidence motion, which carried by 218 votes; 248 Christian Democratic and Free Democratic deputies abstained, while eight coalition deputies, troubled by the maneuver's constitutionality, voted yes for the Chancellor.

headline: Janis Quits Presidency Of California Federal
abstract: Jay Janis, a former head of the Federal Home Loan Bank Board, resigned yesterday as president of the California Federal Savings and Loan Association, the third-largest savings and loan institution in the country .   Sources said that Mr. Janis, 49, who joined California Federal in January 1981, had apparently resigned over management differences with Robert R. Dockson, 65, chairman and chief executive.

headline: THE NEW, HIGH-RATE BANK ACCOUNT
abstract: COMING soon at a bank near you: new opportunities to save money at t he highest interest rates the market has to offer at no risk to you.T he ads could be worded this way. But the promise is exactly what is i ntended in a new Government law intended to make banks and savings a nd loan associations competitive with their old nemesis, the m oneymarket funds.   Many in the financial industry believe that the new law, signed Friday by President Reagan and expected to go into effect within at least 60 days, will create a profound shake-up in the American financial system by making banks and thrift institutions more than equal to the money funds. The big lure of the new accounts that can be offered by the thrift units, bankers say, is that they will be allowed to offer high, money-market interest rates while being insured by the Federal Deposit Insurance Company and the Federal Savings and Loan Insurance Corporation for up to $100,000. The money funds, by contrast, are not insured.

headline: TECHNOLOGY
abstract: ABOUT 12 years ago, a major shift took place in the complex technology used in integrated circuits: Computer chips using a new technology known as metal-oxide-semiconductor, or MOS, started gaining a greater share of the market at the expense of chips using an older technology known as bipolar.   The change had profound effects on products and corporate fortunes. MOS technology helped make possible new types of complex chips, such as the microprocessors used in personal computers and high-capacity memories. And those companies that were able to exploit the new technology were able to rise to prominence. One such company was the Intel Corporation, in which the International Business Machines Corporation yesterday bought a 12 percent stake. Another even named itself after the technology - the Mostek Corporation.

headline: KIM DAE JUNG ARRIVES IN U.S. AFTER BEING FREED BY SOUTH KOREA
abstract: The South Korean opposition figure Kim Dae Jung arrived in Washington tonight and said that his most fervent wish was to return to his homeland and dedicate his life to the peaceful reunification of North and South Korea.   Mr. Kim was given a boisterous welcome at Washington's National Airport by about 300 South Koreans living in the Washington area, including a large contingent of South Korean journalists. Supporters sang the South Korean national anthem as Mr. Kim was escorted to a private room at the airport where he made a brief statement. Mr. Kim spoke in Korean and his remarks were translated by a companion.

headline: SPREADING RISK WITH COMMODITY FUNDS
abstract: THE recent flow of new commodity futures and options has drawn many n ew investors into these lively, but risky, markets, where one can m ake quick and large profits on relatively small cash outlays. These n ew products are also luring investors into the underlying c ommodities markets, where the risks are even greater.   Among those new investors are many who do not even know what commodities their money is riding on, whether they are long or short any market, or how price moves are affecting their investments at any given moment - nor do they particularly care.   These investors are not irrationally reckless; indeed, they are probably being cautious. They are putting their money into commodity funds, or pools as they are called by the trade. Such funds, which ''pool'' the money of many investors and are managed by professional commodities traders, have been around for some time now. They allow a commodity ''play,'' but spread and limit the risk.

headline: U.S. SEEKS TIGHTER CURBS ON EQUIPMENT FOR SOVIET
abstract: The Reagan Administration, in its broadest effort yet to slow the sale of technology to the Soviet Union, is seeking to toughen the system that the United States and its allies use to control the flow of equipment to Communist countries, according to Defense and Commerce Department officials.   The United States is expected to propose more than 100 changes, including many additions, in the list of controlled exports at a meeting in Paris next week of the Coordinating Committee for Exports to Communist Areas, known as Cocom. It will also press for a substantial increase in Cocom's budget and expansion of its enforcement abilities.   The committee, founded in the late 1940's, includes the United States, its allies in the North Atlantic Treaty Organization except Iceland, and Japan.

The Defense Minister, Field Marshal Abdel Halim Abu Ghazala, who attended the war games about 50 miles east of the Suez Canal, was quoted as saying that the exercises were ''defensive in character'' and that Egypt was committed to peace with Israel.

headline: AUSTRALIAN TOWN IS SHAKEN BY A RACIAL CLASH
abstract: A fragile peace between white and aboriginal Australians has been shattered in the small town of Moree in New South Wales near the border of Queensland.   A clash in a bar between whites and aborigines ended early Friday with the death of one aborigine, 19-year-old Ronald McIntosh, and the wounding of two others, Stephanie Duke and Warren Tighe. Today police officers from Sidney were called in by the state government to keep peace in Moree, a town of 10,000 people.   The New South Wales government acknowledged that there were serious problems in towns like Moree that have large aboriginal populations.  ''The Moree tragedy stems from deep social and economic ills which beset people of western New South Wales towns, conditions such as severe unemployment, poor health and bad housing,'' the statement said.

headline: Market Place; The Insiders At Humana
abstract: HUMANA INC. has made a determined effort to substitute quality for quantity by cutting costs and dropping less profitable units. This strategy must be working because the hospital company's earnings have risen sharply and its shares continue to rate high at Value Line, the advisory service.   So why are Humana insiders selling shares at a seldom-seen pace?  One member of the management team, reached by telephone yesterday, said he had sold to raise money to pay for optioned shares. He said his overall holdings had not been reduced significantly.

headline: IRANIANS CHALLENGE OIL LIMITS
abstract: Mohammad Gharazi, Iran's oil minister, tonight dismissed as a meaningless bluff threats by Saudi Arabia and other Arab countries to stage a showdown over oil prices next month.   Speaking at a news conference for foreign correspondents, Mr.  Gharazi said that Iran had set a production goal of three million barrels a day -more than twice the quota of 1.2 million barrels set by the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries. Iran's goal would be the limit of the Iranian oil fields in their current condition, according to Western experts.   He said, however, that the production target had not been reached because of ''direct pressure'' from Saudi Arabia on Iran's oil markets.

headline: People
abstract: * James G. Carter has been appointed vice president, director of marketing for the Somerset Wine Company.

headline: F.C.C. Clears Bell's Permit
abstract: Despite complaints that it is improperly favoring telephone companies, the Federal Communications Commission today awarded the first construction permit for a cellular mobile telephone system to the American Telephone and Telegraph Company.

headline: Unreal Conditions
abstract: To the Business Editor: Paul W. MacAvoy's argument for immediately deregulating natural gas, as espoused in ''The Time to Deregulate is Now'' (Sept.26), assumes unreal economic conditions.   Professor MacAvoy overlooks contractual provisions between pipelines and producers which turn a ratchet on wellhead prices and inhibit market signals from getting to the producers. For example, indefinite escalator clauses would permit decontrolled gas to rise immediately to the highest price of a particular region, thus raising gas prices substantially above the market clearing level. ''Take or pay for'' provisions, where pipelines must ''take or pay for'' gas amounts contracted from producers, prevent pipelines from negotiating for lower-priced gas and further inhibit the market from reacting normally.

headline: Japan Balance Of Payments
abstract: Japan's overall balance of payments swung to a surplus of about $1.61 billion in November from a deficit of $73 million in October, the Finance Ministry announced today.

headline: AD RESEARCH GAINING GROUND
abstract: People who eat frozen TV dinners are harassed and hard-working, a researcher found.  Based on that finding, Leo Burnett, the Chicago advertising agency, created ads for Swanson frozen TV dinners that showed an overworked housewife reaching for the product. The campaign proved ill-conceived when it made its debut some years ago. Harassed consumers, it turned out, did not like to be reminded of how hectic their lives were.   In a study in the early 1970's, Needham, Harper & Steers/Chicago, on behalf of its client, the McDonald's Corporation, confirmed what consumers could see for themselves: Many fast-food establishments were dingy. The agency set about making McDonald's fast-food outlets seem more inviting.

headline: ITALY VOWS TO STUDY LEBANESE TROOP REQUEST
abstract: President Amin Gemayel received assurances today that Italy was ready to consider his request to enlarge the size and scope of the three-nation peacekeeping force in Beirut.   The Lebanese leader, heavily guarded after a bomb attack on his embassy here on Wednesday, also received a warm accolade from Pope John Paul II, lunched with President Sandro Pertini and dined with Prime Minister Giovanni Spadolini.   Mr. Gemayel will return to Beirut on Friday, at the end of a trip that took him to the General Assembly of the United Nations and meetings in Washington with President Reagan, who told him that the United States would consider the request to enlarge the peace force, and in Paris, where President Francois Mitterrand told him that France was ready to increase its contingent.

headline: 14 Are Reported Killed In North Lebanon City

headline: Ruling on Ford

headline: Huntington's Bid for Union
abstract: Huntington Bancshares Inc. of Columbus, Ohio, freed by a Federal Court decision, moved yesterday to merge the Cleveland-based Union Commerce Corporation into Huntington.   Huntington said it had purchased 55.9 percent of the voting shares of Union Commerce.

headline: 'DRAMATIC CHANGE' IN NICARAGUA URGED BY ITS ENVOY TO U.S.
abstract: Nicaragua's Ambassador to Washington has called for a ''dramatic change'' in the direction of the Sandinist Government, saying that it could ease its isolation by improving relations with neighboring governments and by increasing political freedom at home.   The Ambassador, Francisco Fiallos Navarro, made his comments in an interview that local authorities here banned from an opposition newspaper.   (Repeated efforts, both by telephone and through Nicaraguan officials, to reach Mr. Fiallos, who was believed to be in the United States, were unsuccessful this weekend. A spokesman for the Nicaraguan Embassy in Washington declined to comment on the interview.)

headline: Mesa's Credits Total $1 Billion
abstract: The Mesa Petroleum Company said that it had bank commitments for credits of $1 billion to be used in part for a pending takeover bid for the General American Oil Company of Texas.   It said up to $400 million, now unsecured, would be used for corporate needs other than to buy securities on credit.

headline: Santa Fe Industries Plans for Successor
abstract: John J. Schmidt, the president of Santa Fe Industries, has the inside track to become chairman and chief executive officer of the Chicago-based transportation and energy concern. He was recommended yesterday for the position by John S. Reed, the 65-year-old chairman and chief executive who will retire after the annual meeting next April.   Analysts expect Mr. Schmidt, 54, to markedly change Santa Fe's management strategy. The two top executives have long disagreed over which direction to take Santa Fe, which earned $154 million on sales of $2.4 billion in this year's first nine months. Mr. Reed has a reputation as a staunch railroad man, while Mr. Schmidt is viewed as finance-oriented.

headline: Economic Scene; A Reformer For Both Blocs
abstract: AT a time when economic policies seem to have become principally political and ideological weapons to be used in combat by politicians and their agents, it may be useful to remember the contributions of Abba P. Lerner, one of the greatest economists of this century.   Professor Lerner, who died three weeks ago in Tallahassee, Fla., at the age of 79, always called the issues as he saw them, whatever special economic or political interests were involved. And he always pursued the broad interests of humanity, seeking to base his advice on scientific fact and logic.   He did not care whether he was labeled a Socialist or capitalist, and he was actually something of both. He regarded such labels as capitalism and Communism as misleading and, even worse, corrupting of scientific thought on how to help people advance their own welfare freely - and at the same time advance the well-being of the society as a whole. What Mr. Lerner sought to serve was what he called ''everybody's business.''

headline: U.S. Home to Buy Brigadier Industries
abstract: The U.S. Home Corporation, the nation's largest on-site home builder, announced today that it had agreed to buy a controlling interest in Brigadier Industries, the nation's seventh-largest maker of mobile homes, for $25.4 million.   Guy R. Odom, board chairman and chief executive officer of U.S.  Home, said the acquisition of Brigadier would ''provide U.S. Home with a beginning point in the company's commitment to being the dominant builder in more segments of the shelter industry.''

headline: Square D Plans An Acquisition
abstract: The Square D Company, a maker of electrical and electronic equipment, said it had signed a letter of intent to acquire San Diego-based Topaz Inc. for $55.3 million in cash or stock.

headline: Brazil Oil Purchases
abstract: Brazil's state oil company, Petrobras, will double, to 100,000 barrels a day, its purchases of crude oil from the Saudi state oil concern, Petromin, the Petrobras president, Shigeaki Ueki, said.

headline: Peru Sets Out to Crush Guerrilla Organization
abstract: About 1,500 soldiers and police rangers began a sweep through southern Peru today on a mission to crush a Maoist guerrilla group.   President Fernando Belaunde Terry placed seven provinces in three departments, or states, under military control Wednesday night after the guerrillas, members of a group called Shining Path, spurned his request to give up.

headline: I.B.M. Rises by 36.2%
abstract: The International Business Machines Corporation said yesterday that third-quarter profits rose 36.2 percent from its unusually weak third quarter a year ago.   The world's largest computer company said it earned $944 million, or $1.58 a share, for the quarter, compared with $693 million, or $1.18 a share, a year earlier. Revenues climbed 21.6 percent, to $8.17 billion, from $6.72 billion.

headline: MRS. BHUTTO ACCUSES U.S. OF DOUBLE STANDARD
abstract: The widow of Zulfikar Ali Bhutto, the former Pakistani Prime Minister who was executed in 1979, has accused the United States of using a double standard in its relations with the martial law Governments of Poland and Pakistan.   Nusrat Bhutto, whose husband was hanged by the Government of President Mohammad Zia ul-Haq for what officials said was complicity in a plot to kill a dissident member of Mr. Bhutto's political party, is in West Germany for treatment of what doctors believe may be lung cancer.   ''It is unfortunate,'' Mrs. Bhutto said in a conversation at a hotel here Saturday. ''On the one hand the Americans support Zia for five and a half years, giving wheat, giving arms, giving F-16's.'' General Zia came to power after toppling Mrs. Bhutto's husband in a bloodless coup in 1977.

headline: WARSAW IS BRACING FOR NEW PROTESTS
abstract: On the eve of a parliamentary session that is expected to outlaw the independent Solidarity union, the Polish Government has been seizing opposition activists and bracing itself for any flurry of demonstrations.   The Government's prize catch - a sharp blow to the fugitive union leadership - is Wladyslaw Frasyniuk, the Silesian labor chief and one of the organizers of the union's five-man underground coordinating committee.   Thus far, there has been no response from the Solidarity underground to the plans to enact the long-awaited trade union bill at the session of Parliament opening on Friday.   An attempt was made Wednesday to broadcast a clandestine Solidarity message over the radio, but the signal was so weak that it could not be made out.

headline: Mexico Shifts to Austerity to Win Loans
abstract: With a flurry of new laws, decrees and initiatives, Mexico's two-week-old Government has moved rapidly to impose a broad economic austerity program and to tackle the country's huge foreign debt problem.   Many of the new measures effectively reverse the policies of the administration of Jose Lopez Portillo, which bequeathed Mexico's worst economic crisis in 40 years to President Miguel de la Madrid Hurtado on Dec. 1.   Unlike his predecessor, who blamed external forces, such as the drop in oil prices and the rise in interest rates, for Mexico's troubles, Mr. de la Madrid has also stressed that the main answer to the crisis must be found at home, through a belt-tightening program to reduce the budget deficit. A lower deficit would reduce foreign borrowing to finance it. Postponement Asked of Banks   As a quid pro quo for the austerity measures that he has already enacted, Finance Minister Jesus Silva Herzog, in a telex message last weekend to Mexico's 1,400 foreign bank creditors, formally asked for a restructuring of $20 billion worth of Government debt due between August of this year and December 1984 and for $5 billion in new credits next year to ease the country's balance-of-payments crisis.  In effect, the banks were asked to postpone all repayment of debt principal through Dec. 31, 1984.

headline: AFRICANS AT U.N. CRITICIZE DELAYS ON NAMIBIA
abstract: Uganda's Foreign Minister, Albert Picho Owiny, told the 37th session of the United Nations General Assembly today that there was no justification for linking independence for South-West Africa and the presence of Cuban troops in Angola.   The first is a clear-cut colonial issue, he said, while the second concerns a ''bilateral arrangement'' between two independent and sovereign countries   Mr. Owiny said there had been reports for several months about ''substantial progress'' toward a negotiated settlement on the South African-ruled territory, also called Namibia. But he said no such settlement seemed to be in sight.

headline: Irish Leader Wins No-Confidence Vote
abstract: Prime Minister Charles J. Haughey of Ireland survived a no-confidence motion tonight in the parliamentary caucus of the ruling Fianna Fail Party by what was reported as a 58-to-22 vote in his favor.   But the challenge to his leadership, the second this year, was expected to worsen his difficulties as head of a minority government. Two Cabinet members resigned today after refusing to back him. Mr. Haughey is considered a liability by many in his party, which emerged from an election in February as the largest in the lower house of Parliament but fell short of a majority.

headline: Dow Banking Loss Provision
abstract: The Dow Banking Corporation, which is 75 percent owned by the Dow Chemical Company of Midland, Mich., has not ruled out a cut in its dividend this year to finance provisions for doubtful loans, a bank official said.

headline: NEW SOVIET TACTIC IN A WAR IS SEEN
abstract: A British specialist on Soviet military affairs says the Soviet high command may be rewriting its operational planning for invading western Europe. The Soviet aim, he says, would be to win any war in Europe in three to four days before commanders of the North Atlantic Organization could obtain approval from political leaders to fire their tactical nuclear weapons.   This concept is described in the quarterly International Defense Review by Christopher N. Donnelly, a senior analyst at the Soviet Studies Research Center of the Royal Military Academy at Sandhurst, England.   Under such a concept, Mr. Donnelly says, one divisional-size ''Operational Maneuver Group'' would be drawn from each of the five Soviet armies in East Germany, and they would seek to penetrate the forward defenses of the Western alliance at high speed. He suggests that they would also attempt to halt alliance reinforcement, eliminate tactical nuclear weapons sites and destroy field headquarters but that they would not use tactical nuclear weapons.

headline: Technology; Co-generation: New Problems
abstract: NEARLY two years after Harvard University thought it had surmounted the long regulatory delays and legal challenges that have added about $100 million to the cost of a large co-generation power plant, a Massachusetts court has once again put the facility's future in doubt.   In a ruling in September, the Massachusetts Supreme Judicial Court said the state's Department of Environmental Quality Engineering, which had held more than three years of hearings on the project, erred when it failed to consider the possible carcinogenic effects of particulates that might be emitted from the plant's smokestack. The court ordered the agency to hold further hearings.   The 73-megawatt plant, which would be diesel-powered, is in the Mission Hill section of Boston, and the suit that led to the court order was brought by local residents and the neighboring town of Brookline.

headline: 25 Colombia Guerrillas Freed Under Amnesty
abstract: Twenty-five members of the Colombian leftist guerrilla group known as M-19, including its founder, Carlos Toledo Plata, have been freed from jail under a new amnesty law, prison authorities said.   Among the guerrillas freed Saturday, authorities said, was Rosemberg Pabon Pabon who led one of the group's boldest actions in February 1980 when a commando group took over the Dominican Republic's Embassy and held a dozen diplomats hostage, including the United States Ambassador.

headline: Safeway Says Net Doubled
abstract: Safeway Stores announced that net income in the 12 weeks ended Sept. 11 more than doubled, to $39.1 million, or $1.50 a share, from $15.5 million, or 59 cents, in the corresponding period a year earlier.

headline: GUYANA'S LEADER THRIVES AS HIS NATION FOUNDERS
abstract: Amid growing food shortages and hardship, increasing layoffs and dismal economic prospects, the Government of Forbes Burnham has never been more unpopular - or more solidly in power - according to Guyanese who support and oppose him.   President Burnham's opponents, as well as numerous members of the diplomatic community here, say that his continued political good health is the result of rigged elections, manipulation of the work force in the largely nationalized industrial sector and political repression, possibly including the assassination of a political opponent two years ago.   President Burnham, a large, bearded man with a quick wit and a disconcerting laugh, painted a very different picture from that heard on the streets. In an interview in his modest book-lined office here, he brushed aside charges against him, crediting his political wellbeing to a slowly growing public understanding of the goals of his ''cooperative socialism'' and to a disorganized and ineffectual opposition.

headline: MONEY MAGAZINE PROFITABLE FOR TIME INC.
abstract: Rumor had it that time nearly ran out on Money magazine. Time Inc., that is.  Five years ago, cynics at Time Inc. were betting that the giant communications company would fold Money, the personal finance monthly it introduced in 1972. Money was a money-loser. ''There were some questions about whether Money would survive,'' said Marshall Loeb, the magazine's managing editor.   Money marks its 10th anniversary this month. And despite its difficult debut, Money's outlook today is upbeat. After eight years of losses and a major shift in editorial strategy, Money has survived and prospered. Moreover, it has taught Time Inc. executives some hard lessons about how to create new magazines and develop an audience.

headline: Eastern Air Lines
abstract: Eastern Air Lines Inc. said it was prepared to defy a ruling by the Civil Aeronautics Board and cut prices of its tickets sold through travel agents if other airlines begin selling their tickets through nonagency discounters. The board, as part of its airline deregulation move, ruled that ticket sales could be made only by trade assocation-accredited travel agents, thus paving the way for discounters to enter the travel business.

headline: Ownership Expanded At Hong Kong Agency
abstract: Saatchi & Saatchi Compton has acquired the majority holding in Chase Compton Advertising Ltd., Hong Kong. Fifteen years ago Compton International purchased a minority interest in what was then known as Chase Advertising.   Chase Compton, founded more than 20 years ago, has billings of approximately $3 million.

headline: 2 BIG WHOLESALERS CUT HEATING OIL PRICES
abstract: Two of the largest suppliers of heating oil in the Northeast, the Gulf Oil Corporation and the Exxon Corporation, again cut their wholesale heating oil prices yesterday. Analysts said the move had resulted from an unexpected drop in demand.   Future price decreases appear likely, the analysts added.  ''It's good news for consumers,'' said David Morehead, a spokesman for the National Petroleum Jobbers, a Washington-based federation of 15,000 independent petroleum marketers. But not all homeowners are expected to benefit, a spot-check showed. While a New York retailer said yesterday that it was planning to drop its prices, a Maine company said it would not pass along the lower wholesale price.

headline: WEDNESDAY, NOVEMBER 24, 1982; The Economy
abstract: Consumer prices rose 0.5 percent in October, the Labor Department reported. The increase was slightly larger than officials had expected, but not enough to upset a projection that inflation will be down to about 5 percent for the year. (Page A1.) Prices in the New York area rose 1.5 percent. (D3.)   Factory orders for durable goods fell 4.9 percent in October, to a seasonally adjusted total of $69.7 billion, the Commerce Department reported. Analysts said that the decline, the biggest in a year, indicates further declines in overall industrial production, which would keep unemployment high. (D1.)

headline: HOUSE PASSES U.S. AUTO CONTENT BILL
abstract: The House, after long debate, passed tonight by a narrow margin a protectionist trade bill requiring foreign auto manufacturers selling cars here to use substantial percentages of American parts and labor in their vehicles, as well as use American advertising services. The measure was passed by a vote of 215 to 188.    The measure, which is aimed at Japan, is intended to encourage foreign auto makers to build their cars here, thereby creating jobs in the ailing domestic automotive industry. Slim Chance for Senate Passage   Although the bill is given almost no chance of passage by the Senate, the House action was considered highly important because it reflected American frustration at the slow progress Japan has made in opening its markets to a variety of American goods.

headline: Auto Layoffs Reach 251,490
abstract: The number of United States auto workers on indefinite layoff this week reached 251,490, the highest level in seven months, while an industry report showed that car and truck production fell to a 12-year low in October.   The auto makers said Thursday that the increase in indefinite layoffs from last week's 247,767 resulted from more furloughs at the General Motors Corporation, the Ford Motor Company and Volkswagen of America Inc.

headline: Bank Merger
abstract: A proposed $100 million merger between the CBT Corporation and State National Bank of Connecticut has received final approval from Federal banking regulators, following the banks' agreement to sell five branch offices. The approval, granted by the United States Comptroller of the Currency, hinged on the combined banks' divestiture of about $30 million in deposits and as many as six offices. The banks also need approval from the United States Department of Justice.

headline: SPAIN'S NEW LEADER OUTLINES CAUTIOUS PLANS TO PARLIAMENT
abstract: Felipe Gonzalez said today that his new Cabinet would pursue a domestic policy of austerity and would review its military ties to the United States and the North Atlantic Treaty Organization.   In a 70-minute address to Parliament, Mr. Gonzalez, who led his Socialist Party to victory in the election Oct. 28, outlined a domestic and foreign posture as moderate and cautious as the men he has carefully picked for the first Socialist Cabinet since the Spanish Civil War. A parliamentary vote naming the 40-year-old Mr.  Gonzalez Spain's third Prime Minister since the death of Francisco Franco is expected Wednesday or Thursday after a full debate.

headline: A REVIVAL FOR FURNITURE
abstract: Furniture makers, after five depressed years, are predicting a major increase in industry shipments next year and the first half of 1984. They pin that hope on two factors: the higher consumer disposable income that is expected to accrue from the Federal income tax cuts, and the increased residential construction resulting from lower interest rates. Furniture sales are, of course, a direct beneficiary of new housing construction.

headline: APL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: THE DELOREAN: VALUE DEBATED
abstract: When John Z. DeLorean decided in the 1970's to produce a hot new sports car, his intention was to build an ''ethical'' auto. By that, Mr. DeLorean said, he meant one that did not disintegrate five years after it rolled off the showroom floor.   There seems little question that Mr. DeLorean's creation will be seen on the road in the months ahead, auto experts say. What is at issue is the true worth of the stainless-steel car - its original listed price was $25,000 - and whether it will become a collector's item as a result of the closing of the DeLorean factory in Northern Ireland and Mr. DeLorean's arrest on drug charges in Los Angeles.

headline: Market Place; Trane's Deal For G.E. Unit
abstract: THE Trane Company's decision to make an all-cash purchase of General Electric's residential central air-conditioning business instead of the cash-and-stock combination originally planned suggests that Trane is no longer fearful of a takeover.   The original deal was made after O'Connor Securities and O'Connor & Associates acquired a block of Trane stock, and threw a scare into Trane that an unfriendly takeover bid might be forthcoming. O'Connor recently increased its position to 15.3 percent of the company's 10.2 million shares outstanding.   Trane was going to pay $100 million in cash plus enough shares to give G.E. a 15 percent stake in the business. Analysts say that worked out to $165 million. That plan might have deterred a takeover, but would have meant some earnings dilution. From a fundamental point of view, then, analysts prefer the new plan, under which Trane is paying $135 million cash.

headline: RETAILERS' CHRISTMAS GAINS SLIM
abstract: With one day to go till Christmas, retailers around the country are reporting sales gains that, on average, lag behind those of last year's generally weak shopping season.   Performances at the stores vary widely, a spot-check of retailers in various cities found. Many are reporting flat sales, others are showing 2 to 4 percent gains and still others say they are enjoying 8 to 10 percent advances over 1981. The average sales rise appears to be 5 percent or less. The 1981 increase at department stores averaged about 7 percent.

headline: Cummins-Mexico
abstract: The Cummins Engine Company said it had agreed to acquire a 40 percent interest in a new Mexican company, Dina Motores S.A., which will make Cummins small V-diesel engines in Mexico. The partner, Diesel Nacional S.A., also known as Dina, is owned by the Mexican Government. It will hold 60 percent of the venture.

headline: ATLANTA'S FADED MEDIA DREAM
abstract: This city's bid to join New York, Chicago and Los Angeles as major media centers has met with a series of setbacks, leading some executives here to suggest that the business hub of the South may not achieve its goal anytime soon.   McDonald & Little, the agency that put Atlanta into the advertising limelight during the mid-1970's by landing the city's first national account, lost a $10 million account to a Chicago agency early this fall. This, in addition to the loss of two other major accounts since the agency was acquired last year by Ted Bates International in New York, means the company's billings will drop this year to about $20 million, from $51 million in 1981.   Before being acquired last year by Bates, McDonald was the city's largest independent ad agency and, with Henderson Advertising in Greenville, S.C., one of the South's two largest.

headline: Blaze Forces Marcos From Palace in His Robe
abstract: Fire broke out in ceremonial rooms at the palace of President Ferdinand E. Marcos today when a Christmas tree light bulb exploded.   The police said a palace technician was overcome by smoke and collapsed and that another palace aide was injured when he fell off a ladder while trying to flee the fire.   Mr. Marcos was led out of the palace in a robe and slippers and stood on the lawn surrounded by bodyguards as firemen with at least 12 fire trucks brought the blaze under control. Mrs. Marcos was not in the palace at the time.

headline: FRENCH STEEL TOWN TELLS ITS STORY WITH AN S O S
abstract: For misery, Longwy will do. In the valley, the carcass of an abandoned steel mill. On the slopes above, row houses, the color of mud. At the peak of the farthest ridge, a slag heap, a brown pyramid of waste and junk, with a sign on top that says ''S O S.''   Twenty years ago, the Longwy area, close to the Belgian and Luxembourg borders, had 30,000 steelworkers. In those days, the children in school here learned that its freight yard handled more tonnage than any other in France. Now the steel jobs are down to 6,700 and will be reduced further to 4,400 in 1986. Young people leave, and their fathers, automatically retired from the mills at 50, grow old in their first week at home, people say.

headline: Gold Options Open With Spirited Trading
abstract: The first trading in options on gold futures began yesterday on New York's Commodity Exchange. Despite a day of sinking gold prices, there was spirited two-way trading in the new options. An estimated 3,200 options were traded, each based on a Comex 100-ounce futures contract.

headline: As Advertised
abstract: To the Business Editor: In attempting to relax ''truth in advertising rules,'' James C.  Miller 3d, the chairman of the Federal Trade Commission, wants to put some well-established economic findings into practice, despite opposition from both advertisers and consumerists, as noted in ''A Curious Push to Weaken F.T.C. Advertising Rules'' (Nov.14).   Over the past few years, a large body of research has concluded that the current rules do not improve consumer information, but rather increase costs and inhibit head-to-head competition among advertisers.

headline: SPENDING OFF 0.2% FOR CONSTRUCTION
abstract: Spending on building construction declined a slight two-tenths of 1 percent in September, although construction spending for housing continued to rise as interest rates declined, the Commerce Department reported today.   The September decrease, to an annual, seasonally adjusted rate of $229.8 billion, was coupled with a revision in the August figures.  They were adjusted to a six-tenths of 1 percent rise, to an annual rate of $230.2 billion. The August performance had been estimated earlier at a rise of 1.6 percent.

headline: News Analysis
abstract: There is a question about the Socialist-led Government of President Francois Mitterrand that gets asked rather little in France even as it gets more pertinent: Apart from a lot of the speech-making, how much of the Government's leftist program remains intact?   After Mr. Mitterrand's Finance Minister, Jacques Delors, said recently that there would be no increase in the minimum wage, and talked about the need to increase management profit margins, the question seemed real, but very awkward.   For French conservatives, there is no profit in suggesting that Mr. Mitterrand's operating principles in a time of economic problems are now rather like everyone else's in the Western industrial world.  And for the Socialists, it would be waking a nasty sleeping dog to suggest that all the talk of moderation, rigor and austerity is somehow short of a policy that subordinates everything to the welfare of the working man.

headline: ECONOMIC AFFAIRS; WHO'S TO BLAME FOR THE ECONOMY?
abstract: WHY are we going through this immensely costly, painful and d angerous period of high unemployment rates? What caused it?  If one listens to President Reagan, one hears the following story: T he Democrats, who have controlled the White House only four of the l ast 14 years, caused the inflation by their profligacy. Once the i nflation was under way, high unemployment rates followed, like the n ight the day. Untouched by human hands, one might say.  The real story is very different. The inflation was mostly caused by the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries. Unemployment has been purposely induced and purposely tolerated to fight it.

headline: Aide to Begin Confirms Settlements' Expansion
abstract: The Deputy Prime Minister, David Levi, said today that ''a massive program of building'' was being undertaken at established Jewish settlements in the occupied West Bank of the Jordan.   Interviewed on the Israeli radio, Mr. Levi said, ''More settlements will be created soon, but only under the authority of the ministerial committee on settlements.''

headline: DISSENT ON A.T.& T. PLAN
abstract: Affidavits filed by executives of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company show a disagreement within the company over how to handle the divestiture of one of A.T.&T.'s local phone companies.   The affidavits were filed with Federal District Judge Harold H.  Greene in connection with a 471-page reorganization plan explaining how A.T.& T. plans to divest its 22 local phone companies to comply with the antitrust agreement it reached with the Justice Department in January. Judge Greene, who has jurisdiction over the antitrust case, must rule on each aspect of the divestiture.

headline: UNIVERSITY PATENTS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31

headline: NCR, WANG AND APPLE REPORT GAINS
abstract: The NCR Corporation, a diversified manufacturer of data processing equipment and computer systems, said yesterday that third-quarter net income rose 31.2 percent, to $50.1 million, or $1.87 a share, from $38.2 million, or $1.41 a share, in the third quarter of 1981.   The Dayton, Ohio, company said revenues for the period rose to $840.1 million from $800.8 million a year earlier.  NCR said its performance in the quarter was enhanced by improved revenues from services and software sales as well as reductions in inventory and more stringent cost controls.

headline: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
abstract: * Bowne & Co. has named Franz Von Ziegesar president and chief executive officer, succeeding Victor Simonte Jr., who is retiring at year-end.   * CBS Inc. has elected George Vradenburg 3d vice president, and Laurence B. Glasberg vice president and general auditor.   * Celeron Corp., Lafayette, La., has promoted Tom F. Yonker Jr. to senior vice president of gas processing for the Louisiana Intrastate Gas Corp., an operating company of Celeron.

headline: Market Place; Judging Risk In Municipals
abstract: NEW YORK CITY has drawn up plans to lay off at least 3,300 workers and to leave thousands of other positions unfilled. New Jersey is struggling to come up with some new sources of tax revenues. Indeed, in cities and states across the country, governments are scraping to find ways of cutting costs and raising revenues to bring their budgets into balance.   For many investors, this walk along a financial tightrope poses a tricky question. Municipal bonds are still offering tax-exempt yields in the 10 percent range and, now that interest rates have plunged, the rates look particularly attractive. But are they safe?
