headline: McDonald's In Dutch Shift
abstract: There are some new business assignments that bring to the victorious agency more pleasure than the mere size of the billings would justify.   Such is the landing of the McDonald's fast-food business in the Netherlands by the Dutch affiliate of Needham, Harper & Steers.

headline: FORGET THE ECONOMY, STOCKS AND BONDS ARE BUYS
abstract: QUESTION: What investment environment are we likely to encounter next year? What are the big dangers?   BIGGS: An environment that is disinflationary and verges on deflationary. There's certainly a possibility that we're going to have a quarter in 1983 where we actually have a falling Consumer Price Index.   KURTZ: Yes. And one area that could cause concern would be oil, with a price war between the producing countries. If you have a gradual decline in the price of oil, that would be very bullish for the economy. But another scenario, the scary one, is if you have the price of oil collapse down to $20 a barrel or below in a fairly short period of time. That would be downright deflationary.

headline: Zia Defends Flogging As an Islamic Practice
abstract: President Zia ul-Haq of Pakistan yesterday defended his country's practice of flogging criminals, saying that the practice is allowed both by Islamic law and ''the civil law which was inherited from the British.''   Mr. Zia, who said in Washington Wednesday that ''there is a style of flogging,'' was asked at a luncheon of the Foreign Policy Association in New York to explain the difference between ''flogging with style and flogging without style.''

headline: Korean Company Plans U.S. Plants
abstract: The Gold Star Company of South Korea, a maker of electronic products, said it planned to invest heavily in production facilities in the United States. It said the investment could result in the employment of 3,000 Americans and generate annual sales of $500 million by 1990.

headline: British Tourism Up 4%
abstract: More than 9.5 million foreign tourists came to Britain in the first nine months of 1982, a 4 percent increase over the same period last year, the Department of Trade reported today.

headline: British Union Acts to Halt Steel Imports; Britons Set Steel Protest
abstract: The main British steelworkers' union announced today that it planned to blockade ports to halt steel imports. It said the imports were ruining the British steel industry and contributing to unemployment.   Leaders of the union, the Iron and Steel Trades Confederation, appealed to the National Union of Railwaymen and the Transport and General Workers Union, representing longshoremen to help it prevent the imported steel from leaving the docks at Immingham on the Humber River on England's east coast.

headline: Treasury Prices Down a Bit; 2-Year Notes Yield 9.79%
abstract: Prices declined slightly for Treasury securities yesterday as traders and investors waited for new developments that would confirm widespread predictions of lower interest rates in coming weeks.   Weak demand for outstanding Treasury issues spilled over into the regular monthly auction of new two-year Treasury notes, which resulted in a coupon of 9 3/4 percent and an average yield of 9.79 percent. That yield is down from 12.2 percent at last month's sale, but up from 9.59 percent estimated by market participants on Monday.  It was the lowest yield since 8.97 percent in July 1980, and was down sharply from 14.43 percent at last June's sale.

headline: GREAT LAKES INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: CITICORP POSTS GAIN OF 55.6%
abstract: The nation's two largest banks yesterday reported their earnings for the third quarter, conveying two sharply contrasting reactions to falling interest rates.   The BankAmerica Corporation, the nation's largest bank holding company, reported that its operating income fell 13.7 percent, to $103 million, or 70 cents a share, compared with $119.3 million, or 81 cents a share, for the same period a year ago.   Citicorp, the nation's second-largest bank holding company, said operating income in the third quarter increased 55.6 percent, to $210 million, or $1.61 a share, from $135 million, or $1.07 a share, in the same period last year.   While Citicorp and other leading banks benefited significantly from declining interest rates, BankAmerica's net interest income rose only 2.8 percent in the quarter, to $733 million, compared with $713 million in last year's quarter. The net interest margin - the spread between the bank's cost of funds or deposits and what it earns on loans - fell to 3 percent, from 3.1 percent in the 1981 period.

headline: 500 Sikh Militants Arrested in Punjab
abstract: The police arrested 500 Sikh militants today at a Punjab railway station as they were about to board a train to New Delhi to demonstrate for autonomy during the Asian Games, the authorities said.   In New Delhi, another 59 Sikh demonstrators were arrested near Parliament for violating a newly proclaimed ban on assembly, the police said.   Both groups belong to the Akali Dal, or Sikh Party, a militant organization demanding greater autonomy for Sikhs in Punjab state, where most of India's 13 million Sikhs live.

headline: BRIEFS
abstract: * American Electric Power System said it had temporarily idled two mining operations because of a reduction in coal supply requirements.    * Branch Corp. announced that its Branch Banking and Trust Co. unit had agreed in principle to acquire City National Bank of Charlotte, N.C.   * First and Merchants Corp. said directors had authorized it to buy 300,000 of its common shares out of 6,383,968 outstanding.   * Hittman Corp. disclosed that it had reached an agreement in principle to sell its unprofitable Hittman Medical Systems Inc.  subsidiary to Leadenhall Sterling P.L.C. of Britain for about $2.3 million.

headline: TEECO PROPERTIES reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: U.N. ASSEMBLY ASKS A NUCLEAR FREEZE
abstract: Against opposition from the United States and its European allies, the General Assembly called on the major powers today to freeze the output and emplacement of nuclear weapons.   The votes, on two companion resolutions, were 122 to l6 with 6 abstentions, and 119 to 17 with 5 abstentions. They came against a background of mounting demands in the West from political leaders and citizens' groups for a halt to the buildup in nuclear stockpiles.   Today's result, some envoys said, is likely to have more effect in strengthening the pressure for a freeze as a political issue in the West than in influencing the course of arms negotiations.

headline: SOUTH AFRICA SOWS NAMIBIA CONFUSION
abstract: For five years Western negotiators have been regularly thrown off balance and sometimes baffled by the way South Africa varies its diplomatic signals on the intractable issue of South-West Africa.   Seemingly contradictory statements by two key members of Prime Minister P.W. Botha's Cabinet in recent days have left them guessing again.   Defense Minister Magnus Malan, who is often portrayed as a protege of the Prime Minister, seemed to tell a Cape Town business group in unmistakable terms on Saturday that the Government could not accept a settlement that would result in a victory by the South-West Africa People's Organization, the insurgent movement that has been trying to dislodge South African forces from the disputed territory.   On Tuesday night Foreign Minister Roelof F. Botha told a political rally in Stellenbosch that South Africa's only concern was to see a ''free and fair'' election in South-West Africa and that if this produced a victory by the insurgent movement ''there is very little South Africa can do about it.''

headline: U.S. DROPS REFUSAL TO TALK TO SOVIET AT MADRID PARLEY
abstract: The United States, seeking to avoid a political rift in the Atlantic alliance, has dropped its refusal to resume negotiations in Madrid on East-West cooperation.   The Reagan Administration had declined to resume the Madrid talks with the Soviet Union because of the continuing crackdown in Poland.  But the Americans have now won allied consent to make any East-West accord conditional on the Russians accepting and living up to such measures as allowing free trade unions and ending radio jamming.   A senior Administration official said today that the American willingness to resume work on a final Madrid document was more tactical than substantive. He said it was inconceivable to the Administration that the Russians would accept the terms that would be laid down by the NATO alliance, or that any document would be approved.

headline: MATERIAL RESEARCH CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: PROSECUTOR LINKS CHIEF AT WARNER TO BRIBE PLAN
abstract: A Federal prosecutor asserted yesterday that Steven J. Ross, chairman of Warner Communications, had designated the company's assistant treasurer as the ''banker or overseer of a secret cash fund'' containing $170,000 obtained as bribes.   The prosecutor, Nathaniel H. Akerman, made the accusation in an opening statement to jurors in the fraud and racketeering trial of Solomon Weiss, the assistant treasurer. The trial is being held in Federal District Court at Foley Square in Manhattan.   Asked for comment on the prosecutor's accusation, Martin D. Payson, general counsel for the giant entertainment company, said Mr. Ross ''unequivocally denies any authorization or participation or knowledge of any secret cash fund.''

headline: THE EGO AND THE ART OF DAVID GEFFEN
abstract: DAVID GEFFEN'S phone rang all morning, the sound richocheting like c oins off the David Hockney paintings that hang serenely in his F ifth Avenue apartment. First, Sherry Lansing, the president of 20th C entury-Fox Productions, was on the phone. Then Steve Ross, the c hairman of Warner Communications. Mr. Geffen hung up. He knew he waso n a roll and smiled. The phone rang again.   There was a hush, then the former whiz kid of the record industry, who directed the careers of many of the seminal rock groups of the 1970's, let out a cry. He had just clinched a movie deal with Steven Spielberg, the director of ''E.T.'' Holding the phone away from his ear, he started to dance, a crooked little Rumpelstiltskin hop. For one moment, Mr. Geffen, by virtue of his height and his elasticwaist trousers, looked more like a 12-year-old than a bi-coastal mogul of the entertainment industry.   But he is not 12. He is 39. And, after a four-year retirement brought about when a tumor in his bladder was somehow misdiagnosed as cancerous, he has begun a second career with a drive bordering on vengeance. At a time when the fortunes of the entertainment industry are sagging, Mr. Geffen's $100 million show business company for now is soaring.

headline: Data General Earnings Sag
abstract: The Data General Corporation yesterday reported severely depressed earnings for its latest quarter.

headline: NEWPORT ELECTRONICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: DORCHESTER GAS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: RATE OUTLOOK LINKED TO FED
abstract: Although fundamental economic forces such as declining inflation and weaker credit demand are sustaining hopes for a long-term drop in interest rates, the near-term rate outlook will be guided by the Federal Reserve, many analysts suggest.   ''There is nothing new in the economy that sheds much light on where the market is going in the near term,'' said Joseph Bench, vice president at Shearson/American Express. ''The key will be the Fed's behavior after the elections.''   The consensus view is that the overnight rate for bank loans in the Federal funds market will soon drop below 9 1/2 percent and will be accompanied by one or more reductions in the discount rate, which the Fed charges on loans to financial institutions. According to many Fed watchers, the central bank may wait until Nov. 12, when money supply data for October is to be announced, before reducing the discount rate from the current 9 1/2 percent level.

headline: K.G.B. PRAISED BY SOME AND FEARED BY MANY
abstract: The K.G.B., the Committee for State Security, is praised by the Communist leadership as the ''sword and shield'' of the Soviet Union, and, at the same time, is the most widely feared instrument of the Government.   Inside the Soviet Union its 90,000 or so staff officers guard against internal security threats and run the political prisons.  Along the fringes, 175,000 of its border troops patrol the Soviet Union's 41,800 miles of frontiers. Beyond Soviet borders, its scientific-technical operatives sweep Western countries seeking the latest secret inventions, while its ''illegals'' try to penetrate foreign intelligence operations.

headline: Fanfani Says He'll Form A Four-Party Cabinet
abstract: Prime Minister-designate Amintore Fanfani said today that he would submit a four-party coalition Cabinet to President Sandro Pertini on Tuesday after the Republican Party of the departing Prime Minister, Giovanni Spadolini, refused to join.

headline: OTHER STOPS IN THE AREA EXPECTED
abstract: Pope John Paul II will visit El Salvador early next year, a Roman Catholic Church official said here today.  The trip is expected to include stops in other Central American countries and in Haiti.   The announcement of the Pope's journey was made by Auxiliary Bishop Gregorio Rosa Chavez in the Sunday morning homily at the Metropolitan Cathedral here. He said he expected the visit to take place late in February or early in March, but gave no further details. There was no immediate statement from the Vatican.

headline: The U.N. Today; Dec. 2, 1982; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
abstract: Meets at 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.   General Committee - 10 A.M.   Political and Security Committee - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.   Special Political Committee - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M. headline: Mead Cuts Payout
abstract: The Mead Corporation said directors had halved the quarterly dividend 25 cents a common share, payable Dec. 1 to holders of record Nov. 10. The paper producer said the cut had been made to conserve cash and maintain financial strength. It added that its cost-cutting steps should place it in an ''enviable position when the economy recovers.''

headline: TRANSCO ENERGY CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Top 2 Posts Filled At Morgan Stanley
abstract: S. Parker Gilbert has emerged from the anonymity of a management committee at Morgan Stanley & Company as possibly the next top man at the prestigious investment banking firm.   In management changes announced yesterday, Robert H.B. Baldwin, the firm's president, becomes chairman and Mr. Gilbert, 49 years old, succeeds Mr. Baldwin. The changes are effective Jan.1.

headline: Dissident Holder Sells Tosco Stake
abstract: Kenneth M. Good, the shareholder who led an unsuccessful fight to oust Tosco Corporation management last spring, has sold his group's holdings back to Tosco for $49.5 million in cash and securities, the company said.   The combination of $27 million in cash and $22.5 million in threeyear notes amounted to an average price of $19.49 a share. Mr.  Good said last spring that he paid an average of $23.50 a share for his 12 1/2 percent stake.

headline: Barter With East Urged
abstract: Western companies will have to accept more deals with the Communist world involving payment in goods rather than in cash if East-West trade is to flourish, a senior United Nations official said today.   East European countries, which lack hard currency and credits from Western banks, need to import Western technology, the official, Janez Stanovnik, chief of the United Nations Economic Commission for Europe, said in an interview. He is retiring this week after 15 years in the post.

headline: ARRACCA PETROLEUM CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Quake Rocks South Pacific
abstract: A major earthquake rocked the South Pacific this morning just east of the International Date Line, the Pacific Tsunami Warning Center here said. The quake measured 7.2 on the Richter scale, which lists anything higher than 7 as a major quake. The quake was centered in the vicinity of the Kermadec Islands northeast of New Zealand.

headline: Debt Relief For Saarstahl
abstract: An accord with creditor banks on a plan to ease the burden of commercial debts on Arbed Saarstahl, a steel producer, is near completion, a company spokesman said.   In reply to inquiries, he said Wednesday that the agreement, freezing debt repayments until the beginning of 1986, had been reached with leading banks in the consortium of more than 20 West German creditors.

headline: GO-BETWEEN SAYS NASSER SOUGHT ISRAELI PACT
abstract: In the spring of 1955, the Egyptian Government asked a prominent American Quaker to undertake a secret diplomatic assignment intended to bring about a political settlement with Israel.   The American who undertook the mission, Elmore Jackson, says in a newly completed, unpublished account of his efforts that he was making progress toward setting up a meeting of senior Egyptian and Israeli officials, but a sudden outbreak of fighting between Israelis and Palestinians in the Gaza Strip caused the mission to fail.   Mr. Jackson had the backing of the United States Government, and the personal backing of Gamal Abdel Nasser, the Egyptian Prime Minister; Moshe Sharett, the acting Israeli Prime Minister, and David Ben-Gurion, who was serving as Defense Minister but was the principal political figure in Israel.   A State Department official said this week that departmental records confirmed that Mr. Jackson had been on the mission.

headline: KERR-MCGEE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: EGYPT SEEKS TALKS ON BEACH DISPUTE
abstract: Egypt formally asked Israel today to resume negotiations over the future of a narrow strip of Sinai beach that both nations claim. The request came as work on an Israeli luxury hotel neared completion on the disputed, 750-yard stretch of beach south of the Israeli port city Eilat.   The dispute is over where the border between Israel and Egypt runs at the strip of beach, which is called Taba. Attempts to settle the issue were put off so that Israel could meet the Sinai withdrawal timetable, which called for the return of the final occupied strip of the peninsula to Egypt last April 25.

headline: RETAILERS' WEEKEND IS UNEVEN
abstract: Sales on the first weekend of the 1982 Christmas shopping season proved strong in New York, San Francisco, Washington and Cleveland, but failed to reach merchants' hopes in Chicago and Detroit.   Friday and Saturday's sales ranged from 3 percent to 12 percent higher than the equivalent 1981 days, retailers in the six cities reported in telephone interviews. They estimated that yesterday's business in those stores that were open would show the same percentage rises, although rain and poor weather in the afternoon decreased store traffic. A Make or Break Period   In general, year-to-year sales gains of 4 percent or less would mean flat sales, in view of the latest 3.7 percent price rise in department store merchandise. The Christmas season is usually considered a make or break period for retailers.

headline: SIMCOE ERIE INVESTORS LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Talks on Fate of Bases Resume in Athens
abstract: Greek and United States negotiators resumed their talks in Athens today to decide on the possible renewal of a 29-year-old agreement on the status and operation of American military bases in Greece.   The talks, between Deputy Foreign Minister Ioannis Kapsis and Reginald Bartholomew, a State Department official, were held at the Foreign Ministry in the center of Athens.   The negotiations concern the fate of four key bases - two near Athens and two on the island of Crete - and a number of smaller military installations throughout the country.

abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: PAN AM ENGINEERS GRANT CONCESSIONS
abstract: Pan American World Airways said yesterday that it had reached an agreement with the Flight Engineers International Association that includes continuing a 10 percent wage cut and cost-saving changes in work rules.   The two-year contract, which becomes effective Jan. 1 and covers 872 employees, is similar to the concessions granted by the carrier's 1,702 pilots in their contract on Nov. 30.

headline: Spending Rises 1%; Income Up
abstract: Spending by Americans rose a healthy 1 percent last month, while personal income edged up only three-tenths of 1 percent, the Government reported today.   The 1 percent September gain in spending - the third increase in a row - was welcomed by both Government and private economists. But they disagreed on whether it meant recovery from the recession was at hand.

headline: Poland Expects Credits Of $3 Billion in Budget
abstract: Parliament approved today a 1983 budget that anticipates $3 billion in credits from non-Communist banks. According to Western officials, the credits would take the form of a postponement of $3 billion in debt payments.   Deputy Prime Minister Janusz Obodowski, summing up the Government's economic policy before the vote, said Poland ''is ready to start negotiations with our creditors.''

headline: Bolivia to Try 3 Ex-Rulers
abstract: The Supreme Military Court said today that three members of a former Bolivian junta would be tried by a military court on charges of illegal dealing in semiprecious stones. The three -Gen. Luis Garcia Meza, Gen. Waldo Vernal and Rear Adm. Ramiro Terrazas - came to power in July 1980 and ruled for a year.

headline: Reuters Names a New Editor For North American Services
abstract: Margaret Klein, financial services editor for Reuters North America, will become managing editor for the United States and Canada on Jan. 1, the company announced yesterday.

headline: I.L.O. Might Scrutinize Soviet Pipeline Crews
abstract: The Soviet Union has offered to receive a team of International Labor Organization officials to discuss living and working conditions on the pipeline under construction to carry natural gas from Siberia to Western Europe, the I.L.O. said today.   Discussions are under way between the organization, a United Nations agency to which 150 nations belong, and the Soviet Union on the composition of the team and the scope of the mission it would undertake, said Kyril Tidmarsh of Britain, the agency's spokesman.

headline: EMERSON ELECTRIC UP 1.7%
abstract: Internorth Inc. reported yesterday that weakness in its natural gas operations caused net income in the third quarter of this year to plunge 48.8 percent on an increase in revenues of 8.7 percent.   The Omaha company said that earnings in the latest three months plummeted to $14.5 million, or 32 cents a share, from $28.3 million, or 63 cents a share, in the corresponding quarter of 1981. Revenues advanced to $806.2 million from $741.6 million.

headline: General Foods Dividend
abstract: The General Foods Corporation said today that its board had raised the quarterly dividend to 60 cents a share from 55 cents, payable Dec. 3, for shareholders of record Nov.  16. The company last raised its dividend, from 50 cents, in June 1980.

headline: BOLT BERANEK & NEWMAN INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: U.S. DELEGATION TO SEEK TALKS IN MOSCOW
abstract: The Reagan Administration intends to use Leonid I. Brezhnev's funeral as an opportunity to tell the new Soviet leadership that the United States desires better relations but is prepared to continue its military buildup if the Russians prefer confrontation, senior Administration officials said today.   They said that Vice President Bush and Secretary of State George P. Shultz, who head the American delegation to Moscow, hope to have meetings at least with Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko during the approximately 24 hours they will be in Moscow. They are due to arrive there on Sunday afternoon Moscow time and depart Monday afternoon after the funeral.   The main point that Mr. Bush and Mr. Shultz intend to make, the officials said, is that the Administration believes that the Soviet Union is largely responsible for the deterioration of relations by its moves in such places as Afghanistan, Poland and Cambodia, and by its imprisonment of dissidents and its tighter emigration policy.

headline: BALDWIN & LYONS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: SATURDAY, DECEMBER 11, 1982; International
abstract: The U.S. and the Common Market agreed on talks to defuse a crisis over farm exports. After a meeting in Brussels, both sides indicated that while differences remained, they could be settled in follow-up meetings to be held early next year. (Page 1.) The U.S. and its allies agreed to increase the I.M.F.'s basic lending power by 50 percent. Little was said, however, about a U.S. proposal that changes in the world monetary system be discussed. (42.)   A treaty codifying a law of the seas was signed by representatives of 117 nations at a meeting in Jamaica. While the U.S. and other major industrial nations did not sign the document, third world delegates welcomed the signing and contended that the code would be effective. It takes effect if ratified by the legislatures of 60 nations, but would be binding only on the nations that ratify it.  (1.)

headline: FLORIDA PROGRESS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Long-Term Bond Prices Drop; Yield Falls at Treasury Sale
abstract: Long-term bond prices fell slightly yesterday in quiet trading as the United States Treasury sold $3 billion of new 20-year, one-month bonds at an average yield of 10 3/4 percent, down from 11.68 percent at a similar sale in September.   Investor demand for the new 10 3/4 percent bonds, due in February 2003, was not as strong as for the 10 1/2 percent, seven-year notes that sold a day earlier at an average yield of 10.58 percent, dealers said.   While prices of most Treasury issues fell slightly, the seven-year issue closed at an offered price of about 99 30/32, to yield 10.51 percent, down from 100 3/8 earlier in the day, but well above the average price at Tuesday's auction of about 99 19/32.   Prices fell from the best levels of the day, traders said, partly because of disappointment that the Federal Reserve did not buy securities for its own account - thereby giving the markets a sign that it is encouraging lower short-term rates by making credit more plentiful in the banking system. Other analysts said the drop of the past two days in the overnight rate for bank loans in the Federal funds market could indicate that the Fed is encouraging lower shortterm rates.

headline: EUROPE'S FIERCE AUTO RIVALRY
abstract: Inside, the vast windowless factory is eerily silent and clean. The dominant colors are pastel shades of purple, yellow and green.   With only a soft crunch, a 1,500-ton Weingartner press transforms a sheet of steel into the recognizable shape of a car door. Mechanical hands wisk it away onto the production line where 150 robot-welding machines, swaying and snapping like giant praying mantises, gradually build it into another Corsa, General Motors' belated competitor for a share in Europe's important small-car market.

headline: BONN PARLIAMENT VOTES OUT SCHMIDT AND ELECTS KOHL
abstract: Helmut Kohl, leader of the conservative Christian Democratic Party, was elected the sixth Chancellor of West Germany today, replacing Helmut Schmidt after a noconfidence vote in Parliament.   After a debate that took an unexpectedly passionate turn, Mr. Kohl was chosen Chancellor with a seven-cote margin on a procedure known as a constructive no-confidence motion, which simultaneously toppled Mr. Schmidt and designated his successor.   It was the first time in the 33-year history of the Federal Republic that a Chancellor had been removed by Parliament. Reagan Administration officials expressed satisfaction that West Germany would now have a Government "more in tune with the Reagan philosophy" but voiced uneasiness that West German politics might become polarized. Page 4.

headline: Narco Scientific
abstract: Narco Scientific Inc. said it had filed an amended complaint in its lawsuit seeking to block Healthdyne Inc.'s unfriendly takeover attempt. Narco said the new counts, filed in United States District Court in Philadelphia, charge Healthdyne with violating Federal securities and antiracketeering laws by issuing misleading disclosure statements in connection with its tender offer Oct.13 for 711,000 Narco common shares. The complaint maintains that Healthdyne's acquisition of Narco would reduce competition in markets for infant warmers, monitors and phototherapy units.

headline: ISRAEL ASKS WIDER TALKS THAN EGYPT
abstract: The Israeli Cabinet declared today that an Egyptian request to renew negotiations over a narrow strip of desert land claimed by both Egypt and Israel must be part of a broader effort between the two nations to resolve their growing differences.   Last week, Foreign Minister Kamal Hassan Ali of Egypt sent a letter to his Israeli counterpart, Yitzhak Shamir, calling for new talks on the 750-yard stretch of desert beach, called Taba.   The area is south of the Israeli port city of Eilat in the Sinai Desert, which Israel returned to Egypt last April 25.  Mr. Shamir presented the Egyptian request at the weekly Cabinet session. Afterward, the Cabinet secretary, Dan Meridor, told reporters, ''The Egyptian Government wants to resume the negotiations about the demarcation of the border between Israel and Egypt, mainly in Taba.''

headline: Hoechst Asbestos Alternative
abstract: Hoechst, a West German chemical company, said it had developed chemical fibers that could take over some of the industrial uses of asbestos, which has been linked to lung cancer.

headline: CHINA, DOWN ON FARM, GROWS A FEW CAPITALISTS
abstract: Chen Zhixiong is a prospering peasant whose industriousness down on the farm in southeastern China's Guangdong Province has presented China's Marxist ideologists with a quandary.   Under the rural responsibility system that has been introduced in the countryside, Mr. Chen contracted with the local production team to cultivate nearly 50 acres of fishponds.   Finding himself too busy to do all the work himself, Mr. Chen hired some local hands to help raise and catch the fish. He paid them the equivalent of $50 a month, which is four times the average rural earnings, and met his quota. His employees were happy and Mr. Chen ended up rich.

headline: DOW DROPS BY 1002, TO BELOW 900
abstract: Stock prices fell sharply yesterday in moderate trading as investors' anxiety over the recession intensified.  At the final bell, the Dow Jones industrial average was off 10.02 points, to 896.25, the first time since Sept. 1 that the blue-chip barometer has finished below what many analysts consider its critical 900 level.   Turnover amounted to 62.6 million shares, the same as the day before.  Analysts attributed the weakness in stock prices to yesterday's report by the Commerce Department that its index of leading economic indicators, which is designed to detect future economic trends, fell nine-tenths of 1 percent in August, after four consecutive monthly increases.

headline: Del Monte Corp.
abstract: The Del Monte Corporation said it is seeking buyers for two interstate trucking companies and four truck dealerships owned by its Distribution Systems subsidiary. The trucking companies are Willis Shaw Frozen Express Inc. of Elm Springs, Ark., and Ida-Cal Freight Lines Inc. of Nampa, Idaho. All four dealerships are in Idaho. Del Monte is a unit of R.J. Reynolds Inc.

headline: JAPANESE OFFER TRADE CONCESSION
abstract: Japan tentatively promised to take steps soon to open its market further to foreign goods. The Japanese response came in two days of talks with American officials that ended late Saturday.   The American delegation, led by David R. Macdonald, deputy trade representative, had presented a list of areas where it considered further market-opening measures necessary. For each item, the American side asked Japan to issue a timetable of when it will make decisions about the new steps, and Japan agreed.

headline: Japanese Car Import Curb
abstract: The United States will seek to extend the two-year ceiling on Japanese car imports for 12 months to protect the flagging domestic auto industry, according to the American trade representative, Bill Brock.   The American industry, plagued by its lowest sales in two decades, needs more breathing room, he said, to enable it to recover when the economy improves.

headline: BRIEFS
abstract: * American Telephone and Telegraph Co.'s Western Electric Co. will increase the overall level of prices of its manufactured products by 4 percent, starting Jan.1.   * Bethlehem Steel Corp. said it was closing the hot-strip mill at its Lackawanna plant for one week, idling 105 workers, because of a lack of orders.   * Diamond International Corp. said it had completed the planned merger between it and Diamond Acquisition Inc.

headline: ANGLO ENERGY LTD reports earnings for QTr to Sept 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: DUNBAR GARDEN COMPLEX IN HARLEM TO BECOME CO-OP
abstract: In the late 1970's it appeared that the Dunbar Apartments, six brick walk-ups around a spacious, grassy courtyard at 149th Street and Adam Clayton Powell Boulevard, would go the way of far too many Harlem residential buildings and fall into significant disrepair.   Now, however, the future of the 536-unit complex, which occupies a five-acre block between 149th and 150th Streets and Adam Clayton Powell and Frederick Douglass Boulevards, seems assured: As an $11.8 million renovation nears completion, the New York Bank for Savings, which holds the mortgage, has announced plans to convert the building into a cooperative under a noneviction plan. The bank is a division of Buffalo Savings Bank.   And, somewhat to the bank's surprise, its two-week-long promotion advertising that 145 vacant apartments are available for purchase by nontenants has provoked a tremendous response. Thus far more than 600 people, many of them from other parts of the city, have expressed interest and toured the model apartments, according to Eugene H.  Webb, president of Webb & Brooker, the managing agents.

headline: India Sends More Men To Quell Riots in West
abstract: Military reinforcements rushed to the western city of Baroda today to help soldiers quell Hindu-Moslem fighting that left 11 people dead and 30 others injured, officials said.   Though no major incidents of rioting were reported, the border security forces were sent to Baroda to bring an end to violence between Hindus and Moslems that erupted Monday night, Prabodh Raval, the Gujarat State Home Minister, said.   The death toll rose to 11 when two people died today of stab wounds inflicted Tuesday night, the state police said.

headline: Patents; Armor Suit To Protect Divers
abstract: WASHINGTON A photographer who is also a marine biologist was granted a patent this week for an armored skin-diving suit, intended to provide protection from sharks.

headline: AFTER LEBANON: THE ARAB WORLD IN CRISIS
abstract: The Israeli invasion of Lebanon has set off a crisis in Arab politics of revolutionary proportions.  This perception emerges from conversations with Arabs in a tour of Jordan, Lebanon, Syria, Bahrain, Kuwait and Tunisia and talks with Arabs from Egypt and Qatar as well. People say they are deeply humiliated by what took place in Lebanon and despairing of the failure of Arab governments to act Fifth article of a series appearing periodically on the new balance of power in the Middle East since the war in Lebanon. in concerted fashion, or even to let them demonstrate in defense of the Palestinian cause. At a time when the Arab rulers are seen as needing a settlement of the Palestinian problem to defuse the frustration in the Arab world and to spare themselves the wrath of the Palestine Liberation Organization, they are reported in too precarious a position to take the steps needed to start the peace process.   As one American official with long experience in the region said: ''The lack of any Arab governmental response to what took place in Lebanon this summer has exposed the inadequacy of practically every Arab regime, in a way that is wider in its revolutionary potential than the war of 1948, which led to the downfall of almost every important Arab leader.''

headline: The U.N. Today; Dec. 15, 1982; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
abstract: Meets at 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.   Administrative and Budgetary Committee - 10:30 A.M., 3 P.M. and 7:30 P.M   Disarmament Commission - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.   Meeting of Donors to Cambodia Hu- manitarian Program - 10:30 A.M.  and 3 P.M.

headline: CARIBBEAN GETS BAD NEWS ON AID
abstract: The chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee said today that Congress was unlikely to take up the remaining parts of the Administration's Caribbean aid plan when it reconvenes later this month and would probably not consider it for ''six to eight months.''   The chairman, Dan Rostenkowski, Democrat of Illinois, made the assessment at a lunch with seven Caribbean heads of state here this afternoon and later in a briefing to reporters.

headline: World Press Review Raising Ad Rates 15%
abstract: World Press Review, a monthly magazine that monitors what the media are saying the world over, is raising its circulation base to 150,000 from 137,500 with the January issue.

headline: U.S. MILITARY PACT IN TROUBLE IN SPAIN
abstract: American officials have made it clear to the Spanish Government that renegotiation of the new agreement covering United States military bases in Spain would be difficult if not impossible, according to Western European diplomats here.   Felipe Gonzalez, the leader of the Socialist Party, has demanded that the pact, which was initialed in July but has yet to be ratified by Parliament, be reconsidered after the Oct. 28 general election.  The Socialists are expected to finish first in the voting and Mr.  Gonzalez may well be Spain's next Prime Minister.   The military agreement, which runs for five years, was reached only after hard bargaining. Spain strives to maintain especially close relations with the Arab world, and it was deeply worried about the use of airbases here by the United States for the Rapid Deployment Force in the event of a flare-up in the Middle East.

headline: SOUTH AFRICAN POET FREED AFTER 7 YEARS
abstract: Breyten Breytenbach, who is widely held to be the most important living poet in the Afrikaans language, has been released from prison after serving seven years of a nine-year sentence for terrorism.   Rapport, an Afrikaans newspaper, reported today that the 43-yearold poet and painter flew to Paris Saturday to rejoin his Vietnamese wife, shortly before the Prison Services announced that he had been released under a new policy that makes it possible for prisoners convicted on political charges to receive remission of sentence.   The announcement made a point of dashing any hopes that the policy might apply to Nelson Mandela or other imprisoned leaders of the banned African National Congress. ''No hope for remission of sentence or conditional release whatsoever can be cherished by any other persons who persist in their original criminal objectives,'' it declared.

headline: SCHRADER, ABE, CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Market Place; Early-Call Bond Clauses
abstract: ONLY a year ago Wall Street bond ads stressed safety - urging investors to buy short term. Now they stress liquidity less and urge investors to buy long-term bonds and thus ''lock in'' high yields.   Even so, care is essential at a time of sliding interest rates, whether the investor buys individual bonds or bond trusts representing shares in portfolios of bonds. The issuer may have the right to call the bonds in just a few years and thus drastically shorten the period during which the bond holder earns his high rate of return.

headline: NATO SEEKS ACCORD OVER SOVIET TRADE
abstract: The foreign ministers of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization met here today and agreed to look for ways to better coordinate Western policy on trade with the Soviet bloc.   Officials here said that the participants decided to start a series of studies on how their security interests are affected by energy policies and the extension of credits to the Soviet Union and its allies.   The discussions, which took place at the one-day private conference in a secluded inn in the Laurentian Mountains, were seen as a step toward easing the conflicts among the 16 NATO nations over financial dealings with the Soviet bloc.   The conference came four days after Secretary of State George P.  Shultz began discussions with France, Britain, Italy and West Germany on overall East-West economic issues. Officials said that in his talks in New York, Mr. Shultz stressed that he wanted to put aside the controversy over the Soviet natural-gas pipeline project as part of an overall effort to find a new approach to trade issues that would avoid such rifts in the future. The four European countries are the principal suppliers of equipment for the pipeline, which is to carry natural gas from Siberia to Western Europe.

headline: No Headline
abstract: AROUND THE WORLD; Iran Says It Downed An Iraqi MIG-25   LONDON, Dec. 2 (Reuters) - An Iranian pilot shot down an Iraqi MIG-25 jet fighter today before it could bomb targets in the southern province of Khuzistan, the Iranian press agency said.   The report, monitored here, quoted a military communique as saying that Iranian and Iraqi forces had been locked in shelling duels in the southern and northern sectors of the Persian Gulf war fronts in the last 24 hours.

headline: How the I.M.F. Operates
abstract: The International Monetary Fund was created in 1944 to help nations prevent the sort of economic disarray that marked the global depression of the 1930's.   Goals: Its chief responsibility has been to provide credits to any of its 146 member countries that have trouble paying their foreign debts. The fund, based in Washington, operates something like a bank. It makes decisions on loans only after negotiations on changes in economic policy that must be followed by a nation requesting funds.  The conditions, once accepted, act as a signal to commercial banks that the nation qualifies for additional loans.

headline: TESORO PETROLEUM CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: HOW MUCH MORE?
abstract: THE Vredeling Proposal is a classic illustration of what might be t ermed The First Law of Social Engineering: the loftier and the more u niversally desirable the objectives of proposed legislation, the p oorer will be its draftsmanship, the more cumbersome its i mplementation, and the more depressing its results.  No responsible person can defend current levels of unemployment or unannounced plant closings. But the Vredeling Proposal will neither create jobs nor reduce the factors that cause businesses to collapse.   Everyone agrees that if our Western economies are to recover and our workers to return to work, there will need to be increased incentives for investment in production, by both the public and private sectors. But the proposal will be a disincentive to the investment of capital in the economies of the European Community.

headline: Advertising; Greeting Travelers With Ads
abstract: WHAT could be more fitting in an official ''Welcome to the United States'' brochure than something that Americans get more of than anyone - advertising.   Richard M. Shalowitz, the entrepreneur who sold the idea to the United States Customs Service, described the brochure that will be given to everyone arriving in this country beginning in February as ''a Statue of Liberty for the Jet Age traveler.''   Similarly, in a letter to top executives of major ad agencies and heads of big advertiser companies, Stephen A. Jacobs, a special assistant at Customs, wrote: ''We are the first Americans all international travelers confront. It begins with the Customs Declaration. We are going to transform that experience in the same way that the Statue of Liberty transformed the non-jet age welcome to America.''

headline: G.M. to Begin Worker Recall
abstract: The General Motors Corporation said that it would begin recalling 2,400 laid-off workers at a plant in Pontiac, Mich., in January to prepare for production of its new European-style Fiero sports car.   The car, a two-seater with a rear-mounted, four-cylinder engine, will be marketed in the fall of 1983, the company said.

headline: BRIEFS
abstract: * Air Canada and the Quebec government should form a new company to take over operations of Quebecair, a financially troubled regional airline, the Canadian Government recommended.   * Alba-Waldensian Inc., a North Carolina company, announced that it would close its fabric division, which makes men's polyester warp knit suiting fabrics, eliminating about 100 jobs.   * Associates First Capital Corp., a Dallas-based company, said it had agreed in principle to acquire Heritage Federal Savings and Loan Association of Oakland, Calif., for an undisclosed amount.

headline: Trans World Stake Reported
abstract: Lester Pollack, a principal in Odyssey Partners, has declined to comment on reports that the partnership had acquired about 5 percent of the Trans World Corporation, parent of Trans World Airlines.   In an interview Wednesday, Mr. Pollack would neither confirm nor deny that the group would disclose in a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission that it had acquired 1.1 million shares of Trans World and that it would try to split up the company or spin off some of its assets.

headline: Nissan-Alfa Deal
abstract: The Nissan Motor Company and Alfa Romeo will begin joint production of the Nissan Pulsar in Italy in April, an auto industry journal reported.

headline: U.N. Agency Says the Israelis Detained 164 of Its Workers
abstract: The Israeli Army has detained 164 employees of the United Nations Relief and Works Agency since invading Lebanon on June 6, and 83 are still being held, the agency said in a statement today.   The Vienna-based agency said it had asked Israel repeatedly for information about the detainees, who it said were all Palestinian refugees.   The refugees were believed to be in the Ansar prison camp in southern Lebanon, an agency spokesman said.

headline: Operating Chief Named At K.& E. Advertising
abstract: John B. Balson, who joined Kenyon & Eckhardt only eight years ago as a vice president, has been named president and chief operating officer of Kenyon & Eckhardt Advertising, its largest operating unit. It was one of a number of high-level executive changes announced yesterday by Leo-Arthur Kelmenson, president and chief executive of the parent.

headline: PRICE TALKS BY OPEC ARE SHIFTED
abstract: Nigeria today canceled plans to hold the next OPEC ministerial meeting in Lagos. But the Government denied that it had taken the action to prevent its capital from becoming the scene of a showdown between Nigeria and Saudi Arabia over oil prices.   In a statement, Mallam Yahaya Dikko, oil adviser to President Shehu Shagari, said Nigeria did not regard holding the meeting here ''as a national priority or as a matter of great importance.'' Mr. Dikko is president of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries.   ''When it became apparent that some member states felt that an alternative venue would be more appropriate, we took the view that this was a minor matter and ourselves suggested an alternative venue,'' Mr. Dikko said. Oil industry sources said the meeting, scheduled for Dec.9, would probably be held in Geneva or Vienna, OPEC's headquarters.

headline: SALVADOR DISPATCHES A 5,000-MAN FORCE TO COUNTER REBELS
abstract: The Government sent 5,000 troops backed by artillery, fighter-bombers and helicopter gunships into northern El Salvador today to counterattack what officials described as the strongest guerrilla drive in six months.   Strong guerrilla resistance was reported and a national guard commander in northern Chalatenango Province, where the counteroffensive was concentrated, reported Government casualties were heavy.

headline: An A-Plant Switch by China
abstract: China has decided to build its first nuclear power plant in Zhejiang Province near Hangzhou in eastern China, the official New China News Agency said Wednesday. The report contradicted an earlier one from Peking that China had begun to build its first nuclear power station near Shanghai.

headline: Japan's Steel Production
abstract: Japan's crude steel production in September edged down six-tenths of 1 percent from August, to 7.88 million metric tons, the Japan Iron and Steel Federation reported today.

headline: Study Urges Aid Speedup
abstract: The Brandt Commission warned today that the world's wealthier countries must move boldly and quickly to augment credits available to the poorer and developing nations if a worldwide economic collapse is to be avoided.   Summarizing the views of the commission he heads, Willy Brandt, the former West German Chancellor, recommended that the World Bank and the International Monetary Fund increase the capital they have available for developing countries and provide easier loans to these nations.

headline: MONETARISTS DIVIDED ON FED'S STAND
abstract: Monetarists, the economists who watch the Federal Reserve most closely, were widely divided today over the signficance of the changes disclosed last week by the nation's central bank.   Milton Friedman, a Nobel laureate and one of the founders of monetarism, maintained that the Fed is continuing a policy (opposed by Mr. Friedman) of tolerating wide swings in growth of the nation's basic money supply.   ''I don't know what all the fuss is about,'' said Mr. Friedman in an interview. He said that he accepted the Fed's explanation that its decision last week to temporarily tolerate more rapid growth in the money supply did not represent a policy change.

headline: EXCERPTS FROM INTERVIEW WITH CHANCELLOR KOHL
abstract: Following, in official translation, are excerpts from an interview on Tuesday with Chancellor Helmut Kohl of West Germany:   Q. The other day Ambassador Burns talked to the commanders of the German federal armed forces and he said, ''My Government has become doubtful about the advantages of detente; your Government, on the other hand, perceives continuing benefits.'' I wonder what you think of that?   A. If Arthur Burns, in saying this sentence means - that is the way I understood it - that we take a strictly realistic line in our policy, that we are not engaged in any kind of dreams or illusions, then this is exactly the line I'm following.   First of all, we are a firm member of the European community.  Parallel to this is the very closely tied partnership and friendship to the United States.  NATO first of all means a community of ideas, a community of countries which share free and liberal constitutions, with human rights, basic fundamental rights, civic rights. It is my feeling that we have given too little attention to these values and we have given too much attention to the arms. Of course, arms are important. In my policy statement I made three weeks ago, I made the point that the raison d'etre of this country requires friendship and ties with the U.S.; it is part of that raison d'etre. By making this point I had in mind this community of ideas.

headline: PRIME RATE LOWERED TO 11 1/2%, BUT DOW AND BONDS PLUNGE
abstract: The nation's major banks lowered their prime lending rate by half a percentage point yesterday, to 11 1/2 percent, the lowest level since September 1980.   The Chase Manhattan Bank was the first to cut the rate, the basis for loans to small and medium-sized companies, and by the end of the day all of the 10 largest banks had moved to the new level.

headline: Deaths of 11 Russians In Lebanon Disclosed
abstract: Assistant Secretary of Defense Richard N.  Perle has disclosed that several Russians were killed in Lebanon last spring when Israeli jets destroyed a downed reconnaissance plane to prevent secret electronic equipment from falling into Soviet hands. A Pentagon spokesman declined to confirm the account.

headline: Forstmann to Buy Beverage Company
abstract: Forstmann Little & Company, a privately held New York investment firm, said yesterday that it had agreed in principle to acquire Beverage Management Inc. of Columbus, Ohio, for $24 a share, or $98.4 million, in a leveraged buy-out.   The acquisition was approved by Beverage Management's board, and by certain shareholders who control about 42 percent of the company's 4.1 million common shares outstanding.

headline: Deficit of U.S.  Again at High
abstract: The Government has started its new fiscal year the same way it ended the old - with a record budget deficit.

headline: Bomb Threat Delays Flight
abstract: A bomb threat held up a New Yorkbound Varig Airlines jetliner for four hours today while policemen searched the plane for explosives, a spokesman for the Brazilian airline said. No bomb was found aboard the Boeing 747 plane, the spokesman said. Airport officials had received an anonymous telephone threat late Monday, he said.

headline: Advertising; Agencies Also Have Lean Year
abstract: THE economy has been rougher on the ad agencies so far this year than their managers estimated going in, and now they think the fourth quarter is going to be worse.   That information comes from a meeting of the board of the American Association of Advertising Agencies on Sept. 21 in Washington.  Its agenda included a report on actual profits for the first eight months of the year, compared with projections made in January. There was quite a difference, according to Harry Paster, executive vice president of the association, whose member agencies handle threequarters of all money spent through ad agencies in the United States.

headline: Nova Scotia Bank Reply
abstract: The Halifax-based Bank of Nova Scotia has charged that tax fraud charges filed against it in the United States are an attempt to hold the bank responsible for the acts of others. The Justice Department had announced that the bank, Canada's fourth largest, and seven individuals had been indicted by a Federal grand jury in what was called a fraudulent tax shelter scheme involving more than $122 million.

headline: TEXT OF U.S. STATEMENT ON ARAB LEAGUE VISIT
abstract: Following is the text of a Reagan Administration policy statement issued by the State Department today as an Arab League delegation arrived in Washington:   This delegation is coming to the United States at the request of the Arab League. The purpose of the delegation's visit to Washington is to exchange views on how best to restore momentum to the Middle East peace negotiations.   The delegation will present the views of the Arab League. The United States will present its own views based on the President's initiative of Sept. 1.

headline: Hogs, Bellies Fall Limit In Odd Technical Selloff
abstract: Livestock futures crumbled yesterday, with prices of live hogs and pork bellies again declining by their daily permissible limits.  Brokers attributed much of the declines to what they termed ''computer selling'' that ignored increasingly strong fundamental factors pointing to higher beef and pork prices this winter.   The victory of the chartists over the fundamentalists left the December live hog futures down the limit of 1.5 cents a pound, at 54.62 cents. February hogs also fell the limit, to 54.97 cents. All active frozen pork bellies futures closed down the limit of 2 cents a pound, leaving the February contract at 78.70 cents and the March at 77.75.

headline: GREEKS ARE VOTING IN RUNOFF BALLOT
abstract: The second round of municipal elections in Greece is to be held Sunday, and the governing Socialist Party is expected to win decisively with the help of the Communists, even though the two parties are sharply at odds on national policy.   The elections, the first round of which was held last Sunday, are seen as the first indication of how the Government of Prime Minister Andreas Papandreou is faring with the electorate. Mr. Papandreou's party lost ground in that first round.   Despite many local tactical alliances between Communists and Socialists, there is no question of a popular front of the left on the national level, according to Socialist sources. In fact the toughest battles are likely to occur where Communist and Socialistbacked candidates are competing directly for municipal seats, such as in Larissa and Patras.

headline: BUSINESS PEOPLE
abstract: The Japanese postwar economic miracle owes much to the Ministry of International Trade and Industry, the armchair general of Japan's industrial policy. The ministry also directs the nation's trade policy.   In the Cabinet of Prime Minister Yasuhiro Nakasone, elected by parliamentary vote last Friday, the new Minister of International Trade and Industry will be Sadanori Yamanaka. Mr. Yamanaka, 61 years old, is a long-time politician and a former director general of the defense agency who is known as an expert in domestic affairs, but with little international experience.

headline: BATTLE FOR A FRENCH CONTRACT
abstract: Three sophisticated aircraft, two American and one the product of an Anglo-French collaboration, are competing for a multimillion-dollar French contract that may be the United States aviation industry's last big military sales opportunity in Europe for some time.   The contract is to supply France with airborne radar, which would give advance warning of attacking planes, missiles, ships and tanks.  The need for such so-called Eye-in-the-Sky planes, military experts say, has been underscored by the recent wars in Lebanon and the Falkland Islands.   In Lebanon, the Israelis used airborne radar to guide their fighters, which shot down more than 100 Syrian MIG's, and to locate antiaircraft missile bases, which were then destroyed.

headline: BBC in Polish in Jammed
abstract: Poland today began jamming all British radio transmissions in Polish, the British Broadcasting Corporation said.

headline: Venezuela Aids Bank
abstract: The Venezuelan Government has authorized cash injections totaling $230 million for the Banco de los Trabajadores de Venezuela as a first stage in its rescue of the nation's largest bank, financial sources said today. The central bank first freed some $115 million it held as the bank's reserves, and later it authorized the transfer of a similar amount from Venezuela's social security institute pension fund, which is managed by the central bank. The Government intervened Monday to rescue the bank after it ran into severe liquidity problems.

headline: De Beers Interest
abstract: The Anglo American Corporation of South Africa has bought about 10 million shares of De Beers Consolidated Mines, raising its stake in the company to about 34 percent, from 31 percent, De Beers confirmed. But the deputy chairman-designate of Anglo American, Julian Ogilvie Thompson, quashed rumors that a major reorganization of De Beers's diamond trading interests was imminent, and said there were no plans to restructure the central selling organization.

headline: MIDDLE ATLANTIC
abstract: THE Middle-Atlantic region contains some of the most vibrant areas f or employment and some of the grimmest, ranging from the Virginia s hipyards on the Eastern Seaboard, thriving as a result of increased d efense commitments, to the steel mills of northwestern P ennsylvania, which have been declining for two decades.   The unemployment picture varies within the region: 7.6 percent (July) in Virginia, 8.6 percent (July) in Maryland, 10.5 percent (August) in Pennsylvania, and 11.4 percent (July) in the District of Columbia. But career counselors and employment specialists predict that all parts of the region will experience growth in high-technology jobs. As Dr. James Slick, assistant director of career development at Pennsylvania State University, said: ''We continue to see emphasis on the technical as opposed to the nontechnical.''

headline: EXPULSION OF ISRAEL IS AVERTED
abstract: A Western compromise was approved by the International Telecommunications Union conference early today, averting the expulsion of Israel.   The vote of 61 to 57 on a British-sponsored package of amendments to a tough Arab draft resolution also meant that the United States would not carry out its threat to quit the United Nations agency and stop its financial support.

headline: Jordanian Educator Deported By Israel From the West Bank
abstract: The president of a major university on the Israeli-occupied West Bank was ordered deported this week for refusing to comply with a new policy requiring foreign nationals employed in the occupied areas to disavow any connections with the Palestine Liberation Organization, Palestinian and Israeli sources said.   Dr. Munther Salah, a Jordanian national, was one of 16 faculty members of An-Najah University in Nablus denied a work permit after refusing to sign such a statement of disavowal.

headline: Market Place; Mobile Homes Highly Rated
abstract: THE recent decline in interest rates and the expected forthcoming economic recovery are supposed to be good news for manufacturers of mobile homes as well as the rest of the housing industry.   For builders of ''manufactured housing,'' as mobile homes are called in the industry, the growth prospects related to an improved economy are only part of the story. ''Keeping housing affordable is the main objective,'' said Robert Curran, an analyst at Merrill Lynch & Company. ''Interest rates are likely to stay high, so there will be continuing efforts to downsize housing. The industry is moving in the direction of more off-site manufacturing of homes and components.''

headline: RIO ARTIFACTS MAY INDICATE ROMAN VISIT
abstract: Artifacts found in a bay near Rio de Janeiro may mark the wreck of a Roman ship that could have reached Brazil 17 centuries before Portuguese adventurers discovered the region, according to a leading underwater archeologist.   A large accumulation of amphoras, or tall jars, of the type carried by Roman ships in the second century B.C., has been found in Guanabara Bay, 15 miles from Rio de Janiero, according to the archeologist, Robert Marx, who is a well-known hunter of sunken treasure.   The Portuguese navigator Pedro Alvares Cabral is generally credited as having been the first European to reach Brazil, in the year 1500.  Mr. Marx said yesterday that the Portuguese authorities were trying to block Brazil from issuing him a permit to excavate the wreck he thinks is buried there. Like the 5-Gallon Jerry Can   Amphoras are tall jars tapering to the bottom and usually fitted with twin handles. As described by Mr. Marx, they were to the ancient Greeks, Romans and Phoenicians what the five-gallon jerry can was to mobile units in World War II. They were used to carry wine, oil, water or grain on long voyages.

headline: FORMER CENCO LEADER ASSUMES AMERACE JOB
abstract: George S. Deutsch has resigned as president, chief executive and a director of the Amerace Corporation, and speculation has arisen about the future of the company.   Mr. Deutsch, 57, had been president of the industrial concern since 1972. He was succeeded by Shirley D. Brinsfield, 59, a former head of the Cenco Corporation who had joined the board in September.

headline: Soviet War Games End
abstract: The Soviet-led Warsaw Pact ended land, sea and air maneuvers in Bulgaria today, the official Hungarian press agency reported. Reports in the Yugoslavian press have said that more than 60,000 troops and staff were involved in the ''Shield '82'' exercises.

abstract: Burlington Northern Inc. said a Federal court in Delaware had denied a motion by the El Paso Company that sought to extend the proration date of Burlington's $24-a-share tender offer for 50.7 percent of El Paso's common stock. headline: GCA-Matra Pact

The equipment would be made in Europe. GCA, a semiconductor maker based in Bedford, Mass., said further details about the agreement would not be released until it had been approved by the United States and French Governments.

headline: Hijacking Drama Ends And Iranians Are Held
abstract: Two Iranian noncommissioned officers who hijacked an Air Force transport plane to the United Arab Emirates Sunday were in jail in Iran today after allowing the plane to return home, an Iranian diplomat said.   The hijackers - one accompanied by his wife and a teenage son - threatened the pilot of the C-130 Hercules with a hand grenade during an internal flight between Teheran and the southern port of Bandar Abbas and forced him to land in Dubai, the Iranian Consul General, Javad Ansari, said in a telephone interview from the United Arab Emirates.

headline: Massey Expansion
abstract: Massey-Ferguson Holdings of Britain said it would spend about $17.6 million over the next three years to improve efficiency at its Coventry tractor plant. The company, a wholly owned unit of Canada's Massey-Ferguson Ltd., said the program is intended to improve productivity at the plant, which now produces just over 46,000 units a year.

headline: Sahara Rebels Will Quit The O.A.U. Temporarily
abstract: The Polisario guerrilla movement has agreed to withdraw temporarily from the Organization of African Unity to pave the way for a meeting of African leaders, a guerrilla spokesman said today.   But a Moroccan newspaper with close ties to the Government insisted the West Saharan guerrillas must permanently withdraw if the O.A.U.  is to continue functioning.

headline: SEPTEMBER OUTPUT DECLINED AS PRICES OF PRODUCERS FELL
abstract: Industrial production fell again in September, indicating that the recession may not have ended, while the principal index of producer prices slipped, signaling more relief from inflation, the Government reported today.   The reports were the last broad-gauge statistics on the performance of the economy in September to be released before the Nov. 2 election and could provide fuel for both Republicans and Democrats.   The declines in factory output and producer prices were signs of the weakness in the economy that has lifted unemployment above 10 percent, a campaign theme for the Democrats. A Slowdown of Inflation   But the price index also showed a slowdown of inflation, something President Reagan has stressed in campaign speeches on behalf of Republican candidates for Congress.

headline: SALVADORAN CALLS U.S. ENVOY'S CHARGE UNFAIR
abstract: Salvador's Defense Minister said today that he agreed with American criticism of the nation's legal system, but said it was ''unfair'' of the American Ambassador to maintain that as many as 30,000 Salvadorans had been murdered in the last three years.    The Defense Minister, Gen. Jose Guillermo Garcia, said in an interview that the military had urged in vain that the judiciary take action against two well-connected officers implicated in the murders of two American land experts and a Salvadoran Government official.   ''We have done everything within our reach to make justice and we do not care who we are going to apply it on,'' General Garcia said.  ''This has caused us, in the military, problems.''

headline: GEORESOURCES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30

headline: ARAB OF ISRAEL: WAR AND 'BAD DREAMS'
abstract: ''It's like just a bad dream,'' said Mohammed Nimer, who lives in this Arab town in northern Israel, describing how the Israeli invasion of Lebanon affected him as one of Israel's more than 600,000 Arab citizens.   Many Israeli Arabs, the majority of whom live in this region south of the Lebanese border, are still awaiting news of the whereabouts of relatives who lived in southern Lebanon. The families split up when thousands of Arabs fled the area in the 1948 war.   Next to Shefaram, in a hamlet called Ibelin, a narrow road winds through groves of olive trees and tomato patches before reaching the small residential section of private homes tucked into the hillside.  Amni Ali Khalifa, the mother of seven young children, told about the conflicting reports that she had been receiving about her husband's cousin who she said had been living in the Beirut area during the war.

headline: TRI-SOUTH INVESTMENT INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: LOVE FINDS A WAY PAST SOUTH AFRICA'S RACE LAWS
abstract: In every respect except one, Ian Whiteley and his wife, Sherrin, lead an entirely conventional married life here in this town in the northern Transvaal, where white racial attitudes are generally described in geological similes such as granite-like.   What makes them exceptional is that Mr. Whiteley, a former merchant seaman with a straw-colored beard and mustache, happens to be white; his wife, who is of Indian descent, is brown. From those scant epidermal facts it can be deduced that Mr. and Mrs. Whiteley are living together in flagrant violation of at least three laws that are basic to the system known as apartheid.   There is the Prohibition of Mixed Marriages Act, which does exactly what its title says. There is the Immorality Act, which makes it a crime for a white to have any sexual contact with a person of another race. And there is the Group Areas Act, which forbids people of one population group to live in a residential area reserved for another.

headline: PAKISTAN SEEKING 2D ATOM REACTOR
abstract: Pakistan has begun soliciting bids for the purchase of a new nuclear reactor from the West. The move, made on Wednesday, was described by American officials today as likely to complicate American efforts to block the sale of nuclear technology to Pakistan.   They referred to a private appeal made in September by Secretary of State George P. Shultz to the Western European allies and Japan, urging all suppliers not to sell a new reactor unless Pakistan accepts international inspection of all its nuclear facilities. This it has refused to do.

headline: South Africa Detains Leader Of White Supremacist Group
abstract: The leader of a rightwing white supremacist movement has been detained for questioning under South Africa's internal security laws, a police spokesman said today.   The spokesman declined to give further information about the detention Friday night of Eugene Terr'Blanche, 38 years old, a farmer who heads the Afrikaner Weerstandsbeweging, or Afrikaner Resistance Movement. But he denied press reports that the group's secretary, David Botes, was also detained.

headline: No Headline
abstract: U.S. MIGHT CUT AID TO SURINAME OVER KILLINGS   WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 (AP) - The United States said today that it might cut off $1.5 million in economic aid to Suriname after two dozen prominent citizens suspected of plotting a coup were killed while in Government custody last week.   ''Our entire relationship with the Government of Suriname is under review, including our aid program,'' said a State Department spokesman, Anita Stockman.

headline: Nickel at Lows In London
abstract: Nickel prices fell to record lows on the London Metal Exchange today in line with a general long-term decline by metals because of the world recession.

headline: 2 Japanese Hunted on Everest After One Reaches Summit
abstract: Yasuo Kato, a 33-year-old climber from Japan, and a companion were missing on Mount Everest today, a day after Mr. Kato reached the summit, the Tourism Ministry announced.   Mr. Kato was the first non-Nepalese climber to scale the 29,028-foot mountain three times.

headline: SEARLE, G D, & CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: PHILANTHROPIC OUTLOOK SOMBER
abstract: To meet their philanthropic commitments, a number of corporations across the country are drawing down the reserves of their company foundations and these resources may soon be exhausted, according to the companies' executives.   This could make it more difficult for the business community to increase giving at the request of the Reagan Administration, as the Government cuts back on support for education, welfare and the arts.   The condition of company foundations is ''industry specific,'' said Mary Hall, vice president of the Weyerhaeuser Company Foundation. The financial predicament is hardest for those in certain fields - steel, autos, timber, construction and farm equipment - she explained. In other industries, such as high technology, it is expected that company giving will increase.

headline: THE CASE FOR CONVERTIBLE BONDS
abstract: MANY investors these days are torn by the decision to either lock inh igh bond yields or bet that stocks will continue to rally. Rather t han choose, a number of them are opting for convertible debentures, a hybrid security that its fans call the best of all possible w orlds. A convertible debenture is sold as a $1,000 face value bond, w ith a fixed maturity and coupon, but it allows an investor to e xchange the bond for a fixed number of common shares, usually those o f the issuing corporation. The convertibles sell at a discount or p remium in the secondary market (100 is par), and their yields vary a ccordingly.   If the past history of convertibles holds true, they might provide greater downside protection than the common stock to which they are wedded in the event the predictions of a lasting bull market don't pan out. And they would presumably rise in price faster than straight bonds (though not as fast as the underlying common) if the market does continue its surge. At the same time, the convertible offers a far more attractive yield than the common stock dividend, although usually not as rich as that of a straight bond. Convertible preferred stocks, sister securities, act in much the same fashion.

headline: Japanese Loan to China
abstract: Japan is to lend about $250 million to China under an agreement signed today, the New China News Agency said. The money is to be used on a petrochemical project being built at China's biggest oilfield, Daqing, in Manchuria, on the Baoshan iron and steel complex near Shanghai and on railroad and port construction.

abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Iran Is Said to Jail Hijackers On Return of Air Force Plane
abstract: Two Iranian noncommissioned officers who hijacked an air force transport plane to the United Arab Emirates Sunday were in jail in Iran today after allowing the plane to return home, an Iranian diplomat said.   After failing to gain political asylum in the United States and the United Arab Emirates, the hijackers released the 76 passengers. They decided on Monday to fly to Bandar Abbas, across the Straits of Hormuz, the Iranian diplomat, Consul General Javad Ansari, said in a telephone interview from the United Arab Emirates.

headline: Dan River Shares Sold to McDonough
abstract: In a move to fight off a takeover by Carl Icahn, the New York financier, Dan River Inc. said yesterday that it had sold 475,000 shares to the McDonough Company. McDonough is a subsidiary of Hanson Trust of Britain, a company with textile interests.   Dan River, a textile producer, said it had signed an agreement whereby McDonough would work with the company to consider proposals that might result in an offer to buy Dan River at a price equal to or better than yesterday's $18.50-a-share purchase price.
