headline: PEKING PRESENTS A 5-YEAR PLAN
abstract: China presented an overdue five-year plan today that sets cautious goals for economic growth while allocating substantial investment funds for chronic problem areas such as energy and transportation.   In a major report to the National People's Congress, China's nominal parliament, Prime Minister Zhao Ziyang said that the sixth five-year plan, which covers 1981 through 1985, would increase the gross value of industrial and agricultural output to 871 billion yuan - the equivalent of $435.5 billion - by 1985, an increase of just 21.7 percent over 1980.   Mr. Zhao called the modest annual growth target of 4 percent ''safe and appropriate, allowing room for overfulfillment.'' He disclosed that total output in industry and agriculture grew by 4.5 percent in 1981 and would reach 5.7 percent this year. He urged the Chinese to strive to achieve a 5 percent annual growth.

headline: U.S. Industries Picks Financial Executive
abstract: Sigurd D. Medhus, the chief financial officer at the American Express Company, has been appointed executive vice president and chief financial officer of U.S. Industries, a diversified maker of energy-related equipment, building materials and furniture.   Mr. Medhus, 53, fills a position held by A.M. Singer, who is retiring next year.

headline: OVERNIGHT RATES SOAR AGAIN
abstract: Key overnight lending rates continued to soar yesterday, despite moves by the Federal Reserve to help banks inject more liquidity into the banking system.   One immediate result was that several major banks began raising their broker loan rates to 11 1/2 percent from 10 percent. This contributed to declines in the markets for stocks, fixed-income securities and commodities, including precious metals.

headline: Pope Calls on Poles to Pray
abstract: Pope John Paul II today called for Poles to pray for the gains made in their country in the last two years. He was speaking to his countrymen in St. Peter's Square.

headline: WASHINGTON ENERGY CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Mortgage Rate Dip Seen
abstract: Richard Pratt, chairman of the Federal Home Loan Bank Board, said mortgage rates could fall to 12 percent within several months.   Mortgage rates currently are as high as 16 percent.  Mr. Pratt based his predictions on the benefits that thrift institutions are expected to gain from legislation recently approved by Congress.   The legislation directs Federal regulators to devise within 60 days a new type of deposit account to compete directly with money market funds, and gives the thrift units new powers.

headline: CARTER ASSERTS BEGIN WILL NOT GIVE UP SETTLEMENTS
abstract: Former President Jimmy Carter says he believes that Prime Minister Menachem Begin has no intention of ever removing Israeli settlements from the West Bank and ''has a single-minded commitment'' to annex the occupied territories.   Mr. Carter also says that Mr. Begin's secret aim in the 1978 talks that led to the Camp David accords was ''to cut a separate deal with Egypt.'' Mr. Carter says that at Camp David he favored President Anwar el-Sadat of Egypt, who was ''completely open, courageous, generous, farsighted.''   In an interview in this week's Time magazine accompanying the first of two long excerpts from ''Keeping Faith,'' his Presidential memoirs scheduled for publication next month, Mr. Carter called Mr. Begin a man of ''almost unshakable beliefs'' who found it ''very difficult to change his mind.''   ''It was torture for him to agree to remove the settlers from the Sinai,'' said Mr. Carter, adding: ''He has a single-minded commitment to annex permanently all the other occupied territories. He has a tendency to treat the Palestinians with scorn, to look down on them almost as subhumans and to rationalize his abusive attitude toward them by categorizing all Palestinians as terrorists.

headline: ANTI-SHARON PETITION CIRCULATES
abstract: Although public debate over the degree of Israeli responsibility has died somewhat since the establishment of a judicial commission of inquiry, there is still considerable ferment in the army, with significant numbers of senior officers reported backing the resignation of Defense Minister Ariel Sharon.   According to the pro-Government afternoon daily Yediot Aharonot, a petition calling for Mr. Sharon's resignation is circulating in the officer corps and has received 260 signatures so far.

headline: AFRICAN KINGDOM'S SECRET: GROOMING A NEW RULER
abstract: This independent black kingdom, which is clamped in a vise between white-ruled South Africa and Marxist Mozambique, is undergoing the first royal succession it has experienced in this century as tribal elders try to fill the political and cultural vacuum left by the death of King Sobhuza II.   The world's longest-reigning sovereign when he died six weeks ago at the age of 83, Sobhuza was the only king that living Swazis could remember. Gentle in manner but zealous in his defense of traditional values and rites, he managed to embody a remarkable compromise between tribal statecraft and contemporary mass politics. Sobhuza, who appeared before his people either bare-chested in the customary garb of a warrior or clad in a fancy field marshal's uniform with gold epaulets, excelled in both.

headline: News Analysis
abstract: Poland's martial law authorities appear to be successfully pursuing a complex strategy that will allow them to lift martial law by the end of the year - thus mollifying international opinion -while at the same time stamping out the remnants of the Solidarity labor union and any other form of political dissent. The strategy balances highly visible gestures of conciliation, particularly toward the Roman Catholic Church, with a steely use of the powers of state, including a new framework of laws and the overwhelming deployment of masses of special riot policemen to make sure the populace stays in line.   The North Atlantic Treaty Organization countries that imposed economic sanctions on Poland last February in response to the military takeover - a withdrawal of credits that has sorely hurt the already crippled economy by cutting off new hard currency loans to pay for imported parts and materials essential to the country's industry - set three conditions for lifting the punitive measures.  These were the resumption of discussions with the Roman Catholic Church and the nation, the release of the Solidarity leader Lech Walesa and other detainees, and the end of martial law. At the same time President Reagan imposed sanctions against the Soviet Union, which were lifted last week while leaving in place those against Poland.

headline: Patents; Computer Helps Find Filed Data
abstract: WASHINGTON THE International Business Machines Corporation has devised a method of using computers to retrieve letters and documents from office correspondence files. The person who wants such material uses plain English to describe it to the computer, which either shows on a screen where it is or displays its text.

headline: U.S. AND FRANCE AGREE ON STUDIES TO UNIFY STRATEGY ON SOVIET TRADE
abstract: The United States and France announced tonight that they had reached agreement on specific projects for coordinating allied strategy on economic relations with the Soviet Union.   Under the agreements, and with the expected approval of the other allies, the North Atlantic Treaty Organization will for the first time play a major role in defining economic issues that may affect the alliance's security.   The specific details were disclosed at an unusual news conference held close to midnight by Secretary of State George P. Shultz and Foreign Minister Claude Cheysson of France at the Quai d'Orsay, the French Foreign Ministry, after a black-tie dinner. The two men, apparently concerned that the degree of agreement reached by the two governments, which have been at odds in recent weeks, had not been made clear during an afternoon news conference by Mr. Shultz, decided to reveal more of the details.

headline: EXCERPTS FROM SPEECH BY THE POLISH LEADER
abstract: Following, as translated and distributed by the Polish press agency P.A.P., are excerpts from a speech by Gen.  Wojciech Jaruzelski, Poland's martial law leader, in which he announced that martial law would be partly lifted by the end of the year:   Citizens of the Polish People's Republic, Difficult years are behind us. Hard times had rolled over the Polish lands. They had produced internal splits and dangerously weakened that bond that throughout centuries was uniting Poles in the face of the greatest dangers. I will not recall those pre-December days. We all remember them. Nothing can conceal the merciless meaning of the then facts. It is only facts that truly count in politics, in the life of nations.   Exactly one year ago martial law was introduced.  The year that has passed was a great test. We have passed it. It has been passed by the party, by the people's authority and all the citizens. But there is the only winner: the Polish nation. This is the shortest-put truth about the past year.

headline: Production In October Down 0.8%; Drop Biggest Since April; Autos a Factor
abstract: The nation's industrial output fell eighttenths of 1 percent in October, the Federal Reserve reported today. It was the biggest decline since April and evidence that the slumping economy has still not touched bottom.   The decline was the 13th in the industrial production index - a measure of the output of the nation's factories, mines and utilities - in the last 15 months.   The October decline, the third straight after a tiny gain in July, was dominated by weakness in motor vehicle and business equipment production. Analysts did, however, take some comfort from the fact that automobile sales, aided by lower interest rates on car loans, have picked up recently and they said that there was good reason to expect this to be reflected soon in higher production.

headline: UNESCO OPENS 2 DAY PARIS PARLEY ON SETTING AGENDA FOR REST OF 80's
abstract: The United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization opened a two-week special conference here today to try to work out the framework for the organization's activities over the rest of the decade.   There was a short-lived Arab and African challenge to Israel's right to take part in the conference. But in the end Arab delegates went along with the decision of the credentials committee to accept Israel's credentials.

headline: U.S. IS PREPARING ITS POLICIES WITH A NEW KREMLIN LEADER IN MIND
abstract: The Reagan Administration has begun preparing policies toward the Soviet Union that are based on the assumption that there will be an early change in the Kremlin leadership and that it is important that the next Soviet leader have a clear idea of American views, Administration officials say.   Several officials involved in dealing with the Soviet Union said in interviews in recent days that there was a consensus among American intelligence officials that Leonid I. Brezhnev, the Soviet leader for the last 18 years, was in such poor health that he was likely to be replaced soon. But there is no agreement on when this might occur, or who would succeed him, officials said.   Mr. Brezhnev, who will be 76 years old in December, is believed to have been in poor health for years, particularly in the last four years, when his public appearances have decreased drastically.

headline: BRIEFS
abstract: * Early California Industries said its Comet Rice Inc. subsidiary had acquired all the stock outstanding of Pirmi Delta Inc., a rice miller in Greenville, Miss.; terms were not disclosed.   * General Aircraft Corp. and its Helio Precision Products division said they had asked creditors for a moratorium on payment of all existing trade and bank debt until Sept. 1, 1983, so the company might avoid seeking court protection.   * Harsco Corp.'s BMY subsidiary said it had received a $128 million contract to supply military vehicles and weapons to Egypt.

headline: THE CROWD PLEASING YOUNG MARKETS IN STOCK INDEX FUTURES
abstract: THE DIFFERENCES between buying stocks and gambling, which were never altogether clear to some investors, have been blurred still further by the introduction of futures contracts on stock indexes.  And based on the reception these new futures have received, there is no shortage of people who want to bet on the market.   On the Chicago Mercantile Exchange, more than 1.9 million contracts based on the Standard & Poor's Corporation's 500-stock index changed hands in the six months between April 21, when trading began, and the end of October. By contrast, trading volume in domestic certificates of deposit futures, which, until the introduction of S.& P. futures, had been the exchange's hottest new contract, amounted to only 1.4 million contracts in the 10 months through October.   What accounts for all the excitement? Well, the new index futures offer investors a variety of possibilities: some may want to hedge equity portfolios; arbitragers can take advantage of the minute differences in the values of separate contracts, and there is even a school of thought that holds that the indexes can be used as a market forecasting tool. But certainly the most intriguing aspect of these new investment vehicles is the chance to bet on the direction of stock prices for a fraction of the cost of buying a diversified equity portfolio.

headline: Official Slain in Peru
abstract: A gunman shot and killed the regional director of the National Cultural Institute today in the central Andean city of Ayacucho, the police reported. Walter Wong was the third official to be attacked in Ayacucho in less than a week.

headline: Europe-U.S. Steel Accord Expected
abstract: The United States and Western Europe are close to settling their 10-month trade dispute over steel, industry and government sources reported today.   Under the arrangement, which still is subject to final approval by European and American producers, European governments would establish quotas to keep shipments at around 5 percent of the overall American market, a domestic industry official reported. Last year European steel products accounted for 6.3 percent of the United States steel market.   Japan already informally limits steel shipments to the United States to about six million tons a year. Japan, Western Europe and the third world each have about a third of the import market in the United States, with imports, over all, claiming a 20 percent share of the American steel market

headline: Panhandle Eastern Picks a New Chief
abstract: When Richard L. O'Shields became chief executive officer of the Panhandle Eastern Corporation in 1970, his wife, Shirley, recalled yesterday, he passed the word around that he would probably not want to hold the job for more than 10 years.   Yesterday, in keeping with Mr. O'Shields' wishes, Panhandle, a diversified energy company, announced that Robert D. Hunsucker, 57 years old, president and chief operating officer, had been named chief executive officer and that Mr. O'Shields would continue as chairman, with the changes effective Jan.1.

headline: 235 in Egypt Plead Not Guilty to Sedition
abstract: A State Security Court heard 235 Moslem extremists plead not guilty to sedition charges today during a sixhour hearing.

headline: FINANCE BRIEFS
abstract: * Puget Sound Power and Light Co. filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission an offering of 400,000 shares of adjustable rate cumulative preferred shares, series A, through Salomon Brothers.   * Security Pacific Corp. issued $100 million in 10 1/2 percent notes, maturing in 3 1/2 years, through Goldman, Sachs.

headline: Israeli Minister, in Argentina, Raises Issue of Missing Jews
abstract: Foreign Minister Yitzhak Shamir of Israel told Argentina's President and Foreign Minister today that Israel is concerned about nearly 1,000 Jews who disappeared during the military regime's war on leftist terrorism from 1975 to 1979.   Mr. Shamir, who arrived Monday for a three-day visit, met for an hour and a half with Foreign Minister Juan Aguirre Lanari, then went to Government House for a brief talk with the President, Gen.  Raynaldo Bignone.

headline: I.M.F. Loan To Mexico
abstract: The International Monetary Fund today gave final approval for a $3.9 billion loan to Mexico and said $2 billion of new trade credits had been arranged from 10 industrial nations.   The loan by the 146-nation fund is the centerpiece of a financial rescue operation intended to provide Mexico with enough cash to make foreign payments, including those on its $85 billion foreign debt, one of the highest in the world.   The credit agreement requires Mexico to impose sharp cutbacks in public spending and reductions in a variety of Government services.  The austerity program is intended to make more funds available for foreign debt repayment.

headline: EAGLE CLOTHES INC reports earnings for Yr to July 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Allegheny Ludlum Deal
abstract: The Allegheny Ludlum Steel Corporation said today that it had formed a partnership with Sumitomo Metal Industries of Japan for the manufacture and marketing of industrial titanium products. The partnership, the ALS Metals Company, will manufacture and market pure titanium, sheet, strip, plate and welded tubing for industrial application in the United States and Canada.

headline: NEW YORK BANK PROFITS SURGE
abstract: Despite problems in collecting on foreign loans, New York City's major bank holding companies reported strong earnings for the third quarter.   Elsewhere in the country, however, results were mixed. Chicago's two major banking companies showed relatively weak results, while earnings at most of those in California were under downward pressure.    The biggest factor in the strength of the New York bank holding companies was a sharp decline in interest rates during the quarter.  The companies' rise in earnings came largely at the expense of borrowers. This was because of an unusually large spread between the interest rates that banks charged on the loans they made and the interest rates that the banks themselves paid for funds.

headline: Tang to Buy McLouth Assets
abstract: Tang Industries, the Chicago-based metals manufacturer, said it had reached a definitive agreement to buy ''substantially all of the operating assets'' of the troubled McLouth Steel Corporation of Detroit for $75 million.

headline: REAGAN HAILS POLAND'S EASING OF MARTIAL LAW
abstract: President Reagan welcomed today what he described as recent ''partial steps'' easing the military crackdown in Poland and promised to relax United States sanctions against Poland if ''meaningful liberalizing measures'' were introduced in the future.   In what an Administration official said was a ''modification'' of the United States position toward Poland, Mr. Reagan also omitted a specific reference to the Solidarity trade union when he listed the conditions Poland would have to meet before the sanctions could be lifted.   In the past, Mr. Reagan has said the sanctions would not be lifted until Poland lifted martial law, released Lech Walesa and other detainees and restored ''dialogue and reconciliation'' with both Solidarity and the Roman Catholic Church.

headline: WEST BLOC BIDS EAST ACCEPT FREE UNIONS
abstract: The two-year-old conference that is reviewing the 1975 Helsinki accords on European security resumed here today with Western nations making fresh demands on the Soviet bloc to accept free trade unions and the right to political self-determination.   A list of suggestions that appeared to be both an effort to bridge the gap between the United States and Western Europe and a response to the sitution in Poland was put forward by the 10 nations of the Common Market. The demands were supported by the United States.   Warning that ''East-West relations remain at a low ebb characterized by mutual distrust and lack of confidence,'' Thomas Rechnagel, the Danish delegate to the conference, said the Common Market nations felt a need to respond to the abolition last month of the Polish union Solidarity, to the Soviet reduction of emigration permits and to Moscow's elimination of direct-dial overseas telephone connections. Denmark holds the European Community's rotating presidency.

headline: HABIB CONFERS WITH MUBARAK ON LEBANON AND WEST BANK
abstract: President Hosni Mubarak met for 80 minutes today with Philip C. Habib, the special American envoy, on how to obtain a rapid withdrawal of foreign troops from Lebanon and how to include Palestinians and Jordanians in peace talks.   Foreign Minister Kamal Hassan Ali later described Mr. Habib as hopeful that progress could be made by the end of the year on the withdrawal from Lebanon of Israeli, Syrian and Palestine Liberation Organization forces. ''Negotiations for this purpose should take place as soon as possible,'' Mr. Ali said.

headline: NEW ENGLAND
abstract: THE unemployment rate in New England mirrors the national average, b ut the region is still attractive to people seeking jobs in h ightechnology fields. The Boston area, with its many major u niversities and research centers, is the technology hub, but s outhern New Hampshire and Vermont have drawn some of the business.   Minicomputers and electronics research related to defense have the most promising growth outlook, according to Mark Lauritano, senior regional economist for Data Resources of Lexington, Mass. Mr.  Lauritano said President Reagan's large military budget was expected to bring an even bigger bonanza to high-technology companies developing guidance systems and other defense projects. ''This is the only sector in New England that has shown no sign of a recession,'' Mr. Lauritano said. Southern Maine, with its shipbuilding industry, and Connecticut, with its electronics and aircraft concerns, will also see defense-related job growth, he said.

headline: Salvador Prelate Hails Rights Move by Regime
abstract: El Salvador's top churchman today praised the Government's creation of a human rights commission but said the body could only be judged by its action.

headline: No Headline
abstract: AROUND THE WORLD; 8 Polish Union Leaders Vow to Fight   WARSAW, Dec. 26 (Reuters) - Eight leaders of the banned Solidarity trade union have signed a statement from detention refusing to accept the Government's outlawing of the union and vowing to fight for its revival.   ''The Polish crisis cannot be solved without Solidarity,'' they said in the statement, which was dated Dec. 10 and signed by key union leaders held at Bialoleka Prison in Warsaw under martial law internment orders.

headline: Bank Tie Near In Florida
abstract: Great American Banks Inc. of Miami has announced that its shareholders have approved the company's acquisition by Barnett Banks of Florida Inc. in a $17 a share transaction valued at about $47 million.   According to the agreement, which is subject to approval by Federal bank regulators, Great American shareholders will receive either 10-year tax-deferred senior investment notes or $17 cash per share.   Barnett, a multibank holding company with 197 offices in Florida and $6.3 billion in assets, has a separate agreement to buy the nearly 56 percent of Great American held by the Combanks Corporation of Winter Park, Fla. for about $23 million.

headline: Talks on Cuba's Debt
abstract: Japanese banks expect the formation soon of a steering committee of Spanish, French, Japanese, British, Canadian and other banks for talks on the rescheduling of Cuban debts of $1.3 billion due before the end of 1985, banking sources said today. Leon Torras, governor of Cuba's central bank, is visiting Tokyo to explain a request for rescheduling 32.5 billion yen, or about $120 million, of syndicated loans supplied by Japanese banks.

headline: BRITON ASSAILS THE U.N. RESOLUTION AS 'ARGENTINE-INSPIRED CHARADE'
abstract: Foreign Secretary Francis Pym lashed out today at supporters of the United Nations resolution calling for negotiations on the future of the Falkland Islands, and rejected the General Assembly decision.   Without mentioning the United States, which announced its support for the resolution two days ago, Mr. Pym said just before the vote that the ''result will bring little credit to those whose memories proved so short.''   The resolution, declared Mr. Pym in the House of Commons, is ''an Argentine-inspired charade.'' And he maintained that ''the whole idea of Argentina introducing a draft United Nations resolution calling for negotiations is absurd, after her flouting of the United Nations Charter and her defiance of the Security Council.''

headline: GERMAN CAUTIONS ON MISSILE DELAY
abstract: The new Defense Minister of West Germany, Manfred Worner, warned today that failure to deploy Pershing 2 missiles in Europe on schedule a year from now would ''trigger very, very serious consequences.''   The technical ability of the United States to meet the deployment schedule of the Pershing missiles has been questioned because two test flights have been unsuccessful. A third test firing has reportedly been scheduled for Friday.

headline: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
abstract: * Chase Manhattan Bank has appointed Jagan M. Reddy, Paul Ramsden, Karyn C. Reynolds, Cecilia B. Richardson, Somchit Sertthin, Geoffrey E.M. Smith, Richard Tai Ning Tsoi and Primo Zanoni vice presidents.   * Chemical Bank has named Nancy B. Benedict, Vijay K. Bhargava, Maria N. Dahlman, Ulrich Gnath, Raymond J. Heaney, Didier Livertoux, Paul I. McCarthy, Bruno Mercier, Patricia A. Micka, Henry D.  Morneault, Vicenzo Repola and Robert S. Rogers vice presidents.

headline: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
abstract: * American Appraisal Associates, Milwaukee, has elected Ronald Goergen vice president of administration and Lee P. Hackett vice president of operations.   * Analogic Corp., Wakefield, Mass., has named John McG. Dobbs a vice president and chief scientist.

headline: ICAHN MAKES DUAL OFFER FOR DAN RIVER
abstract: Carl C. Icahn, the New York financier, offered yesterday to pay stockholders of Dan River Inc. either $15 a share or $18 a share for a big stake in the old-line Southern textile producer, depending on how the company reacts to the offer.   The two-pronged proposal was viewed as a device to put pressure on directors of the company to support Mr. Icahn. So far Dan River has opposed his interest in the company. Despite a generally weak stock market, Dan River shares rose 1 7/8 yesterday, to 16 1/4, in brisk trading.

headline: Lloyd's to Name Outside Chief
abstract: The newly formed governing council of Lloyd's of London has unanimously decided to appoint the first independent chief executive for the troubled insurance exchange.   The move came in response to a wave of scandals that has tarnished the reputations and dented the balance sheets of some of Lloyd's best-known participants. According to published reports, it had been urged on reluctant Lloyd's officials by both the Bank of England, the pre-eminent voice in Britain's financial community, and the Department of Industry.

headline: ISRAEL ELABORATES ON WARNING BY MASSACRE COMMISSION
abstract: A spokesman for the commission investigating the massacre of Palestinian civilians in Beirut said today that the warnings issued Wednesday to nine senior Israeli officials did not constitute ''interim findings, interim results.''   The three-man commission published a resolution, in accordance with the law, warning the officials, who included Prime Minister Menachem Begin, Defense Minister Ariel Sharon and Foreign Minister Yitzhak Shamir. The panel said the officials might be found to have failed in their duties by not being aware of the dangers of asking Christian Phalangist militiamen to enter two Palestinian refugee camps, and, in some cases, of neglecting to act quickly to reports to stop the deaths of as many as 800 Palestinian men, women and children.   The spokesman, Bezalel Gordon, said at a briefing today that the purpose of issuing the resolution was to warn the officials that they were ''liable to be harmed'' by the commission's findings and to give them 15 days in which to decide whether they wish to retain lawyers, reappear before the commission to examine testimony and to cross-examine witnesses.

headline: Amarex Petition
abstract: Amarex Inc. said its creditors had filed a Chapter 7 involuntary bankruptcy petition against it in Oklahoma's bankruptcy court. The company said it had authorized a motion to transfer the case to Chapter 11 of the bankruptcy code, which would make it a debtor in possession and require it to file a plan of reorganization.

headline: NEVADA SAVINGS & LOAN ASSN reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Dome Sees Progress
abstract: Dome Petroleum Ltd. has said it can meet its operating and capital requirements, as well as interest and dividend payments in 1983, without the need for additional funds. But it said its financial status had not improved enough to allow it to make principal payments on its huge debt. The statement came in the company's quarterly report with the Securities and Exchange Commission, filed this week.

headline: MEXICANS TO SHIFT GUATEMALA EXILES
abstract: Mexico has decided to start moving refugees away from camps on its border with Guatemala in the hope of discouraging the Guatemalan Army from making new incursions into Mexican territory in pursuit of suspected guerrillas, according to senior Mexican officials.   The officials also disclosed that President Jose Lopez Portillo had decided not to send troop reinforcements to the area. They said he wanted to minimize the risk of military clashes with Guatemala and avoid the worsening of political tensions on the Mexican side of the 565-mile-long border.   Last month Mexico formally protested over several border incidents involving Guatemalan troops and resulting in the deaths of five Mexicans. According to officials in Mexico's southern state of Chiapas, incursions by the Guatemalan Army have been far more numerous than previously reported. Guatemala has denied the Mexican accusations.

headline: NELSON RESEARCH & DEVELOPMENT CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Argentine President Promises Elections in '83
abstract: President Reynaldo Bignone announced today that elections would be held in Argentina next year, probably in the fourth quarter.   A presidential spokesman said General Bignone announced at a Cabinet meeting today that he had decided to call elections in 1983 after reaching an agreement with the armed forces.

headline: Nigeria Decides to Withdraw From U.N. Force in Lebanon
abstract: United Nations officials said today that Nigeria had withdrawn a company of soldiers from the peacekeeping force in Lebanon and would soon withdraw the remainder of its troops.   A company of 180 to 200 men that had completed its scheduled tour of duty and returned home on Nov. 10 will not be replaced, according to the United Nations officials.

headline: Treasury Rates Show Decline
abstract: The Treasury's weekly auction of three- and six-month bills yesterday produced moderately lower average rates. On the three-month bills, the average rate was 7.857 percent, down from 7.995 a week ago, while that on the companion issue slipped to 8.104 percent, from 8.205 percent.   Based on a four-week average rate formula, the maximum rate that savings banks and thrift institutions may pay on six-month savings certificiates, as a result of the auction, is 8.768 percent, starting today. Last week's ceiling was 8.769 percent. For the banks' 91-day savings certificates, the rate declined to 7.857 percent from 7.995.

headline: Treasury Note Offering
abstract: The Treasury said yesterday that it will consider issuing a note in early December with a maturity of about five years and additions to upcoming two-year and four-year note maturities. The reason given was to fulfill the Treasury's net financing requirements of about $26.3 billion in the current quarter.

headline: Breyers Closing
abstract: The Kraft Dairy Group said it would close its Breyers ice cream plant in Long Island City, Queens, next April as part of a companywide consolidation program. The plant, which employs 350, also manufactures Sealtest ice cream and sherbets and Light 'n' Lively ice milk. Fred Rasmussen, vice president of the Kraft Dairy Group, a unit of Dart & Kraft, said the company would also discontinue its frozen dessert distribution facilities in Farmingdale, L.I., and Hillside, N.J. The company will maintain its sales ofices in Fairlawn, N.J. and distribute its frozen desserts made elsewhere in the Northeast.

headline: MONOGRAM INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: SMALL BANKERS FEEL THE PINCH
abstract: Despite the customary lavish receptions, this year's annual convention of the American Bankers Association is not a particularly joyous affair.   It is clear that few banks represented here - or communities where the institutions do business - have been totally spared by the recession. This year, in fact, at least partly because of the troubled economy, there are only 10,000 bankers and spouses attending, compared with 12,000 at last year's convention in San Francisco. Much of the chatter at this year's meeting is whether the bankers will be able to afford to attend next year's convention, which will be in Hawaii.

headline: JOSEPHSON INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Panhandle Suing Columbia Gas Unit
abstract: The Panhandle Eastern Corporation's pipeline unit said it had sued a subsidiary of the Columbia Gas System for its failure to purchase the minimum amount of natural gas called for in their contract.

headline: PETROMINERALS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: United Asks Delay On 20 Boeing 767's
abstract: Richard J. Ferris, the chairman of UAL Inc., said yesterday that its subsidiary, United Airlines, and the Boeing Company had reached an agreement under which United could stretch out to 1989 the delivery of some of the 20 remaining Boeing 767 aircraft it has on order.   United's was the first and largest order for the the 767's.

headline: WHAT IS NEEDED FROM THE GATT TALKS?; JAPANESE GOOD WILL
abstract: THE focus of United States trade policies has shifted, and a reneweda ttack on Japan Inc. is about to begin. Desperate to stave off an e xpected wave of protectionist sentiment in the next Congress, the R eagan Administration feels it must bring about a major reorientationo f Japan's economy.  The Business Roundtable and other major industrial associations are saying that the depressed yen is killing them. The Reagan Administration is itself deeply worried about next year's foreign trade and current accounts. If a significant economic recovery does occur in the United States, and if the dollar continues to be strong, imports are expected to soar, and exports to be weak. The yen value is crucial, not only in relation to American imports, but also to the competitive position of our exports.

headline: Greek Leader Accepts Offer For Official Visit to Warsaw
abstract: Prime Minister Andreas Papandreou has accepted an official invitation by Wojciech Jaruzelski to visit Poland, the Government announced today.   The invitation to Mr. Papandreou, the statement said, was extended by General Jaruzelski when the two met in Moscow during the preparations for the funeral of Leonid I. Brezhnev. It said the date of the visit was not fixed.

headline: TAX IS CUT FOR BRITISH BUSINESSES
abstract: Business got some of the tax relief it had been seeking as Sir Geoffrey Howe, the Chancellor of the Exchequer, made the Government's annual fall economic presentation to Parliament here this afternoon.   However, the economic message left uncommitted a large proportion of the ''extra'' funds the Government has accumulated by building up a smaller-than-expected deficit.   Falling inflation and interest rates, along with higher prices for North Sea oil, have reduced the Government's borrowing needs in the current fiscal year, which ends March 31. It is widely thought here that some of the savings will appear in the next budget as a personal income tax cut in anticipation of a late summer or fall election.

headline: Harvester Sheds Hauler Business
abstract: The debt-ridden International Harvester Company said it had sold its off-highway hauler business to the Payhauler Corporation, a company formed by three former Harvester employees. It did not give the price, which it said was in cash and notes.

headline: GIRARD CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: COURT TO RULE ON UTILITY COOPERATION CASE
abstract: The Supreme Court agreed today to review Federal rules designed to force utility companies to cooperate in the development of competing sources of energy. The case could produce one of the most important regulatory decisions of the new term.   The case is an appeal by the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission, joined by the paper industry, from a lower court ruling that invalidated the commission's interpretation of a key section of the Public Utility Regulatory Policies Act of 1978.

headline: Olympic Coins Deal
abstract: The United States Treasury has retained D'Arcy-MacManus & Masius/ New York to sell some 52 million gold and silver 1983 and 1984 Olympic Commemorative Coins. The assignment goes all the way from the creation of the proper advertising through packaging and distribution.

headline: NEW YORK TELEPHONE CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: PINKERTON'S IS BEING ACQUIRED
abstract: As part of a continuing acquisition campaign, American Brands Inc.  will acquire Pinkerton's Inc., one of the biggest names in security services.   Under an agreement announced by the two companies late Monday night, American Brands will pay $77.50 a share, or about $165 million, for all of the 2.15 million outstanding shares of Pinkerton's class A and class B stock.   The Class A stock, the only stock with voting privileges, is not publicly traded. The class B stock, which is traded over the counter, has been below $60 this year, but in the last week it has been in the 70's. It was quoted yesterday at $73.50.

headline: Israeli Theater Faces Charges For Performing Banned Play
abstract: Criminal charges will be filed against the Neve Zedeck theater company for twice performing a banned play, ''The Patriot'' by Hanoch Levin, a Justice Ministry spokesman said today.

headline: RATES PLUNGE IN LIVELY RALLY
abstract: In a dramatic credit market rally, interest rates tumbled sharply yesterday while prices of Government notes and bonds soared in response to reports that the Federal Reserve would tolerate moneysupply growth above its previously announced targets.   However, economists warned that it was too early to tell whether the Fed had made a significant change in monetary policy.  ''I'm saying that we now have a modification in Fed policy,'' said David M. Jones of Aubrey G. Lanston & Company. ''But I believe the central bank is still holding to the same general monetary approach adopted in October 1979.''

headline: Sri Lanka Reports A Dispute With U.S.
abstract: The United States has asked Sri Lanka to recall a ranking diplomat from Washington in retaliation for the ouster of his American counterpart in Colombo, the Government announced today.

headline: Bonn Is Investigating Report About Slave Labor on Pipeline
abstract: A spokesman for West Germany's governing Christian Democratic Party said today that it was investigating charges that the Soviet Union was using slave labor to build the new natural gas pipeline from Siberia to Western Europe.   The spokesman, Gunther Reichert, said in a statement that the party's members of Parliament had asked the European Confederation of Trade Unions to take ''appropriate initiatives'' to determine whether the charges were true.

headline: TEXACO FINDS OIL OFF CALIFORNIA COAST
abstract: Texaco Inc. said yesterday that a well it operates off the coast of southern California had yielded large oil reserves. It said the well, one of six drilled in the area, confirmed that a ''giant oil discovery'' had been made.''

headline: Belzbergs Make Bid For Gas Company
abstract: The First City Financial Corporation, a Canadian financial services company headed by the Belzberg family, said yesterday that it had offered $48.50 a share, or an indicated $256.1 million, to acquire the Suburban Propane Gas Corporation of Morristown, N.J.   The offer, made in a letter to Propane's management, was made public by the Canadian company in Vancouver, British Columbia.  Officials of the two companies met yesterday to discuss the proposal, a spokesman for the New Jersey company said, but he declined to elaborate.

headline: WORLD BANK AIDE SEES CHINA AS BIG BORROWER
abstract: China may eventually rank with India as the World Bank's two largest borrowers, according to a top bank official who has completed talks with the Government here.   ''We are still far from reaching our cruising altitude with regard to China,'' said Munir P. Benjenk, the World Bank's vice president of external relations. He estimated that China might approach India's level some time in 1985.

headline: Soviet Atom Test Recorded
abstract: A Swedish seismological institute said today that it had registered an underground nuclear explosion in the Soviet Union. The institute, the Hagfors military observatory, said the explosion occurred at the Semipalatinsk nuclear test area in Siberia on Sunday. The tremor registered 6.7 on the Richter scale, officials said.

headline: ATTORNEY GENERAL SPEAKS TO AFGHANS
abstract: Attorney General William French Smith toured an Afghan refugee camp in Peshawar today and offered the largest refugee population in the world Washington's ''firm support in these difficult times.''   Mr. Smith flew to Peshawar after meeting Government officials in Islamabad for talks on stemming the flow of opium from Pakistan and coping with 2.7 million refugees from the fighting in Afghanistan.   From Peshawar, his delegation flew by helicopter to the Khyber Pass, which guards the border with Afghanistan.  He received a warm welcome from troops there and North West Frontier Province tribal elders who showered him with garlands and presented him with two decorated rams.

headline: U.S. SAYS ALLIES BLOCK PIPELINE ACCORD
abstract: High State Department officials said today that three negotiating sessions with American allies in Washington had failed to resolve the dispute over the sanctions that the United States has imposed against builders of the Soviet natural gas pipeline to Europe.   They said an accord on a new, overall East-West trade policy under which the sanctions would be dropped was being blocked by some of the allies, especially France.   Officials here, summarizing the state of the negotiations between the United States and its key allies, said they still hoped for an eventual accord, but they refused to predict the outcome. Last month some officials were freely predicting an agreement would have been reached by today -Election Day - but now they are talking of much more difficult negotiations ahead.

headline: PRESIDENT PLEDGES TO GIVE BRAZILIANS A $1.2 BILLION LOAN
abstract: President Reagan said today that the United States would provide $1.2 billion in emergency short-term loans to Brazil, and he appealed to lenders around the world to help Brazil and other countries through their financial crises.   In his first full day of meetings on his South American trip, Mr.  Reagan praised Brazil for undertaking austerity measures to overcome its huge debt problem, in which up to $14 billion in loans will fall due in the months ahead. Such measures are similar, Mr. Reagan said, to ''the painful steps necessary to overcome the economic crisis that threatens our people'' in the United States.   Among the Brazilian austerity steps are cuts in Government social programs, a reduction in imports and possible cuts in workers' wage increases.

headline: MOZAMBIQUE KEEPS TO MARXIST ROUTE
abstract: Although Mozambique appears to be trying to improve relations with the West, there has been no matching domestic move to deviate from Marxist theory.   While some foreign diplomats attribute Mozambique's poor economic performance to unsuccessful socialist ventures, the ruling Mozambique Liberation Front has made what one diplomat called ''only a pious bow'' in the direction of looser economic controls to provide greater incentives. Instead, recently published guidelines for next year's party congress call for ''the reinforcement of the controlling position of our Marxist-Leninist party.''   The guidelines are framed in what are called the ''eight theses'' up for discussion at the fourth party congress of the Mozambique Liberation Front, known as Frelimo. The first of these says: ''Our conquests result from the socialist nature of our revolution. Only the people's struggle under the direction of Frelimo can defend, consolidate and widen them.''

headline: AIR CARGO EQUIPMENT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: COSTA RICA MOVES TO CLOSE DOOR TO FUGITIVES
abstract: Costa Rica's new President is moving to reverse his country's reputation as a good place for North Americans to escape the law.   The President, Luis Alberto Monge, has begun a roundup of fugitives. Further, Costa Rica has negotiated a new extradition treaty with the United States to close loopholes in an existing 60-year-old treaty.   Over the last decade, Costa Rica has become home for thousands of American retirees and investors who have been wooed by the tranquillity, climate and tax breaks offered by this rare Central American democracy. In return, Costa Rica has earned much-needed foreign exchange.

headline: SLOW DAY FOR TREASURY ISSUES
abstract: A modest rally late yesterday in the prices of Treasury securities ended a day of slow and directionless trading in which the money markets again waited in vain for the Federal Reserve to reduce two key interest rates.   Dealers said that the failure of the Federal funds rate and the discount rate to come down caused the poor reception accorded the Treasury's new $6 billion of three-year notes, which were auctioned Wednesday, and the equal lack of retail interest in yesterday's $4 billion of 10-year Treasury notes. All this weighed heavily on the money market.   For more than a week, the market has been expecting a cut in the discount rate, which the Fed charges on loans to financial institutions. Traders have also been expecting the Fed to push down the Federal funds rate, which is the interest on overnight loans between banks. Any reduction of these two key rates stimulates investment, tending to raise the prices of fixed-income securities and lower their yields.

headline: BERKEY PHOTO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: SOVIET SAYS POLAND CAN RELY ON HELP IN UPHOLDING REGIME
abstract: The Soviet Defense Minister, Marshal Dmitri F. Ustinov, said today that Poland's martial-law Government could rely on Moscow's help in its effort to maintain Communist rule.   In a message to the Polish leader, Gen. Wojciech Jaruzelsi, on Polish Army Day, Marshal Ustinov said: ''There can be no doubt that all the calculations of internal counterrevolutionaries and imperialist forces to undermine the foundations of socialism in Poland to weaken the unity and solidarity of the socialist community are doomed to failure.''   General Jaruzelski is Defense Minister as well as Prime Minister and head of the Polish Communist Party.

headline: Britain Reviews Concorde Aid
abstract: British Airways will keep flying the Concorde, Sir John King, chairman, said today after reports that the Government would end public financing of the supersonic plane.  ''Concorde services will go on,'' he said.

headline: GROUP OF BIDS FOR SUBURBAN PROPANE
abstract: The multimillionaire Bass family of Fort Worth has joined with top executives of the Suburban Propane Gas Corporation to seek to buy the company, the Morristown, N.J., propane supplier said yesterday.   In a move to frustrate a possible takeover bid from the Belzberg brothers of Canada, who control 12 percent of Suburban's stock, the Bass group offered to pay $45 a share for the company's 5.3 million shares, or $238.5 million.   Wall Street arbitragers, flush with cash at a time of almost no takeover activity, bid up the price of Suburban Propane by 4 7/8, to 45, yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange.

headline: GAF CITES INTEREST BY 7 CONCERNS
abstract: The GAF Corporation said yesterday that it had been approached by four companies interested in either acquiring it outright or participating in a leveraged buy-out. At the same time, GAF said, three other companies have indicated an interest in buying its building materials group.   The developments were disclosed in a letter to shareholders from Jesse Werner, chairman and chief executive of the New York-based company.

headline: Newmont in Deal For Copper Unit
abstract: The Newmont Mining Corporation said it had agreed in principle to acquire the Cities Service Company's Miami copper operations in Arizona for $75 million in cash.

headline: Top Credit Officer Quits At Continental Illinois
abstract: George R. Baker, executive vice president of the Continental Illinois Corporation and the Continental Illinois National Bank and Trust Company, has announced that he will resign Dec. 31 to pursue other interests.   Mr. Baker, 53, who had been mentioned as a possible successor to the bank's 61-year-old chairman, Roger E. Anderson, was responsible for the bank's dealings with its corporate customers. He was also the bank's senior credit officer during a period in which it made many loans that have subsequently gone sour, including those it purchased from the failed Penn Square Bank of Oklahoma City.

headline: Stock Index Plan Approved
abstract: The Commodity Futures Trading Commission has approved a plan by the New York Futures Exchange to trade futures on the New York Stock Exchange's composite index, an agency spokesman said today.   The New York Futures Exchange will allow trading in its new contract simultaneously with a similar one it already offers, which is also based on the New York Stock Exchange composite index. The new contract differs from the existing one in size and the allowable minimum price fluctuation.

headline: Work Clothes Renter Tracks Unemployment
abstract: Bruce L. Cohen is not an economist but he has a good track record forecasting the nation's unemployment rate.  Mr. Cohen, 39, is the newly elected president and chief executive of Servisco, a Hillside, N.J., company that rents work clothes and uniforms to more than 45,000 companies, including airlines, oil companies, manufacturers and fast-food outlets.   ''Every week I see the number of new account orders, rental decrease orders and people who have quit taking service,'' he said.

headline: Dancer to Develop Direct Marketing Unit
abstract: Dancer Fitzgerald Sample, 11th-biggest agency in the United States and a powerhouse in packaged goods advertising, is joining the the other agencies that have already developed direct marketing capability either by acquiring companies or personnel. It has chosen the latter route in a very modest way.

headline: RAYMARK CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: TUESDAY, OCTOBER 26, 1982; Markets
abstract: Stock prices plunged, reflecting investor concern over the course of interest rates. Pension funds and institutional investors unloaded large blocks of stock, sending the Dow Jones industrial average down 36.33 points, to 995.13, its second-biggest single-day drop ever.  Trading volume was moderate, remaining well below recent record levels. The largest stock market decline occurred on Oct. 28, 1929, during the crash that preceded the Depression. (Page A1.)   Short- and long-term interest rates rose in the credit markets in what analysts said was a technical correction following the huge declines earlier this month. (D10.) Prices of all three stock index futures fell sharply along with the actual market indexes on the commodities markets. (D12.) The dollar rose to a 12-year high against currencies of major industrial trading partners. Gold and silver prices tumbled. (D12.)

headline: BOMBS DAMAGE ATOM PLANT SITE IN SOUTH AFRICA
abstract: Four bombs exploded today and Saturday at South Africa's only nuclear power station, which is under construction on the rocky Atlantic coast just north of Cape Town.   The underground African National Congress, in a statement issued in Dar es Salaam, Tanzania, said it was responsible for the attack on the station, which was not in operation.   No one was injured in the bombings, the police said.  The security police said tonight that the damage to the Koeberg power station was still being assessed, but that there was no danger from radioactivity to the population of Cape Town or workers at the site.

headline: More Confident Consumer Seen
abstract: Consumers grew more confident in November that business conditions and job opportunities will improve in coming months, according to a new survey released yesterday.

headline: Bloom of Dallas Gets Abbott
abstract: The bright-eyed Bloom Agency in Dallas has become agency for Abbott Laboratories' Murine eye drops and Murine Plus, as well as another eye product called Clear Eyes.   The agency is not permitted to release billing figures, according to C. Anthony Wainwright, chairman, who could say only that the budget would be ''several millions.''

headline: Holiday Note
abstract: Stock and commodity markets, banks and Government offices in the United States were closed yesterday in observance of Thanksgiving.  Markets and banks will be open today as usual. The Federal Reserve Board will postpone its release of weekly money supply figures from this afternoon to Monday afternoon.

headline: Market Place; Genentech's Outlook Now
abstract: GENENTECH Inc. offers speculators the quintessential fad stock.  Genentech, the highly acclaimed leader in the promising field of genetic engineering, has carried a stratospheric price/earnings multiple since the public offering of 1.1 million shares at $35 each in October 1981. Few would question that this tiny company, with revenues of $15 million last year, was overvalued at a P/E ratio of more than 100.   Now, after years of research and the apparent perfection of a major product, Genentech may soon experience its first exposure to the commercial market and - if all goes well - its first important earnings.

headline: ZIMBABWE POLICE TAKE SMITH TO CAPITAL AND SEARCH HOME
abstract: Former Prime Minister Ian D. Smith, who angered the Government by criticizing it while abroad recently, was taken with his wife from their farm today and escorted by policemen to their home in a suburb of this capital city. The home was searched room by room for four hours.   The Government said it had not arrested Mr. Smith, who headed the white minority Government of Rhodesia before the country was renamed Zimbabwe and black majority rule was established.

headline: FRASER INC (CANADA) reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: The Pentagon
abstract: To the Business Editor: The words of David Blond, a Pentagon strategist and advocate of increased Pentagon funding, in ''At War Over the Pentagon'' (Nov.14), deserve especially careful scrutiny. In the context of the fostering by the Japanese Government of technological change, Mr. Blond is quoted as saying that ''... only the Department of Defense's budget is rich enough to experiment with new approaches to complex problems.''

headline: DEXTER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: PACIFIC LUMBER CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: FRIDAY, DECEMBER 24, 1982; The Economy
abstract: An extension to restructure the bankruptcy courts was denied Congress by the Supreme Court. The decision cast substantial doubt on the ability of the Federal court system to handle corporate and personal bankruptcies in the foreseeable future. At issue is the jurisdictional status of the bankruptcy judges. (Page A1.)   The Senate gave final approval to a 5-cent-a-gallon increase in the gasoline tax to finance highway repairs and mass transit, after breaking a filibuster by two conservative Republicans. (A1.) Highway experts argued that the bigger trucks allowed under the legislation would require costly added road maintainance and cause safety problems. (A1.) Oil industry analysts believe that the tax rise will go virtually unnoticed by motorists because it will be offset by a further drop in oil prices and strong competition. (B4.).

headline: Tokyo Stock Market Gains
abstract: The Tokyo stock market average rose 71.15 today, to 7,966.77, its highest point this year, in active trading that reflected expectations of a lower interest rates soon, dealers said.

headline: ARABS AT U.N. RENEW ATTACKS ON ISRAEL
abstract: Arab countries today reopened their campaign in the Security Council to halt Israeli settlement in the West Bank but, at the urging of the United States, confined themselves to making speeches.   The Arab diplomats strongly condemned Israel's policy as a threat to peace. They held back, however, from offering the customary Council resolution that ends debates.

headline: Big Thrift Unit Merger
abstract: The nation's third- and fourth-largest savings and loan associations have proposed a merger that would create the biggest one in the country, with assets of nearly $20 billion.   The California Federal Savings and Loan Association, based in Los Angeles, with assets of just over $10 billion, agreed Tuesday to merge with the American Savings and Loan Association, a subsidiary of the First Charter Corporation of Beverly Hills, Calif., with assets of slightly less than $10 billion.

headline: PHILIPPINE PRIESTS RECEIVE A WARNING
abstract: President Ferdinand E. Marcos vowed today to crack down on what he called rebel priests who help anti-Government guerrillas.   ''The days of the friars are long gone,'' Mr. Marcos, 64, told a nationally televised gathering of war veterans in a speech that appeared certain to increase the Government's rift with the Roman Catholic Church.

headline: Whirlpool to End Ice-Machine Line
abstract: The Whirlpool Corporation plans to stop producing commercial ice-making machines at its St.  Paul, division early in 1983, said Andy Takacs, Whirlpool vice president for public relations. The cutback will eventually eliminate about 100 of the 1,260 Whirlpool jobs at St. Paul.   The decision to stop building commercial ice makers was made last week based on the concern's belief it could not effectively compete in the market because it does not offer a full line of the machines, Mr. Takacs said.

headline: A.T.&T. Down 3.7%; First Fall Since '75
abstract: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company, citing the recession's adverse impact on demand for phone services, yesterday announced its first quarterly decline in net income since 1975.   The company said that earnings for the quarter ended Nov. 30 fell 3.7 percent, to $1.84 billion, or $2.07 a share, from $1.91 billion, or $2.31 a share, in the same period a year earlier. The number of shares outstanding rose to 872 million in the period from 810 million a year earlier.   Revenues in the November quarter rose 9.2 percent, to $16.6 billion, from $15.2 billion in the same 1981 period. In the quarter ended May 30, 1975 - the last time A.T.& T. reported a decline in earnings - net income declined 5.5 percent, to $789 million, from $835 million in the period a year earlier.

headline: ON THE FRONTIER
abstract: To the Business Editor: Karen Arenson has lost a good point.  The stagnancy that existed in 1932 was by no means lifted by F.D.R.'s New Deal, nor by Keynesian moves.

headline: The U.N. Today; Dec. 13, 1982; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
abstract: Meets at 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.   Economic and Financial Commit- tee - 6 P.M.   Administrative and Budgetary Committee - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

headline: GIANT FOOD INC reports earnings for 12 weeks to Nov 6
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: THEY FOUGHT IN SPAIN: NOW THE CAUSE IS REDEEMED
abstract: Once they were fighters, men who tried to stop fascism in Spain with guns and grenades. Today, more than 40 years later, Americans who volunteered in the Loyalist cause in the Spanish Civil War are watching proudly as a Socialist government is coming to power in that country.   ''I feel a wonderful feeling for the Spanish people,'' said Arthur H. Landis, who was wounded in a battle at Teruel in the winter of 1937. ''The black days are over. Barring World War III, fascism is not coming back.''

headline: Begin's Wife Is Hospitalized
abstract: Prime Minister Menachem Begin's wife, Aliza, was taken to a hospital Monday because of respiratory pains and blood circulation difficulties, hospital officials said tonight.  Her condition was descibed as ''serious but stable.''

headline: Pakistani Visits North Korea
abstract: President Mohammad Zia ul-Haq of Pakistan arrived in Pyongyang, North Korea, today for a state visit, North Korea's official press agency reported.

headline: AT SOUTH AFRICA'S 'IN' RESORT, THE UNSEEN SHANTIES
abstract: ''That's Johannesburg by the Sea,'' a Cape Town intellectual snorted. ''I wouldn't go near the place at this time of year.''   He was talking about Plett, the diminutive by which this boom town of a resort is known in the most affluent suburbs of Johannesburg, 700 miles to the north. At the balmiest time of the year there, wellto-do whites lock up their houses and turn their backs on their swimming pools in order to travel in convoys of Mercedes and BMW sedans to Plett.

headline: DEALERS CRITICIZE BOND RULE
abstract: A requirement that new municipal bonds must be issued only in registered form after Jan. 1 drew criticism from securities dealers attending the annual convention of the Public Securities Association here this week. They said that the market for state and local government bonds might be disrupted and that more time was needed to prepare for the change.   The little-noticed section of the tax bill passed by Congress last month was intended to help the Internal Revenue Service spot individuals who purchase tax-exempt bonds with unreported income.  When bonds are registered, a record of ownership is maintained by the issuer. With bearer bonds, allowed under the current system, there is no record of ownership. Securities dealers, however, are already required to keep records of purchases and sales.

headline: What's New in Consumer Research; THE EYES HAVE IT
abstract: Eye-tracking research, which shows marketers what consumers read or don't read when they view a print ad, has labored under a cloud of suspicion since it was first introduced on Madison Avenue some two decades ago.   Those doubts are gradually lifting, however, as eye-tracking studies become more sophisticated, thanks to new computerized technology that gauges eye movement. When talking to research directors on Madison Avenue it is not uncommon to see a raised eyebrow when eye-tracking is mentioned, but a growing number of marketers are coming to believe that eye tracking, used with other research tools, such as recall tests, can prove useful.

headline: TERRORISTS KILL A TOP GENERAL IN MADRID
abstract: Two men on a motorcycle drew up beside a car carrying a top Spanish general this morning and killed him with a hail of submachine gun fire.   The victim was Gen. Victor Lago Roman, 63-year-old commander of the elite Brunete First Armored Division, whose tank regiments are stationed around Madrid. The police said they believed that the killers, who escaped, were Basque separatist extremists.

headline: Holder of Most Stock Will Head Autotote
abstract: James H. Pierce has been named chief executive of Autotote Ltd., a manufacturer of computerized wagering systems.  Mr. Pierce, 52, will succeed Martin I. Zwerin, 57, who is taking early retirement but will remain at the company through early 1983 to aid in the transition. Mr. Pierce, who is acquiring a large block of Autotote stock and will be its largest individual shareholder, is also scheduled to become chairman of the company.   For the past nine years, Mr. Pierce has been president of the Amtote division of the General Instrument Corporation, which is a larger competitor of Autotote.

headline: BETHLEHEM STEEL LOSES $208.9 MILLION IN QUARTER
abstract: The Bethlehem Steel Corporation, the nation's second-largest producer, reported a loss of $208.9 million for the third quarter, the second-highest quarterly loss in its history.   The company attributed the poor results to a continued decline in steel demand and to a pretax charge against earnings of $97 million, primarily from the previously announced shutdown of its Los Angeles plant. The company suffered its worst period in the third quarter of 1977, when it lost $477 million, also from a large writeoff for plant closings.

headline: Knight-Ridder Profit
abstract: Knight-Ridder Newspapers Inc. today announced earnings of $23.8 million, or 73 cents a share, in the third quarter of 1982 - little changed from the $23.9 million, or 73 cents a share, a year earlier, despite a rise in operating revenues of 5 percent. Full-run advertising linage declined 9.1 percent. Daily circulation rose 5.6 percent and Sunday circulation was up 5.7 percent, largely as a result of circulation gains from the concern's newspapers in Philadelphia, Knight-Ridder said.

headline: TIGER INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: 3D-QUARTER PROFITS FELL 15% TO 20%
abstract: Corporate profits in the third quarter slumped 15 percent to 20 percent from the third quarter of 1981, economists estimate.  Companies did benefit from spending cuts taken earlier in the year and from declining interest rates. But weaker demand and unexpected factors, such as the sharp drop in value of the Mexican peso, generally wiped out the gains.   Earnings in the third period were up from the weak level of the second quarter, however.  Two major sectors have not yet reported results: the auto makers are expected to show a sharply mixed performance, and earnings of oil companies are likely to fall.

headline: CELANESE CANADA LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: PLAINS RESOURCES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: ISRAELI OFFICER CHALLENGED ON TESTIMONY
abstract: Attorneys for senior Israeli officials began cross-examining middle-ranking army officers in public hearings today, in an effort to throw their credibility into question before the state commission investigating the deaths of Palestinian civilians in Beirut.   The key witness of the day was the man who served as duty officer in the army's situation room soon after Lebanese Christian militiamen entered two refugee camps in Beirut. The officer, Lieut. Col. Reuven Gai, testified Nov. 11 that he had conveyed a report that 300 Palestinians were dead to Avi Dudai, a civilian aide to Defense Minister Ariel Sharon, about 11 A.M. Friday, Sept. 17, some 10 hours before Mr. Sharon reported having heard that civilians were being murdered.   Two other army officers confirmed Colonel Gai's testimony, and the commission warned Mr. Dudai - who had denied receiving any such report - that he could be found to have failed to fulfill his duties by virtue of having neglected to convey the report to the Defense Minister.

headline: FRIENDLY FROST INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: BROKERS AGLOW AT MEETING
abstract: Good cheer and conviviality mark the annual convention here of the nation's brokers and securities analysts, who are basking in the bright south Florida sun and the glow of prosperity from the richest quarter in their history.   ''If you don't make it in the brokerage business now, you'll never make it,'' suggested Donald E. Weston, chairman of Gradison & Company, a Cincinnati-based firm. ''You've got to be deaf, dumb and blind not to be able to do business now.''   ''The psychological momentum is out there - those who do have money are beginning to turn it loose, and those who don't have it, don't have to worry about it anyhow,'' said Joseph Ancona, a senior vice president of Daniel & Bell Inc., a small New York brokerage firm, as he stood in a crowded, sumptuous oceanside reception.

headline: RAVEN INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Manville Insurers Are Subject of Suit
abstract: Two companies with asbestos-related claims against the Manville Corporation, which is in bankruptcy proceedings, said they had asked the Bankruptcy Court in New York to permit the claims to be brought against Manville's insurance carriers.

headline: MOORE MCCORMACK RESOURCES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Market Place; Propane Stake Of Belzbergs
abstract: WHEN Samuel Belzberg, the Canadian businessman, joined his brothers, William and Hyman, three years ago to buy a 5 percent slice of Bache Halsey Stuart Shields, Wall Street seemed perplexed.   Bache had once been the No.2 stockbroker in the country, after Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner & Smith. But it had been overtaken years ago by more dynamic Wall Street firms. It seemed an unusual investment for Sam Belzberg, a former used-car salesman with a reputation for knowing a good thing when he saw one.

headline: 2 Hangings in Zimbabwe Are First Since 1980
abstract: Two Zimbabwe dissidents convicted of murder have been hanged in the country's first executions since independence in 1980, a Government spokesman said today.   Prime Minister Robert Mugabe had previously taken a stand against capital punishment on moral grounds.

headline: BONN TO PURSUE TIES WITH EAST, NEW CHIEF SAYS
abstract: Chancellor Helmut Kohl said today that his new Government intended to pursue good relations with Communist Europe and that it wanted ''friendship and partnership, but not dependency'' in its ties with the United States.   In forceful language at his first news conference since he was elected Chancellor Friday, Mr. Kohl appeared to go out of his way to stake out a West German foreign policy of considerable continuity with that of his predecessor, Helmut Schmidt.   ''The Americans are our most important partners and allies - to put it simply,'' Mr. Kohl said, when asked whether ''new accents'' could be expected in West Germany's ties with the United States.  ''Without the umbrella and protection of the United States, we wouldn't have the Federal Republic as it is today.''

headline: AROUND THE WORLD WITH A NEW STRATEGY
abstract: A CURRICULUMIN FLUX   Several years ago, Harvard deans started hearing from more and more alumni who wanted to know what the school was doing to train managers to deal with labor and personnel issues. Their answer: Not much.   The alumni were concerned about Western companies facing competition from the Japanese, who, they said, have ''beaten us in the human resources management area and turned it into a competitive advantage,'' said Prof. D. Quinn Mills.   Harvard began requiring a course in human resources management in the spring of 1981, covering union relations as well as sex discrimination, compensation and productivity. Today Harvard is emphasizing work force relations even more and the subject is making its way into many courses because it is seen as a competitive business weapon.   But despite the addition of the course and the revamping of other parts of the curriculum, some professors grumble that Harvard's business education needs a more fundamental overhaul. They share a nagging doubt: that some research is getting too academic and Harvard may be neglecting to teach managers how to put into effect the strategies they develop.

headline: BEEHIVE INTERNATIONAL reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Maybelline-Marschalk; Dodge Choice Narrows
abstract: The Marschalk Company, one of the Interpublic Group, will be splitting with the people who make Maybelline products on Jan.1. It has been a four-year relationship.
