headline: Benazir Bhutto Detention Extended by 90 Days
abstract: Pakistan's military authorities have extended for 90 more days the detention order on Benazir Bhutto, the daughter of former Prime Minister Zulfikar Ali Bhutto, family sources said today.

headline: BRIEFS
abstract: * American United Energy Corp. said it had acquired International Nuclear Safety Systems Inc. in an exchange of stock valued at about $8 million.

headline: HEINZ, H J, CO reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 27
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Nigerian Toll Put at 452 In Religious Riots
abstract: A newspaper here reported today that the death toll in religious rioting in northeast Nigeria had risen to 452.

headline: MEREDITH CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: VW America Prices Up
abstract: Volkswagen of America Inc., a subsidiary of Volkswagenwerk A.G., said today that suggested retail price increases on its 1983 cars will average about 3 percent above the comparable 1982 model.

headline: KLEER-VU INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: REAGAN VISITS THE SOVIET EMBASSY
abstract: President Reagan visited the Soviet Embassy here today to express his condolences on the death of Leonid I. Brezhnev. He also used the occasion to express the desire that the United States and the Soviet Union ''live in peace.''

headline: RELIGIOUS RIOTS IN INDIA APPEAR TO WANE
abstract: After a month of sporadic fighting among Moslems, Hindus and the police that has left 29 people dead, the latest and largest eruption of violence in the northern Indian city of Meerut appears to have been contained.   Although officials could not say that the violence had been stamped out, they said the situation was rapidly stabilizing.  Religious strife has threatened India's stability from time to time since the day it achieved independence. The latest episode of rioting began a month ago Wednesday. After sporadic knifings, shootings, bombings and burnings, the violence reached a crescendo in the last five days, during which 16 people were killed.

headline: ARGENTINA AGREES ON SPENDING CUTS TO GET I.M.F. LOAN
abstract: The Argentine Government has agreed to make spending cuts that may prove politically unpopular as a condition for obtaining $2 billion in loans from the International Monetary Fund, Argentine officials announced today.   The loans from the international lending agency represent an emergency first step intended to help Argentina avoid default on its foreign debt of nearly $40 billion, the world's third-largest.  Argentina's installment payments on the debt are about $1.7 billion in arrears, according to banking sources.   But the ''belt-tightening'' aspects of the agreement are expected to meet with opposition from labor and political leaders who fear that they might increase unemployment and limit wage increases. The nation's economic problems have sparked demonstrations in recent months against the military administration.

headline: FINANCE BRIEFS
abstract: * Delta Air Lines plans to offer $88 million of tax-exempt bonds maturing in 1992, 1997, 2002 and 2012 to finance Atlanta airport facilities.   * Federal Express Corporation has filed an offering of one million shares with the Securities and Exchange Commission.

headline: OHIO FERRO-ALLOYS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Court Overturns Curb on Icahn
abstract: A panel of the United States Court of Appeals for the Fourth Circuit voted 2 to 1 in Alexandria, Va., to overturn a preliminary injunction that prevented Carl C. Icahn and companies he controls from voting his stock in the Dan River Company. Mr. Icahn, who is offering to acquire the textile company, owns about 15 percent of its stock.   Lawyers for Mr. Icahn had contended that the injunction was a misapplication of Federal law, while lawyers for Dan River argued for its continuance, saying that the takeover bid has been marked by deception and explicit threats to stockholders.   Mr. Icahn is offering to buy 2 million more shares of Dan River for $16.50 each on the condition that Dan River stop its suit against the offer.

headline: PROSPECTS
abstract: Frustrations at the Fed   These are disappointing, worrisome days for the Federal Reserve Board, whose Open Market Committee is scheduled to meet in Washington this week. In spite of some midsummer monetary stimulus, the economy remains terribly weak. And, while conditions seem to warrant more assistance, analysts say the bank is likely to sit on its hands for the next few weeks at least.   Large increases in the basic money supply have pushed monetary growth roughly 2 percentage points above the upper end of the Fed's target range for the year, says William Griggs, economist at Schroder Bank. With another bulge likely in October, the Fed, which remains wedded to its tight money policies, is unlikely to ease further until after the November elections.

headline: Sun Co. Outlay
abstract: The Sun Company's capital spending will drop to about $1.4 billion in 1982 from $1.5 billion in 1981 and will probably fall several hundred million dollars further in 1983, the company president, Robert McClements, told analysts. The company had previously announced plans for capital spending to average $1.7 billion a year for the 1982-84 period.

headline: TRACOR INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: WEDNESDAY, NOVEMBER 17, 1982; The Economy
abstract: Treasury Secretary Donald T. Regan may recommend that the 1983 personal income tax cut be advanced from July to January, Administration officials said. They said he feels the continuing lag in industrial activity requires Federal action to avert another year of slow growth and high unemployment. (Page A1.)   Industrial output fell 0.8 percent in October, the biggest decline since April, the Federal Reserve reported. The decline, the 13th in 15 months, was seen as evidence that the recession has still not hit bottom. (D1.) Producer prices rose a modest 0.5 percent in October, a rate that would translate to 5.7 percent annually. (D3.)

headline: ISRAEL, IGNORING U.S., KEEPS TROOPS IN BEIRUT OUTSKIRTS
abstract: Israel, ignoring both United States and Lebanese Government policy, is keeping troops and armored vehicles in Baabda, site of Lebanon's presidential palace.   The Israeli military command said today that it was maintaining a force of ''infantry and armor, the minimum to protect ourselves.'' The command spokesman, Col. Yehuda Levy, said the Israelis were ''cooperating very closely with the Lebanese Army.''   ''We do not expect to fight the Marines,'' he added, referring to the United States Marines who are guarding Beirut International Airport.

headline: Commodities
abstract: WHENEVER commodity exchanges solicit business for a new futures or options market, which seems to be the case almost every week, the first question brokers ask is: ''If we put our clients into your new market, how quickly can we get them out?''   The question is important because new markets often take time to attract participants. Commodity traders always favor the most active markets, often moving in and out of them to snatch quick profits or to limit losses. What commodity traders fear most, aside from losing money, is being in a ''thin market'' because the gaps between prices will be much wider.

headline: Goodyear, General Get Tire Contracts
abstract: The General Tire and Rubber Company and the Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company have been awarded $28 million in contracts to supply 750,000 tires to the Nissan truck assembly plant here, Nissan officials said.   Goodyear will supply 250,000 tires under an $11 million contract, officials said. General Tire was given a $17 million contract to build 500,000 tires.

headline: FEDERAL-MOGUL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Thai Police Report Capturing 185 Pounds of Heroin in Raid
abstract: The Thai police said today that they had seized 185 pounds of heroin after a gun battle with seven traffickers on a beach southeast of Bangkok.

headline: HUDSON BAY MINING & SMELTING CO LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: MAUI LAND & PINEAPPLE CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Advertising; The Role Of Reader Research
abstract: There were two areas of conflict as the annual meeting of the Magazine Publishers Association got underway at the Cerromar Beach Hotel here today. The first, strictly a publishing industry matter, was what role reader research should play in editorial decision-making; the second was protectionism as a matter of national policy.   The big picture, which included far more than just protectionism, was handled by former Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr.; William M. Agee, well-known chairman of the Bendix Corporation and also the president of the Allied Corporation, and Thomas R. Donahue, secretary-treasurer of the A.F.L.-C.I.O.   The inside issue was in the hands of Steve H. Price, executive vice president/general manager of Newsweek, and John Mack Carter, the legendary editor of Good Housekeeping. Because they were insiders, the audience of magazine publishers, advertising executives and members of the American Society of Magazine Editors responded more readily to them than to their invited guests. After all, the problem they presented was one they could handle, unlike those presented by the men with the global view.

headline: CALCULATING THE MONEY SUPPLY
abstract: They may not be aware of it, but the millions of Americans who are holding ''All Savers'' certificates maturing in October will probably create ''money'' this month.   Likewise, those who decide to take advantage of legislation signed yesterday by President Reagan that will allow financial institutions to offer a new kind of high-yielding account are likely to destroy some ''money.''   What investors do with their money is of great concern to the Federal Reserve, whose role is to control the nation's money supply and which has a critical impact on the course of the economy. But control of the money supply implies knowing how much money exists in the system.

headline: ENERGY VENTURES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: FINANCE BRIEFS
abstract: * Armco Inc. said it intended to exchange up to 1.5 million shares of its common stock for up to $25 million principal amount of its debt securities owned by Goldman, Sachs & Co.   * Bank of America Overseas Finance N.V.'s $100 million issue of eight-year, 13.375 percent Eurobond notes are priced at par, through Credit Suisse-First Boston.   * Bowne & Co. filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission a proposed sale of 500,000 of its shares by two shareholders, through Alex. Brown & Sons.

headline: Bolivian Aides Ousted In Italian Fugitive Case
abstract: The Government has dismissed senior drug-control officials in the case of an Italian right-wing extremist who was extradited this month.   Interior Minister Mario Roncal said Friday that the National Anti-Drug Trafficking Council under the regime of Gen. Luis Garcia Meza had ''blatantly fabricated the legal grounds'' for hiring the Italian, Pierluigi Pagliai, who was wanted in the 1980 Bologna bombing in which 85 people died.

headline: ANGOLA REBELS YIELD 2 SOVIET CAPTIVES
abstract: The two Russians, bearded and bronzed after two years of captivity in the bush, were seated beneath a large canvas mural that was said to depict the struggle of Jonas Savimbi's insurgent movement against Soviet and Cuban intervention.  Next to them was a lean-to, draped with a banner that exhorted, ''Let's stop Soviet mad dreams.''   The burly insurgent leader, in starched camouflage fatigues and a green beret with three gold stars on it, stood in the shade of the lean-to while a chorus of 30 sang a kind of revolutionary torch song in ardent Portuguese, exalting his leadership. The ceremony here Sunday afternoon at the headquarters of Mr. Savimbi's Union for the Total Independence of Angola, known as Unita, seemed a cross between a political rally and prize-giving day at the end of a wilderness survival course.

headline: DILLON COMPANIES reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 2
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: TRADE CONFEREES REACH CONSENSUS DESPITE DISPUTES
abstract: A conference of 88 nations reached a consensus this morning on ways to strengthen the world trading system, although differences remain between the European Economic Community and other countries over subsidized competition in agriculture.   Deadlocks between the United States and the 10 Common Market nations and between developed and developing countries were broken after a world trade conference went into extended session this weekend under the chairmanship of Canada's Deputy Prime Minister, Allan J. MacEachen.   The conference of trade ministers had been teetering on the brink of failure since it opened Wednesday. Collapse would have intensified economic nationalism and protectionism at a time of growing unemployment and debt strains on the world's delicate financial mechanisms.

headline: 2 Soldiers Wounded in Ulster
abstract: Two soldiers were injured by a bomb while on foot patrol in the border village of Crossmaglen, one of the most dangerous areas in Ulster for British troops, the police said today. A police spokesman blamed the Irish Republican Army and said one of the soldiers was seriously hurt, the other only slightly injured.

headline: NORTHWESTERN STEEL & WIRE CO reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: KOHL DEVISES PLAN TO INSURE MARCH ELECTIONS
abstract: Chancellor Helmut Kohl officially informed President Karl Carstens today of his plan to lose a confidence motion next week to open the way for the dissolution of Parliament and general elections on March 6.   The meeting between the two Christian Democrats was the last in a series Mr. Kohl has held to circumvent the rigidities of the West German Constitution, which does not give a chancellor the power to dissolve Parliament.   Though President Carstens is known to doubt the legality of the unusual no-confidence device, he is not expected to oppose the expressed wish of the major parties for new elections.

headline: NOBEL LAUREATE'S WRITING BRINGS A WIDE VARIETY OF RESPONSES
abstract: At once fantastical and historical, lushly imaginative and politically topical, the writing of Gabriel Garcia Marquez has met with a variety of critical responses. He has been praised for his inventive use of modernist conceits and his ability to conjure up an entire continent in the imagination; at the same time he has been chided for ideological posturing and for writing short stories that tend to cramp his style and inhibit his formal powers.   I.B. Singer, who was himself a Nobel Prize laureate in 1978, yesterday commended the Nobel Prize committee's choice of Mr. Garcia Marquez, while at the same time lamenting the dearth of truly important writing in this century.

headline: POOR LANDS AT U.N. DEPLORE WORLD ECONOMY
abstract: Delegates from eight less-developed nations added to the growing chorus here about the crisis in the international economy.   Om Pradhan, the representative from Bhutan, said millions of people in the developing countries of Asia, Africa and Latin America live in almost total deprivation because of the dire state of the international economic system.   Lieut. Gen. Jean-Louis Gervil-Yambala, Foreign Minister of the Central African Republic, told the General Assembly that excessive external debt, unfavorable balance of payments and a deteriorating foreign exchange rate were the principal causes of the world economic crisis. Other speakers said inflation, high interest rates and protectionism were responsible.

headline: LA MAUR INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30

headline: THE BURDEN OF A BIG HARVEST
abstract: The fall harvest is almost over here in the grain belt. Rows of hay and stalks of corn stand in the rust-colored fields. Huge combines roll through acres of soybeans, gathering up and spewing out the last fruits of this year's bumper crop.   But the bountiful harvest, usually an occasion for thanksgiving, is increasing the grief in the nation's depressed bread basket. Grain elevators are bulging. Many large commercial storage centers here and in the region are not accepting any more crops. And a rash of bankruptcies has hit small elevators in rural areas, making them unavailable for storage.

headline: Military Analysis
abstract: Western intelligence sources say the Soviet Union, in the nearly three years it has had troops in Afghanistan, has apparently reduced the level of rebel resistance only marginally.   This summer's fighting against the insurgents in the Panjshir Valley, the informants say, underscored the extent of the Soviet problem. The valley, north of Kabul, the Afghan capital, is important because land communications to the Soviet Union run through it.

headline: Malta Curbing Imports
abstract: The Government of Malta, where 7.8 percent of the work force is unemployed, has banned the importation of 49 items and announced plans to promote local industry. The list includes products already made locally and ranges from soap and shampoo to shoes, clothing and leather goods. The Government attributes the high unemployment to the international recession, which has resulted in a drop in exports and a slump in tourism.

headline: NEW U.S. PLAN ON I.M.F. QUOTA
abstract: The United States has told four of its allies that it favors increasing the resources of the International Monetary Fund by 40 percent to aid countries that cannot make ends meet, monetary sources reported today.   The new American plan represents a substantial narrowing of positions between the United States and other countries. Earlier this year Washington had resisted any increase, while other countries were urging a minimum of 50 percent.   Reagan Administration representatives also said they now wanted a shorter timetable for getting the new resources into place at the fund, which is the principal agency for such aid.

headline: Investing; IS IT TIME TO TAKE PROFITS IN THE MARKET?
abstract: ''I N a lifetime you don't get many chances to make 35 percent on your money in just a few months. Why risk trying to make it 50 percent?'' Those were the sentiments of money manager Robert Torray, after several furious weeks in October of taking profits by selling off $500 million in stocks and moving the proceeds into Treasury bills and other short-term securities. The money is still there, according to Mr. Torray, whose firm manages a total of $1.5 billion for pension funds, waiting ''until we find stocks we think are too cheap. Right now there are not many around.''   Judging from the sawtooth pattern of the stock indexes in the last couple of weeks, a number of other money managers have also become leery of the market's ability to sustain its current prices. In fact, last Monday and Tuesday saw some of the highest levels of institutional selling this year. Hit hard by the selling were utility stocks, along with technology, aerospace and food issues - groups that had been among the best gainers of recent months. But also afflicted with heavy institutional selling were the lackluster machinery stocks, which may indicate that some institutions have lost faith in an imminent economic recovery.

abstract: The Consolidated Natural Gas Company said it would withdraw from a project to import large quantities of liquefied natural gas from Algeria.   The company said it had stopped negotiations with Sonatrach, the Algerian national gas and oil company, to restore deliveries to the Cove Point, Md., terminal, which is owned by Consolidated and Columbia Gas System. The deliveries were interrupted by Sonatrach in April 1980, as a result of a pricing dispute.

headline: Pacific Telephone
abstract: The Pacific Telephone Company, citing a slumping economy that has stalled new construction, said it will lay off 200 employees by the end of this year. The cutbacks, the first in seven years for the company, also include provisions for downgrading 900 employees to lower-paying jobs. The company, California's largest employer, has about 108,000 employees.

headline: Soviet Aircraft Keep a Watch On Maneuvers by U.S. Navy
abstract: Soviet aircraft have repeatedly buzzed a 15-ship United States naval task force on exercises in the north Pacific, the Navy command here said today.

headline: SALVADOR NAMES 7 TO RIGHTS PANEL
abstract: Alvaro Magana, the provisional President, today named the director of the national police, a Roman Catholic priest, a young peasant leader, an engineer and three lawyers to form the Government's Commission on Human Rights.   The purpose of the panel, as outlined in a multiparty pact signed in August, will be to ''accomplish the complete operation of the inalienable human rights of individuals'' and guarantee ''physical security'' for Salvadorans.   Officials and members of the new panel said today that the methods by which the commission will try to fulfill this mandate had not yet been determined.

headline: Sea-Law Talks Hear Plea by Canadian
abstract: Canada said today that it hoped difficulties preventing some countries from signing a United Nations Law of the Sea Convention could be worked out by a preparatory commission that is to begin work in March.   External Affairs Minister Allan J. MacEachen of Canada was addressing the first meeting of the final session of the Law of the Sea Conference here.

headline: U.S. Plans to End Restraint on Ford
abstract: The Justice Department tentatively agreed to terminate a 44-year-old court order limiting dealings between the Ford Motor Company and certain credit companies.

headline: ECONOMISTS, IN POLL, SEE 'MODEST' 1983 RECOVERY
abstract: The national economy will recover from the recession next year, but growth will be ''quite modest'' and unemployment will remain above 9 percent, according to a new poll of business economists.   In a more positive vein, the National Association of Business Economists said today that interest rates should decline a bit more next year, inflation should remain relatively low and both housing starts and sales of new cars should rise.   But the association, in summarizing the findings of its poll, said, ''The economy remains weak, and the outlook for 1983 is for only a moderate recovery.''

headline: BOLD BOLIVIAN IN TOP SPOT
abstract: When Hernan Siles Zuazo, the Presidentelect of Bolivia, was last President in the 1950's, he confronted a crippling miners' strike by visiting the most belligerent mine.   Gunshots and explosions went off on his approach. As he sat down with the union leaders, a miner handed him a lighted stick of dynamite. Mr. Siles Zuazo took it, refusing to put out the fuse. A miner snatched the stick and threw it away just before it exploded.

headline: WEDNESDAY, OCTOBER 20, 1982; The Economy
abstract: Housing starts rose 14.4 percent in September, to an annual rate of 1.146 million, with starts on single-family houses up 6.6 percent, to a rate of 663,000, the highest since July 1981. (Page D1.)   Personal spending rose a strong 1 percent in September, while income edged up three-tenths of 1 percent. The gain in spending was the third consecutive monthly increase. (D1.)

headline: BUSINESS PEOPLE; President of Belo Corp.  To Assume Chief's Title
abstract: The A.H. Belo Corporation, owner of The Dallas Morning News, has announced that James M. Moroney Jr., president and chief operating officer, will assume the additional title of chief executive on Dec.  31.  Mr. Moroney, 61, will succeed Joe M. Dealey, 63, who has been chief executive since 1960. Mr. Dealey will remain as chairman until he retires in 1984.

headline: SEEKS ARMS PACTS WITH SOVIET; Andropov Speech; Excerpts from speech, page A13.
abstract: Yuri V. Andropov, the new Soviet party leader, said Monday that the Soviet Union would seek detente with the United States. He also heralded a new drive to aid the domestic economy through incentives and decentralization.   Mr. Andropov told a meeting of the party's Central Committee that the Soviet Union would not make ''preliminary concessions'' as a means of improving relations with the United States. He also said nobody should expect ''a unilateral disarmament'' by Moscow of the kind that, he implied, American negotiators have demanded in nuclear weapons talks in Geneva.

headline: Household's Chief Stresses Synergism
abstract: The buzzword around the offices of Gary G. Dillon, the new president and chief executive officer of Household Manufacturing Inc., is synergism.   Household International of Chicago, one of the nation's largest multi-industry conglomerates with interests in financial services, merchandising, manufacturing and transportation, recently completed a major consolidation of its manufacturing subsidiaries, setting up Household Manufacturing in the process.   The move joined its Wallace Murray building products unit, which Household International acquired last year to bolster its sagging manufacturing division, with its King-Seely Thermos consumer products unit to create a single division with combined annual sales of $878.5 million.

headline: Amax President Will Retire Early
abstract: John Towers, president and chief operating officer of Amax Inc., a major metal producer, will be retiring early from the company at the age of 61. The company said the retirement was part of its efforts to restructure and reduce its management as a result of continuing poor conditions in the metal industry.   Mr. Towers will leave Dec. 31 but continue as a director and as chairman of the board's executive committee. Pierre Gousseland, also 61, chairman and chief executive, will assume the additional duties of president and chief operating officer.

headline: No Headline
abstract: WORLD STEEL EXECUTIVES EXPECTING POOR DECADE   TOKYO, Oct. 11 (Reuters) - Steel executives from the non-Communist world today predicted that profits this year would be virtually nonexistent and that demand was likely to remain sluggish at least until the end of the decade.   ''My guess is that steel profits will be a global rarity, if not actually extinct, for calendar 1982,'' Frederick Jaicks, chairman of the International Iron and Steel Institute, told 290 delegates from 36 countries attending the institute's annual conference.   The four-day conference, a forum for talks on technical issues concerning makers of steel, is taking place during a severe slump in world steel demand, production cutbacks, layoffs and trade disputes between American and European producers.   This year ''promises to go down in the books as the worst within working memory of most, if not all, senior steel executives assembled here,'' said Mr. Jaicks, who is also chairman of the Inland Steel Company of Chicago.

headline: WHITE MOTOR CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: News Analysis
abstract: In private, many Arab diplomats here acknowledge that they have painted themselves into a corner by demanding Israel's expulsion from the current session of the General Assembly.  These envoys say they want a face-saving escape from the decision of the Arab League members here at a closed-door meeting last week, although only Mahmoud Aboul-Nasr of Oman will say this in public.   On Tuesday, the members of the larger Islamic Conference Organization, particularly Pakistan, offered what appeared to be a plausible way out: instead of challenging Israel on the Assembly floor, the Arabs would sign a letter expressing reservations over Israel's credentials in view of its ''flagrant violations'' of international law and United Nations resolutions. But such meetings operate under what they call a rule of consensus, meaning unanimity.  Libya said no, and that blocked that exit.

headline: FINANCE BRIEFS
abstract: * Bank of New England Corp.'s 540,000 depository preferred shares were priced at $50 each, through Goldman, Sachs & Co.   * Borg-Warner Corp.'s $100 million of adjustable rate convertible notes due in 2002 were priced at $1,000 per note, convertible to common stock at $38 a share, through Goldman, Sachs.

headline: BRIEFS
abstract: * AAR Corp. said its American Aviation Resources subsidiary had obtained from a North American airline that it did not identify the U.S. marketing rights for four Boeing 767 aircraft, valued at $180 million.   * Arrow Airways announced that it would offer a $99 one-way flight from New York to Miami during the midweek, beginning Nov. 11.   * Atlantic Richfield Co.'s president, W.F. Kieschnick, told reporters after an analysts' meeting in New York that retail gasoline sales at the company's Arco stations are up 50 percent from last year, to 106,000 gallons a month for the average station.

headline: LEBANON AND ISRAEL MODIFY HEATLH-CARE RELATIONS
abstract: Palestinian refugees in Israeli-occupied southern Lebanon in need of critical medical care will be allowed to go to Israel to get it, but Lebanese patients in the south will have to go to Beirut for specialized medical attention.   Israeli officials made this decision Tuesday after Lebanese health officials had informed their Israeli counterparts that cooperation with Israel regarding medical needs in the south was being discontinued.   According to the Israeli Government press office here, the original Lebanese decision was objected to by Israel on the ground that it would endanger patients and force the closing of a kidney dialysis clinic set up by the Israelis in the Palestine refugee camp of Ein Hilweh, near Sidon.

headline: People
abstract: * Walter E. Reichel elected executive vice president of Ted Bates/New York.

headline: SEEKS ARMS PACTS WITH SOVIET
abstract: President Reagan urged Congress tonight to give sympathetic consideration to his proposed MX missile basing plan, but it is certain to meet substantial Congressional opposition.    In his televised address to the nation, Mr. Reagan asserted that the MX, which he renamed Peacekeeper, ''is the right missile at the right time'' and asked Congress to examine the facts before drawing a conclusion about his proposal.   The immediate reaction from Congress, which must provide the money for the missile bases, ranged from conservative skepticism to liberal opposition, with Administration officials say- Transcript of the address is on page A14. ing that prospects for the President's plan, which would cost $26 billion for the initial deployment but could cost more than $40 billion with potential additions over the next 10 years, were too close to call.   The reaction from Gov. Ed Herschler of Wyoming to the proposal to base the missiles in his state was enthusiastic (Page A15.) Secretary of Defense Caspar W. Weinberger asserted that the proposed deployment of 100 MX missiles, in an oblong cluster of silos called dense pack, would not violate the second strategic arms limitations treaty, which the Administration has said it would observe even if the Senate did not ratify it.

headline: Banks' Loans Scrutinized
abstract: The nine largest United States banks have nearly nine times their combined capital in outstanding loans to foreign countries, a House Banking Committee study said today.   The report was released as the panel's chairman, Fernand J. St Germain, Democrat of Rhode Island, announced that Treasury Secretary Donald T. Regan would testify Tuesday on the international activities of American banks.

headline: Con Ed Refund Begins in '83
abstract: The Consolidated Edison Company said yesterday that it would refund $20 million to its natural gas customers beginning Jan. 1 through credits in January, February and March.   The refund results from credits for its use of natural gas as a fuel to produce electricity and steam.

headline: Dec. 1-10 Auto Sales Up 14 1/2%; Discounts Tied To Big 3 Gains
abstract: The nation's Big Three automobile manufacturers reported today that new car sales from Dec. 1 to 10 were up 14 1/2 percent over the same period last year, marking the seventh consecutive 10-day reporting period of improved sales.   Analysts were reluctant, however, to declare the long auto sales slump ending. ''It's encouraging, but we shouldn't get carried away with enthusiasm,'' said Philip Fricke of Goldman, Sachs & Company.  ''The comparison is off a relatively poor performance last year so the percentage gain is not indicative of a market that is roaring ahead.''

headline: U.S. WELCOMES MOSCOW INTEREST IN EASING STRESS
abstract: The Reagan Administration said today that it welcomed Yuri V. Andropov's interest in a relaxation of tensions and was ready ''to respond positively to any positive Soviet action.''   At the same time, however, the Administration said that the speech Monday by the new Soviet Communist Party leader ''contained no substantive change in familiar Soviet positions.'' It also said that Mr. Andropov, in casting doubt on American sincerity at the arms control negotiations in Geneva, had misrepresented Washington's position.   The American statement was issued by the State Department in advance of a luncheon meeting between Secretary of State George P.  Shultz and Ambassador Anatoly F. Dobrynin, the first extended session held by the two sides since the death of Leonid I. Brezhnev two weeks ago. Mr. Shultz and Vice President Bush had a 30-minute meeting with Mr. Andropov in Moscow last week.

headline: KUHN IS VOTED OUT AS BASEBALL COMMISSIONER
abstract: Bowie Kuhn was deposed as commissioner of baseball today when five teams in the National League voted not to renew his contract after 14 years in office.   Mr. Kuhn, a 56-year-old lawyer and the sport's fifth commissioner, said he would serve out his term, which expires next August. The search for his successor will be directed by the executive council of the two major leagues, made up of eight club owners. But the procedure threatened to be mired in organized baseball's complex rules. Several of the commissioner's supporters even suggested today that he might in some way succeed himself in office. (Page A17.)   Under baseball's rules, a commissioner must be hired or re-elected by nine of the 12 clubs in the National League and 10 of the 14 in the American League. When Mr. Kuhn came up for his third seven-year term today, he won by 11 to 3 in the American League but lost by 7 to 5 in the National.

headline: SWEDES NOW SAY SUBMARINE MAY HAVE ESCAPED TO BALTIC
abstract: Sweden's military conceded tonight for the first time that a foreign submarine that penetrated its coastal waters nine days ago may have escaped into the Baltic Sea.   A statement issued by Lennart Ljung, commander of the armed forces, said the belief that the phantom submarine was still bottled up in a coastal bay near the country's Musko naval base was ''diminishing with each passing day.''   He even suggested that the submarine might have made good its escape as early as Oct. 1, the day its periscope was first spotted.  The admission seemed to wipe out previous statements by navy spokesmen that there were positive ''indications'' that the submarine was still cornered in a coastal bay about 35 miles south of here. In fact, the military said today, there have been no signs indicating the presence of a submarine for some time.

headline: More G.E. Layoffs
abstract: The General Electric Company said it would lay off 5,200 of its remaining 10,000 employees at its Appliance Park plant here from the end of November. The company said appliance sales are 15 percent below last year's levels. A G.E.  spokesman said employees affected by the move were expected to be back at work on Jan. 3.

headline: FOR INTEL, A VOTE OF CONFIDENCE
abstract: Throughout the electronics revolution of the 1970's, the Intel Corporation repeatedly proved itself more far-sighted and technologically astute than competing manufacturers of semiconductors and microprocessors.   But for Intel, like other makers of the tiny circuits that provide the ''brains'' for computers, telephone switching equipment and an expanding array of advanced electronic products, the 1980's have brought problems. The recession has reduced sales. Lower capital spending has dulled the entrepreneurial zeal. And Japanese companies have broadened their assault on the American producers' markets.

headline: PORTUGUESE PRIME MINISTER SAYS HE WILL QUIT
abstract: Portugal's Prime Minister, Francisco Pinto Balsemao, announced his resignation today but said there would be no early general elections.   He said in a statement to the press that he had decided to devote himself entirely to his Social Democratic Party, which emerged as the biggest loser in local elections last weekend.

headline: No Headline
abstract: AROUND THE WORLD; Soviet Aide Warns U.S.  On New Missiles   MOSCOW, Nov. 5 (Reuters) - A senior member of the Soviet Politburo warned today that Moscow would counter any attempt by the United States to gain military superiority.   ''Our country does not accept anyone's right to military superiority,'' Viktor V. Grishin, head of the party organization in Moscow, said at a Kremlin rally.

headline: PEOPLE EXPRESS: A SURVIVOR
abstract: A year and a half after its maiden flight, People Express Airlines is still aloft and even turning a profit in what has proved to be a dream-shattering atmosphere for some of its competitors.   At the outset of this era of deregulation, it looked easy. The general formula was lower-cost labor coupled with used aircraft to produce lower fares. But some upstarts failed to get financing, some went broke and others are struggling with deficits. The recession, the air controllers' strike and competition from the established lines combined to make the task formidable.

headline: No Headline
abstract: West German stock prices soared today to their highest levels of the year after a larger-than-expected cut in interest rates yesterday by the Bundesbank, the nation's central bank.   The Commerzbank index of 60 leading shares rose to 744.4, 16 points up from Thursday's closing level. After Thursday's close, the Bundesbank cut a full percentage point off its key discount and Lombard interest rates, at which it lends to commercial banks.

headline: GUATEMALANS TELL OF MURDER OF 300
abstract: Guatemalan soldiers participating in an offensive against rebel forces entered the tiny Guatemalan Indian village of San Francisco on July 17 and killed over 300 men, women and children, according to survivors who have taken refuge in Mexico.    One survivor, 57-year-old Mateo Ramos Paiz, said he witnessed much of the killing and was saved when he was trapped under the corpses of some 10 men who had been killed by grenades.   ''I apologized to the dead, took my boots off and fled after dark,'' he recalled in an emotional account.  Another villager said he escaped death when he and seven other peasants were ordered to bring two cows from nearby fields to be slaughtered to feed the soldiers.

headline: I.R.A. PARTY POSTS MORE ULSTER GAINS
abstract: More gains were announced today for the political arm of the outlawed Provisional Irish Republican Army in Wednesday's elections in Northern Ireland, causing widespread private expressions of dismay among officials in London.   Tabulation of the votes, while not yet complete, showed that the I.R.A.'s political organization, Sinn Fein, had picked up two more seats, for a total of five, in the 78-member assembly. This showing was widely regarded as an important psychological victory for the party, which entered 12 candidates, all in urban areas where Roman Catholics are concentrated, and campaigned on a slogan of ''A ballot in one hand and a gun in the other.''

headline: BUSINESS FORUM; Reader Comment; BROKERS-BANKERS
abstract: WITH reference to last week's articles by Senator Jake Garn and R epresentative Charles Schumer, the regulatory problems that confronto ur financial markets and institutions transcend the Glass-Steagall A ct.  Glass-Steagall and other laws that govern our financial institutions and markets are mostly products of the Depression. But some that have served the nation well are no longer responsive to major problems and opportunities of the 1980's.

headline: Du Pont's Net Off 29% in 3d Quarter
abstract: E.I. du Pont de Nemours & Company reported yesterday that its net income in the third quarter declined 29 percent, to $195 million, or 82 cents a share. It added that the quarter would have produced a loss without the earnings of its Conoco Inc. subsidiary.   While Du Pont did not break out details of Conoco's oil and gas operations, it said those operations contributed $1.10 a share to earnings in the quarter.

headline: LAW OF THE SEA PROVISIONS
abstract: Following are the main provisions of the Law of the Sea Treaty, which was signed yesterday in Montego Bay, Jamaica:   Territorial Waters - Each nation's sovereign territory extends 12 miles beyond its coast. In this zone, however, all foreign vessels must be allowed the right of innocent passage, that is, passage that does not threaten the nation's security.   Free Passage - Beyond 12 miles, all ships and planes, military and commercial, can move freely. Submarines can travel under water.  Exclusive Economic Zone -Every coastal nation has exclusive rights to the fish and other marine life in the waters extending 200 miles beyond its shores. When nations are separated by a body of water less than 400 miles, they must establish dividing lines for the zones.

Fildes, 44, who previously was president of the United States subsidiaries of Biogen N.V., an international biotechnology company.

headline: Chile Said to Arrest Over 200 In Anti-Government Protests
abstract: The police have arrested over 200 people for staging an anti-Government protest in three Chilean cities, Roman Catholic church sources said today.

headline: BONN CHEMICAL INDUSTRY LAGS
abstract: West Germany's giant chemical companies are finally showing the strains of the world recession, newly reported thirdquarter earnings show.   By aggressively generating foreign sales, now about 60 percent of their total, the companies had been able to shield themselves from the slump affecting their German clients - the construction, automobile and textile industries. But this year, diminished orders from debt-stifled developing countries and from customers in European countries whose currencies have weakened against the West German mark are putting strong pressure on sales and profits.   BASF A.G. reported today that its pretax profits in the third quarter totaled 122 million marks, or $48.8 million, 54.9 percent less than in the same period in 1981. Hoechst A.G. reported Thursday that its third-quarter earnings amounted to 151 million marks, or $60.4 million, 33 percent less than last year. Wednesday Bayer A.G.  posted third-quarter earnings of 34 million marks, or $17.2 million, a 45 percent drop from the third quarter of 1981.

headline: CONGRESS SEEMS STALLED ON BANKRUPTCY COURTS
abstract: Congress appeared stalemated today in its efforts to meet a Supreme Court deadline of Dec. 24 to reorganize the nation's bankruptcy courts.   The Justice Department and many legal experts have warned that unless Congress acts before its scheduled adjournment next week, the bankruptcy system will be paralyzed by legal uncertainty, greatly disrupting the affairs of debtors and creditors alike.   There had been widespread reports among Senate staff aides that a bankruptcy bill would be brought to the floor last Wednesday and then again today. But the threat of a filibuster by Senator Howard M.  Metzenbaum, Democrat of Ohio, apparently deterred the Republican leadership from bringing up the bill. Senator Metzenbaum opposes efforts by the consumer credit lobby to cut down on what it sees as abuses by bankrupt debtors.

headline: Paine Webber Posts Records
abstract: Paine Webber Inc. said yesterday that it earned $20 million, or $1.44 a share, in the fiscal fourth quarter, ended Sept. 30.

headline: AUSTRALIAN COURT DRAMA ENDS
abstract: One of Australia's most sensational murder trials ended this week in the northern city of Darwin when a jury refused to believe a story told by a clergyman's wife that a wild dog had carried off her 9-month-old daughter two years ago.   After a seven-week trial that Australians all over the country followed by television, a jury of nine men and three women unanimously found 34-year-old Lindy Chamberlain guilty on Friday of murder. Mrs. Chamberlain, who is soon due to give birth to her fourth child, was sentenced to life imprisonment.

headline: 'RENTING UP' IN TODAY'S SOFTER MARKET
abstract: Before the Rockrose Development Corporation could start reconstructing the various industrial buildings of the Manhattan Refrigeration Company in the West Village as residential apartments, it had to let them thaw out.   The buildings were like a gigantic freezer, caked with ice, said Peter Thomson, partner in the architectural firm of Rothzeid Kaiserman & Thomson, which designed the conversion. They had to thaw gradually, over two months, before reconstruction could safely begin, he said.   That was about two years ago. Now only 44 apartments of the 234 remain to be rented, and Rockrose has established the northern fringe of the far West Village as a location that can command luxury rents.

headline: Credit Markets; U.S. BILL RATES HOLD STEADY
abstract: Rates on the new three- and six-month Treasury bills were virtually unchanged yesterday from Tuesday's auction results, while prices of longer-term Treasury issues rose.   Given the continuing softness of basic interest rates, dealers said the earlier profit taking represented a move by traders to convert more of their recent paper profits into cash. In many cases, the dealers noted, the resulting cash has flowed into the booming stock market. The fresh buying later reflected a sharp advance in the Chicago financial futures markets.

headline: Militiaman and Prison Guard Are Killed in Attack in Ulster
abstract: A part-time corporal in the Ulster Defense Regiment and a prison guard were killed today in an attack near here.

headline: LEBANESE SHIFTING VIEW OF MASSACRE
abstract: Reluctantly, painfully and with a sense of guilt, more and more Lebanese, both Moslems and Christians, are beginning to admit that Lebanese Phalangist militiamen were probably the killers in the massacre at the Palestinian refugee camps in West Beirut in September.   The official explanation of the Government, given by President Amin Gemayel, is still that the Phalangists had no role in the killings, that Israeli troops occupying the area around the Sabra and Shatila camps were solely responsible for the deaths. No Outcry for Full Inquiry   But the passage of time has opened some minds among the Lebanese.  Stories about the Phalangist involvement are beginning to spread quietly in living rooms. Local newspapers have been printing accounts of the Israeli inquiry into the massacre, and these accounts repeatedly report the Phalangist role.

headline: Touche Ross Unit
abstract: Touche Ross & Company said its German Treuverkehr A.G. subsidiary would merge with two concerns, Dr. Ratsch of Dusseldorf and Mulheim's Westdeutsche Industrie-Treuhand, on Jan 1. It said the merged companies would have a fee volume of more than $25 million.

headline: WOOLWORTH FINDS BUYER FOR ITS BRITISH HOLDINGS
abstract: The F.W. Woolworth Company said yesterday that it had agreed to sell, for $279 million, the 52.6 percent interest it holds in Britain's Woolworth chain. The sale, part of a plan to divest itself of unprofitable properties, would result in a loss of about $80 million in the current fiscal year ending Jan. 31, the company said.   Under the agreement, Paternoster Stores, a newly formed investment group, would make an offer valued at $1.40 a share, or about $527 million, for all of the British unit's outstanding shares. Because the American parent has already agreed to tender its shares, the offer would be directed at the 47.4 percent interest that is held by British investors.

headline: OPEC FAILS TO SET QUOTAS ON OUTPUT FOR EACH MEMBER
abstract: Oil ministers from the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries ended a frustrating two-day conference today unable to agree on the crucial issue of production quotas for individual members.   The group did agree to raise its official production ceiling to a total of 18.5 million barrels a day, from the largely ignored 17.5 million limit set last March. The adjustment was an attempt to bring the official level more closely in line with actual production, currently estimated at 19.5 million barrels.   They also reaffirmed their commitment to the $34-a-barrel base price - a level set in October 1981 but undercut both on the spot market and by members offering discounts, as an oversupply of oil developed. But without allocating production among the countries, analysts believe it is virtually impossible for OPEC to enforce the overall production limit intended to defend that official price.

An Iraqi high command communique said the raids ''knocked out Iranian air defense command and control centers'' and ''destroyed other important military targets'' in Abadan, the Khuzistan capital, and in the towns of Dizful and Ein Khosh.

headline: TUESDAY, NOVEMBER 9, 1982; Markets
abstract: The stock market declined sharply as investors displayed disappointment on the Federal Reserve's failure to cut the discount rate. The Dow Jones industrial average fell 14.34 points, to 1,037.44. Analysts saw the decline as a temporary retreat after last week's 60-point advance. Volume dropped to 75.2 million shares. (Page D1.)   Interest rates rose slightly in quiet trading. Based on the weekly Treasury bill auction, the maximum rate for new 91-day savings certificates will rise to 7.964 percent. (D11.) The dollar rose against most currencies, while gold prices fell $11 an ounce, to $406, in New York. (D16.) Stock index futures trading is growing rapidly. (D16.)

headline: Andropov's Son Speaks At East-West Session
abstract: Igor Y. Andropov, son of the new Soviet Communist Party leader, today told a session of the East-West conference on European security that the West had ignored important issues when making up a package of human rights amendments.   Western sources at the conference, which meets in closed session, quoted Mr. Andropov as having said that a number of subjects like Lebanon and the deployment of United States MX missiles had been ''ignored by the West in formulating its amendments to the final document to be issued by the Madrid conference.''

headline: Pfizer to Purchase Lab Systems Maker
abstract: Pfizer Inc., the diversified health-care and chemicals company, said yesterday that it had agreed in principle to acquire Valleylab Inc. in a tax-free merger involving an exchange of all Valleylab stock for 1.65 million shares of Pfizer common stock.   Pfizer's stock fell $5.125 on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday, to $70, putting an indicated value on the transaction of about $115 million.

headline: Signal Plans Sale
abstract: The Signal Companies said it entered into a preliminary agreement to sell its interest in Golden West Broadcasters for $225 million cash to Gene Autry and Kohlberg, Kravis Roberts & Company, an investment firm. As part of the deal, the television unit of Golden West would be sold to a new company formed by Kohlberg Kravis. Mr. Autry, who already owns 51 percent of Golden West, would become sole owner of the radio part of the business.

headline: Auto Worker Layoffs
abstract: The number of auto workers reported on indefinite layoff rose to 247,767 this week, the highest level in six months, according to industry reports today.

headline: LABOR TAKES SEAT BUT TORIES TAKE HEART
abstract: The Labor Party won two important by-elections Thursday, but the margins of victory in traditional Labor areas were narrower than expected and indicated that the Conservative Party retains a strong lead nationwide.   The results of the two elections for Members of Parliament were closely watched because of an increasing sense that the country is headed for a national election within the next year even though Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher does not have to call a vote until May 1984.   The results confirmed that although four months have elapsed since the end of the war over the Falkland Islands, Mrs. Thatcher has retained much of her new-found popularity. The results of a Gallup Poll issued earlier this week showed the Tories with 40.5 percent support, compared with 29 percent for Labor.

headline: Peru Is Sending Army Against Andes Rebels
abstract: President Fernando Belaunde Terry today ordered the armed forces to take control of three provinces in the Andes that have been wracked by Maoist guerrilla violence.   The Government said the decision had been made after the Maoist movement, Sendero Luminoso (Shining Path), had ignored a 72-hour ultimatum to lay down its arms.

headline: AMWAY REJECTS CANADA COURT ORDER
abstract: The Amway Corporation said today that its chairman, president and two other top executives would not appear before a Canadian court to face criminal charges that they cheated the Government of $28 million in customs duties.   The four executives had been scheduled to appear in Ontario Provincial Court in Ottawa Tuesday to face the charges, which were filed on Nov. 17. Those charged include Jay VanAndel, the chairman of the direct sales company; Richard DeVos, the president; William Halliday Jr., executive vice president for sales, and C. Dale Discher, vice president for investments.   Mr. DeVos told a news conference at the company's headquarters in Ada, Mich., near Grand Rapids, that ''fundamental constitutional rights of U.S. citizens have been violated by Canadian officials in the investigation of this case, which can only be resolved by a U.S.  court.''

headline: FINANCIAL MARKETS CLIMB, WITH STOCKS AT RECORD VOLUME
abstract: The financial markets rallied dramatically yesterday, fueled by hopes that interest rates would continue to decline.Stock market volume surged to a record level of 147.1 million shares and prices rose sharply. In the credit markets, interest rates tumbled and prices of Government notes and bonds soared. The dollar plummeted, while prices of gold and silver climbed.   Most of the nation's major banks cut their prime rate, or what they charge their key corporate customers for loans, by half a percentage point, to 13 percent, the lowest rate in two years.

headline: Egypt Reduces Oil Price Again
abstract: Egypt, which reduced its oil prices on Dec. 1, announced a second reduction today.  An official of the Egyptian General Petroleum Company said the price of the key Suez blend would drop 75 cents a barrel on Jan. 1, to $31.

headline: AROUND THE WORLD
abstract: President Mohammad Zia ul-Haq flew here today for a two-day visit that is to include a trip to the Johnson Space Center. Pakistani opposition groups said they planned to protest General Zia's visit.

headline: POLISH TARIFF STEP IS CALLED SYMBOLIC
abstract: In moving to deprive Poland of its ability to export manufactured goods to the United States at favorable tariffs, President Reagan has decided on another largely symbolic step to demonstrate his repugnance at the martial law crackdown, Administration officials say.   The President, the officials say, took the step without any conviction that it would be duplicated by the United States' allies in Western Europe or that it would produce an early improvement of conditions in Poland.   The officials also said that Mr. Reagan, in deciding to cut off the most-favored-nation tariff status, had seized on one of the few levers left to him, to show his anger at the banning of the Solidarity union on Friday.   In briefing reporters, the officials said the loss of the status would have only minimal effect on either Poland or the United States.  Although one official said that ''it is very clear the Soviet Union bears a major responsibility for the situation in Poland,'' he added that no further sanctions were planned against Moscow. This is because any new sanctions against the Soviet Union would almost inevitably have to include an embargo on United States grain exports.

headline: Real Estate; Planned Units Arise In Jersey
abstract: THE financier Thomas Fortune Ryan fenced off a thousand acres of woodland in the hills of this western New Jersey town many years ago and used it as his private deer-hunting preserve. He had other property as well, some of it farmland, and he called it all Panther Ledge Farms.   Farmland aplenty survives in Allamuchy township, but on Ryan's deer preserve it is housing that has claimed the landscape. A planned unit development called Panther Valley is under construction in the scenic, rocky terrain looking toward mountains to the west. Other long-term development projects with a range of housing choices for buyers are in the planning or early construction stages in New Jersey, but nothing of Panther Valley's scope is so far advanced.

abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: NO 'TEARFUL ADIOS' FOR MEXICAN LEADER
abstract: During his final weeks in office, President Jose Lopez Portillo has revisited every state in Mexico, dedicating public works worth billions of dollars, listening to speeches lauding his performance and addressing crowds of peasants and workers trucked in to bid him farewell.   To many Mexicans, the ritual is all too familiar. The power of Mexican Presidents during their six-year terms seems only matched by their pain at having to step down. And, as if bracing for the criticism that inevitably follows, they frequently leave office with praise still ringing in their ears.

headline: REAGAN CRITICIZED BY COLOMBIA CHIEF ON VISIT TO BOGOTA
abstract: President Reagan encountered sharp public criticism of his Administration's policies today from Colombia's President and jeers from crowds on the street after flying to that country from Brazil for a five-hour visit.   Later, after flying here from Bogota, Mr. Reagan met this evening with President Alvaro Magana of El Salvador and declared he was prepared to certify that El Salvador had made sufficient progress on human rights to warrant renewal of its military aid.   Mr. Reagan's statement about El Salvador was a surprise, because Administration officials had said he would not determine the country's human rights status until after he returned home from his Latin American trip. Congress has required the Administration to certify progress on human rights if military aid is to be renewed in January. Comment by Reagan   At the meeting with Mr. Magana, Mr. Reagan was asked if he would certify such progress. ''On the basis of everything we know now, yes, of course,'' he replied.

headline: Careers; Women As Senior Executives
abstract: WOMEN make up an increasing number of senior managers in large American corporations, a fact recently documented. Announcing results of a survey based on responses from 300 top women executives, Richard M. Ferry, president of Korn/Ferry International, said, ''We couldn't have conducted a survey of top woman executives five years ago.'' In 1979, when the management recruiting firm did a study of top managers, there were responses from 1,700 men and 8 women.   The new survey, exclusively of women, was conducted for Korn/ Ferry by four students of the Graduate School of Management at the University of California at Los Angeles under the aegis of the school's dean, J.Clayburn La Force Jr. Such tasks, he said, are part of the curriculum called ''management field study.''

headline: FOR LEBANON, 'A DIRTY WAR' IN MOUNTAINS
abstract: At a bend in a road of this foggy mountain village, an Israeli Army major confronted the commander of a group of local Moslem militiamen today. They had a terse discussion about the latest killings in what appears to be turning into a new, small but growing Lebanese civil war.   As the Israeli officer and the local commander of the Progressive Socialist Party militia argued about responsibility for the killing here Friday night of five Christian militiamen, an Israeli tank and two armored personnel carriers and a squad of Israeli soldiers took positions by the side of the road. The force was intended to prevent retaliation by the Christian militiamen fortifying the town of Suk al-Gharb, less than a mile away, higher up on the mountain road.

headline: RECESSION IN EASTERN EUROPE FORCES REAPPRAISALS OF POLICY
abstract: Poland's empty shop windows are only the most extreme manifestation of the hard times setting in throughout Eastern Europe and the Soviet Union as the worldwide economic slowdown catches up with the centrally planned Communist economies. In all these countries, the rates of economic expansion are slowing and are likely to continue slowing, and shortages of manufactured goods and food are becoming more acute. The Soviet Union's harvest was poor again this year, and its new five-year economic plan projects the lowest growth ever for industrial output.   Moscow's East European satellites are weighed down by an immense burden of foreign debt and can no longer hope to borrow their way out of trouble as they did in the past. Two of the coun- Second article of a series appearing periodically on current world e conomic problems. tries - Poland and Rumania - are, for all practical purposes, bankrupt. Socialism has shown itself no better able to resist current economic trends than capitalsm.   Hard times have been fueling dissatisfaction with the way Communist economies are run and creating pressure for change, even though a low-growth environment makes change painful. In the Soviet Union and in all of its satellites, economic troubles have stimulated new moves to relax the cumbersome centralized planning mechanism imposed by Stalin - moves to expand economic freedom and to assign a greater role to market forces in determining economic decisions, especially in agriculture.

headline: News Analysis
abstract: Relations between Egypt and Israel, which were expected to improve dramatically after the return of the last occupied area of Sinai to Egypt in April, are at their lowest point since the peace treaty between the two nations was signed in March 1979.   The deterioration was quickened in large measure by the Israeli invasion of Lebanon on June 6. President Hosni Mubarak of Egypt harshly criticized the Israeli action, although his remarks fell far short of the demands by Egyptian opposition parties for a break in relations between Israel and the only Arab nation to recognize it.   After Christian Phalangist militiamen killed hundreds of Palestinian civilians in September at the Shatila and Sabra refugee camps in the Israeli-occupied Beirut area, Mr. Mubarak recalled the Egyptian Ambassador, Saad Mortada, from Tel Aviv.

headline: MADISON SQUARE PARK AREA ENTERS CONDOMINIUM ERA
abstract: On a grim day in October 1966 the New York City Fire Department endured its worst catastrophe. The floor of a drugstore collapsed as firemen fought a stubborn five-alarm blaze that engulfed three buildings on Broadway near 23d Street. Twelve men died.   The charred buildings long stood empty, but eventually they were demolished. The land became part of a 28,000-square-foot site that the owner, the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company, put on the market. The plot is on the east side of Broadway from 22d Street to 23d Street.

headline: SEARS PLANS TO SELL 4 SHOPPING CENTERS
abstract: Sears, Roebuck & Company, a diversified concern with major interests in retailing and financial services, announced today that it had agreed to sell four company-owned shopping center developments to Corporate Property Investors Inc., a private New York concern. Sears did not disclose the purchase price nor the terms of the agreement.

headline: Amcon's Head Resigns; His 'Masters Disagreed'
abstract: David O. Lloyd-Jacob, has resigned as chairman and chief executive officer of the Amcon Group and as a board member of the parent company, Consolidated Gold Fields Group.   Consolidated Gold Fields is a major British mining concern with substantial gold operations in South Africa. Amcon is its American subsidiary, with interests in mining and mineral operations and equipment for the energy industry.

headline: Military Analysis
abstract: Western analysts say that the Sudan's decision to send troops to help Iraq repel Iranian attacks along its frontiers could lead to similar action by other Arab governments, particularly those Persian Gulf countries that are deeply concerned by Iran's aggressive policy.    However, American and European analysts noted that it might be some time before Sudanese troops actually arrived in the war zone. At the moment Iranian and Iraqi troops are locked in combat in the mountains east of Baghdad, Iraq's capital.   Iraq claims to have stifled a series of Iranian offensives that began Thursday night and to have begun successful counterattacks. The communiques issued by both sides, analysts said, are heavy with propaganda but light on facts.

headline: 43 Deny Charges In Cairo Conspiracy Trial
abstract: Forty-three of the 300 people being tried on charges of conspiring to overthrow the Government after the assassination of President Anwar el-Sadat denounced the charges today as ''sheer lies.''   The 43 were the first group of defendants to be asked to respond to the charges after a 10-day court recess. If convicted, the defendants face the death penalty.   Judge Abdel Ghaffar Ahmed called the names of the 43, one by one, summarized the charges and then inquired, ''Is this true?'' or ''Did this happen?''

headline: Limited Seeks Roaman's
abstract: The Limited Inc., the women's apparel chain based in Columbus, Ohio, which bought control of Lane Bryant Inc. earlier this year, said yesterday that it would buy Roaman's Inc., a privately held retailer of women's apparel, for $6.5 million in cash and notes.  Roaman's had sales last year of about $98 million.

headline: Savings Unit In Suit Accord
abstract: The Beverly Hills Savings and Loan Association said it had agreed to seat Sheldon Appel as a director and settle suits arising from Mr. Appel's attempts to be seated.   The agreement called for the association to include Mr. Appel on its management's slate of directors until 1986 and pay an undisclosed sum to Mr. Appel and two other investors.

headline: DETROIT WOOS YOUNGER BUYERS
abstract: American auto makers this fall are offering a variety of sporty, performance-oriented cars - all backed by aggressive advertising - in a bid to win back younger car buyers who have shifted to imports in large numbers.   The new cars, in many respects a return to Detroit's essence, mark a turn away from the industry's emphasis in recent years on the virtues of economy and value. But American car buyers under the age of 35 have defected to imports in disproportionate numbers, industry analysts point out, and Detroit is betting that models stressing youthful values can win them back.   There has been a belated recognition in Detroit ''that they are losing young buyers,'' said Maryann N. Keller, an industry analyst with Paine, Webber, Mitchell Hutchins. ''The son no longer automatically buys what his father drove,'' she said. ''There are no more Buick families.''

headline: Economic Nominee
abstract: The Senate Banking Committee today approved, by a vote of 7 to 4, President Reagan's nomination of a Harvard economics professor, Martin Feldstein, to be chairman of the Council of Economic Advisers.

headline: PRICE CURB ON NATURAL GAS URGED
abstract: As a result of sharply rising natural gas prices, Congress is coming under intense pressure to legislate emergency relief for consumers that could take effect in the current heating season.   Representatives of the United States Conference of Mayors and various members of the Northeast-Midwest Congressional Coalition held separate news conferences today to urge quick passage of measures to hold prices down, reflecting what appears to be increasing concern from constituents about soaring bills.   The cost of natural gas ''has created a national emergency,'' asserted Senator Arlen Specter, a Pennsylvania Republican who spoke in support of a coalition-sponsored bill introduced today. The measure, among other things, would require gas pipelines to supply the least expensive gas available even if it meant voiding existing supply contracts.

headline: Auto Layoffs Reach a Record
abstract: The number of auto workers on indefinite layoff this week rose to a record 254,914, major car makers said.

headline: SURRENDER AFTER A 16-HOUR SIEGE
abstract: Nine Turkish gunmen who said they were against the military regime in Turkey seized the Turkish Consulate here and dozens of hostages in a storm of gunfire Wednesday, but gave themselves up early today after nearly 16 hours of negotiations, the police reported. They said all of the hostages were released.   The gunmen charged into the consulate Wednesday morning. The police said five people were injured by flying glass as consular employees and visitors scrambled to escape.

headline: FOR ELITE IN GUATEMALA CITY, NERVOUSNESS AMID SPLENDOR
abstract: When Miss Universe and Miss Brazil recently paused in this city's most luminous hotel, it was a scintillating moment for Guatemalan society.   Local society leaders turned out in their finery, and young men posed, hoping for the attention of the beauty queens.  ''We need to forget a little,'' said a woman who, like many other wealthy Guatemalans, has spent much of last year safely ensconced in the United States. She paid $100 to the Rotary Club Ladies for four tickets to the show. ''It's been a long war here,'' she said, vaguely waving toward the street, ''and we don't know what will happen next.''

abstract: * Allied Maintenance Corp. has appointed Jack M. Feiring president and chief operating officer, succeeding Donald H. McCampbell, who has been named vice chairman.   * American Broadcasting Companies has appointed Bruce Maggin vice president-cost management of a newly created cost management department.   * American Fletcher National Bank, Indianapolis, has elected Gary B. Brown senior vice president and manager of the administration and support group.   * Chesebrough-Pond's Inc., Greenwich, Conn., has appointed John P.  Murray Jr., who is president of the Prince division, to corporate vice president of the parent company.

headline: FINANCE BRIEFS
abstract: * American Hospital Supply Corp. filed with the S.E.C. an issue of 1.1 million shares of its common stock to be exchanged for up to $58.7 million of American's 25-year, 7 7/8 percent debentures, through Merrill Lynch White Weld Capital Markets Group.   * Detroit Edison Co. filed with the S.E.C. an offering of 2 million shares of preferred stock, through Morgan Stanley & Co.   * General Foods Corp.'s issue of 2.3 million shares of common stock is offered through Goldman, Sachs & Co.

abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Swift Enlarging Iowa Facilities
abstract: The Swift Independent Packing Company, the freshmeats packing concern spun off from Esmark Inc. two years ago, will begin a $10.5 million expansion of its beef and pork operations in Iowa, John A. Copeland, chairman and chief executive officer, said.   Under the plan, Swift would invest $7 million in its two-year-old Des Moines beef plant.

headline: DOW JONES & CO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: LLOYD'S ELECTS MEMBERS OF NEW OVERSIGHT UNIT
abstract: The 20,000 members of Lloyd's of London, the world's largest insurance market, today elected eight British investors and four working members to a new governing council charged with overseeing sweeping regulatory reforms mandated by Parliament.   The vote was seen here as a victory for Establishment members of the exchange: All of the winners had the backing of leading brokers and managers of the investor syndicates from which members buy insurance in Lloyd's busy trading room.   They will set about modernizing Lloyd's self-regulatory systems at a time when the exchange's reputation is at a low ebb. Scandals involving reinsurance placed abroad and complaints that underwriters have violated limits on the risks to which they can expose investors have shaken the three-century-old institution.

headline: Steel Output Up 2.1%
abstract: Steel production increased by 2.1 percent in the week ending last Saturday, to 934,000 short tons, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday. The previous week's production was 915,000 short tons. For the year to date, adjusted production stood at 68.6 million tons.

headline: Earnings and Sales Up At BBDO International
abstract: BBDO International reported increased sales and earnings for the third quarter and nine months ended Sept. 30.

headline: Zimbabwe Tries a White M.P.
abstract: A white Zimbabwean member of Parliament went on trial today on charges of plotting against the Government of Prime Minister Robert Mugabe. Wally Stuttaford, who was detained last December, pleaded not guilty.

headline: Unstable Tangle
abstract: To The Business Editor: Robert A. Bennett, in ''The Puzzling Tangle of Global Finance'' (Dec.12), stated that we can avoid any crisis in the international banking system as long as the central banks are ready to print more money.   This is only partially true.

headline: Advertising; The Error Of the Mass Audience
abstract: IN recent years, says Robert H. Levenson, vice chairman and senior creative person at Doyle Dane Bernbach International, he has sensed a growing tendency among advertising people to think of their audiences ''in terms of multitudes.''   That's too bad, he said this week, because ''the essential thing in persuasion is to remember that there are individual human beings on the receiving end of your messages.''   Mr. Levenson has sent out a lot of messages in a quarter century of writing advertising copy at Doyle Dane, penning them on behalf of such folks as Volkswagen, Mobil, Sara Lee and Clairol. These days, he has responsibility for Doyle Dane's creative work on the international scene.

headline: HACKENSACK WATER CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Du Pont Forecast
abstract: Edward G. Jefferson, chairman of E.I.  du Pont de Nemours & Company, said today that the company expected earnings to be flat to slightly higher in the fourth quarter.

abstract: Previous   Year

headline: No Headline
abstract: OPEC Output Drop Is Seen   LONDON, Nov. 3 (AP) - Crude oil production by the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries is expected to average 19.5 million barrels a day in the fourth quarter of this year, according to petroleum analysts at the brokerage firm of Grieveson, Grant & Company.   The estimate compares with production of 20.3 milion barrels a day in the period a year earlier, and is based on a ''normal'' winter.

headline: SELIGMAN & ASSOCIATES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: MUIR SUIT IS REOPENING THE DIRKS-S.E.C. BATTLE
abstract: The decade-long saga of the battle of Raymond L. Dirks with the Securities and Exchange Commission begins a new chapter today.  Mr. Dirks, widely known for his role in exposing a fraud at the Equity Funding Corporation in 1973, is scheduled to go to trial on civil charges of securities fraud stemming from an underwriting by John Muir & Company of $6 million of Cayman Islands Reinsurance Corporation securities.   According to the commission, Cayman Re, as the company is known, agreed to invest $1.6 million of the money raised through the sale of the securities in highly speculative, newly issued stocks underwritten by Muir and recommended by Mr. Dirks, the general partner who made Muir one of the flashiest firms on Wall Street before its financial collapse in August 1981.   The S.E.C. charged that Mr. Dirks and others had employed ''devices, schemes or artifices to defraud'' in connection with the purchase and sale of securities of Cayman Re beginning in December 1980. Muir was ordered liquidated by a Federal District Court judge after the firm fell below the New York Stock Exchange's minimum net capital requirements.

headline: Monogram Sale To Nortek Inc.
abstract: Nortek Inc. said it had agreed to buy a 30 percent stake in Monogram Industries for $35.4 million from three Monogram officers and directors and their families. Nortek makes building products and provides textile services. It is based in Cranston, R.I. It said it would propose a combination with Monogram, of Santa Monica, Calif., which makes electrical materials and is active in real estate.

headline: SHULTZ SAYS U.S. LOOKS TO DEEDS FROM NEW LEADERSHIP IN KREMLIN
abstract: Prime Minister Nikolai A. Tikhonov said today that President Reagan's recently expressed desire for improved relations was in full accord with Soviet intentions.   ''The Soviet Union has been and is for normal and even better, friendly relations with the United States,'' Mr. Tikhonov told a group of visiting American businessmen at a Kremlin dinner. ''There were such relations in the past, and they can again become a reality.''   His words were the warmest addressed to the United States by a senior Soviet official in some time, perhaps since relations plummeted after the Soviet military intervention in Afghanistan in December 1979.

headline: SOUTH AFRICAN BARS A BLACK ROLE IN 3-HOUSE PARLIAMENTARY SYSTEM
abstract: Any suggestions that blacks might be given representation in a projected three-chamber South African Parliament have been denounced as ''purposeful lies'' by the Cabinet minister in charge of putting the new system into effect.   Speaking Monday night at a political meeting at Brits, near Pretoria, J. Chris Heunis, the Minister of Constitutional Development and Planning, said that neither blacks in the rural homelands set aside for them nor those in the white areas of South Africa would be incorporated into the new constitutional arrangements. These proposals, which became official policy of the ruling National Party a month ago, envisage replacing the present single-chamber Parliament with a three-chamber one in which whites, Indians and colored groups, as South Africa calls people of mixed ancestry, would sit separately.

headline: STALEY, A E, MANUFACTURING CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **
