abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: BRIEFS
abstract: * Anaconda-Ericsson Inc. signed contracts totaling $37 million with eight affiliates of the United Telephone System of Kansas City to supply them with cellular, or mobile, telephone systems.   * Associated Truck Lines Inc., a unit of American Natural Resources Co., announced that it had agreed to purchase 1,000 truck trailers from the Fruehauf Corp. for $11 million.

headline: REAGAN WRITES TO BEGIN URGING FASTER PULLOUT
abstract: President Reagan has sent a letter to Prime Minister Menachem Begin in an attempt to prompt faster action by Israel in withdrawing its troops from Lebanon, according to Administration officials.   The letter, which deals with the failure to bring about the withdrawal of foreign troops from Lebanon, was carried to Mr. Begin by the special envoy Philip C. Habib. A point of emphasis in the letter reportedly is that Israel bears primary responsibility for the continuing problem.

headline: AREA COSTS UNCHANGED FOR MONTH
abstract: The Consumer Price Index for the New York-northeastern New Jersey area, seasonally adjusted, was unchanged in November following a sharp jump in the previous month.   Samuel M. Ehrenhalt, Regional Commissioner of the Bureau of Labor Statistics, described the stabilization of prices last month as good news for consumers, with declines in a wide range of food products, finance charges for home and auto purchases, home furnishings, appliances, and home maintenance and repair services. Offsetting the effect of those declines, he said yesterday, were higher prices for homes, fuel oil, natural gas, medical care and tobacco.

headline: B.P. Ships Said To Interest Iran
abstract: Iran is holding talks with a shipping subsidiary of the British Petroleum Company to buy two of the company's supertankers, shipping sources said. B.P., which has said it wants to dispose of more than a third of its tanker fleet, declined comment on the report.   The sources said Iran is interested in two very large crude carriers, which have been operating under a joint venture called the Irano-British Shipping Service Company. Sources said a deal could involve a barter of oil for the ships.

headline: U.S. Officer Appointed For Credit du Nord Unit
abstract: Credit du Nord, a large French bank, is seeking to expand in the United States and has named James. R. Drumwright to do the job.  Mr. Drumwright, 53, will be the bank's chief executive for the United States, a newly created position.  Credit du Nord, with assets of $9 billion, began operations here three years ago when it sent Luc de Clapiers, 37, to be its representative in New York.

headline: MASONITE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: 300 BELIEVED KILLED IN RELIGIOUS RIOTING IN NIGERIA
abstract: Some 300 people are believed to have been killed Tuesday in religious rioting 750 miles northeast of here, the Nigerian radio reported today.   An official statement issued here said the rioting erupted in the northeastern town of Maiduguri when policemen tried to arrest 16 members of an extremist Moslem sect that proclaims Mohammadu Marwa, and not Mohammed, as the prophet of Islam. The 16 were publicly repeating their devotion to Mohammadu Marwa, who was killed nearly two years ago in religious rioting, and urging people not to mention the name of Mohammed.

headline: APPLE'S NEW COMPUTER FACES UNEXPECTED RIVAL
abstract: A battle is about to break loose in the small-computer business involving a new generation of machines far more sophisticated and easier to use than those now on the market.   Apple Computer Inc. is expected to introduce formally in January its long-awaited ''Lisa'' machine and to sell it for $7,000 to $10,000. At that price, industry analysts said, it is likely to be more attractive for business use than as a home computer. Apple is also developing a less expensive model for the home-computer market.

headline: GODFREY CO reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 27
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: HENREDON FURNITURE INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 2
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: IN COSTA RICA, A SOUR VIEW OF THE GUARDS
abstract: The extensive security precautions for President Reagan's visit here startled many Costa Ricans who had been eager for a chance to cheer and wave at the President.   The surprise stems from the fact that Costa Rica is a democracy without an army, where the police are unarmed and the President of the country walks around unescorted, vulnerable only to attacks by women who come up to kiss him. It is also unabashedly the most pro-United States country in Latin America.   But most people here were reduced to watching Mr. Reagan on television. And even then Mr. Reagan was often barely visible through his bevy of Secret Service agents.

headline: BREZHNEV BURIED IN MOSCOW POMP
abstract: Leonid I. Brezhnev was buried today in front of the Kremlin Wall after a state funeral exceeding in scale and pomp anything seen in the Soviet Union since the death of Stalin in 1953.   Before the largest gathering of foreign dignitaries ever assembled here under Communist rule, Mr. Brezhnev's coffin was borne atop a gun carriage into the heart of Red Square. After a lavish tribute from the new General Secretary of the Communist Party, Yuri V. Andropov, Politburo pallbearers carried the coffin to a spot behind the Lenin mausoleum that was symbolically the most distinguished burial place of any modern Soviet leader. Artillery Fires Salute   There, to the strains of Chopin's ''Funeral March,'' the man who held the posts of head of state and party leader, the latter for 18 years, was laid to rest. As the red-satin cover of the coffin descended into the grave, field guns erupted within the Kremlin walls and tugboats on the Moscow River sounded sirens in farewell.

headline: 7 HURT IN A BLAST AT TORONTO PLANT
abstract: Seven people were wounded, one of them critically, in a car-bomb explosion early today that damaged a Toronto factory that produces radar-evading guidance systems for the cruise missiles to be deployed in Europe.   Three company employees and a Toronto policemen remained hospitalized this evening as a result of the blast at the Litton Systems plant, which along with a sister factory in Salt Lake City makes the guidance components for the low-flying missiles. One of the workers, a Litton security guard, was reported to be in very serious condition with a fractured skull and a broken leg.

headline: RUSSELL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 3
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Pension Trust Mergers Set
abstract: The Beverly Hills Savings and Loan Association said today that it had agreed to acquire National Associates Inc., and had agreed in principle to acquire Planning Counselors Inc. and National Associates Inc. of Northern California. Terms of the three cash transactions were not disclosed.

headline: Exocet Sale Said to Spur A British-French Brawl
abstract: Four British sailors from the aircraft carrier Hermes suffered minor injuries in a brawl with French civilians that broke out after an argument over France's arms sales to Argentina, police sources said.   Other British sailors caused damage in this port city while the brawl was taking place outside a cafe Thursday night, the sources said.

headline: REDMAN INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 1
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: DOW GAINS 7.36 POINTS, TO 1,007.36
abstract: Adhering to its usual post-Thanksgiving Day pattern, the stock market rose yesterday. The Dow Jones industrial average gained 7.36 points, to 1,007.36. Its loss for the week was 13.89 points. Selected retail issues were among the better performers. Precious-metal stocks, reflecting higher prices for gold bullion, also moved in the forefront of the general advance.

headline: Daughter of President Of Honduras Is Seized
abstract: The daughter of the Honduran President, Roberto Suazo Cordova, was kidnapped here today by an unidentified guerrilla group that is demanding publication of a ''political manifesto'' in return for her life, the Government announced.   Interior Minister Ricardo Mendez Ruiz said Xiomara Suazo Estrada, 33 years old, was kidnapped in Guatemala City, where she has lived with her mother for 20 years.

headline: ATLANTIC METROPOLITAN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: AFGHAN IS ADAMANT ABOUT FIGHTING ON
abstract: Babrak Karmal, the Afghan leader, said today that there would be no compromise with the guerrillas and that Soviet troops would remain until the rebels gave up or were defeated.   At a news conference, Mr. Karmal appeared to rule out the sort of accommodation with the insurgents that is said to have received some private encouragement from the Soviet Union.   Asked whether his Government would accept a coalition with the rebels, his answer was emphatically negative.  ''Afghanistan has no tradition of compromising with gangsters,'' he said.  His wording seemed to rule out even the sort of phased withdrawal of Soviet troops, believed to number more than 100,000, that Leonid I. Brezhnev offered in a speech last year.

headline: ACTION ON CHINATOWN JAIL PUT OFF AFTER PROTEST
abstract: A plan was approved for selling apartments in city-owned buildings to their tenants for $250 each. Page B2.   Twelve thousand demonstrators poured out of Chinatown and past the courthouses of Foley Square to City Hall yesterday to protest plans to build a jail in their neighborhood.   Hours after the protestors with their dancing dragon and their drums and cymbals went home, their side won a partial victory.The Board of Estimate voted early this morning to defer until December a decision on the $101 million jail project on the outskirts of Chinatown and Little Italy.

headline: Gerber Shutdown
abstract: Gerber Products said it was closing its Rochester baby food plant because of a decline in sales caused by a revival of breast feeding.

headline: Your Money; Broker C.D.'s: The Benefits
abstract: THE unusual combination of Federal deposit insurance and no-penalty negotiability can be found in a product being offered by many brokerage firms. Commercial banks and savings and loans associations have long issued certificates of deposit, but now these instruments are available from Wall Street.   The first offering was made last June, by Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner & Smith, which has since sold almost $2 billion worth from many banks and savings and loans. Since then, other concerns, including Dean Witter Reynolds and Bache Halsey Stuart Shields, have also made bank certificates available. These firms often market certificates under their own trade names, such as Easy Cash C.D.'s or C.D. Plus.

headline: DEL-VAL FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: SATURDAY, NOVEMBER 27, 1982; International
abstract: Participants at the GATT trade conference in Geneva began intense, last-minute bargaining to forestall its collapse. Basic differences on a wide range of issues separated the major trading blocs. The Common Market delegates went into extraordinary session to discuss issuing a separate policy statement, which would mean a breakdown in a 35-year consensus on world trade rules. (Page 35.)   The Soviet Union and its East European satellites are feeling the impact of the worldwide recession. Economic growth is slowing and a huge burden of foreign debt has piled up, while shortages of manufactured goods and food are becoming acute. Throughout the region, pressure to relax central planning has begun to mount, given impetus by Yuri V. Andropov, the new Soviet leader. (1.)

headline: BANTA, GEORGE, CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Paine, Webber Sues Merrill
abstract: Paine, Webber, Jackson & Curtis Inc. filed suit in Federal District Court in Wilmington, Del., yesterday asking that Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner & Smith Inc.'s patent on the Cash Management Account be declared invalid.   Last August, Merrill Lynch received a patent for the investment tool, which allows customers to keep stocks, bonds and other securities in one umbrella account.

headline: FORD REDUCES FINANCING RATE
abstract: The Ford Motor Company said today that it had lowered to 10.75 the interest rate it will charge to finance the purchases of all 1982 Ford and Lincoln-Mercury models. The company also instituted rebates of $200 to $1,000 on selected models to help increase the sales of leftover 1982 models.   The announcement came three days after the General Motors Corporation, also seeking to reduce dealers' inventories, cut its financing rate to 10.9 percent, from 18 percent, on 1982 models.

headline: Bodyguard Is Seized In Ghanaian Plot
abstract: An attempted coup against the Ghanaian leader, Flight Lieut. Jerry J. Rawlings, may have been mounted by soldiers loyal to a member of his ruling council, The Guardian reported today from Accra.

headline: Chinese Coal Drive
abstract: China has imported $1 billion worth of technology and equipment and used $700 million in foreign funds to increase coal production, the official Xinhua News Agency reported today.

headline: Your Money; Those 'Secret' Money Funds
abstract: MONEY market funds have captured the fancy of the public, with well over $200 billion now invested in them. But another type of fund, relatively unknown and with far less in overall assets, has attracted interest from a growing number of sophisticated investors.   The new type of funds, whose portfolios consist of either Government and agency or tax-exempt securities, are known as intermediate-term or limited-maturity bond funds. Such funds generally have many of the same features as short-term money market funds - preservation of capital, no sales charges, telephone redemptions and automatic reinvestment - but they differ in the maturities of their investments.

headline: Iran Says It Shelled Iraqi Oil Installations
abstract: Iranian artillery shelled Iraqi oil installations and docks at Chahar Cheraqh across the Shatt al Arab waterway inside Iraq on Wednesday, setting part of them on fire, the Teheran radio reported today.   In a broadcast monitored in London, the radio said two Iraqi helicopters were shot down Wednesday on the southern front of the Persian Gulf war.

headline: Kuwait Quits Talks On Gulf Assets Sale
abstract: Kuwait has pulled out of negotiations with the Gulf Oil Corporation on a takeover of Gulf's oil refining and distribution network in Europe, the official Kuwait News Agency reported today. A Gulf spokesman in Pittsburgh confirmed that the negotiations had ended, but would not elaborate.

headline: BUSINESS PEOPLEf; Stockbroker Wins Bayly Proxy Fight
abstract: David T. Marantette 3d, a Detroit stockbroker, has won a proxy fight to replace directors of the Bayly Corporation, a Denver maker of jeans and casual wear.   Mr. Marantette said that stockholders voted at a meeting on Sept.  20 for his proposal to replace the directors with a seven-member slate of Detroit-area investors, including himself.   Bayly challenged the election results, but United States District Judge John H. Pratt on Tuesday ordered them to stand. Unofficial returns showed the Marantette slate won by a margin of nearly 2 to 1. The judge directed Bayly management to complete the election process and to permit the Marantette slate to assume positions as directors.

headline: U.S. POLICY DISMAYS NUCLEAR INDUSTRY
abstract: Leaders of the nation's nuclear industry have begun to express disappointment with the Reagan Administration, on which they had once pinned their hopes for a reversal of the industry's precipitous decline.   The industry's two largest trade associations, the Atomic Industrial Forum and the American Nuclear Society, met here last week, and unlike most conventions, the spirit there was glum.   Expressions of disenchantment with the nuclear policies of the Administration, once considered nuclear energy's greatest ally, were repeated in official speeches, news conferences and informal chats.   ''The nuclear power industry hasn't been helped all that much by the Reagan Administration,'' said Theodore Stern, executive vice president of the Westinghouse Electric Corporation, one of the largest suppliers of nuclear reactors, at a lunch with reporters last Tuesday.

headline: REPAIRING LLOYD'S OF LONDON
abstract: There is plenty of superficial evidence that the venerable Lloyd's of London insurance exchange is flourishing.  The trading floor, known simply as The Room, is crowded with brokers. The list of people wishing to invest in the Lloyd's syndicates, with which insurance brokers place their clients' risks, has grown to 1,900, almost 50 percent more than a year ago. A new Lloyd's building designed by Richard Rogers, architect of the Pompidou Center in Paris, is rising on Lime Street.   But the outward vitality of the three-century-old institution masks the extent of the damage that has recently been done to Lloyd's by the wave of scandals involving some of its best-known participants.  The scandals involve accusations of the misappropriation of tens of millions of dollars in premiums and the possibility that some insurance risks had been resold to shadowy offshore firms with insufficient capital to cover them. Underwriters' Exposure   The questionable deals could result in high claims against underwriters who have pledged everything down to their cufflinks to cover risks that their syndicates have insured.

headline: O.A.U. Chairman Tries To End Chad Impasse
abstract: President Daniel arap Moi of Kenya, the outgoing chairman of the Organization of African Unity, began informal talks today in an effort to end the impasse over Chad delaying the opening of a meeting of the O.A.U.   Heads of state or prime ministers from 15 countries were reported in Tripoli, and four more were expected Tuesday, when the meeting is scheduled to open. But 34 nations are needed for a quorum, and it was apparent that the meeting would not start on schedule.

headline: MURPHY, G C, CO reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 28
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Caterpillar Layoffs
abstract: The Caterpillar Corporation said it was laying off 350 nonunion employees at its Davenport and Bettendorf plants because of a strike by union production employees.

headline: The U.N. Today; Dec. 20, 1982; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
abstract: Meets at 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.   Administrative and Budgetary Committee - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M. TRUSTEESHIP COUNCIL   Meets at 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

headline: MAXCO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: BREZHNEV RENEWS CALL FOR DETENTE BUT WARNS WEST
abstract: Leonid I. Brezhnev used the anniversary of the Bolshevik Revolution today to renew the Soviet Union's commitment to detente with the West. But he warned that ''a crushing retaliatory strike'' awaited any potential aggressor.   In an apparent allusion to the Reagan Administration, the Soviet leader added, ''Our might and vigilance will cool, I think, the hot heads of some imperialist politicians.''   It was the second speech in 12 days in which Mr. Brezhnev adopted an unusually harsh tone when speaking of the United States.  The speech was delivered at a reception in the Kremlin that followed the annual military parade through Red Square marking the 65th anniversary of the Bolshevik Revolution in 1917. Mr. Brezhnev led other members of the ruling Politburo in the lineup atop the Lenin mausoleum, remaining for two hours in subfreezing temperatures as regiments of fighting men, columns of tanks and rockets and throngs of civilians paraded past.

headline: PROSPECTS
abstract: The Gas Problem   Scores of congressmen have begun a feverish campaign to deal with sharply rising natural gas prices, ''problem'' caused mainly by Congress itself when, in 1978, it rushed to deregulate energy prices after four decades of control.   But analysts say it's unlikely that any of the half-dozen bills introduced last week to freeze prices, or provide other remedies, will pass in the current special session. There won't be enough time - with Congress devoting much of what's left in the special session to committee assignments and other administrative housekeeping chores.   Nor would quick action, no matter how drastic, provide significant price relief for consumers this winter. Nationwide, prices are expected to rise an average of 20 percent, roughly the same as last year.

headline: SUN ELECTRIC CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: De Lorean Asset Sale Delayed
abstract: A Federal bankruptcy judge today adjourned a hearing on an offer to acquire the assets of the De Lorean Motor Company after a new, higher offer for those assets was made in court here.   Attorneys for Charles De Lorean, brother of the company's founder, John Z. De Lorean, and Don Massey, a De Lorean dealer, bid $10.5 million for the assets of the defunct sports car maker, or about $500,000 more than a previous offer by Sol A. Shenk, president of Consolidated International Inc. of Columbus, Ohio.   The new bid came after attorneys for some of De Lorean's creditors expressed fears that a hasty decision to sell would not be wise.

headline: Daimler Shop in China
abstract: Daimler Benz A.G. said today that it had opened a vehicle workshop and spare parts depot in China.

headline: ANNA FREUD, PSYCHOANALYST, DIES IN LONDON AT 86
abstract: Anna Freud, daughter of Sigmund Freud and an eminent psychoanalyst in her own right, died at her London home today at the age of 86, her family said. ---- Focused on Child Analysis   ''I started out as an elementary-school teacher. I changed from that to the field of analysis and child analysis. From then on, I moved constantly back and forth, from the theoretical study of these problems to their practical application. I agree that one has to have special luck to do this, and that most people do not have this.''   This was Anna Freud's self-effacing summary of a long and productive life. It was true, of course, so far as it went; but it obscured the fact that Miss Freud, eminent in her own right, virtually invented the systematic study of the emotional and mental life of the child and elaborated it in 50 years of observation, discussion and writing.

headline: BEMIS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: PAKISTAN PAYS POLITICAL PRICE FOR STABILITY
abstract: Nearly five and a half years after Gen. Mohammad Zia ul-Haq seized the leadership of Pakistan in a bloodless coup and established what he said would be an interim Government, his martial-law regime appears to be free of effective opposition and prepared to hold power for some time to come.   In those five and a half years, Pakistani and Western officials here say, the Zia Government has given this strategically important country a stability it has not often known during its 35-year history and has brought about an economic revival that has produced a growth rate in real gross national product of 6 percent a year. The Government also says it has gone some distance toward creating a fusion of Islamic and democratic principles that, if brought to fruition, would give the country a distinct new identity.   But as President Zia prepares to leave here on Sunday for a week's visit to the United States, his Government remains under seemingly incessant pressure from the educated classes for free national elections and an early end of martial law.

headline: U.S. MILITARY HOUSING AREA IN GERMANY IS BOMBED
abstract: A powerful bomb destroyed at least 20 cars, shattered windows and damaged buildings at a United States Army housing area in the south German town of Giessen today. It was the latest in a series of attacks that the police say are apparently part of coordinated attempts to intimidate American soldiers.   A police spokesman said the identity of the terrorists and the type of explosive used were not known. The spokesman said no one was injured in the attack, which caused damage estimated at $157,000.

headline: DEEP IN SIBERIA, 3 CENTURIES OF FAITH IN GOD
abstract: Karl Osipovich Lykov was raised to honor God, keep the ways of his ancestors and to distrust men.  His forebears had fled into the Siberian wilderness three centuries ago to elude ecclesiastical changes and the modernizations of Peter the Great. When revolution and civilization intruded in the 1920's and 1930's, Karl Osipovich moved his dwindling community of Old Believers farther into the primeval taiga until it was only he, his wife and two children who pressed on deeper and deeper into the uninhabited forest.   They stopped on a rugged hillside near the headwaters of the Abakan River, in the Sayan Mountains of southern Siberia, 200 miles from any major human settlement. There, augmented by another daughter and son, the clan scrounged a primitive existence from the brutal land and lived their rigid faith until recently discovered by the outside world.   The children had grown to adulthood in a world bordered by a day's march from their crude hut, conscious of civilization only through the tattered prayer books they learned to read and the dire teachings of the father that the world out there was rife with sin, temptation and godless men.

headline: HEAVY LOSSES CONTINUE AT STATE SAVINGS BANKS
abstract: Operating losses among New York State savings banks continued to mount in the third quarter despite the decline in interest rates that began in mid-August, Alan R. Cohen, Acting Superintendent of Banking, reported yesterday.   For the 92 state-chartered savings banks in New York, aggregate operating losses increased to $331.5 million in the third quarter, from $301.9 million in the second. But the third-quarter loss was somewhat less than that of $369.9 million posted a year earlier.   Despite the continuing large losses, the outlook for the savings banks is somewhat rosier because of the drop in interest rates and new legislation that permits the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation to inject capital into savings institutions whose surplus accounts - the amount by which their assets exceed their liabilities -are being eroded by operating losses.

headline: On the Frontier
abstract: To the Business Editor: Regarding ''On the Frontier of a New Economics'' (Oct. 31) by Karen Arenson.   * The problem is worldwide; thus thinking should, at least in part, concern the global economy and incorporate the views of non-Americans.

headline: GROWTH POSING SEVERE THREAT TO THE OLD CITY OF DAMASCUS
abstract: This ancient oasis capital with its ramparts and palaces, mosques, public baths and caravanserais, is seriously threatened by modern times.   Alarmed by a construction boom and the rapid deterioration of the traditional quarters, the Government's Department of Antiquities and Museums has embarked on a crusade at home and abroad to save Old Damascus.   Nobody knows how old Damascus really is, although Syrians generally say it is the oldest continuously inhabited city in the world. The Bible indicates that Damascus existed before Abraham's time. Some historians, referring to neolithic remains found in the area, believe the site was occupied as early as 6000 B.C., while Egyptian texts show Damascus as an important economic and political center by the middle of the second millenium B.C.

headline: PHILADELPHIA NATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Turbo Offers A Settlement
abstract: Financially troubled Turbo Resources Ltd. offered to settle its longstanding problems with the Ontario Securities Commission and the minority shareholders of Merland Explorations Ltd.   Ken Travis, Turbo president, said that the company would no longer pursue the minority shares and as a bonus it would offer Merland's minority shareholders its properties in Oklahoma and Texas valued at $28.5 million (United States).

headline: NIMSLO MAKES OFFER FOR BERKEY PHOTO
abstract: Berkey Photo Inc., one of the nation's biggest photo processors, said yesterday that it had received an unsolicited merger offer from the United States subsidiary of Nimslo International Ltd., a British maker of three-dimensional cameras.   Details of the offer were not disclosed.

headline: STOKELY-VAN CAMP CHIEF IN BID TO BUY COMPANY
abstract: William B. Stokely 3d, the 42-year-old chairman of Stokely-Van Camp Inc., has formed an investor group to acquire the company, the Indianapolis-based food processor announced yesterday.   No formal proposal has yet been made by the group, the company said. But it added that, subject to financing, Mr. Stokely's group would offer $50 a share, or $136.5 million in cash, for the company's 2.73 million shares outstanding. Mr. Stokely, a member of the company's founding family, already owns or controls 13.6 percent of the canner, one of the nation's largest.   Stokely-Van Camp had 3.2 million shares outstanding until last May, when it bought back some 13 percent, reducing the total to 2.7 million. In addition to the 13.6 percent block owned or controlled by Mr. Stokely, a 7.4 percent stake is owned by the Minas Basin Pulp and Power Company, based in Nova Scotia.

headline: HARVESTER-AUSTRALIA PUT IN RECEIVERSHIP
abstract: The debt-ridden International Harvester Company announced today that its Australian subsidiary would go into courtsupervised receivership, the equivalent of bankruptcy proceedings in this country.   Harvester said the reorganization will result in a one-time charge in the fiscal year 1982 of $87 million but that it anticipated no increase in its projected 1982 net loss of about $1.6 billion.

headline: WHEN ENMITY KILLS A LONG PARTNERSHIP
abstract: For John Doran and Edward J. Lennon Jr., breaking up is hard to do.  In fact, although the two elderly co-owners of the T.J. Ronan Paint Corporation still share an office at their small South Bronx paint manufacturing plant, they have barely been on speaking terms for the past six years.   They are engaged in an involuntary dissolution proceeding - the business version of an exceedingly messy divorce.  The saga of Ronan Paint is thus a classic example, albeit extreme, of the problems that can arise when business partners stop being friends.

headline: FED OPPOSES DREYFUS BANK PROPOSAL
abstract: The Federal Reserve Board has challenged another attempt by the Dreyfus Corporation, a major mutual fund company, to get into the banking industry.   In a letter to the Comptroller of the Currency, released today, the Fed concluded that a proposal by Dreyfus to set up its own bank exceeded the limits of the Glass-Steagall Act of 1934, which separates banking and securities underwriting activities.   According to the letter, Congress has given the Fed authority to enforce the Glass-Steagall Act with respect to national banks. The act provides that a national bank's charter may be forfeited if a violation of the act continues for 6-months after a warning from the Fed and the bank could be fined $1,000 a day.

headline: ON NICARAGUAN BORDER RAIDERS FAN FIRES OF WAR
abstract: The church bells clanged furiously and the villagers came running through the trenches cut across the town square. Within five minutes, some 60 peasant women, teenagers and men of nondescript age who formed the ''first alarm'' section of the local militia were standing in formation like trained soldiers, clasping World War II Czech rifles.   Although this ''test of readiness'' was staged for the benefit of visitors, the new bullet holes in the walls of this small border village, l25 miles north of Managua, offered evidence that such alarms were also part of real life.   Less than half a mile away, the narrow Guasaule River marks the Nicaragua-Honduras border. This frontier, running from the Pacific to the Atlantic coast, is the scene of fighting that the Nicaraguans say has rapidly increased over the past two months.

headline: Tender Bid by Mesa Is Oversubscribed
abstract: The Mesa Petroleum Company today won the first round in its battle to take over the General American Oil Company of Texas.   Mesa said that as of midnight last night 19.7 million shares, or 77.5 percent, of General American's outstanding stock were tendered to it under its $40-a-share offer.

headline: VAN DYK RESEARCH CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Market Place; Market Shifts For Levi Jeans
abstract: LEVI STRAUSS & COMPANY has announced the closing of a jeans plant in Hobbs, N.M., and plants in Clovis, N.M., and Plainview, Tex. that make jeans and other garments. Last April it closed a jeans plant in Laredo, Tex.   The company's profits, which fell 46 percent in the May quarter from a year earlier, partly because of the sluggish economy and poor sales, improved substantially in the August quarter but still were 17 percent below 1981.   To be sure, the jeans industry is going through difficult times.  And according to Jay J. Meltzer, apparel analyst for Goldman, Sachs & Company, Levi Strauss is ''just trimming its sails - getting rid of overhead and becoming a lean and mean company in a tough business.'' The market for jeans today is ''much tougher,'' he noted. Unit sales will fall 4.5 percent this year, he estimated, and future growth will be ''quite modest.''

headline: JACOBS ENGINEERING GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: '83 FARM PROFIT RISE IS HELD UNLIKELY
abstract: American farmers, already experiencing one of their worst years since the Depression, were warned today by the Department of Agriculture that 1983 income would probably be just as poor.   Department economists said that while inflation and interest rates might decline further next year, there was little chance that farmers' profits would be greater than this year's. In 1982, net farm income is expected to fall to $19 billion, from $25 billion in 1981. The economists made their remarks at the department's annual outlook conference.

headline: WORLD OIL GLUT CRAMPS NIGERIA'S DEVELOPMENT
abstract: After years of unfettered spending, Nigeria's leaders are seeking to lower the expectations of their citizens, and have warned that the economic future can no longer be computed on high oil production levels or high oil prices.   The implication for American business executives, a Western economist said, is that ''this may be the time to survey the market'' rather than to embark on new investment.   For, like many other OPEC members, Nigeria has been caught in a recession caused by the abundance of oil on world markets, the increased proportion of competitive non-OPEC oil available to buyers, improved energy conservation in the West and the general slowdown in Western economies.   Nigeria is America's second-largest supplier of imported oil after Saudi Arabia and a substantial buyer of United States foodstuffs. Its income has been steadily falling since 1980, when production of highpriced oil was the main element in export earnings of more than $26 billion. The projection for this year among Western economists is that export earnings will be about $16 billion.

headline: G.& W. Profit Off 15.1%
abstract: Gulf and Western Industries, a diversified holding company, said yesterday that profits for the first quarter of its 1983 fiscal year fell more than 15.1 percent from a year earlier. For the quarter just ended, G.& W. said, earnings fell to $60.8 million, or 80 cents a share, on sales of $1.24 billion. In 1981, the company reported earnings of $71.6 million, or 93 cents a share, on sales of $1.32 billion.

headline: REX-NORECO INC reports earnings for Yr to July 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Not Overblown
abstract: To The Business Editor: In ''Social Security's Overblown Problems'' (Nov.14), Barbara R.  Bergmann has not done anyone a service by attempting to minimize the problems facing the Social Security system.   The system has two funding problems, one short-term, the other long-term. The National Commission on Social Security Reform estimates that $150 billion to $250 billion additional revenues will be needed between now and 1990. This is the short-term funding problem, and although this amount is not small it can be raised.  Prof. Bergmann suggests taxing Social Security benefits; I agree with that suggestion.

headline: CHILE RIGHTS ABUSES PERSIST, MONITORS IN COUNTRY REPORT
abstract: Although there is budding political expression in Chile, now in its 10th year of military rule, widespread abuses of human rights continue, according to human rights groups and Roman Catholic Church officials.   The human rights issue has recently taken on added importance because the Reagan Administration is considering lifting a 1976 embargo on arms shipments to Chile. To do so, the White House first has to certify to Congress that the Government here has made ''significant progress'' in ending abuses.   Some progress is apparent to a visitor returning to the country after an absence of many months. Opposition to the Government of Gen. Augusto Pinochet, once voiced only quietly, has emerged over the last year in the press, in the music of the young, and in open conversations that can be overheard almost anywhere in this Andean country of more than 11 million people.

headline: Military Analysis
abstract: Since Iraq's forces are well organized and trained, deploy thousands of tanks, guns and missiles and are superior in the air, why are they not winning the war with Iran? Why are Iraq's frontiers threatened by an Iranian army that includes thousands of untrained boys and whose air support is negligible?   These questions arise after 10 days of discussions with foreign diplomats here and of carefully supervised visits to various fronts, all inactive or nearly so. Some answers can be found in parts of the military situation.   Since Iraqi troops retreated from Iranian territory in the southern oil-producing province of Khuzistan earlier this year, the army and its leaders have emphasized a defensive strategy.

headline: Fonar Scanner Tie
abstract: The Fonar Corporation of Melville, L.I., said it had signed an agreement valued at $31 million for the purchase and distribution by Universal NMR Inc. of Fonar's mobile nuclear magnetic resonance whole body scanner. Under the agreement, Universal will purchase 25 Fonar scanners and become the exclusive national distributor of the units.  The contract covers a period of three or four years, depending on when the scanner receives Food and Drug Administration approval, and is renewable for an additional three-year period.

headline: Zia's Stay Is Extended At Walter Reed Hospital
abstract: President Mohammad Zia ul-Haq of Pakistan, who was admitted to a hospital here Sunday for a routine medical checkup, remained hospitalized today, a Pakistani Embassy spokesman said.

headline: PATENTS; Efficient Collection Of Energy From Sun
abstract: A stationary device to track the position of the sun throughout the day has been invented for the Dow Corning Corporation, Midland, Mich. The purpose is to increase knowledge of energy obtainable from the sun without requiring excessive power to compensate for cloud obscurity.

headline: TRYING TO SERVE ALL THE WORKERS
abstract: ANALYSIS of the declining fortunes of America's labor unions has b ecome an increasingly popular pastime. Nothing succeeds like successa nd vice-versa. During recent periods of economic decline, these woesh ave compounded and are, according to labor's spokesmen, brought a bout in major part by the Reagan Administration's actions and a ntilabor attitude.  A panoply of reasons contributing to the decline in organized labor's fortunes have been well documented, and not denied by their leaders, at least quietly. But despite these adversities, there is little reason to predict that labor's power will substantially wane during the coming years, or that the basic adversarial foundations of its policies will change much.

headline: News Analysis; A SOVIET-CHINA THAW?
abstract: After an interval of three years, the Soviet Union and China are talking to each other again at an authoritative level. But officials on both sides say the deep differences that made the two nations antagonists for two decades seem unlikely to yield at any time soon.   All the same, diplomats here generally agree that the United States would be unwise to discount the possibility that there will be some lowering of the temperature between the two Communist powers. Apart from the benefits such a development might bring in relationships with the United States, a lessening of intensity would be a relief from an exhausting dispute that has taken on a life of its own, outstripping original causes.

headline: Knowlton Harvard Post
abstract: Winthrop Knowlton has been appointed the first director of the business and government center at Harvard University's John F.  Kennedy School of Government. The center will study such factors as the performance of the American economy, international competitiveness, capital formation and regulatory reform. Mr.  Knowlton, who will become a public service professor at the school, is a former Assistant Secretary of the Treasury for International Affairs and a partner of White, Weld & Company. He had been chief executive officer of Harper & Row Publishers Inc., first as president and then as chairman, and remains its chairman.

headline: ALFA PLANS EXTENSIVE DIVESTITURE
abstract: The troubled Alfa Industrial Group, Mexico's largest conglomerate, has proposed divesting itself of all but a handful of its more than 50 subsidiaries as the only way of resuming payments on its $2.3 billion foreign debt.   The proposal was drawn up by Alfa's financial advisers, Lehman Brothers Kuhn Loeb of New York, and presented to the corporation's 134 private foreign creditors at a meeting in Houston on Dec. 15, banking officials reported.   Initial reactions are expected when Alfa's management meets again with foreign bankers in Houston Jan. 20. ''But don't expect any quick solution,'' one banker warned. ''This could take six months or more to sort out.''

headline: BURLINGTON SETS OFFER TO EL PASO
abstract: In a major diversification move, Burlington Northern Inc. said yesterday that it planned to offer $24 a share for up to 25.1 million shares, or just over 50 percent of the El Paso Company, a diversified energy concern whose main business is producing natural gas. If fully subscribed, the offer would be valued at about $516 million.   One analyst said that the offer for El Paso reflected the longtime ambition of Richard M. Bressler, chairman of Burlington, to give a major push to Burlington's oil and gas business. ''It comes as no surprise,'' Robert D. Long, railroad analyst for First Boston, said in an interview.

headline: Judge Objects To a Tax on Oil
abstract: The Federal windfall profits tax on oil companies was declared unconstitutional today by a Federal judge, who cited the exemption of oil produced in Alaska from the 1980 tax.

headline: Money Data Due Today
abstract: The Federal Reserve Board is scheduled to issue its latest money supply report today at 4:15 P.M. Announcement of the figures, normally released Friday afternoon, was delayed because of the Thanksgiving holiday.

headline: BEGIN CALLS BLAMING OF ISRAEL FOR KILLINGS 'TOTALLY DESPICABLE'
abstract: Prime Minister Menachem Begin, in a letter made public today by the Israeli Embassy, said that "the whole campaign over the last 10 days" to blame Israel for the massacre of Palestinians in West Beirut was "unbelievable, fantastic and totally despicable."   In the letter Senator Alan Cranston, Democrat at California, Mr.  Begin said that hours after the killing of Lebanon's President-elect, Bashir Gemayel, he conferred with his colleagues and expressed concern about he possibility of "revenge" against the Palestinians.   "I uttered the following words: 'Take over as soon as possible the major junctions between the two parts of Beirut to prevent a revenge on the Moslem population by the Christians,'" Mr. Begin said in the letter, which was dated Sept. 29.   "This was the deciding aim of our forces entering West Beirut early the following morning," Mr. Begin said. The next day, Lebanese Christian militiamen were allowed into the refugee camps, and the massacre began almost immediately.

headline: EASTERN GAS & FUEL ASSOCIATES reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: POLAND SAYS 317 ARE STILL IN INTERNMENT
abstract: More than 10,000 people were interned at one time or another during the year since martial law was imposed to crush the Solidarity union, and 317 are still interned, the Polish authorities said today.   Issuing figures for the first time, the Government said 3,616 others had been arrested for violating martial law, and investigations were under way in 2,822 of these cases. Anyone jailed under these charges would presumably not be released in the manner of the internees, who are held temporarily rather than under a court sentence.

headline: Cameraman and Wife Seized By Armed Men in El Salvador
abstract: A Salvadoran freelance television cameraman and his wife were kidnapped by armed men from their home in suburban San Salvador today, friends of the couple reported.   They said a group of men in uniform stood outside the house while armed civilians entered and dragged out Jose Luis Diaz, 29 years old, and his wife, Fidela, at 1 A.M. The couple's 4-year-old son was not taken and neighbors were caring for him.   A police spokesman said he had no knowledge of the incident.

headline: LOCAL VOTE IN GREECE A TEST FOR SOCIALISTS
abstract: When Greeks vote next Sunday, they will be looking for solutions to urgent problems of pollution, garbage, traffic congestion, poor social services - for an improvement in the quality of life.   But foremost on their minds will be the performance of Prime Minister Andreas Papandreou's Socialist Government, which was voted into power just a year ago on a program for radical change in domestic and foreign policy.   Although the elections now are local and the campaign has been confined to local issues, the results will be generally interpreted as the first significant popularity test for Mr. Papandreou.

headline: No Headline
abstract: AFGHAN REBELS SAY THEY INFLICTED HEAVY DAMAGE ON AIRPORT   ISLAMABAD, Pakistan, Dec. 29 (AP) - Reliable rebel sources in Afghanistan say that an attack on a military airport Dec. 21-22 resulted in the destruction of 10 helicopters and damage to the runway and to buildings.   The rebel sources said that 130 Soviet and Afghan troops had been either killed or wounded in the attack, but gave no breakdown. Soviet and Afghan troops counterattacked after the raid, killing about 24 rebels and 12 civilians and suffering about 24 of their own killed, the sources said.

headline: BRIEFS
abstract: * American Telephone and Telegraph Co. won its third construction permit for cellular mobile telephone systems, adding Pittsburgh to earlier approvals for Chicago and Boston. The permit was granted by the Federal Communications Commission.   * Bolt Beranek & Newman Inc. said it had agreed in principle to sell its BBN Instruments Corp. subsidiary to Vibro-Meter Corp., a Torrance, Calif., subsidiary of Vibro-Meter S.A. of Switzerland.  Terms were not disclosed.

headline: Sears to Close Flagship Store
abstract: Sears, Roebuck & Company, the nation's largest retailer, will close its flagship department store on Chicago's State Street next spring and sell the 91-year-old National Historic Landmark building for conversion into an office building.

headline: LAKER'S LIQUIDATOR SUES
abstract: The liquidator for Laker Airlines Ltd. filed a suit today in United States District Court in Washington, charging several airlines and the McDonnell Douglas Corporation with conspiracy to drive Sir Freddie Laker out of business.   Christopher Morris, the Touche Ross & Company accountant who is overseeing liquidation of the airline portion of Sir Freddie's travel operations, said here today that the suit charges violation of American antitrust law and is seeking triple damages amounting to 600 million, or about $954 million at current exchange rates.   ''These people conspired together to force Laker out of business by dropping their prices to a level where they were not making a profit and offering a superior product,'' Mr. Morris said.

headline: AWAITING THE SURGE IN MEXICO VACATIONS
abstract: When Mexico untethered the peso from an official exchange rate of 70 to the dollar in early December, the currency promptly plunged on the free market to 148 to the dollar - cutting the cost of hotels, meals and travel for American travelers to Mexico by more than half.   But while the action makes Mexico something of a fire sale in vacation terms, some travel agents predict that Americans would nonetheless shy away for awhile from what they perceive as a financially shaky situation.   Industry officials point out that even though the new market rate for the peso is now in line with black market rates that have prevailed since August, when Mexico imposed exchange controls, Americans have not exactly flocked to Mexico.   ''In the short run, people might tend to stay away,'' said David Hillman, vice president of marketing and administration at Thomas Cook Travel. ''They don't want to worry about Government stability and currency problems. They don't understand the impact of devaluation on them when they travel.''

headline: BIG LOSS POSTED BY WOOLWORTH
abstract: The F.W. Woolworth Company, which has reduced its retailing operations sharply in recent months, reported yesterday a loss of $428 million in its fiscal third quarter as a result of special charges for discontinued operations.   Woolworth said earnings from continuing operations fell 22.2 percent in the fiscal third quarter, to $14 million from $18 million in the 1981 quarter.   But in the latest quarter, ended Oct. 31, the company also took a one-time charge of $428 million for the discontinuance of the 336-store Woolco chain in the United States and the sale of the company's 52.6 percent interest in British Woolworth. Those operations also produced an after-tax loss of $14 million in the quarter before their disposal, bringing the total to $442 million.

headline: FELDSTEIN SEES SLOW JOB GROWTH
abstract: Martin S. Feldstein, the President's chief economic aide, said today that it would take five or six years to bring the unemployment rate down to 6 or 7 percent from the postwar peak of 10.4 percent reached in October.   Martin S. Feldstein, chairman of the Council of Economic Advisers, said that bringing the unemployment rate down to this level sooner would require economic growth at a pace that might ignite inflation again.   ''The type of moderate and sound rate of economic growth that is consistent with declining inflation can bring the unemployment rate down to the 6 to 7 percent range within the next five or six years,'' he said at a breakfast meeting with reporters.

headline: Level Lowest In Five Years
abstract: Industrial production in September dropped for the 12th time in 14 months, hitting the lowest level in more than five years, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.   The decline of six-tenths of 1 percent in output was the biggest drop since last spring. But analysts inside and outside the Government said better times might be coming for hard-pressed big industry.

headline: ANTHEM ELECTRONICS reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Tricentrol Clarification
abstract: Tricentrol P.L.C. said today that it had acquired interests of 8.3 percent in six offshore blocks in the Gulf of Mexico rather than eight as reported in its statement last Friday. The company's share of the bidding was $11.1 million rather than $11.3 million, as stated earlier.

headline: DELOREAN USED COMPLEX FINANCING TO SUPPORT A NETWORK OF COMPANIES
abstract: John Z. DeLorean, in trying to start a new auto company, operated through a tangled web of corporations, here and abroad, attracting financing from such blue-ribbon sources as the British Government and the Bank of America, and fending off questions from business associates and the Internal Revenue Service about how the money was spent.   Federal investigators say Mr. DeLorean had apparently exhausted his legitimate financing sources, but was still determined to make his sports car venture a success. As a result, they said, the 57-year-old businessman turned his entrepreneurial quest toward a more risky but potentially more lucrative source.   Mr. DeLorean, whose flamboyant life landed him on the society pages as often as on the financial pages, was arraigned yesterday in Los Angeles on charges of financing a $24 million cocaine deal with two Californians.   On Tuesday, shortly before his arrest, the British Government announced that DeLorean Motor Cars Ltd., the Northern Ireland-based maker of luxury sports cars, would be permanently closed after being in receivership for eight months.

headline: No Headline
abstract: Drop in OPEC Output Is Seen   TULSA, Okla., Nov. 22 (Reuters) - Oil production in the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries is not expected to exceed 19.5 million barrels a day in the fourth quarter, the Oil and Gas Journal said today.   The magazine said OPEC had been expected to produce more than 20 million barrels daily in the current quarter.

headline: LIBYAN SEEKS EXPULSION OF ISRAEL FROM U.N.
abstract: Abdulati Obeidi, Libya's Foreign Minister, called on the United Nations today to expel Israel, which he referred to only as ''the Zionist entity,'' on the ground that it was not a peaceloving nation.   He also criticized United States proposals for peace in the Middle East, saying they ignored resolutions of the United Nations, the Organization of African Unity and the group of nations professing nonalignment.  These resolutions call for a separate Palestinian state under the leadership of the Palestine Liberation Organization.

headline: No Headline
abstract: AROUND THE WORLD; Foes of Army Rule Win An Election in Uruguay   MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, Nov. 29 (UPI) - Opponents of the nine-year-old military Government appeared today to have won a major victory over pro-Government candidates in primary elections Sunday, and they vowed to work for a quick return to democracy.   More than 1.2 million of the 2 million Uruguayans voted to elect the 500 members of the nation's three approved parties who will choose presidential candidates for elections in November 1984.

headline: GATT Bid By Poland
abstract: Poland today called on the agency that polices world trade to urge the repeal of sanctions imposed by President Reagan on American imports of Polish products.   Andrzej Dorosz, the Polish Deputy Foreign Minister, told the council of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade that Washington's suspension of most-favored-nation tariff treatment of Polish goods was driving them out of the American market with ''devastating effect.''   The council, which is made up of most of GATT's 88 member states, put off a decision on the Polish request. But it left open the possibility that Poland's dispute with the United States may be raised in the meantime before the full GATT assembly that begins here on Nov. 24.

headline: CURTISS-WRIGHT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30

headline: PALMY DAYS OVER FOR A NAZI IN BOLIVIA
abstract: He has often be seen strolling down the street here, or sipping coffee in the late morning at the Cafe La Paz, where he sat at his favorite table, his back to the wall.   A grandfatherly figure with long white hair, he recently declined, politely, to be interviewed. His friends described him as a kind fellow, burdened by grief over his wife, who is dying of cancer.   He is also one of the world's most wanted men. He is Klaus Barbie, who was the SS commander in Lyons, France, between 1942 and 1944.  Mr. Barbie, condemned to death in absentia by a French military tribunal after World War II, is accused by the French Government of deporting thousands of French Jews to their deaths in concentration camps, killing hundreds of French Resistance sympathizers, burning women and children in their homes, and murdering Jean Moulin, the leader of the Resistance.

headline: Regan Backs Extra Money Growth
abstract: In a marked change in the Administration's position, Treasury Secretary Donald T. Regan today encouraged the Federal Reserve to permit extra growth in the money supply, if that is what the Fed wants to do.   Mr. Regan, at a news conference, expressed a more tolerant attitude than in the past to fluctuations permitted by the Fed in the amount of currency and checking account deposits available for spending.  ''If they overshoot by a slight amount for a short period of time, we would not object,'' he said.

headline: Jacobs Group Lifts Pabst Offer to $30
abstract: A group headed by the Minneapolis investor Irwin Jacobs has raised its offer for 3 million shares of the Pabst Brewing Company to $30 a share from $24. The withdrawal deadline remains midnight next Friday, the group said, and the offer will expire at midnight, Dec. 2, unless further extended.

headline: ATHEY PRODUCTS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Top Esmark Executive To Look for Successor
abstract: Donald P. Kelly, chairman, president and chief executive of Esmark Inc., says that he is not necessarily looking for a successor in his own image when he gives up the title of chief executive next year, as he has announced that he will do.   ''Too often a board will mistakenly try to replace a c.e.o. with a similar individual,'' Mr. Kelly said in an interview. ''Each c.e.o.  has his own style and vision of where he wants the company to go.''

headline: EXECUTIVES
abstract: * Armco Financial Corp., Middletown, Ohio, a unit of Armco Inc., has named Bernard L. Lavery president and chief executive officer.   * Cannon Mills Co., Kannapolis, N.C., has promoted Joseph E. Orland to senior vice president and director of manufacturing.

headline: FINANCE BRIEFS
abstract: * Associates Corp. of North America filed with the S.E.C. for $500 million of debt securities, with terms to be set at the time of sale.    * The Republic of Austria filed with the S.E.C. for an offering of $400 million of debt securities.

headline: Continental Insurance
abstract: Continental Insurance Companies has announced that it has developed a new policy to help protect buyers of commercial liability insurance against inflation. Called Inflation Protection, the policy, Continental said, was the first of its kind to be marketed in the United States. It correlates liability limits to the Consumer Price Index and can be written for most classes of business and a wide range of risks.

headline: Quake in North Vietnam
abstract: A strong earthquake shook a region near Vietnam's northern frontier with China, the Vietnam News Agency reported today. The agency said the quake struck Wednesday and registered 6.6 on the Richter scale, setting off tremors that were felt in most parts of northern Vietnam. It gave no reports of damage or casualties.

headline: Harvester Sale

headline: Southeast Banking Sets an Exchange
abstract: The Miami-based Southeast Banking Corporation said it and Florida National Banks of Florida Inc. had signed a definitive pact for the exchange by Florida National of certain banking offices, nonbank assets and cash for its stock held by Southeast.   Florida National will exchange seven banks with 15 offices and the nine First Marine branch offices in Palm Beach County it recently acquired from Barnett Banks of Florida Inc. Florida National will also transfer nonbank assets and $7.5 million.

headline: The Talk of San Salvador
abstract: It is dusk outside an apartment house near the center of El Salvador's capital, and an American military adviser walks into the courtyard with a visitor, who starts to climb into a waiting taxi.   The adviser was an infantryman in Vietnam and trained troops in Cambodia, Laos and Thailand in the late 1960's.  He breaks into a grin. ''All I want to do is win one war, that's all, just one,'' he says. ''It'll be like winning the World Series for me.''

headline: THE RETREAT IN PLANT SPENDING
abstract: When officials at the Dravo Corporation decided three years ago to move into a new office building in downtown Pittsburgh, they had no idea that a prolonged economic downturn was on the way. The engineering and construction company budgeted some $21 million in 1982 to cover the cost of moving and buying new equipment for what was to be called Dravo Tower, a 54-story edifice.   But the $21 million has never been spent. ''We had planned to start moving in this month,'' said William P. Stewart, a Dravo spokesman. ''But those plans have been scrapped.''

headline: ...AND TRYING TO PUT IT BACK
abstract: Among the new technologies that arcade game manufacturers are counting on to generate new consumer enthusiasm are three-dimensional games and those incorporating the videodisk.   Sega Enterprises, a Los Angeles company 85 percent owned by Gulf & Western Industries, has just started shipping what is believed to be the first three-dimensional arcade game, SubRoc-3D, in which a player pilots a submarine-rocketship, and enemies and obstacles come hurtling toward or away from the player.   The system is made by the Matsushita Electric Industrial Company of Japan, known for its Panasonic products. Instead of wearing special glasses, as people watching three-dimensional movies must do, players look through a periscope that contains the necessary lenses.

headline: Draper Meets Gemayel To Discuss Withdrawal
abstract: The American envoy Morris Draper met today with President Amin Gemayel of Lebanon and officials of the multinational peacekeeping force for talks aimed at arranging the withdrawal of Israeli, Syrian and Palestinian forces from Lebanon.   Lebanon's Government television said that Mr. Draper's next stop on his current trip would be Israel.

headline: Funds Down $6.5 Billion
abstract: Assets of the nation's money market funds dropped $6.5 billion, to $210.9 billion, in the week ended Wednesday, marking the fourth consecutive week of declines, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday.   It attributed the continued outflow to the lure of the new deposit accounts being offered by banks and thrift institutions, as well as shareholders' need to finance holiday spending.

headline: CBS to Sell Parts Of Paperback Unit
abstract: CBS Inc. announced that it had agreed to sell major portions of its Popular Library paperback books unit to Warner Publishing.

headline: TRAINING A FUTURES TRADER
abstract: When the discount rate dropped half a point just before the session's end, the pit exploded. Prices shot up. Traders with contracts on the line screamed, sweated and muscled their way across the undersized, crowded floor as transactions flashed on the board above.   All was as normal on the floor of the New York Futures Exchange.  Except it was 7:40 P.M., more than three hours after closing time, and most of the people crowded into the pit were not traders at all.

abstract: China is inviting foreign businesses to invest in 10 projects to develop coal, China's major source of energy, the New China News Agency said today. The projects are valued at more than $3 billion. The agency noted that an agreement was signed earlier this year between China and the Occidental Petroleum Corporation on a feasibility study for developing a mine in north China's Shanxi province.

headline: FOR 500,000 GUATEMALANS, THE WAR COMES HOME
abstract: The guerrilla war in Guatemala has uprooted 500,000 people, officials say.   The evidence can be found in such places as Chimaltenango, where, to a visitor coming upon an eerie, quiet landscape of untended fields, charred Indian huts and a few horses running wild, it seemed as though a great disaster had struck.   Only military convoys ore along the backroads of the free-fire zone north of Chimaltenango, a province in the heart of Guatemala where strangers are tantamount to enemies.   The people who used to hoe the cornfields fled the war months ago.  In a region 20 miles long by 40 miles wide, about 30 villages and hamlets are either destroyed or badly damaged.

headline: WINSTON MILLS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 2
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: The Talk of Kinshasa
abstract: If cities moved, Kinshasa's gait would be a fitful lurch.  Its life rises and breaks, moments of high fever giving way to collapse and dulled sleep. Beneath the town, the Congo River smashes into rapids, but at Kinshasa the water sits - a dark brown lake, syrupy, cola gone flat.   The city is enormous, with a population of perhaps three million, although no one could really count the people waiting for buses, begging, pushing wheelbarrows, peering from huts, lying in the dirt, walking, shouting, riding in limousines.

headline: COLECO'S NEW VIDEO CHALLENGE
abstract: Attack and defend: In the fantasy world of video games, that is the theme played out daily on millions of American television screens.  And much like the characters in those electronic conflicts, Coleco Industries is bent on conquest - the $5 billion home video game market - at the expense of two well-entrenched rivals, Atari Inc. and Mattel Inc.   To that end, the Hartford-based company recently introduced its Colecovision home video game system, a cartridge-playing console, to face Atari, the industry leader, and Mattel, the marketer of Intellivision, in the marketing arena.   Industry analysts and toy store owners say Colecovision's graphics -especially color quality - are generally superior to those of its competitors, and that in many stores it also enjoys a price advantage. But marketing battles, especially at Christmas, are never easy.

headline: Dane Plans Bank Talks
abstract: Henning Christophersen, Finance Minister and Deputy Prime Minister, will visit New York, Washington and Frankfurt this week for talks with Denmark's major bank creditors. He will seek to allay growing concern that Denmark is unable to put its financial house in order, according to political analysts and banking sources.

headline: European Car Sales Up
abstract: Automobile sales in the European Economic Community rose nearly 1 percent this year from 1981 in spite of the economic slump. But 1981 was an exceptionally poor year, with sales just climbing back to their level of five years ago, a spokesman for the community said today. ''The outlook for the European automobile market for 1983 is one of very modest growth with demand in some national markets showing no change or even a slight fall,'' the spokesman said.

headline: DOW DROPS AS RECORD WEEK ENDS
abstract: Prices dropped yesterday as the New York Stock Exchange completed a week in which the volume of trading was the heaviest in history.  The Dow Jones industrial average, which was in the minus column throughout the session, closed down 3.77 points, at 993.10. For the week the average rose 6.25 points, primarily because of declining interest rates.   Trading on the Big Board settled back yesterday to 80.3 million shares after exceeding 100 million shares in each of the four previous sessions.

headline: Guinness Peat Debts
abstract: Guinness Peat Group P.L.C. is considering legal action against those responsible for the bad debts incurred by its subsidiary, Performance Tyre Ltd., its chief executive, Alastair Morton, has disclosed. Guinness Peat has received a file on the case and will be trying to recoup the $24 million provision made in last year's accounts, Mr. Morton said after the annual meeting on Friday.

headline: COMPUTER MEMORIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Economic Scene; Slump's Effect On the Banks
abstract: WHETHER one blames so-called Reaganomics, supply-side economics or monetarism, the country is feeling the effects of a classic recession, following an inflationary boom.   As in past recessions, banks have not been spared the agonies, as was evident at this week's annual convention of the American Bankers Association in Atlanta. From the biggest to the smallest, practically all banks say they have been hurt by the steep downturn in the economy. Yet, the bankers are basically optimistic. As they see it, the recession and its effects have forced them to become better bankers, which, in turn, will create a stronger banking system.

headline: NEW YORK CITY FINANCES---REASON FOR WORRY, AGAIN
abstract: ''THE worst pain is behind us,'' Mayor Koch said last January when presenting his financial plan for 1981. And it seemed to many that New York City's chief executive was right.   After years of deficits, a near bankruptcy and a budgetary crisis that shook the municipal credit markets and brought Albany and Washington to the rescue with loan guarantees and financial aid, the nation's premier city had put its books in order and balanced its budget a year ahead of schedule. The Big Apple seemed ready at last to loosen its belt and begin restoring crucial services and even expanding them.   But the good times were short-lived. This week, a subdued Mayor Koch warned his city that economic forces beyond his control had created new budget gaps of $341 million for the fiscal year ending June 30 and an alarming $1.3 billion deficit for the next fiscal year.

headline: GONZALEZ INSTALLED AS SPAIN'S PREMIER
abstract: Felipe Gonzalez was sworn in today as the first Socialist Prime Minister of Spain since the 1930's.  At a brief ceremony at the palace of King Juan Carlos on the outskirts of Madrid, the 40-year-old Mr. Gonzalez placed his hands on a Bible and, facing a cruficix, took the oath to the Constitution, using the secular word ''promise'' rather than the religiously laden ''swear'' used by his predecessors. Mr. Gonzalez, the youngest Prime Minister in Europe, is a nonpracticing Roman Catholic.   After taking the oath, Mr. Gonzalez formally communicated to Juan Carlos the names of the 17 men who will make up his Cabinet, which will be sworn in Friday.

headline: RISING PRICES FOR HEATING OIL
abstract: The nation's major oil producers are entering the winter heating season with their lowest supplies of heating oil in more than 20 years. Although oil company officials and industry analysts say they do not expect shortages to occur, they also say that the relatively short supplies of refined heating fuel are pushing up retail prices.   In large part, the reduced level of heating oil stocks reflects the changing economics of the oil industry. With crude oil in generous supply, and with consumption declining because of the recession and conservation measures, the oil industry has scaled back the use of its refineries and is attempting to hold down the cost of keeping refined products in storage.

headline: MARYLAND CUP CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: A REPORTER'S NOTEBOOK: IRAQIS TRY TO IGNORE WAR
abstract: It was 8 in the morning and the childern were going to school. By twos and threes they trudged across bare fields to the neat, white schoolhouses. Not an unusal sight in the West. But here in Iraq it was a testament to the introduction of universal education by President Saddam Hussein - a program for which he will be remembered long after the ubiquitous posters bearing his face are torn down and replaced by those bearing another visage.   The size of the country and the unreliability of communications militate against political conformity, but President Hussein is trying anyway. Posters showing him in uniform, holding a baby, smoking a cigar, grave in a business suit are everywhere. This is a cult of personality Stalin might have envied. But they are pictures.  For security reasons, few Iraqis ever see their leader in person.

headline: CONSUMER DEBT RISES $1.1 BILLION
abstract: The nation's consumers took on $1.1 billion more in new installment debt in September than they repaid, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.   The increase was the biggest monthly credit expansion since June and was seen as a sign that consumers were starting to believe that the recession was coming to an end.   However, the gain was still well below the increases of $2 billion or $3 billion a month that were common last year before the recession took hold.

headline: DEBT CRISIS FORCES SHIFT BY BRAZIL
abstract: A balance-of-payments crisis is about to force Brazil to arrange a loan with the International Monetary Fund and accept direct assistance from the United States, two steps that it has long argued were fundamentally against its political interests.   Combined with a joint effort by six United States banks to furnish $600 million in loans to get Brazil past the end of the year, the actions are giving the United States more leverage in Brazil than it has enjoyed in more than a decade.   In years past, Brazilian leaders have contended that the country was managing its massive foreign debt with a prudence that forestalled the need to resort to the International Monetary Fund.  And the architects of its foreign policy altered the pattern of its trade and diplomatic initiatives to emphasize underdevelopednations and reduce dependence on the United States.

abstract: In the trade, they are called dual career ladders. Companies, mostly in industries that depend heavily on scientific research, set up two parallel career paths - one for managers, the other for scientists and technicians. In theory, salaries and status are equal at equivalent levels on the two ladders, even as high as the top rungs.

headline: Dan River Plan To Avoid Icahn

headline: A Successful Journey From Print to NBC-TV
abstract: The commercials that the NBC-TV Network has been running to promote its new season, and which have been complimented for their creativity, are the work of Steve Sohmer, who may be remembered in the New York area as the former creative director of the Newspaper Advertising Bureau.   You might say his transfer from print began when he started his own creative boutique that did some good, and unique, promotion films for newspapers.

headline: CUBAN POET, JAILED 22 YEARS, ARRIVES IN PARIS
abstract: Armando Valladares, the Cuban poet who spent 22 years in prison for criticizing Fidel Castro and was freed after the personal intervention of President Francois Mitterrand, was reunited with his wife today on his arrival in Paris.   The tall, emaciated 44-year-old writer stepped slowly down from a special French Government jetliner that picked him up in Madrid early today. The poet flew to Spain aboard a Soviet IL-62 jetliner that left Havana Thursday.

headline: COLONEL COUNTERS SHARON TESTIMONY
abstract: A top Israeli military aide, testifying at an inquiry into September's slaying of hundreds of Palestinian civilians at two refugee camps in Beirut, today contradicted testimony by Defense Minister Ariel Sharon about the decision to allow Phalangist militiamen into the camps.   Lieut. Col. Zeev Zecharin, an aide to Israel's Chief of Staff, said that the decision to use Christian Phalangist militiamen to enter the Palestinian refugee camps of Shatila and Sabra was discussed by Israeli officials on the evening of Tuesday, Sept. 14, the day that President-elect Bashir Gemayel, the Phalangist leader, was assassinated.   On Oct. 26 Mr. Sharon told the three-member board of inquiry that the question of the Phalangists' entrance into the camps had not come up at the Tuesday night meeting, and that neither had the broader question of the Phalangists' role in the planned Israeli sweep into West Beirut after Mr. Gemayel's assassination. The meeting was attended by Mr. Sharon and by the Chief of Staff, Lieut. Gen. Rafael Eytan.

headline: News Analysis
abstract: Yuri V. Andropov, who surprised Washington by the speed with which he outmaneuvered rivals for the Soviet Communist Party leadership, is regarded here as a tougher, smarter, shrewder competitor for the United States than Leonid I. Brezhnev.   His first speech, emphasizing Soviet military might, was read here as an expected show of forcefulness, an echo of Mr. Brezhnev's final theme, and a political bow to the important constituency of the armed forces at the vulnerable moment of succession. Washington is looking for a more definitive outline of policies in the coming days.   On the record, the new Soviet leader is seen by American specialists as a man of contradictions, a cultivated and fairly well traveled party careerist personally fascinated by Western society but concerned that Soviet society has become too corrupt and consumerminded, a strong advocate of the Soviet military buildup but a backer of negotiations with the West who has warned on occasion that detente was in danger and required ''constant movement forward.''

headline: YEAR-END PLANNING FOR INCOME TAXES
abstract: SPECIAL year-end strategies to minimize taxes have always been de r igueur for upper-bracket taxpayers, but this year new and recent taxl egislation makes such planning a virtual necessity even for those w ith more modest incomes. Indeed, people with casualty losses or s ubstantial medical expenses may sacrifice hundreds of dollars in taxs avings unless they take action now to nail down those deductions fort he 1982 tax year.   ''Year-end tax planning used to be thought of as buying five exotic tax shelters,'' says M. Donald Wright, a tax partner in the Philadelphia office of Arthur Andersen & Company, the accounting firm. ''But year-end planning should really be just a matter of making sure that what we thought would happen all year actually took place.''

headline: ISRAEL'S LEBANESE ALLY FAVORS TREATY
abstract: Maj. Saad Haddad, the leader of a pro-Israeli Lebanese militia organization controlling southern Lebanon, said today that any negotiated plan for the withdrawal of foreign forces must include continued links between Lebanon and Israel.   The major spoke of the need for a guarantee that the border remain open, ''this time officially and legitimately.'' The border has been open on a limited basis for several years.   Major Haddad, in an interview at the Arazim Hotel on the border here, spoke with misgivings of the first stage of talks for a phased withdrawal of Syrian and Israeli forces. The talks are being held under American auspices.
