headline: ECONOMIC AFFAIRS; THE WAR OVER PENTAGON SPENDING
abstract: AS a nation, we are waging a war among ourselves over our ability tow age war. On Nov. 22, the President fired off a salvo with one of h is typically effective television speeches. He spoke of the need to s pend more on defense so we can cajole the Russians into mutual r eductions in defense spending in the future. In opposition, others a rgue that the Russians will not be impressed with increases in U nited States defense spending if they are inefficient and that therei s no way that the huge increases sought by the President can be i mplemented efficiently. Still others - though a notable minority - d o not see the Russians as much of a threat at all.  The higher levels of defense spending desired by the President are impressive. Between the fiscal years 1981 and 1987, outlays would grow almost 15 percent a year. The increase in the fiscal year 1983 alone will be almost $34 billion. For perspective, this far exceeds the entire amount of the President's originally recommended 1983 spending levels for housing assistance ($8.9 billion), food stamps ($10.3 billion), and Aid to Families with Dependent Children ($6.9 billion).

headline: R.J. REYNOLDS CHIEF TO STAY INDEFINITELY
abstract: The question of who would succeed J. Paul Sticht as chairman and chief executive of R.J. Reynolds Industries next year has been answered - the successor will be Mr. Sticht himself. headline: MONDAY, NOVEMBER 1, 1982; The Economy
abstract: Corporate third-quarter profits plunged because the recession, high interest rates and a strong dollar combined to slash domestic and foreign sales. The poor profits in turn provoked dividend cuts, plant closings and increased unemployment. (Page D1.) A compilation of earnings reports appears on page D8.

headline: Washington Watch; Coal Pipelines Gain Support
abstract: WASHINGTON THE White House, increasingly sensitive to the sharp rise in unemployment, may be softening its opposition to legislation that would clear the way for construction of seven or more large pipelines to carry coal.   Although many in the Administration have supported the idea of coal slurry pipelines, the White House has until recently shown no sign of retreating from President Reagan's statement last November that the Federal Government should not give pipeline sponsors the eminent domain authority they need to to build them. This is a matter that should be left to individual states, he said.   Coal slurry legislation is opposed by railroads, which are both coal-carrying competitors and the owners of land that would have to be crossed, and by Western interests who argue that slurry lines would deplete water resources.

headline: AT AQABA, SUNTANS AND BORDER DISPUTE
abstract: Egyptian Border - Despite a sharp desert wind, Scandinavian tourists were sunning themselves on this disputed stretch of Gulf of Aqaba beach front, which has come to symbolize the strains in the Egyptian-Israeli peace efforts.   The tourists were lolling around a huge swimming pool, complete with a bar in the middle, on the grounds of a new Israeli luxury hotel called the Aviya Sonesta. An Israeli checkpoint was a few hundred yards away on one side, and an Egyptian position a few hundred yards away on the other.   The Sonesta was completed and opened to its first guests in November despite the Israeli-Egyptian dispute over Taba, the 750-yard stretch of beach front where the hotel was built. Most of the guests so far have been Europeans on package tours, although curious Israelis come on weekends and fill many of the hotel's 340 rooms, which are furnished in wicker and beige decor.

headline: WHITE HOUSE SAYS PRESIDENT HAS FAITH IN SALVADOR ENVOY
abstract: The White House said today that the United States Ambassador to El Salvador, Deane R. Hinton, retained the ''full faith and confidence'' of President Reagan despite the controversy over a recent speech that had not been fully cleared by the Administration.   Larry Speakes, the White House spokesman, said that the Administration's policy toward El Salvador remained unchanged and that President Reagan was committed to ''political, economic, social reforms taking place within the ongoing democratic process in that country.'' Mr. Speakes said the Administration sought ''quiet diplomacy as a more effective form of diplomatic relations than public discussion of bilateral relations.''   Mr. Speakes's comments, in response to reporters' questions, came after the disclosure that President Reagan and White House aides had been upset about a recent speech in San Salvador by Mr. Hinton, who bluntly criticized the Salvadoran legal system and said that rightist death squads posed as much of a threat to El Salvador as leftist guerrillas. The speech had been cleared by the State Department, but not the White House. ''Most ambassadorial remarks are not,'' Mr.  Speakes said.

headline: Economic Analysis
abstract: Last of six articles that have appeared periodically on current world economic problems   After three decades of the greatest growth in history, the world economy has been caught for the last three years in what a committee of international economists assembled by the United   Nations calls ''a vicious spiral of contraction.'' The key economic issue facing all nations today is how to break that spiral and get back on a path of steady growth. But there are sharp disagreements among governments on how to proceed.   High unemployment in the industrial world, the most severe since the Depression of the 1930's, is increasing pressure on governments to pursue ''beggar my neighbor'' policies, excluding foreign goods or devaluing currencies to save jobs at home, whatever the consequences for other nations. Suffering and Instability   Disputes between industrialized countries and developing countries have grown worse as the developing nations see the prices of their commodities fall and the incomes of many of their people depressed to - or below -the subsistence level.

headline: DEBATE CONTINUES TO RAGE ON CITY'S J-51 TAX POLICY
abstract: In September, New York City's J-51 tax benefit program, offering tax abatements and exemptions to owners who undertook to renovate their property moderately or substantially, lapsed because the Legislature adjourned without voting to extend it.   But debate continues among city officials, housing activists, developers and lawyers. The 27-year-old program is the most hotly disputed city housing policy since the urban renewal of the 1950's and 1960's.   Broadly stated, the question is whether J-51 tax benefits have rehabilitated residential buildings that otherwise would have decayed or whether they have largely resulted in subsidies for luxury dwellings, displacing low- and moderate-income renters.

headline: The Talk of Whitehorse
abstract: Some of the boys in a saloon here the other night were talking about a local woman who had won $1,800 in a lottery. The consensus was that her decision to put the money in the bank showed a sorry lack of ambition.   ''What I'd do,'' said one, ''is tie a snow shovel to the hood of my car and drive south until nobody had the faintest idea what the damn thing was.''   It is a time-honored sentiment. Robert Service, the gold rush poet, wrote that ''some say God was tired'' when He made the Yukon, which Service described as ''the cussedest land that I know.''

headline: ABC-TV News to Ayer
abstract: The ABC-TV Network, all of whose nontelevision advertising promotion has been handled by McCaffrey & McCall, has split off the news operation and assigned it to N.W. Ayer. Thus, that venerable agency will create the print and radio advertising needed to promote such programs as ''World News Tonight,'' ''Closeup,'' ''20/20'' and the Barbara Walters specials.

headline: Rise in Indiana Standard Price
abstract: The Standard Oil Company (Indiana) said it had raised the price it pays for crude oil purchased in the United States by $1 a barrel, effective Oct. 1.   A spokesman said the increase brought the price the company pays for key west Texas crude to $33 a barrel, matching higher prices posted previously by Exxon, Gulf Oil, the Sun Company and Shell Oil.

headline: Trade Report Delayed
abstract: The Commerce Department said today that its report on the United States merchandise trade balance in November, scheduled for release tomorrow, would be delayed indefinitely because of a computer failure.

headline: BRIEFS
abstract: * Avnet Corp. called a special shareholders meeting for Jan. 19 to consider an increase in the number of authorized shares in order to split its stock 2 for 1.   * Citizens and Southern Corp. said it had agreed in principle to acquire Farmers and Merchants Bank, Aiken, S.C., for an undisclosed amount of cash.

headline: A.T.& T. TO ASSIGN NEW UNITS' STOCK TO SHAREHOLDERS
abstract: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company told its 3 million shareholders today how it will distribute stock in the local telephone companies that it will divest by Jan.1, 1984.   In a filing with the United States District Court, A.T.& T. said it would distribute one new share in each of seven regional phone companies for every 10 shares of A.T.& T. stock now held.   Under an agreement with the Justice Department, the company must divest itself of its 22 local telephone companies, which account for 80 percent of all local phone operations, by Jan.1, 1984. 7 Large Regional Companies   These local companies will be grouped in the seven regional operations - each a huge corporation in its own right.  No analyst was willing to speculate today at what level the new stock would trade or what might happen to the price of A.T.& T.  stock, once the divestiture was completed. That stock fell 62 1/2 cents today, to close at $59.875 on the New York Stock Exchange.

headline: Fedders Lawsuit
abstract: The State of Kentucky has settled its 1981 lawsuit against the Fedders Corporation with an agreement that Fedders will inspect, repair, replace or extend warranties for defective heating and air-conditioning units in many homes, state officials said. Attorney General Stephen Beshear said that as many as 250 residents had complained of problems with heat pumps or airconditioners and that total repairs and refunds could cost more than $100,000. Under terms of the settlement, Fedders, based in Edison, N.J., denied any wrongdoing.

headline: Gulf Oil Write-Off
abstract: The Gulf Oil Corporation announced it would take a $50 million after-tax write-off against fourth-quarter earnings to cover the permanent closing of its 75 percent owned refinery near Milan, Italy. The write-off was disclosed in Gulf's third-quarter report to shareholders following the termination of talks with the Kuwait Petroleum Company for sale of that refinery and other European operations.

headline: Mine Closings
abstract: The United States Steel Corporation's Quebec Cartier Mining Company unit said it would proceed with the previously announced shutdown of its Mount Wright and Gagnon iron ore operations next Monday. A spokesman for Quebec Cartier said the Mount Wright facility would reopen on Jan. 3; operations at the company's 8 percent owned Gagnon facilities at Fire Lake and Lac Jeannine will not reopen before Jan. 15.

headline: UNESCO AGREES ON ITS PLAN FOR FUTURE
abstract: Delegates from 158 member nations of Unesco wound up a two-week special conference here tonight by adopting a plan for the organization's future activities that included a divisive chapter on information and mass communications and another on collective rights as distinct from human rights.   Agreement on the final resolutions for 13 programs - including activities in science, education, culture and development - was by consensus, without a vote.   In their closing statements, delegations from the industrial nations and the third world, after clashing frequently during the debate, all voiced reservations about some aspects of the plan, as did the Soviet delegation, which by and large had sided with the third world.   The texts adopted today will serve as the basis for efforts by Amadou-Mahtar M'Bow of Senegal, Unesco's Director General, to work out a precise program for 1984 and 1985. The program will have to be approved by Unesco's General Assembly next summer, and some of the arguments will undoubtedly be resumed then.

headline: U.S. BLOCKS RISE IN NATURAL GAS RATE
abstract: The Government, reacting to continuing increases in natural gas prices, refused today to allow a major pipeline company to pass along to utility customers the extra costs of importing liquefied natural gas from Algeria.   The immediate result of the decision, a temporary denial of a request by a subsidiary of the Panhandle Eastern Corporation for a waiver of its set rates, was to prevent consumer rate increases from taking effect Monday. The affected consumers are mainly in five Middle Western states, including 700,000 in Illinois.   Although imports of Algerian natural gas account for only a small part - less than 1 percent - of the nation's gas supplies, today's move was part of a significant recent effort by Federal regulators to hold gas prices down. Algerian natural gas currently costs about $7 per 1,000 cubic feet, versus an average price of about $2.27 for domestically produced gas, and the importer had sought a rate increase to reflect this differential.

headline: Mine Kills 2 Israelis
abstract: Two Israeli officers were killed today and three were injured when their army vehicle hit a mine in eastern Lebanon, the Israeli Army spokesman said.

headline: Economic Illness
abstract: To the Business Editor: In a letter to The New York Times entitled ''The Economy's Illness Is Being Misdiagnosed'' (Sept. 19), Paul L. Pryde asserts that ''the United States is undergoing a fundamental economic transformation from a manufacturing society to one engaged in the production of information''; and on this basis he projects a ''new wave of economic growth.''   It's a comforting message - not to worry that we've lost the competitive edge in key manufacturing industries - we're on the way to something new and better. Unfortunately, it lacks substance.

headline: Costa Rica Default Bid
abstract: In a move that could spark similar actions elsewhere, a Swiss investor has taken legal action to have Costa Rica formally declared in default on a loan.   The Banque Gutzwiller, Kurz, Bungener said today that the unidentified Swiss investor had asked a Geneva court to declare Costa Rica in default on a $9.13 million bond issue that the bank arranged in 1980.   Costa Rica, which has been negotiating the rescheduling of about $1 billion of its foreign debts because of a prolonged slump in coffee exports, has not paid any interest on the bond issue since October 1981. Arrears total $960,000.

headline: Nordic Bourse Plan
abstract: The industry federations of the four main Scandinavian countries have proposed that companies in Sweden, Norway, Denmark and Finland be listed on each others' stock exchanges, the Swedish federation said today. A joint report, which is being considered by the four governments, said the idea is to increase regional cooperation and widen markets for Scandinavian companies.

headline: Stocks Climb; Dow Up 3.58
abstract: Increased institutional buying sent stock prices moderately higher yesterday with the biggest price moves posted by issues responding to specific news developments.   The Dow Jones industrial average, which was in the plus column throughout the session, closed up 3.58 points, to 907.19, after being ahead 9.29 points at 2 P.M. The late weakness was attributed to profit taking.   Turnover on the New York Stock Exchange climbed to 69.8 million shares from 55.7 million shares on Monday. A total of 1,257 blocks of 10,000 shares or more changed hands yesterday, compared with 988 the day before.

headline: A European Steel Fine
abstract: The European Economic Community's executive commission will fine Klockner-Werke, a West German steelmaker, up to $19.5 million for exceeding its production quota in the third quarter of 1981, a commission spokesman said today.

headline: ISRAELIS TO DISCUSS RULE SHIFT WITH ARAB SCHOOL PERSONNEL
abstract: The chief of the Israeli adminstration in the occupied West Bank will meet with officials of Arab universities on Wednesday to discuss a change that is intended to end protests over the special work permits that have been required for foreign teachers. Whether it will be acceptable to the protesters was not clear.   The Israeli Defense Ministry announced on Sunday that foreigners teaching in West Bank institutions would no longer be required to sign an oath that they would not support the Palestine Liberation Organization. The oath had been denounced by opponents as politically biased and an introduction of politics into education. About 20 foreigners have been dismissed for refusing to sign.

headline: Investigation Of Columbia
abstract: A special district attorney's unit set up four years ago after a scandal involving Columbia Pictures is investigating possible embezzlement at the 20th Century-Fox Film Corporation.   ''The task force is looking into possible misappropriation and embezzlement of funds,'' Al Albergate, a spokesman for the district attorney, said today.

headline: FEW NEW PROMISES IN PACT WITH U.S., EUROPEANS CONTEND
abstract: The agreement on East-West trade that President Reagan linked to the lifting of the Soviet gas pipeline sanctions represents little in terms of new commitments by the United States' main European allies, Western European officials said tonight.   With one apparent exception, an undertaking not to sign or approve new contracts for the purchase of Soviet natural gas while a series of studies are under way, the agreement covers areas where attempts have been made for years to coordinate Western policy.   The undertaking was reported to involve no major European concessions, and the announcement of the end to sanctions was welcomed in West Germany, Britain and Italy, three of the four countries principally affected. France Shuns Agreement   The French Foreign Ministry noted the lifting of the measures, but said France ''is not a party to the agreement announced this afternoon in Washington.''

headline: News Analysis
abstract: Negotiations between Israel and Lebanon start Tuesday in an atmosphere of uncertainty about the ability and willingness of President Amin Gemayel to reach an accord on Israel's major demands for security arrangements and normalization of relations.   Despite assertions by Israeli officials during the last 10 days that the Beirut Government has endorsed a working paper setting forth Israel's main points, Defense Minister Ariel Sharon is reported to have failed, in a trip to Beirut late last week, to get a Lebanese signature on the document.   And officials here now say that Moslem figures in the Lebanese Government, including Prime Minister Shafik al-Wazzan and others, are resisting key elements of an accord for fear it would damage Lebanese ties with the rest of the Arab world, just at a time when considerable infusions of oil money are needed for economic recovery and reconstruction. Informed officials in Jerusalem expect the talks to take at least two months, and possibly much longer. U.S. Viewed as Dubious   In addition, there is a vague sense in Israeli political circles that the United States is somewhat cool to Israel's desire for an immediate accord on normalization, fearing that it would contribute to further internal strife in Lebanon, which could open opportunities to the Soviet Union for renewed influence there.

headline: SUSPECT IN LAUNDERING MONEY
abstract: By all appearances, Eduardo Orozco-Prada was a very successful coffee importer. He lived on a two-acre estate in an affluent New York suburb, with an indoor swimming pool in a half-million-dollar home. From offices on Wall Street, Mr. Orozco owned or controlled numerous companies and had accounts in some of New York's biggest banks. Through these accounts and companies, Mr. Orozco, his brother and other associates moved tens of mil Last of two articles. lions of dollars in cash, say Federal authorities, whose curiosity was piqued by the large money flow. Was the 43-year-old Mr. Orozco a terrific exporter-importer, investigators asked, or was his wealth primarily from another source - money laundering?

headline: Former Guerrilla Leader Sworn as Chad President
abstract: A former guerrilla leader was sworn in as President of Chad today, four months after his rebel army took control of this battered capital.   Speaking at the ceremony, the new President, Hissen Habre, appealed to his four million constituents to unite and bring 17 years of civil war to an end.   Chad's civil service disintegrated during the war, and its various regions became virtual fiefdoms. Mr. Habre, who is about 40 years old, entered Ndjamena at the head of his forces on June 7, toppling the provisional government of Goukouni Oueddei.

headline: China Mountain Road Opens
abstract: China's first highway through the Tianshan range of the remote northwest Xinjiang region has opened to traffic, cutting 620 miles from the old route, People's Daily reported today.

headline: WORKERS CLOSE ISRAELI AIRPORT
abstract: Employees of El Al Israel Airlines forced the closing of Ben-Gurion International Airport today by blocking the runways with three jetliners. They were protesting the Government's decision, made Sunday, to liquidate El Al unless the work force accepted a reorganization involving big staff cuts.

headline: Kuwait Puts Damper On Holiday Festivities
abstract: Kuwait today banned parties to celebrate Christmas or the New Year in hotels, clubs or public places and Interior Ministry sources said offenders would be punished.

headline: REAGAN AIDE FIGHTS CONGRESSIONAL CUTS IN NATO
abstract: The Reagan Administration said today that the adoption by Congress of pending legislation to reduce the American role in the North Atlantic Treaty Organization would be a blow to United States and allied security.   Testifying before the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, Lawrence S. Eagleburger, Under Secretary of State for Political Affairs, said that refusing to raise the number of American troops in Europe and reducing the money for modernizing the allied nuclear forces would raise doubts in Western Europe and in the Soviet Union about the American commitment to the alliance and lead to speculation about ''a more general American retreat from Europe.''   Mr. Eagleburger filled in for Secretary of State George P. Shultz who left Washington with President Reagan on a trip to Latin America. But Mr. Shultz, through a spokesman, said that Mr. Eagleburger was reflecting his own concerns as well.

headline: Market Place; Winnebago's New Outlook
abstract: BEFORE the energy crisis slowed sales of its fuel-thirsty motor homes, Winnebago Industries made some investor-employees rich in its hometown of Forest City, Iowa.   For example, a $1,250 investment in 100 shares of Winnebago in 1966 had mushroomed into 32,000 shares worth $1.5 million in 1972. But that was the year the stock plunged - from 48 to 20. The following year, the shares plummeted all the way to 2 7/8, and some Winnebago paper millionaires rejoined the proletariat.

headline: Israeli Professors Strike
abstract: Israel's state-owned universities were closed today as the professors' union began its third two-day strike in a month to demand salary increases.

headline: 10,000 Rwandans in Uganda To Leave After Being Evicted
abstract: Ten thousand Rwandan refugees have chosen to leave Uganda for Rwanda or Tanzania rather than obey a Ugandan order to move into two overcrowded refugee camps, a United Nations official said by telephone from Kampala today.   Tom Unwin, representative of the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees in Uganda, had earlier protested to the Ugandan Government about the order.   He said tens of thousands of Rwandans had been evicted from their homes in the Ankole district of southwestern Uganda and were being forced to enter two refugee camps already overcrowded with about 27,000 Rwandans.

headline: DOW OFF 9.20, TO 1,018.76, REVERSING EARLIER RISE
abstract: The Dow Jones industrial average fell yesterday for the third consecutive session, bringing the decline for the week to 12.60 points, as concern over the economy plus unexpected weakness in the video game stocks continued to depress prices.   The blue-chip barometer, which was ahead more than 6 points at 11 A.M. yesterday, fell 9.20 points, to 1,018.76, as selling pressure intensified in the last 90 minutes of trading.   In the overall market, declining issues on the New York Stock Exchange outnumbered gainers by 976 to 613. Volume on the Big Board fell to 86.4 million shares, from 90.3 million.

headline: Upper Volta Broadcast Names Coup Leaders
abstract: The new rulers of the West African country of Upper Volta were identified tonight, 48 hours after a coup toppled the military Government of Col. Saye Zerbo.   There was still no word on the fate of Colonel Zerbo, a former paratrooper with the French forces, who took power in a bloodless military coup two years ago.

headline: TRADE CONFERENCE IN GENEVA DIVIDED OVER BASIC ISSUES
abstract: An 88-nation trade conference here was extended tonight into an unexpected fifth day as participants sought to overcome deep divisions over how to shore up the world trading system. ''We are making progress, but work needs to be done,'' said Gerald Regan, Canada's Trade Minister.   A failure to conclude fundamental agreements is widely expected to heighten dangers of economic nationalism and protectionism.  The four-day conference of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, more than 18 months in preparation, had been called expressly to check the protectionism that has been set off by the worldwide recession and rising unemployment in most countries.

headline: Zapata's President Adding Chief's Post
abstract: Ronald C. Lassiter, president and chief operating officer of the Zapata Corporation, will add the duties of chief executive officer on Jan. 1.   Mr. Lassiter, 50 years old, will succeed B. John Mackin, 65, who will continue as chairman and chairman of the board's executive committee.   Zapata, based in Houston, operates 23 offshore drilling rigs under contract to oil companies and participates in exploration and develoment activities. It also operates a fleet of 78 supply vessels and is in the fishing industry with a 47-vessel fleet for anchovies and menhaden.

headline: Nepal Enters the Space Age
abstract: The son of King Birendra of Nepal spoke with Prince Charles of Britain today through a communication satellite earth station linking Nepal with the outside world. Britain provided about $1.2 million to help build the station, which replaces the high frequency radio system used since 1964.

headline: I.B.M. Introduces Document System
abstract: The International Business Machines Corporation introduced a computer terminal designed to transmit and store images of documents electronically.

headline: TEXAS ENERGIES CO reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: DOW POSTS 13.98 GAIN, TO 1,005.70
abstract: Stocks rallied yesterday in response to climbing bond prices and growing sentiment on Wall Street that Republican candidates would not fare as badly in today's elections as forecasters had expected last week.   The Dow Jones industrial average, which had been ahead less than a point at noon, finished at 1,005.70, up 13.98 points. This was a reversal of last week's performance, when the Dow tumbled nearly 40 points in its largest weekly loss since March 1980.   ''The feeling in the marketplace today was that the Republicans would retain control of the Senate while losing perhaps 12 to 15 House seats - or far less than recent expectations,'' said William M. LeFevre of Purcell, Graham & Company. ''This would lead to less dissension in Congress and some fine-tuning of President Reagan's programs.''

headline: News Analysis
abstract: In retrospect, the most predictable aspect of the transition after Leonid I. Brezhnev's death should have been the puzzles and mysteries surrounding the new leader. The Soviet Union has always been compulsive about secrecy, and Yuri V. Andropov had come in from 15 years in the state security service.   His first round of political appointments and speeches did provide some tantalizing clues about his style and blueprint for the future, but often they raised as many questions as they answered.   How a career officer of the security police in the small Transcaucasian republic of Azerbaijan became a prospective Prime Minister of the Soviet Union, why the position of Soviet President remains vacant and what shape Mr. Andropov's ruling Politburo will take were questions to which the public record could provide only fragmentary hints.

headline: WHAT'S NEW IN ORGANIZATIONAL PSYCHOLOGY; ETIQUETTE OF THE BOARDROOM
abstract: If you want to serve on a company's board of directors, don't ask what the job pays. When one well-known public figure did just that, he was disqualified from further consideration, according to two researchers at the University of Chicago's Graduate School of Business who recently studied the do's and don't's, truths and myths, of the corporate board room.  For their study, Paul M. Hirsch, an associate professor of sociology, and Thomas L. Whisler, professor of business policy, talked with 75 directors of large companies. Because women directors with experience in business are much in demand but short in supply, all but a handful of the directors studied were men.

headline: DANISH CONSERVATIVES PROMISE AUSTERITY
abstract: Denmark's new Prime Minister, the conservative Poul Schlueter, today presented austerity measures to revive the country's debt-ridden economy.   Speaking at the opening of the Parliament, Mr. Schlueter said his four-party coalition would present legislative program aimed at cutting public spending and expanding state revenues by $7.2 billion over two years.

headline: Your Money; Smaller Effect Of Deductibles
abstract: THE advantages of insurance deductibles, used by many high-income and not-so-high-income taxpayers to reduce their premium costs, will be limited next year as a result of two sections of the 1982 tax law.    A deductible in the insurance business is a provision requiring the policyholder to absorb losses up to an agreed-upon amount. Insurance companies charge less for policies with deductibles because they do not have to handle so many small claims.   This year's Tax Equity and Fiscal Responsibility Act took on two individual deductible areas, personal casualty and theft losses and medical expenses. In both cases, the Government will share less of this cost and more tax dollars will thereby go to Washington.

headline: Searle Appoints Head Of Its Sweetener Group
abstract: G.D. Searle & Company of Chicago has announced plans to form a separate business group to manage its Nutrasweet low-calorie sweetener and has named Robert B. Shapiro to head it.   The formation of the group, scheduled for Dec. 1, ''shows we take this market very, very seriously,'' said Mr. Shapiro, who has been serving as vice president and general counsel at Searle. ''This could be our fast-growing product during the next several years.''

headline: Careers; Air Force Attractive In a Slump
abstract: THERE is one big business so little affected by the recession that it is still hiring - the Air Force. Brig. Gen. Scott Harpe, 45 years old, a flier who is commander of the Air Force Recruiting Service, says, ''The recession has had a good impact on our recruiting.'' In an interview, he said that not only have more men and women applied to the services but the quality of applicants has also improved.  General Harpe has 4,000 people in his recruiting unit worldwide.   ''I also have noticed a change in attitude,'' he said. ''There is a more patriotic feeling than 10 years ago, when it was not so popular to talk about patriotism. It's a much more favorable environment for us. When things get tough we have real attraction.''

headline: E.E.C. Inflation Data
abstract: Inflation in the European Economic Community continued its downward trend last month, with price rises slowing to an annual 10.3 percent, rate, compared with 10.7 percent in the 1981 month, the E.E.C. statistics office said today.

headline: MALONE & HYDE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 18
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: SALVADOR REBEL LEADER QUESTIONS U.S. MOTIVES
abstract: The leader of the political arm of the Salvadoran guerrilla movement has described as ''artificial smoke'' reports that the Salvadoran Government, with American encouragement, is making efforts to establish contact with the rebels.   In an interview in New York this week, Guillermo Manuel Ungo, head of the Democratic Revolutionary Front, said a negotiated political settlement was the only ''viable alternative'' to the war and he predicted that peace would come in 10 to 20 months.   He added, however, that ''the American Administration has been talking about talks, but not making any concrete steps toward them.'' The intention of the United States and Salvadoran Governments, Mr.  Ungo said, was ''to appease public opinion by giving the impression you are having talks.''

headline: BRISTOL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Farmers' Prices Up By 0.9%
abstract: Prices farmers get for raw products rose nine-tenths of 1 percent in November but did not make up ground lost in a sharp decline the month before, the Agriculture Department said today.   Further, according to records of the department, the increase failed to budge the historic ''parity'' ratio from its lowest reading since the depths of the Depression.

headline: Metropolitan Savings
abstract: The Metropolitan Savings Bank, New York, and the First City Federal Savings and Loan Association of Bradenton, Fla., have agreed in principle to merge. Metropolitan's chairman, Luke A. Baione, said his institution, which has assets of $5.9 billion, would acquire all First City Federal's shares outstanding at $40 each, or a total of $33.5 million. First City Federal has $762 million in assets and has 20 offices on Florida's west coast.

headline: DICKENSON MINES LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: FREE DEMOCRATS AND GREENS LOSE GROUND IN BAVARIA ELECTIONS
abstract: The Free Democratic Party was eliminated from the legislature in the southern state of Bavaria today as Franz Josef Strauss's conservative Christian Social Union scored a convincing victory in local elections.   In the first test of opinion since the selection of Chancellor Helmut Kohl 10 days ago, his national Free Democrat coalition partners continued the downward slide in popularity that had encouraged them to desert Helmut Schmidt's Social Democratic-led Government last month.   But the radical Green antinuclear protest movement, which appears to have displaced the Free Democrats as West Germany's third party, failed to win the 5 percent of the popular vote that would have gained it representation in the 204-member Bavarian assembly.   According to official results, Mr. Strauss's Christian Social Union, the Bavarian branch of the Christian Democrats, took 58.3 percent of the vote, or 133 seats; the Social Democrats, 31.9 percent, or 71 seats; the Greens, 4.6 percent, and the Free Democrats, 3.5 percent.

headline: Boeing Seeks Sale Of Planes to Libya
abstract: The Boeing Company is asking the Federal Government for permission to sell as many as 12 jet airliners to Libya for the state airline, a company spokesman said.

headline: AN EXPERIENCED BUT CONTROVERSIAL MANAGER
abstract: The selection of Donald Paul Hodel as the new Energy Secretary has put the department for the first time under the leadership of an energy specialist with long experience. Nonetheless, Mr.   Hodel, a 47-year-old from Oregon, is not likely to feel entirely comfortable, since President Reagan long ago proposed that the department be abolished and its pieces transferred to other arms of Government.   In addition, environmental groups have worked actively to prevent Mr. Hodel's appointment. They regard as hostile the views he expressed as No.2 man to Secretary James G. Watt at the Department of the Interior.

headline: 40,000 MEN IS THE ULTIMATE GOAL
abstract: The Reagan Administration said today that it had agreed to rebuild and train the Lebanese Army over the next year so that it can eventually maintain the internal security of the country with some 28,000 light infantry forces and another 12,000 troops in support.   Deputy Secretary of State Kenneth W. Dam, in a speech in Chicago tonight, said the American and Lebanese goal was to provide equipment and training to the Lebanese so that they have four brigades by February and seven brigades later in the year.   Pentagon officials said that a Lebanese brigade consists of about 4,000 soldiers. Currently, he said, the Lebanese Army has four brigades, but only about half of the soldiers are at any given time prepared for action. The goal, they said, is to bring them quickly to 75 percent effectiveness and later to as close to 100 percent as possible. There are about 20,000 men in the Lebanese Army, officials said, and the goal is to bring it to 40,000 by 1984.

headline: Business and the Law; State Controls On Takeovers
abstract: ILLINOIS might be defeated in its efforts to control corporate takeovers, but there is apparently no stopping Ohio. In June, the United States Supreme Court struck down an Illinois state law regulating corporate takeovers. Under that law, tender offers for companies in which 10 percent or more of the shares was owned by Illinois residents were subject to a waiting period and had to be registered with state officials so they could judge their fairness.   In the transaction that led to the High Court decision, the MITE Corporation, a Delaware corporation with headquarters in Connecticut, made a tender offer for the Chicago Rivet and Machine Corporation without registering with Illinois officials.

headline: CHAMPION INTERNATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Midway President Led New York Air
abstract: Midway Airlines of Chicago said yesterday that it had named Neal F. Meehan, former president and chief executive officer of New York Air, as Midway's president and chief operating officer.   Mr. Meehan, 41 years old, succeeds Gordon Linkon, who was forced to resign in July over differences in marketing strategy with the board.   ''My role will be to complement Arthur Bass, who will handle the marketing strategy,'' Mr. Meehan said. ''My job will be to make the strategy work.'' Mr. Bass, Midway's chairman and chief executive, joined the airline in August from Federal Express, where he was president.

headline: VOTE SEEN AS MILD SETBACK TO GREEK SOCIALISTS
abstract: The Socialist Government of Prime Minister Andreas Papandreou enters its second year this week after receiving a mild setback in municipal elections last Sunday.   Although the elections were of a local nature, the results were generally regarded as the first gauge of the public's opinion of Mr.  Papandreou's Panhellenic Socialist Movement since its landslide victory in the parliamentary elections of Oct. 18, 1981, on a program of sweeping change. It took national office three days later, ending decades of conservative rule.   Although most results last Sunday were inconclusive, requiring runoffs wherever lead candidates failed to poll 51 percent of the vote, it was the kind of election in which almost everybody could claim victory, and did loudly.

headline: EXCERPTS FROM SPEECH BY GROMYKO
abstract: Following are excerpts from a speech today by Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko of the Soviet Union to the General Assembly, as translated by the Soviet Mission:   A session of the United Nations General Assembly is a unique opportunity to review the international reality in all its diversity and to sense more profoundly what is of greatest concern to people on different continents. And one becomes convinced once again that of the multitude of problems in today's world the main problem, the one that stands out, is that of averting the threat of nuclear war.   Virtually everyone agrees that world developments have been evolving in an alarming way. People are asking themselves whether the insane arms race can be halted and the slipping toward the abyss prevented.   Those are legitimate questions. The Soviet Union is adamantly convinced that peace, which is the greatest universal value, can and must be preserved. And it must be a just peace.

headline: Angola Reported Ready To Meet South Africa
abstract: Angolan and South African Government representatives are expected to meet today on neutral ground for direct talks after seven years of undeclared war, official Cape Verdean sources said.

headline: 2 Chilean Unionists Exiled
abstract: Two labor leaders were exiled today after a demonstration yesterday, according to the Interior Minister, General Enrique Montero. He said Manuel Bustos and Hector Cuevas had violated a law banning street demonstrations and were put on separate flights out of Chile to undisclosed destinations.

headline: GREECE SHOWS ANTI-U.S. BIAS WITHOUT ZEST
abstract: As United States military personnel enter the Hellenikon Air Base near here, they pass by huge banners at the entrance reading, ''Yankees Go Home.''   Similar sentiments were seen in an election last month in the coastal suburb of Glyphada, the site of the base. In that election, a pro-American Mayor was ousted after 19 years in office and was replaced by a member of the pro-Soviet Greek Communist Party.   In addition, the future of the American bases in Greece is being negotiated by American and Greek representatives.  Nevertheless, most American military personnel apparently believe they are here to stay. They feel that anti-Americanism has declined considerably and is not likely to return to the levels it reached during the 1974 Turkish invasion of Cyprus and the collapse of the rule of the colonels, who were seen here as American backed.

headline: THURSDAY, DECEMBER 9, 1982; Companies
abstract: The overseas communications market was opened up to competiton by the F.C.C. The move clears the way for companies to compete with A.T.& T. abroad just as companies like MCI now do in the U.S.  longdistance market. The agency also voted to allow A.T.& T. to start offering data and message services such as telex. (Page D1.)   The head of Atari's video game division was relieved of his duties, and the parent company, Warner Communications, said its 1982 earnings will be well below previous expectations. (D1.)

headline: British Production Off
abstract: The output of all British industries fell four-tenths of 1 percent in October from the month before, the Central Statistical Office reported today.

headline: 5 Die in Sri Lanka In Raid by Rebels
abstract: Three policemen and two civilians were killed today when secessionist guerrillas attacked a police station in Sri Lanka's northern Jaffna Peninsula, the police said.

headline: Irvine Resignation
abstract: Peter Kremer has resigned as president of the Irvine Company, a development concern and one of the largest landowners in southern California.

headline: Hunger Striker Arrives In Paris From Moscow
abstract: The daughter of a Soviet general who participated in a 33-day hunger strike last summer in an attempt to win permission to emigrate arrived in Paris today, her husband reported. They have not seen each other since 1976.

headline: WHITE HOUSE CONFIRMS REAGAN PLANS A LATIN TRIP
abstract: President Reagan is planning to visit Brazil, Colombia and Costa Rica in December, the White House announced this evening.   The five-day trip, for which Mr. Reagan will leave Nov. 30, was described by a White House official as ''an expression of the President's continuing interest in Latin America.''   The White House announcement was made after Brazilian newspapers had carried a report about a recent telephone call from Mr. Reagan to President Joao Baptista Figueiredo, who had extended an invitation to President Reagan.

headline: HARRODS SPINOFF FROM HOUSE OF FRASER EXPECTED
abstract: Lonhro Ltd., the mining conglomerate that controls 30 percent of the House of Fraser, the retailing giant, is expected to announce on Friday shareholder approval of its motion to spin off the renowned Harrods of Knightsbridge from Fraser, spokesmen for both companies said today.   The plan was narrowly defeated today at a special shareholders meeting called by Lonhro, which is led by Roland Rowland. In a show of hands, 24 were opposed and 18 in favor. But because the turnout was not considered representative of Fraser's 30,000 shareholders, Lonhro will recalculate the vote on the basis of proxy material submitted within the past week by Fraser shareholders, as well as today's vote. The outcome will be announced Friday morning, the spokesmen said.

headline: No Headline
abstract: TEXT OF LETTER FROM REAGAN   WASHINGTON, Nov. 11 (AP) - Following is the text of a letter President Reagan sent today to Vasily V. Kuznetsov, the First Vice President of the Soviet Union, on the death of Leonid I. Brezhnev:   WASHINGTON, Nov. 11 (AP) - Following is the text of a letter President Reagan sent today to Vasily V. Kuznetsov, the First Vice President of the Soviet Union, on the death of Leonid I. Brezhnev:   Please accept my condolences on the death of President Leonid Ilyich Brezhnev. President Brezhnev was one of the world's most important figures for nearly two decades.

headline: Nashua Violation
abstract: The Nashua Corporation said that, as a result of previously reported losses, it is in technical violation of covenants in bank loan agreements made earlier this year, and that it expects directors to suspend dividend payments.

headline: POLAND MAKES THE DATE OFFICIAL: DEC. 31
abstract: The Council of State, Poland's collective presidency, formally announced tonight that, as promised, martial law will be ''suspended'' on Dec. 31.   The announcement was in the form of a two-paragraph statement by Henryk Jablonski, head of the council, that cited Government-approved legislation passed Saturday by Parliament. That legislation, which amends the civil and criminal code, empowered the Government to suspend - or reimpose - martial law.

headline: BONN AND PARIS TO SEEK A COMMON MILITARY POLICY
abstract: President Francois Mitterrand said today that France was taking steps to consult with West Germany about nuclear strategy and that the two countries had decided to seek a common military doctrine in Western Europe.   At a news conference on the second day of their talks, Chancellor Helmut Kohl and President Mitterrand announced the formation of a coordinating committee of their foreign and defense ministries that will meet between the heads of state conferences that take place every six months.   ''Questions of security policy took up a very large part of our talks,'' Mr. Kohl said in a statement. ''We have, for the first time in 19 years, activated an agreement of the French-German friendship treaty which explicitly points to the development of a common security policy.''

headline: SOUTHEASTERN PUBLIC SERVICE CO reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: BRAZIL'S BIGGEST BANK SAID TO GET BAILOUT CREDIT IN U.S.
abstract: Brazil's biggest bank, the Government-owned Banco do Brasil, was unable to meet more than $175 million in foreign exchange commitments last week and was rescued from default only by the intervention of several major New York banks, banking sources said last night.   The bank, which is majority owned by the Brazilian Government and is Brazil's primary institution for financing the country's international trade, had essentially run out of dollars to meet prior commitments, the sources said. It was said to have been saved from defaulting on these commitments when the American banks stepped in and provided the bank's New York agency with the funds that it needed.   Among those participating in the credit, put together at a special meeting at the New York Federal Reserve Bank, were Morgan Guaranty, Chase Manhattan, Citibank, Banker's Trust and Manufacturers Hanover, the sources said. Terms or duration of the bailout package were not immediately available.

headline: CHINA ENERGY: CHANCE FOR U.S.
abstract: China's plans to double its energy output by the end of the century to sustain its modernization drive provide the most substantial potential here yet for American business.   Ventures in oil, coal and hydropower are moving American investment into a new phase that could provide a substantial base not just for bilateral trade, but also for the broader Chinese-American relationship, which has been buffeted by disagreements over the status of Taiwan.   While Peking has shifted politically toward a position of equidistance between Washington and Moscow, it continues to look to the United States for technology that the Soviet Union does not have. Last year, China's trade with the United States ran $5.5 billion, about 25 times larger than China's trade with the Soviet Union.

headline: IRAN IS SAID TO GET NORTH KOREA ARMS
abstract: North Korea has become the leading supplier of arms to Iran in an arrangement that has helped Iran finance its continuing war with Iraq, according to a high-ranking American defense official.   The official, Francis J. West, Assistant Secretary of Defense for Intern@ational Security Affairs, said Iran had been paying North Korea partly in cash and partly in oil.   Military analysts, who provided details at Mr. West's request, said North Korea had provided about 40 percent of the approximately $2 billion worth of weapons, ammunition and equipment Iran acquired abroad this year. Ignoring OPEC Guidelines   To pay for the arms imports, oil industry analysts said, Iran has increased its oil production beyond the limits set by the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries. They said it had also cut prices below those of OPEC and established the guns-for-oil bartering arrangement with North Korea. North Korea has maintained good relations with Moscow and with Peking and has accepted military aid from both. North Korea, according to Andrew J. Pierre in his book, ''The Global Politics of Arms Sales,'' has ''received assistance from Moscow in developing co-production and assembly plants for weapons, especially artillery pieces.''

headline: SOUTH AFRICA MOVES AGAINST A 'MIXED' SCHOOL
abstract: The South African Government has decided to spend nearly half a million dollars to build an extra primary school for a northern town, ending a 50-year tradition of allowing Indian and mixed-race children to be educated together.   The town, Vryburg in northern Cape Province, is one of many small places where complete separation of races has not taken place because either their Indians or coloreds, as mixed-race people are known, have not been considered numerous enough to justify the expense of separate schools. These communities, however, have separate schools for whites and blacks.

abstract: The El Paso Company said it expected to reduce its 1983 capital spending to $317 million from more than $700 million this year.

headline: A Major Japanese Newspaper Offers New Service in English
abstract: A major Japanese newspaper, Asahi Shimbun, has established a news service that offers articles in English focusing on Japan and Southeast Asia.   Selected major articles from the organization, the Asahi News Service, will be made available to overseas and United States clients of The New York Times News Service.

headline: OIL BLOWOUT IS SOWING FEAR IN ALBERTA BACKWOODS
abstract: The scene was a cozy mobile home with homilies to Mom, Dad and assorted virtues hanging on the wall. A half-dozen residents of this backwoods village of 65 were sitting around the kitchen table, drinking coffee and talking about unpleasant things.   Clifford Whitelock, a farmer, said his cattle had begun to abort their calves. David Nichols, who works in a natural gas processing plant, told of watching a pet rabbit stagger aimlessly around one evening and then finding the animal dead the next morning. Margaret Grinde said her asthmatic husband had gone through more pills and medicinal sprays in the last seven weeks than he had used for years.  All at the table, it seemed, have been beset recently with headaches, nosebleeds and upset stomachs.

headline: U.S. OFFICIAL DEFENDS POLICY ON CUBANS IN ANGOLA
abstract: A senior State Department official contended today that the United States was politically realistic in seeking simultaneous accords on the departure of Cuban troops from Angola and on independence for South-West Africa, the disputed territory also known as Namibia.   The official said that a historic opportunity now existed to solve the two issues, the presence of 15,000 Cuban soldiers in Angola and South Africa's continuing occupation of Namibia.   On Tuesday, Angola's Foreign Minister, Paulo Jorge, accused the United States of ''suffering a kind of paranoia'' over the Cuban troops.

headline: RUBIK'S CUBE: A CRAZE ENDS
abstract: It was just two years ago that Rubik's Cube, the maddening, Mondrian-colored brainchild of a Hungarian architecture teacher, hit the American market in force.   By last June, the Ideal Toy Company had sold 30 million cubes worldwide for $5 to $10 each; imitators had unleashed millions more under names like Magic Puzzler and Le Cube. By any name, one thing was certain: The Cube had become a national obsession.   But the craze has died. Street corner merchants hawk ''E.T.'' paraphernalia now, and electronic video games have taken over toy store shelves. Even Rubik's most enthusiastic proponents admit the cube has become passe.

headline: REAGAN DENOUNCES THREATS TO PEACE IN LATIN AMERICA
abstract: President Reagan concluded his Latin American trip with a speech in Costa Rica Saturday in which he called for an end to ''foreign support for terrorists and subversive elements'' in Central America. He also met in Honduras with the leaders of that country and Guatemala, to whom he pledged support.   Then, on the flight back to Washington aboard Air Force One, Mr.  Reagan made the unexpected statement that he was leaning toward approval of a military aid package to Guatemala because material he received from Gen. Efrain Rios Montt led him to believe that charges of widespread human rights abuses had been ''a bum rap.''   ''I very frankly think that they've been getting a bad deal,'' Mr.  Reagan said, noting that General Rios Montt had been elected President of Guatemala years ago but had never been allowed to assume office. ''He is totally dedicated to democracy in Guatemala,'' he said.

headline: Advertising; New Focus For Legal Magazines
abstract: WHAT occupational group can note that 43 percent of its largely male membership owns 10 or more suits each, has an average household income in the $100,000 range and is the target of advertising for such automobiles as Rolls-Royce, BMW and Mercedes?   No, not the nation's healers. This time we are talking about lawyers.  Only in recent times have the publications written for them come to realize that their readers - whose professional needs have long attracted a certain category of advertiser - also comprise a virtually recession-proof target group for upscale consumer advertising.

headline: Iraq Contends Iranians Were Again Repulsed
abstract: Iraq said today that Iranian troops had made another attempt to cross into Iraqi territory but had again been repulsed. The attackers, a communique said, were wiped out.

headline: Spending Cut By Brazil
abstract: The Government today announced spending cuts aimed at complying with International Monetary Fund guidelines for easing Brazil's financial crisis.   Akihiro Ikeda, special secretary for economic affairs in the Ministry of Planning, said he considered the spending plans to be ''very austere.''

headline: News Analysis
abstract: With his election season address on the economy tonight, President Reagan went further than he has in the past in acknowledging that unemployment - not inflation - had become the No.1 problem facing his Administration and the No.1 worry afflicting voters.  In almost all his recent speeches on behalf of political candidates around the country, Mr. Reagan has concentrated on arguing that his policies have brought inflation and interest rates down.   This was part of a conscious strategy devised by aides convinced that the 99 million Americans who have jobs would be impressed by the improvement in the ''purchasing power'' of their dollar and relatively untroubled because others were without jobs.   In many of these speeches, Mr. Reagan has spoken of unemployment almost as an afterthought, following a litany of economic pluses that have come the way of most Americans.

headline: POLAND TO MINT COINS BEARING POPE'S FACE
abstract: The Polish Government, eager to rebuild its depleted reserves of foreign exchange, has decided to mint some $20 million of gold and silver coins stamped with the face of Pope John Paul II.   The coins are to be marketed worldwide at a substantial but as yet undetermined premium over their metallic content by Italcambio, a company in Milan that has recently signed the distribution agreement, according to Kenneth M. Crosby, a former Merrill Lynch International executive who is now a Washington consultant and was involved in the transaction.   Mr. Crosby said the idea was that of Ellen Jacobsen, a New York public relations consultant who has worked on it with the Polish authorities over the last three and a half years.

headline: PRESIDENT'S COST PANEL UNDER FIRE
abstract: Representative William D. Ford, chairman of the House Post Office Committee, said today that President Reagan's advisory committee on reducing the cost of government was deliberately organized to avoid the conflict-of-interest requirements of Federal law.   The allegation by Mr. Ford, a Democrat from Michigan, was based on his reading of an interim report by the General Accounting Office, the investigative arm of Congress. Its report described the organization and procedures of the Presidential panel, known as the Grace Commission, but drew few conclusions.

headline: Auto Stockpiles Cut
abstract: The five United States automobile makers trimmed their inventories to an average 70-day supply at the end of September from an 88-day stockpile just a month earlier, an industry trade journal said today. Ward's Automotive Reports attributed the decrease to temporary plant closings, sales incentives and price reductions.

headline: Duke of Energy
abstract: The Duke of Energy Corporation, a diversified holding company with three data-processing subsidiaries, said that it had signed a letter of intent to acquire Terminals Unlimited for 3.53 million shares of Duke in a transaction valued at $21 million. Terminals Unlimited is a computer sales and service company based in Falls Church, Va. Duke of Energy will relocate its corporate headquarters on Jan.1 from Cushing, Okla., to Dallas.

headline: New York Phone Appoints Chairman
abstract: Delbert C. Staley, president and chief executive of the New York Telephone Company, will move up Feb.1 to become chairman, a post that has been vacant for several years, the company said yesterday. Mr.  Staley, 59 years old, retains the title of chief executive, but not that of president.   William C. Ferguson, 52, executive vice president of Michigan Bell, has been asked to be New York Telephone's president and chief operating officer, a job that will give him most of the day-to-day responsibility for operating New York Telephone.   Mr. Staley has already been designated as chief executive of the proposed Northeast Region Holding Company, a job that will be taking much of his time after A.T.& T.'s 22 local telephone companies are divested in 1984. The Northeast Region will own New York Telephone and the New England Telephone and Telegraph Company. The other local phone companies will be grouped as subsidiaries in six other regional holding companies.

headline: WHIRLPOOL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Schering Assignments Are Shifted to Warwick
abstract: Warwick Advertising, which earlier this week was one of the agencies mentioned in a Schering-Plough product shuffle, has been picked by the client for additional assignments.   From the U.S. Cosmetics division, the agency has been assigned Ultra-Slim lipstick, Brush/Blush brands, Kissing Glosses, Shine and Shape and Cover Stick, all previously handled by the Marschalk Company.   Out of the U.S. Proprietary Drugs and Toiletries division, Warwick was assigned Coppertone Shade sunscreen products and Regutol laxative, both previously at Foote, Cone & Belding, and St. Joseph Aspirin-Free Tablets for Adults, a new product.

headline: FIRST CITY FEDERAL SAVINGS & LOAN ASSN reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Ex-Officer at Warner Begins Trial Testimony
abstract: A former high executive of Warner Communications Inc. testified in Federal court yesterday that he had pleaded guilty to criminal charges and agreed to cooperate with the Government in hopes of receiving a lenient sentence.   The former executive, Jay Emmett, appeared as a key witness in the fraud trial of Warner's assistant treasurer, Solomon Weiss, in Federal District Court in Manhattan.   The 54-year-old witness, wearing a trimly tailored blue suit, testified for less than an hour before the session in the small, crowded courtroom ended for the day. While he did not reach the main issues in the case yesterday, Mr. Emmett will return to the witness stand today, when his testimony is expected to focus on charges that Mr. Weiss participated in a scheme to defraud the company.

headline: U.S. Coal Faces Competitive Challenge
abstract: The United States, the world's biggest coal producer, is running into stiff competition from other exporting countries in its efforts to capture a bigger chunk of the world's coal markets. Depressed economic conditions, which are curbing industrial demand over much of the globe, have added to American producers' problems.   As one example of the stiffening competition for coal sales abroad, Commerce Department and industry sources note, a major, Governmentbacked drive to sell more steam coal to Japan has been hurt by Australian and South African price-cutting: The two countries are selling caol in Japan at prices some $5 a ton below the American landed price, the sources report.   Poland, which had lost export customers as a result of last year's deep economic and social unrest, is selling its coal at prices $7 to $8 a ton below American list prices to recover markets in Scandinavia, Austria, Italy and other points in Western Europe, the same sources reported.

headline: Cairo Confessions Contested
abstract: Lawyers defending Moslem fundamentalists accused of plotting to overthrow the Egyptian Government asked the court today to ignore their clients' confessions, which they said were extracted under torture. The case involves 300 defendants, 20 of whom are still at large.

headline: INVESTORS SNAP UP BELL STOCK
abstract: An underwriting syndicate headed by Morgan Stanley & Company yesterday sold 16.5 million shares of common stock in the American Telephone and Telegraph Company for $990 million.   The entire equity offering - one of the largest in history - was snapped up by investors at the $60-a-share offering price, Morgan Stanley said.   The huge offering of new shares prompted heavy trading of existing A.T.& T. stock on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday. About 1.7 million shares changed hands, and the stock closed at $60, unchanged from Tuesday's close.

headline: Tird article of a series appearing periodically on current world economic problems
abstract: A host of social arrangements have softened the impact of the recession in Western Europe, but Europe's economic troubles are widely regarded as more difficult to resolve than the recession in the rest of the industrialized world.   Although Europe's unemployment rate of 10.3 percent roughly equals that of the United States, the European countries' tightly woven social security systems mean that there is no talk of anyone's going hungry or being turned out into the cold.   In Britain, for instance, the benefits for those who are thrown out of work go far to make up for their lack of a paycheck. A similar structure of organized aid exists in West Germany, at least for workers who had long employment records before being laid off.   At the same time, however, there is deep concern that Europe has fallen so far behind in creating new markets and is so bound to expensive social service mechanisms that it does not have the same capacity as the United States or Japan to lift itself out of the recession.

headline: A Deadline For Braniff
abstract: Pacific Southwest Airlines said it would end talks on a venture with Braniff International unless Braniff signed contracts with four of five unions by Tuesday.   The directors met with Braniff executives to review Braniff's progress with its pilots, flight attendants, flight dispatchers and teamsters' unions.

headline: SWISS WATCH INDUSTRY SLUMP
abstract: If Switzerland's delicate economy has been described as a finely tuned watch, then something seems seriously wrong with what might be called its mainspring.   From one point of view, ''the watchmaking industry is in a fundamentally healthy state,'' as Ulrich Spycher, chairman of Societe Suisse pour l'Industrie Horlogere, the group that makes Omega, Tissot and, in the United States, Hamilton watches, said in a recent interview. Indeed, Swiss watchmakers, in the rugged Jura Mountains, have managed to remain at timekeeping's technological cutting edge, and exclusive houses - like Piaget, Patek Philippe and a dozen others that produce luxury timepieces for the gilded set in New York or Riyadh, Saudi Arabia -are flourishing.   Last year, the industry shipped $2.1 billion worth of watches abroad, more than 90 percent of production, according to Theo Radja, chief economist at the Watch Industry Association here. Their high added value, he said, puts them among Swiss industry's most lucrative foreign exchange earners.

headline: TRYING TO SORT OUT INVESTING IN FIXED ASSETS
abstract: No FIELD OF INVESTING has a monopoly on obfuscatory language, but certainly the market in fixed assets is as saturated with technical terminology as any. With the proliferation of new types of accounts, it has become harder but more important than ever to be able to differentiate between BAN's and RAN's, or tell Ginnie Mae apart from Fannie Mae.  Here, then, is a guide to fixed-income investments, starting with short-term instruments and running through mortgagebacked securities and corporate and tax-exempt bonds to the market in long-term Government bonds. Where possible, current yields have been given to facilitate comparisons between different types of securities. SHORT-TERM FIXED ASSETS   Passbook Account: The lowest common denominator in the fixed-asset market. These accounts are simply deposits at a bank or savings institution that carry a specific interest rate but have no set date of maturity. Currently, commercial banks may pay 5 1/4 percent on savings acounts, while savings institutions may pay 5 1/2 percent.

headline: First National Boston
abstract: The First National Boston Corporation said yesterday that its board had agreed to a plan for First National to acquire the Fall River Trust Company through a stock exchange.

headline: Money Fund Assets Rise
abstract: Assets of the nation's money market mutual funds rose $1.12 billion in the week ended Wednesday, to a record $229.94 billion, the Investment Company Institute reported yesterday. Over the past three weeks, the funds' assets have grown by $5.3 billion.

headline: Franco Bolla's English Debut
abstract: Advertising fans watching ''Falcon Crest'' on CBS-TV tonight will get to hear the first English spoken on television by Franco Bolla, who for the past three years has - through a translator - been spokesman for his family vineyards.

headline: Caffeine-Free Dr Pepper Set
abstract: The Dr Pepper Company entered the decaffeinated soft drink market, announcing it would begin selling a Pepper Free brand next year.   The caffeine-free, sugar-free product was introduced at a meeting of 60 licensed bottlers and will be sold in Texas, California, Oklahoma, Kansas, Arizona and Nevada.   ''Pepper Free answers a need, according to our research, by health-conscious consumers who want a sugarless, decaffeinated Dr Pepper,'' said Robert Hannegan, president of Dr Pepper USA.

headline: THURSDAY, OCTOBER 7, 1982; Markets
abstract: Stock prices soared on expectations of falling interest rates, with institutional investors buying heavily. The Dow Jones industrial average rose 37.07 points, its second-biggest rise ever, to 944.26, its highest level in 14 months. Since mid-August, when rates first began to fall, the Dow has risen almost 160 points. Volume was 93.6 million shares, up from Tuesday's 69.8 million. (Page A1.)   Prices rose and yields fell in the bond market after a drop in the Federal funds rate to 8 3/4 percent, from 10 percent. The Treasury's bellwether 14 percent bond due in 2011 climbed a point, to yield 11.62 percent. (D1.)

headline: CALIFORNIA MICROWAVE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: ULSTER BOMB KILLS THREE POLICEMEN
abstract: Three policemen were killed in Northern Ireland today when a large bomb planted by Irish nationalists exploded under their car.   The bomb, which the police said was made of 1,000 pounds of explosive, left a crater 60 feet wide and 40 feet deep and the blast was heard five miles away, according to reports from the scene. The outlawed Irish Republican Army later said it was responsible.

headline: Guardian Fund Officer Gets a Neuberger Post
abstract: Kent Simons has been named president of Guardian Mutual Fund Inc., succeeding Roy R. Neuberger, 79, the well-known money manager who created the fund in 1950. Mr. Neuberger will remain the fund's chairman.   For Mr. Simons, 47, the title of president means little change in responsibilities: he has been portfolio manager of the $220 million fund since August 1981. In a sense, the appointment is a vote of confidence, since two other managers earlier had tried their hand at the fund. One did not last because he left the company and the other ''had a different style than Roy did,'' Mr. Simons said.

headline: Stock Distribution By Chrysler Corp.
abstract: The Chrysler Corporation said that more than 84,500 American and Canadian hourly and salaried workers each received about 74 shares of company stock for the 1982 year of their employee stock ownership plan.   The common stock, added to about 66 shares that were put into employee accounts in the first year of the plan in 1981, gives each worker about 140 shares worth approximately $2,100, the auto maker said in a statement.

headline: WHEELING-PITTSBURGH STEEL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: DECLINE IN RATES IS EXPECTED TO CONTINUE
abstract: With the Federal Reserve all but advertising an easier credit policy, interest rates are expected to resume their downward trend this week despite the sudden and unnerving disappearance of buyers last Thursday and Friday. Money market specialists became even more convinced of this Friday, after the Fed reported a $6.9 billion jump in the nation's basic money supply for the week ended Oct.6.   Despite the central bank's strenuous efforts to de-emphasize this M-1 figure, which consists of currency in the hands of the public and funds in all types of checking accounts in banks and savings institutions, expectations that the number would be much higher tended to drive many institutional buyers away late in the week. So did the sharp price swings earlier in the week, dealers said.

headline: WHAT DOES STOCK RISE MEAN?
abstract: In hourly radio reports, nightly news broadcasts and column after column of tiny, gray statistics, the stock market news has been flooding the nation: record volume of shares traded, near-record spurts in the stock market averages.   The numbers dwarf anything that has come before. At least on paper, the value of the issues traded in the market has risen some $350 billion in barely three months, as the widely watched Dow Jones industrial average climbed from less than 780 in early August, to 1,036.98 yesterday, spurred by rapidly falling interest rates.   If the market's gain of more than 30 percent in just 10 weeks were not impressive enough, President Reagan has hailed the market as the harbinger of the long-awaited economic recovery. But some analysts, including many business executives, caution against attaching too much weight to the market's performance, or to its significance to most Americans.

headline: Xerox Cuts Prices
abstract: The Xerox Corporation said it had reduced the prices on seven copier models an average of 16.5 percent. The Rochester-based company said the new prices are: the 2350 copier, reduced 8 percent, to $3,295; the 3300-II, 20 percent, to $3,595; the 3300-I, 9 percent, to $4,495; the 3400, 22 percent, to $6,995; the 3450, 20 percent, to $7,995; the 5600, 19 percent, to $29,000, and the 5600 with finisher, 18 percent, to $30,600.

headline: MIG's Are Reinforced On Isle North of Japan
abstract: The Soviet Air Force has deployed new warplanes on a disputed island off the northern Japanese coast in what might be a response to American plans for strengthening the United States Air Force in northern Japan, military sources said today.   The sources said a squadron of 12 delta-wing MIG-21 supersonic fighters landed at the air base on Iturup Island, known in Japan as Etorofu, last week and appeared to be on permanent assignment.

headline: Jos. Schlitz Site
abstract: The Jos. Schlitz Brewing Company is selling its former Milwaukee headquarters to two brothers, Harold and B.J.  Sampson of Milwaukee, who plan to develop the space for industrial and commercial use, the company said.

headline: MEXICO SOFTENS IMPACT OF BANK NATIONALIZATION
abstract: Mexico's new Government moved to soften the impact of the nationalization of the country's private banks last September by announcing plans to sell off 34 percent of the nationalized banks.   The move is expected to stir criticism from leftist and nationalist groups that have pledged to fight any efforts by the one-month-old Government of President Miguel de la Madrid Hurtado to reverse or weaken the state takeover of the banking system.   But the proposal, contained in a bill sent to Congress Monday night, does not contemplate returning shares to the former bank owners. It would offer them for purchase by Federal, state and municipal agencies, bank workers and bank users. No single shareholder would be allowed to own more than 1 percent of the stock in the banks.

abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Japan Steel Exports Dip
abstract: Japan's steel exports in September totaled 2.45 million metric tons, down three-tenths of 1 percent from a year earlier, the Japan Iron and Steel Federation said today. Exports to the United States tumbled 52.3 percent, to 304,000 tons, as a result of weakened demand for pipe and other oilfield products.

headline: WALCO NATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: A CATCH-22 FOR PRETORIA'S BLACKS AND A POSSIBLE OUT
abstract: When the smoke lifted from the 21-gun salute that marked the start of a recent ''summit conference'' here between Prime Minister P.W. Botha and the leaders of four tiny black states that have taken the nominal independence South Africa offers its former tribal reserves, the Government was said to have committed itself to a new development strategy that stressed interdependence rather than separation.   It was not necessary to travel far from the spacious Union Buildings, the seat of the South African Government, where the red carpet had been rolled out for the leaders of the black states, to find a test case for the new approach and for a long-promised development bank that is now supposed to give it practical content.   One of southern Africa's largest squatter colonies, a dense warren of mud block structures with sheet metal roofs, is only about 16 miles and half an hour away, at the edge of a standard black township that is itself separated by several miles from the affluent white suburbs.   Known as Winterveld, the squatter colony houses blacks of uncertain legal status in an area of fewer than 40 square miles: about 120,000 of them, if you accept the official count; three to four times as many, if you go by the estimates of churchmen who have been active in the area.

headline: DeLorean Co.  Fund Inquiry
abstract: The Northern Ireland police are investigating the finances of John Z. DeLorean's bankrupt auto plant in Belfast, the British Government announced today.   The Times of London reported that the receiver, Sir Kenneth Cork, had found evidence of missing funds.

headline: Furniture Makers Await a Recovery
abstract: Furniture makers are waiting for falling interest rates to pull them out of a three-year slide.  The $9 billion-a-year home furniture industry has been hurt by high interest rates and economic stagnation. ''Things are tough - to put it bluntly,'' said Douglas Brackett, vice president of the Southern Furniture Manufacturers Association.

headline: FINANCIAL RETAILING AT SEARS
abstract: Stan Janda of nearby Manassas, Va., walked into the Sears, Roebuck & Company store at the Fair Oaks Mall the other day to return an item. Soon, however, he found himself browsing through racks of literature at the store's financial service center, where employees were selling insurance, stocks and bonds, and homes.   But on that day, all Mr. Janda did was browse. Such is the challenge faced by Sears: Can the world's largest retailer interest its traditional shopper in the financial services on which it has staked so much?

headline: COMPUTER ENTRY SYSTEMS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Canadian Oil Dispute To Be Decided by Court
abstract: Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau and the Premier of Newfoundland have failed to settle their differences over whether the federal Government or the province should have control over at least two billion barrels of oil lying off the Newfoundland coast.   ''There is no deal,'' the Prime Minister said Friday after his brief meeting with Brian Peckford, the Newfoundland Premier whose refusal to accept terms agreed to by other provinces has held up exploitation of the rich fields.

headline: Gromyko Plans Bonn Visit
abstract: Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko of the Soviet Union will pay an official visit to West Germany Jan. 16-18, the Foreign Ministry announced today.
