headline: Ethnic Albanian in Yugoslavia Gets 15-Year Prison Sentence
abstract: Hidajet Hiseni, 28 years old, an ethnic Albanian journalist, was jailed for 15 years today on charges of antistate activities in Kosovo Province, where nine people were killed in ethnic Albanian riots last year.   The sentence was imposed by a court in the provincial capital of Pristina after Mr. Hiseni had admitted leading a clandestine group, ''the Marxist-Leninists of Kosovo.'' The court said the group's aim was to force the secession of Kosovo, an ethnic Albanian autonomous province, from Yugoslavia and amalgamate the province with Albania.

headline: THE ECONOMIST AS PREACHER
abstract: Last week, George J. Stigler, a professor at the University of Chicago Business School, was awarded the 1982 Nobel Memorial Prize for Economic Sciences for his research in the fields of industrial structure and government regulation. The tall, 71-year-old professor, noted among his colleagues for both his sharp wit and his passion for the marketplace, recently completed his 13th book, ''The Economist as Preacher, and Other Essays.'' It will be published in December by the University of Chicago Press. Excerpts from the book follow. ECONOMISTS seldom address ethical questions as they impinge on e conomic theory or economic behavior. They (and I) find the subject c omplex and elusive in comparison with the relative precision and o bjectivity of economic analysis. Of course the ethical questions arei nescapable: One must have goals in judging policies, and these g oals will certainly have ethical content, however well concealed it m ay be. These lectures will explore some of the problems raised by e thical questions, using the history of economics as an important v ehicle in the exploration....

headline: TRIESTE HURT BY YUGOSLAVS' TRAVEL STRICTURES
abstract: Until mid-October this was a city of lively traffic between East and West, but now only an occasional car appears at the border to give immigration and customs officials something to do.   As a result, this city at the head of the Adriatic Sea, once a great marketplace where Yugoslavs by the thousands came daily to buy the consumer goods of the West, bewails a heavy loss of business.  Sadly, Trieste ponders one more blow from history, which has reduced it from being the only - and flourishing - port of the vast Austro-Hungarian empire to a backwater of Italy.   The Yugoslavs stopped coming on Oct. 17, ''black Sunday'' for the extensive retail economy that existed here and in the border town of Gorizia, 26 miles to the north, to satisfy a large consumer market that had money but a limited supply of attractive goods on which to spend it. On that day the Yugoslav Government, owing more than $20 billion to Western creditors, decided to limit the outflow of private money.

headline: Adams Resources
abstract: Adams Resources and Energy Inc. said its creditors had waived until March 31, 1983, the technical default that arose Sept. 30 under its loan agreement.

headline: MERCHANTS BANCORP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: No Headline
abstract: GHANA SAYS IT CRUSHED A COUP   ABIDJAN, Ivory Coast, Nov. 24 (UPI) - The head of Ghana's military Government said today that there had been an attempted coup, but that it had been crushed.   The Ghanaian leader, Flight Lieut. Jerry J. Rawlings, who seized power in a coup on Dec. 31, announced on the Accra radio that ''loyal troops'' had put down a rebellion led by ''misguided individuals.''

headline: A NEW LIBEL LAW STIRS PROTEST BY MEXICO PRESS
abstract: Within days of taking office this month, Mexico's new President, Miguel de la Madrid Hurtado, moved to carry out an ambitious campaign pledge to end corruption and curb abuses of power by the Government.   But the huge package of ''moral renovation'' proposals the President sent to Congress also included a new libel law purportedly aimed at punishing irresponsible journalism. And the resulting protests by newspapers at what they call the gag law has come to overshadow the entire anticorruption debate.   Every day columnists have been denouncing the law as an attack on press freedom. One recent morning, cartoonists in most Mexican newspapers published a blank space to protest the bill. The previous day, journalists held a silent demonstration outside the Senate building where the law was being debated.

headline: PACO PHARMACEUTICAL SERVICES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 28
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: 'LOUSY BUMS' JIBE AT POLES BY REAGAN GETS ON THE RECORD
abstract: An off-the-cuff remark by President Reagan, calling the Polish military Government ''lousy bums,'' became a point of friction over the weekend between White House officials and broadcasters who aired it on nationwide television.   Mr. Reagan, in his regular Saturday radio address, announced that he had canceled Poland's most-favored trade privileges in retaliation for Warsaw's banning of the Solidarity trade union.   In a brief voice test for audio technicians, President Reagan referred to the Polish military Government as ''a bunch of no-good lousy bums.'' Minutes later, in the actual broadcast, he referred to the Warsaw rulers as ''a military dictatorship.''

headline: Genentech Posts a Loss
abstract: Genentech Inc., a San Francisco genetic engineering company, reported a net loss of $1.2 million in the third quarter of 1982, after a profit of $246,000, or 3 cents a share, in the similar period of 1981. Sales for the period rose 15.3 percent, to $7.2 million, from $6.1 million.

headline: Caterpillar Plans 2,000 Layoffs
abstract: The Caterpillar Tractor Company said it would lay off 2,000 nonunion employees because of a strike by the United Automobile Workers union. The company said the layoffs of technical and clerical employees had resulted from a lack of work linked to the strike, which began Oct.1.

headline: Guerrillas in Ulster Threaten New 'Action' Against Troops
abstract: The Irish National Liberation Army, which says it was responsible for the bombing Monday in which 11 British soldiers and five civilians were killed, warned today of possible ''further action without warning'' against British forces in Northern Ireland.   The threat came as three of those killed in the bombing of a discotheque in Ballykelly were buried in ceremonies attended by both Roman Catholics and Protestants.   The National Liberation Army, a Marxist offshoot of the Irish Republican Army, said in a statement, ''If acts of brutality against prisoners in Armagh jail do not cease action will be taken against the present administration without warning.''

headline: BRIEFS
abstract: * Beatrice Foods Co. said it had purchased a majority stake in Winner Food Products Ltd., a Hong Kong producer and distributor of specialty Chinese foods, for a sum it did not disclose.   * Clevepak Corp. said it would discontinue operations at its Still River manufacturing plant in Torrington, Conn., laying off 80 workers.   * Coleco Industries declared a 2-for-1 stock split, payable in the form of a 100 percent stock dividend on Jan. 28 to shareholders of record Dec. 31.

headline: C.N.W. RAIL STAKE PUT AT $76.2 MILLION
abstract: The Interstate Commerce Commission today set a price of $76.2 million for the Chicago and Northwestern Transportation Company, also known as C.N.W., to buy a half interest in the rail route to Wyoming's Powder River Basin coal fields built by the Burlington Northern Railroad Company.   The commission acted after the C.N.W. and the Burlington Northern were unable to agree on a price for joint ownership and operation of a 94-mile line that runs between Shawnee Junction and Coal Creek Junction, Wyo., the I.C.C. said.

headline: MEXICAN WRATH FALLS ON TEEN-AGE SEER AND SECT
abstract: All over Mexico there are shrines to the Virgin Mary and myriad saints that are visited by thousands - in some cases millions - of pilgrims each year. The visitors ask for miracles, give thanks for favors granted or merely seek forgiveness and protection.   But New Jerusalem, site of a reported apparition of the Virgin Mary in October 1973, has suddenly become famous throughout the country, not because of its miracles but because Mexican news organizations have chosen to denounce those in charge of the shrine as charlatans, asserting they use violence, sex and extortion to promote their faith.   The particular targets of the attacks are 72-year-old Nabor Cardenas, an unfrocked priest who is referred to as Papa Nabor, and 16-year-old Arcadia Garcia, who claims to receive messages from the Virgin Mary and is known here as Mama Maria de Jesus. Between them, they control the lives of the 5,000 or so pilgrims who have settled in New Jerusalem, some 180 miles northwest of Mexico City.

headline: BRITISH SPY HURT THE U.S., MRS. THATCHER DECLARES
abstract: Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher told an angry Parliament today that a Briton who confessed to passing secrets to the Soviet Union had damaged the security interests of the United States as well as those of the Atlantic alliance.   She said a full inquiry had been ordered into the case of Geoffrey Arthur Prime, who over many years had access to top-secret intelligence-gathering operations conducted by Britain and the United States. Mrs. Thatcher said that beyond examining details of the Prime case, and what information was passed to the Soviet Union, the investigation would look into ways to tighten security checks on Government workers who had access to secret information.   ''It is not only British interests which have been damaged,'' Mrs.  Thatcher told an unruly House of Commons. ''The damage extends to the interests of the United States Government. And of course the damage to our own and United States interests is damage to the interests of the Atlantic allaince as a whole.''

headline: BLOUNT INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: News Analysis
abstract: The elimination within the next month of ceilings on the amount of interest banks may pay on certain consumer checking and savings accounts is expected to have profound effects on the economy.   While many consumers will benefit from higher returns on their federally insured accounts, many also might have to pay more for their credit as a result of the pending changes.   ''It's going to be a mixed blessing for the consumer,'' said Irwin L. Kellner, senior vice president and chief economist for the Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company. ''For savers, it will offer an opportunity to obtain higher rates than before, but it will result in higher rates for borrowers because, obviously, it means banks' cost of money will be higher than it otherwise would be.''   The nation's financial structure, itself, could also be significantly changed as a result of the decision by Federal regulators on Monday to authorize an account that has no interest rate ceiling. Except for requiring a $2,500 minimum balance, the account, which will be offered beginning Jan. 5, will be indistinguishable from ordinary checking accounts.

headline: A CHILEAN'S DARK WORLD: EXILED IN HIS OWN LAND
abstract: When Juan Carlos Martinez Hofmann was banished this year to this isolated village in southern Chile, his punishment was underlined by the name of the community itself: Selva Oscura means dark jungle.   Mr. Martinez is one of hundreds of largely insignificant political opponents of the nine-year-old regime of Gen. Augusto Pinochet who have been sent into temporary exile in the distant corners of this Andean country.   ''It's the loneliness that gets to me,'' he said, sitting in the pale light of his boardinghouse living room, with rain pounding outside. ''No one talks to me.''

headline: U.S. Bought 2 Currencies
abstract: In order to calm what they viewed as disorderly markets, the United States intervened in foreign exchange markets four times during August-October, officials at the Federal Reserve Bank of New York said yesterday, buying a total of $102 million equivalent in West German marks and yen. The New York Fed acts for the central bank and the Treasury in foreign exchange operations.

headline: TURKS VOTE TODAY ON MUCH-CRITICIZED NEW CHARTER
abstract: Despite the likelihood that a constitution proposed by Turkey's military Government will be approved in a referendum Sunday, there is a strong current of opposition to it and some officials believe that a substantial negative vote could be a serious blow to the ruling junta.   Up to 20 million Turks may vote on the constitution, which would mark the first step back to democratic rule, while insuring continued military control for the near future.   Some diplomats here feel that if the vote falls below 60 percent, it would be a serious reversal for Gen. Kenan Evren and the other members of the ruling military junta, with unforeseeable consequences.

headline: Looking for Oil in India
abstract: Dalbir Singh, India's energy minister, said today that 37 foreign oil companies had been invited to submit exploration bids by Jan. 15. The companies include 22 based in the United States.

headline: PLANNING TRIP TO RESTLESS REGIONS
abstract: Pope John Paul II stepped off an airliner onto Spanish soil today for the start of the first visit by any Pope to this predominantly Roman Catholic nation.   The Pope is beginning his 10-day pastoral journey at a time of high political excitement in Spain, which only Wednesday elected its first Socialist government in nearly half a century.   Because Felipe Gonzalez, the Socialist leader, has not yet been installed as Prime Minister, the Pope was greeted on behalf of the Government by the outgoing Prime Minister, Leopoldo Calvo Sotelo.  King Juan Carlos, accompanied by Queen Sofia, was the first to salute the Pope as he stepped from the plane at the airport outside the capital.

headline: INLAND SEES LOSS
abstract: The Inland Steel Company said today that it expected a third-quarter loss nearly double that of the second quarter, which was $23.2 million, compared with a profit of $29.5 million a year earlier. In New York, Joseph Wyman, an industry analyst with Shearson/ American Express, said virtually all of the major steel companies will report operating losses for the third quarter.

headline: Energy Resources
abstract: The Energy Resources Corporation has announced that M.F. Schwenk had resigned as president, but would continue as chairman and chief executive officer until Jan. 31.  Kenneth Wanamaker, formerly treasurer of the company, has been named president.

headline: AMF INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: REAGAN IS ANGERED BY G.O.P. HECKLER
abstract: As a crowd listened in astonishment, President Reagan was interrupted in mid-speech by a Republican heckler at the White House today. The President responded with his most fiery oratory of the campaign and a blunt order to the heckler: ''Shut up!''   Mr. Reagan's reaction shifted from surprise to anger to aggressiveness as Gary Arnold, the Republican candidate for Congress from California's 16th District, stood up at a rally for Republican candidates in the East Room, loudly cut off the President in midsentence and accused him of abandoning conservative principles.   ''We have a Tylenol-taxing situation here,'' Mr. Arnold, a 41-year-old marketing analyst, shouted as the President glared over at him. ''And we have Reagan-mortis setting into the nation's body politic!''

headline: FOR FOREIGNERS, RED IS THE COLOR OF SOVIET CARPET
abstract: An American with fluency in Russian arrived in the historic town of Suzdal with his family only to find the entrance to the dining room at his hotel barred.   ''No places,'' barked a doorman, even after the visitor explained in Russian that he was staying at the hotel and had three hungry children and no place else to eat.   Finally the American appealed to the hotel administrator, who blurted out in horror, ''I'm so terribly sorry. He apparently mistook you for Russians.''

headline: Greece Says Common Market Will Help Build Pipeline Spur
abstract: The European Economic Community will almost certainly help build a branch from the Siberian pipeline to carry Soviet natural gas to Greece, an official statement said today.    It said Greece gained that assurance this week at a meeting of Common Market energy ministers in Brussels.  Last month the Yugoslav press agency Tanjug said Greece had postponed plans for a pipeline to bring Soviet gas here through Rumania and Bulgaria because the Greeks expected a big increase in domestic natural gas output.

headline: NEW TAX BREAKS FOR HYBRID COMPANIES
abstract: called Subchapter S corporations, permitting them s pecial tax benefits. But several recent changes in the tax laws havem ade this tax vehicle attractive as well for owners of cash-rich c ompanies.   This year's cut in the top individual tax rate to 50 percent from 70 percent ''and the pension parity provisions in the tax law passed this summer have made Subchapter S corporations a really viable tax planning tool,'' said Donald J. Ercole, a tax partner in Arthur Young, the accounting firm. ''And that doesn't take into account the changes made by the new Sub S law.''

headline: Commodities; One Vast Market Emerging
abstract: THOSE who doubt that the stock, commodities and money markets will soon become one vast marketplace were given still another example of this ongoing process on Friday, when the American Stock Exchange quietly began trading in options on 90-day Treasury bills.   The options are not based on futures, but actual instruments, just like the options on 10-year Treasury notes that the exchange introduced Oct. 22. Soon, the nation's second largest stock exchange will open trading in 90-day certificates of deposit and Treasury sixmonth bills, which will also be based on cash instruments.   Meanwhile, the giant Chicago Board of Trade and the Chicago Mercantile Exchange, which handle about 50 percent and 30 percent of the total commodities trading volume, respectively, will soon start futures and options markets in sub-indexes of the popular stock market averages. So will the New York Stock Exchange's subsidiary, the New York Futures Exchange.

headline: Talks on Selling Sotheby's Held
abstract: Sotheby's, the auction house, indicated it was up for sale.  The 239-year-old fine art auctioner said it had entered into preliminary talks with unidentified potential buyers.

headline: Kaiser Sells Stake In Mining Concern
abstract: The Kaiser Aluminum and Chemical Corporation said yesterday that it had agreed to sell its 45 percent interest in Comalco Ltd., an Australian mining concern, for $343 million in cash.   The two buyers are the Australian Mutual Provident Society, that country's largest life insurance concern, and CRA Ltd., a mining and exploration concern that also holds a 45 percent interest in Comalco, Kaiser said.

headline: Buitoni Shifts
abstract: Reports in the food trade indicate that the Buitoni Food Products Corporation, Hackensack, N.J., has recently undergone a change in its top management as a result of declining sales.

headline: REAGAN, WITH PORTUGUESE CHIEF, ASKS BETTER LINKS
abstract: President Reagan conferred today with the Portuguese Prime Minister and said later that the United States would seek to ''broaden and strengthen'' its security ties with the Lisbon Government.   Mr. Reagan also said current negotiations to renew the agreement for a United States military base in the Portuguese Azores ''should lead to an early and mutually satisfactory conclusion.'' The fiveyear agreement expires in February.

headline: Pan Am Has Union Accords
abstract: Pan American World Airways said it had reached agreements in principle with all five of its major labor unions calling for concessions on work rules and a continuation of a 10 percent wage freeze that went into effect two years ago.   C. Edward Acker, the airline's chairman, who had threatened to shut it down unless the three remaining unions accepted a package calling for concessions, said that the carrier had reached agreement with the three.

headline: U.S. PUTS AN 'IF' ON MORE TROOPS FOR LEBANON
abstract: The Administration said today that it had received a Lebanese request to double the number of peacekeeping forces in Lebanon but would agree only if there was an end to the deadlock over the withdrawal of Israeli, Syrian and Palestine Liberation Organization troops from that country.   The United States, France and Italy have about 3,400 troops in the Beirut area, and about 1,300 of them are American marines. On Monday, Lebanon asked the countries to double the size of the force, Deputy Secretary of State Kenneth W. Dam told the Senate Foreign Relations Committee.   In Brazil, President Reagan told reporters that the request from President Amin Gemayel was designed ''to help speed up the removal of foreign forces'' from Lebanon. But Mr. Dam said that no action would be taken on the request until there was movement at the negotiating table toward the withdrawal of the foreign forces.

headline: A LOOK BACK AT 1982 STOCK PICKS
abstract: THE chancey art of picking favorite stocks for the new year has b ecome a tradition on Wall Street. This process finds research a nalysts and market strategists setting down their choices - and thenc rossing their fingers. And every year, it seems, International B usiness Machines turns up on the recommended lists.  But I.B.M., the most widely owned stock in institutional portfolios, often disappoints its boosters. In 1981, shares of the data-processing giant lost ground because of lower profits. Actually, the stock had languished in performance since 1973, despite impressive earnings growth.

headline: POPE BEGINS VISIT TO MAFIA STRONGHOLD
abstract: Pope John Paul II arrived in Sicily today on a long-awaited pastoral journey to Italy's most troubled region, where the Roman Catholic Church has recently taken its strongest action against the Mafia.   Last month the Sicilian Bishops' Conference pronounced an edict of excommunication on those who murder or kidnap on behalf of the Mafia, as well as those who order or abet such crimes. Although similar declarations were issued in 1944 and 1952, last month's edict for the first time mentioned the Mafia by name.   Last night, however, four more people were reported murdered here by the Mafia. Two of the victims were teen-aged boys, a 15-year-old slain with an uncle and another man, and a 17-year-old. The night's slayings brought the number of known victims in the Palermo district this year to 124; 130 more are missing and believed dead.

headline: ISRAEL DEPORTS BRITON WHO REFUSED TO SIGN PLEDGE ON P.L.O.
abstract: A British biology instructor was deported today for refusing to sign a form that Israel requires from foreigners before they can teach at schools in the Israeli-occupied West Bank.   The deportation was denounced by a Roman Catholic clergyman who is an official of Bethlehem University as a violation of academic freedom and as evidence of ''a clear pattern of harassment by the military'' toward universities in the West Bank that teach Palestinian Arabs.   The form, devised this year by the Israeli Army in order for foreign teachers to get a work permit, requires the teachers to sign a statement that they will not ''do any kind of work'' and not ''give any services directly or indirectly which will help or support the so-called Palestine Liberation Organization or any other hostile organization.''

headline: THE LABOR DEPARTMENT REPLIES
abstract: To the Business Editor: William Winpisinger seems to hold the view that worker health and safety can only be measured in terms of inspections, citations and fines, and that employers must be bullied by big government into providing decent workplaces for their employees.   We reject that notion. We don't believe that the Occupational Safety and Health Administration should be a police agency sending enforcement officers to every worksite in this great land regardless of the health and safety records of individual employers. That isn't necessary and, for an agency with positions for 1,200 inspectors covering three million worksites, it isn't possible.

headline: Litton Net Falls 31.7%
abstract: Litton Industries, a diversified manufacturer of high-technology equipment based in Beverly Hills, Calif., said yesterday that net income in its first fiscal quarter ended Oct. 31 declined 31.7 percent, to $52.9 million, or $1.26 a share, from $77.4 million, or $1.86 a share, a year earlier.

abstract: Kurtz & Tarlow has been named agency for two brands from the Lehn & Fink division of Sterling Drug.

headline: Caterpillar Trucks
abstract: The Caterpillar Tractor Company said it may soon stop producing lift trucks at its Towmotor Corporation unit in Mentor, Ohio. It cited overcapacity and reduced demand, which it said would be met through increased production at its plants in Leicester, England, and Dallas, Ore. It also said Towmotor, which employed about 1,300 people at the end of the third quarter, is negotiating to make lift trucks outside the United States.

headline: PROSPECTS
abstract: The Main Event   The Christmas season, retailing's main event, begins this week, and should clearly determine whether the consumer will lead the country out of recession. Holiday shoppers, who could give merchants at least 25 percent of annual sales and as much as 50 percent of profits, are perhaps more crucial now than in quite some time. In simple terms, the issue is whether the stimulus of income tax cuts and supply-side economics can outweigh the drag of the highest jobless rate in decades and a recent slew of unfavorable economic indicators.   Ever the optimists, retailers see the season's prospects ranging from moderately good to very promising. ''A year ago, we stumbled into the season with sluggish sales and high inventories,'' said a top department store executive. ''This tied up our dollars so that we couldn't capitalize on market opportunities to attract shoppers. This year, caution was the word on expenses and inventory accumulation so that we have the financial flexibility to move quickly. Besides, a tight belt and some hunger has made us better businessmen.''

headline: Kaufman Cites U.S. Problems
abstract: Henry Kaufman, chief economist and managing director of the investment banking firm of Salomon Brothers Inc., said today that a strong economic recovery was unlikely in the United States.   He also warned of a continued risk of worldwide depression.

headline: FED FUNDS IN AMPLE SUPPLY
abstract: The Federal Reserve is providing the banking system with an ample supply of funds at the same time that business credit demands are weakening, according to Fed data published late yesterday.   The combination of an accommodative monetary policy by the Fed and weakening credit demands among large businesses keeps alive the hope that short-term rates will decline further in coming weeks, analysts said. The latest data, however, do not point toward an immediate drop in rates.

headline: BACK IN VOGUE WITH MUTUAL FUNDS
abstract: RICHARD TISCH, president of the Richbar Sales Corporation, a 46-year-old New York dress importer, has a bout $850,000 in investments, and almost all of it is in mutual f unds. ''I used to trade stocks, but frankly I couldn't keep up with i t,'' he said. ''There were tons of trading slips and it was s upercostly.''   Almost without interruption since 1975, Mr. Tisch has had his assets in the 44 Wall Street Fund, an aggresive growth mutual fund.  ''Now I only have to check one price,'' he added.   Mr. Tisch's experience is one of the indications that mutual funds, the billion-dollar babies of the 1960's, are back on the investing scene in a big way.

headline: Kohl, Despite Setback, Is Hopeful on '83 Vote
abstract: Chancellor Helmut Kohl said today that he still believed his Christian Democratic Party had a good chance of winning the general election in March, despite losing a Hamburg state election Sunday.   ''We did not achieve our aim; we have undoubtedly suffered a setback,'' Mr. Kohl told reporters after party leaders met to discuss the victory of the opposition Social Democrats.

headline: NAUGLES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 21
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: MORE HEADY DAYS FOR SPAIN: FIRST VISIT BY A POPE TODAY
abstract: After the emotionally draining events of the last 48 hours, which saw the election of the first left-wing government here in more than four decades, Spain is now girding itself for the first visit it has ever received from a Pope.   Pope John Paul II arrives Sunday for a 10-day tour of a nation with a rich and turbulent Roman Catholic past. He will find here a church full of self-doubt.   In downtown Madrid today, workers were pulling down election paraphernalia and putting up posters heralding the arrival of ''Juan Pablo'' - the ''witness of hope,'' they called him. In a shoe store off the Gran Via, Mercedes Fernandez, a clerk, was so busy reading a leaflet about the visit issued by the Spanish bishops that she scarcely had time to take the money proffered by her impatient customers.

headline: KEEPING HEILEMAN IN THE PACK
abstract: LA CROSSE, Wisc.  IN his cluttered office by the banks of the Mississippi, Russell G.  Cleary, president, chairman and chief architect of the House of Heileman, has made sure that one piece of paper does not get lost among the stacks.   Hung prominently in a simple frame on the wall, between an overstuffed teddy bear and a collection of empty beer bottles and cans, is Mr. Cleary's favorite quotation: ''On the plains of hesitation bleach the bones of countless millions who at the dawn of decision sat down to wait and waiting died.''   Hesitation certainly has not been a problem for the 49-year-old Mr. Cleary since he took over the reins at G. Heileman Brewing Company a dozen years ago. During those years, Heileman, largely through acquisitions, rose to fourth place from No.15 in the highly competitive and shrinking beer industry and, according to analysts, will capture about 7.8 percent of the national market this year.

headline: ECONOMIC BELLWETHER SHOWS RISE
abstract: The index of leading economic indicators, the last major economic report to be released before the Congressional elections Tuesday, rose five-tenths of 1 percent in September, the Government reported today.   The increase, while relatively modest, gave the Reagan Administration new hope that the long-awaited recovery may be at hand, as Administration officials have maintained.   The index, which is intended to forecast future economic trends, has now risen in five of the past six months and is up 4.2 percent since March. But more than half of September's gain came from the surge in stock prices, which began in mid-August. Stock prices are one of the 10 components in the index.

headline: BUSH REMAINS FIRM ON NAMIBIA POLICY
abstract: Vice President Bush said here today that despite criticism by black African leaders, the Reagan Administration would continue to link the issue of independence for South-West Africa with the withdrawal of Cuban troops from Angola.   Mr. Bush, addressing a news conference at the end of a three-day visit to Kenya, said that connecting the two issues ''seems to me the only specific idea for how you actually accomplish an end that everybody wants.''   ''We see this as a way to accomplish the fulfillment of an independent Namibia, an Angola free of foreign forces and a separation between South African forces and Angola,'' Mr. Bush said.  ''That's our position. We are going to stay with it.''

headline: POPE TELLS ALL PRIESTS IN ROME TO WEAR ONLY CLERICAL DRESS
abstract: Pope John Paul II has instructed all priests in Rome to wear only clerical dress.  The instruction, which was the result of a letter to Ugo Cardinal Poletti, vicar general for Rome, is likely to be interpreted by church liberals as further evidence supporting their belief that Pope John Paul II is a church conservative eager to put an end to interpretations of the teachings of the Vatican Council that he deems too liberal.

headline: Yemeni Says 2,800 Died in Earthquake
abstract: More than 2,800 people died in the earthquake and severe aftershocks in Yemen last week, and it is estimated that 700,000 were driven from their homes, the nation's Prime Minister said today.   More than 40,000 tents are needed to shelter the homeless, many of whom are living exposed to the elements, the Prime Minister, Abdel Karim al-Iryani, said at a news conference in Sana, the Yemeni capital.

headline: Japan Plans Bond Sales
abstract: The Japanese Finance Ministry said it would issue the equivalent of about $55.84 billion in bonds in the fiscal year starting April 1, up 27.8 percent from the amount that is projected in the original budget for the current year.   The offering was decided at a meeting with a syndicate of 33 Japanese banks and securities houses, the ministry said over the weekend.   Of the 1983 issues, the syndicate will underwrite $27.62 billion, which comprises $26.78 billion of 10-year bonds and the rest of fiveyear bonds, it said.

headline: BRIEFS
abstract: * Adams Resources and Energy Inc., a Houston company, said it intends to sell a least half of its producing oil and gas properties in an effort to avoid default on certain provisions of its loan agreements.   * AM International Inc., which is in Chapter 11 bankruptcy proceedings, said it had retained Eastdil Realty to assist it in the real estate aspects of its reorganization.   * Colt Industries said it had signed a definitive agreement to sell its Crucible mill in Midland, Pa. to Jones & Laughlin Steel; terms were not disclosed.

headline: ROTATION HOME FOR BEIRUT MARINES MAY BE DELAYED BY THE PENTAGON
abstract: The Defense Department said today that the scheduled rotation home next month of the marines in Beirut might be delayed, as speculation grew that their role may be more extensive than originally planned.   A Pentagon spokesman, Henry Catto, said: ''Some delay in their rotation can be expected. The whole situation in Lebanon is a changing one as diplomats make progress toward the withdrawal of all foreign forces.''

headline: WARNER, TANDY UP
abstract: The RCA Corporation yesterday reported a significant jump in earnings for the third quarter of 1982 compared with a very weak quarter last year. The increase came on improvements in most of the company's businesses except its consumer electronics operations.   Net income for the three months ended Sept. 30 was $47.6 million, or 40 cents a share, compared with a loss of $104.8 million in last year's period.   The 1981 quarter included an after-tax write-down of $150 million, which was partly offset by a one-time gain of $18.1 million from the sale of a building. Not including those special factors, earnings in the third quarter were 75 percent higher than in 1981. Third-quarter revenues rose 2.5 percent, to $2.04 billion, from $1.99 billion in the comparable period last year.

headline: Norwegian Party Fights Funds for Missiles
abstract: Norway's opposition Labor Party has declared its opposition to financing launchers for new North Atlantic Treaty Organization missiles in a move that could threaten the minority Conservative Party Government.   The Labor Party leader, former Prime Minister Gro Harlem Brundtland, announced Friday night that the party would oppose any Norwegian payments for launchers for the planned deployment of 572 Pershing 2 and cruise missiles.

headline: Careers; Corporate Real Estate Managers
abstract: THE General Motors Corporation, worrying about the recession and the slump in car sales, made an innovative real estate deal some months ago when it received about $500 million for its New York office building on Fifth Avenue. G.M. is using the money for working capital.   The transaction not only showed the new interest that many companies are taking in their real estate but also indicated potential job opportunities.   This process has been going on for some time, according to Alan M.  Higgins, president of the General Tire Realty Company and manager of its real estate. ''The turning point in our industry came in the last four or five years,'' he said in an interview.

headline: BLACK HISTORY BEING REVISED IN ZIMBABWE
abstract: For decades, every schoolchild who grew up in this country, the former Rhodesia, learned that its history essentially began in 1855 when the Scottish explorer David Livingstone made his way to the great falls on the Zambezi River and named them after Queen Victoria.   Now, as one of the first tangible fruits of its independence of only two and a half years, Zimbabwe is getting a new past. New history texts for primary schools are just off the presses and a hotly competitive race is on among several publishing houses, each with its own team of historians, to see who can be first with historical surveys for high school and university students.   The new texts all seek to meet a deeply felt need: to show that the black people who live in the modern @Zimbabwe have been shapers of history and not just bystanders.

headline: BILL TO CURB URANIUM IMPORTS ANGERS TWO KEY U.S. ALLIES
abstract: A proposal pending in Congress to limit uranium imports has angered two major American trading partners and, according to Administration officials, may endanger the Government's drive to lower international trade barriers.   Canada, this nation's biggest trading partner, and Australia have objected to a provision in a bill pending before the House that would suspend new foreign uranium contracts after uranium imports exceeded 37.5 percent of total domestic demand. The provision emerged from a House-Senate compromise on the Nuclear Regulatory Commission authorization bill, which passed the Senate last Friday and is awaiting action by the House.   The provision is designed to assist the ailing domestic uranium industry but, according to Canadian and Australian officials, it would disturb the international uranium market. American trade officials argue, moreover, that such a trade policy would undermine American efforts to combat protectionism and might invite retaliation.

headline: NEW BRUNSWICK TELEPHONE CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: GREENS GIVE BONN POLITICS NEW CONTENT
abstract: Dorli Rauch does not much resemble the average West German politician.  Mrs. Rauch, a slight, soft-spoken 32-year-old schoolteacher and mother of two, seems more at ease in a heavy sweater and coveralls on her farm near here than on the political stump.   But in state elections in Hesse Sept. 26, a wave of discontent with the country's three established parties and their seemingly insensitive treatment of environmental issues helped the Greens, an alliance of amateur populist politicians, environmentalists and proponents of disarmament and neutralism in Central Europe, to win 22 percent of the vote in Frankenberg. Mrs. Rauch, the local Green candidate, became one of nine Green legislators who now hold the balance of power in the Hesse state parliament.   But the sweeping gains for Mrs. Rauch's party, which was unknown in her electoral district a year ago, helps explain how it has displaced for the moment the small Free Democratic Party as the state's third-largest political force. It was the Free Democrats whose break with Helmut Schmidt over welfare policy led to the Chancellor's ouster by Parliament Friday and the election of Helmut Kohl as his successor.

headline: Ziff-Davis Purchase
abstract: Software Communications Inc., the San Francisco-based publishers of PC: The Independent Guide to IBM Personal Computers, has been acquired for an undisclosed price by the Ziff-Davis Publishing Company. Ziff-Davis already publishes several microcomputer magazines, including Computers and Electronics, Creative Computing, Microsystems, Small Business Computers, and Sync. PC, a monthly microcomputer magazine of 400-plus pages, began publication in February and has a current circulation of 75,000.

headline: Sotheby Officer Joining Goldman, Sachs Unit
abstract: ''I wanted to return to my first love, which is investment banking,'' said Peter J.R. Spira, who is leaving the troubled Sotheby Parke Bernet Group for the Goldman Sachs International Corporation.   Mr. Spira, 52, is finance director of Sotheby's, the auction house based in London.

headline: HALLIBURTON TUMBLES BY 38%
abstract: The Halliburton Company reported yesterday that a marked drop in results from domestic oilfiled services caused net income in the third quarter to plunge 38 percent and revenues to shrink by 21.4 percent.   The diversified Dallas-based company said that net income in the latest three months fell to $118.7 million, or $1.01 a share, from $191.5 million, or $1.62 a share, in the first three months of 1981.  Revenues dropped to $1.76 billion, from $2.24 billion.

headline: PANSOPHIC SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: WHITE HOUSE ANSWERS ISRAELI CRITICISM ON AID
abstract: The Reagan Administration, responding to Israeli criticism, said today that it was ''puzzled that Israel can call into question our good faith'' simply because the White House opposed Congressional attempts to increase aid to Israel.   President Reagan's spokesman, Larry Speakes, defended the Administration's opposition to a vote last week by the Senate Appropriations Committee to allocate more money for Israel than the $2.5 billion already sought by the Administration in the 1983 budget.    Reading a prepared answer in response to a question at the daily White House briefing, Mr. Speakes said the Administration had already proposed a 21 percent increase and that any more might come at the expense of other allies' needs.

headline: 300 Die as Hurricane Sweeps Western India
abstract: The death toll has reached at least 300 in the hurricane-battered western Indian state of Gujarat, authorities reported today.

headline: Poet Traveling to U.S.  To Be Married to Wife
abstract: Armando Valladares, the poet who was freed from a Cuban jail after 22 years and has been living here in exile, said today that he would fly to the United States to be married to his wife, Marta, in a religious ceremony in Miami.   The couple were married in a civil ceremony in 1969 in the jail where he was serving a 30-year sentence.

headline: Hormats Gets Post At Goldman, Sachs
abstract: Robert D. Hormats, who resigned in August as Assistant Secretary of State for Economic and Business Affairs, has joined Goldman, Sachs & Company to head a new international financial services group.   Mr. Hormats, 39 years old, received a Ph.D. in international economic issues from the Fletcher School of International Law at Tufts.

headline: Rebel Suspect Killed in Italy
abstract: A suspected left-wing urban guerrilla fell to his death from a seventh-floor window here today when policemen raided an apartment and arrested three other suspects, confiscating arms and ammunition, the police said. The three arrested, two men and a woman, are believed to be connected with the Red Brigades guerrilla group, the police said. Their names were not disclosed.

headline: BACHE FIRM FINED $400,000 FOR ROLE IN '80 SILVER CRISIS
abstract: The New York Stock Exchange yesterday fined a prominent brokerage firm $400,000 for permitting the Hunt brothers of Texas to speculate so heavily in silver as to endanger the firm's survival and then failing to give the stock exchange timely notice of the developing crisis.   The fine, against Bache Halsey Stuart Shields Inc., was the largest ever levied by the exchange.  In a related development, a 279-page staff report of the Securities and Exchange Commission, released in Washington, assailed the stock exchange for insufficient surveillance of Bache and other brokerage firms dealing with the Hunts in the weeks leading up to the silver crisis in the spring of 1980. Failure to Get Information   In some of the strongest language to come from the regulatory body under the chairmanship of John S.R. Shad, a former executive of the E.F. Hutton brokerage firm, the S.E.C. staff said that the exchange had failed to get sufficient information from Wall Street firms dealing with the Hunts, had failed to verify the little information it got and had ''failed to be alert to the potential of a crisis situation as it developed.''

headline: KAMAN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: HOW AND WHERE TO FIND A FINANCIAL ADVISER
abstract: WHOM CAN YOU TRUST with your money? Catherine Carmany, for one, w ould like to know. At 29, the New York suburban housewife now c ontrols a nest egg that her parents put into trust for her years a go. The Wall Street bank that manages her money has it invested e ntirely in stocks, however, and Mrs. Carmany would like more d iversity. She would also like to be ''a little involved,'' she said.   Her father, an elderly stockbroker who lives in another city, has suggested that she find herself an investment adviser. How to do so is the problem. ''I know there's somebody out there who would be interested in doing something with my money,'' she said, ''but I've asked everybody I know, and nobody knows anybody. Some connection seems to be missing.'' If a number of people might like to be in Mrs. Carmany's shoes, there are also many who share her complaint. Selecting a personal investment adviser would appear to be about as difficult as choosing a surgeon.   Many people regard the whole array of investment advisers with suspicion. For one thing, it is doubtful that the adviser shares one's own reverence for his hard-earned money. For another, the question inevitably arises: If they're so good at investing other people's money, why aren't they just multiplying their own?

headline: The U.N. Today; Nov. 10, 1982; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
abstract: Meets at 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.   Political and Security Committee - 10:30 A.M.   Special Political Committee - 10:30 A.M. headline: News Analysis
abstract: Diplomats assessing the swift appointment of Yuri V. Andropov as General Secretary of the Communist Party believe that he wants to make an early beginning on a tightening of discipline through the whole of Soviet society, to lessen inefficiency and waste that caused widespread disillusionment in the last years of Leonid I. Brezhnev's tenure.   The expectation of a tougher approach is also widespread among ordinary Russians, and it could mean an even more extensive crackdown on the dissident movement than the one Mr. Andropov presided over during his 15 years as head of the K.G.B., the intelligence and internal-security agency. In addition, it probably heralds a drive to curb the absenteeism, slothfulness and heavy drinking that have contributed to the country's chronic economic problems. But it could also mean some changes that many think are badly needed.

headline: MEXICO CRISIS SEEN AS A THREAT TO ALL
abstract: The President of Mexico, Jose Lopez Portillo, told the United Nations General Assembly today that Mexico's financial crisis was the crisis of all the third world and that it threatened the stability of the world monetary system.   He called for ''profound institutional reform capable of rechanneling international economic relations.'' Low prices for raw materials, he said - in Mexico's case, meaning oil - coupled with climbing interest rates have become ''the blades of a pair of scissors that threaten to slash the momentum achieved in some countries and to cut off the possibilities for progress in the rest.'' Asserts Growth Is Only Answer   ''The countries of the South,'' Mr. Lopez Portillo went on, ''are being criticized by the very countries that made loans for them and that now haggle over extending the credit needed for continued growth.'' Only growth, he said, will make it possible for the poor countries to pay off loans from the rich.

headline: Danish Parliament Backs Economic Plan
abstract: The Danish Parliament approved the minority Government's tough economic package today, saving the country from the second general election in a year.   Poul Schluter, Denmark's first conservative Prime Minister in 81 years, had said he would call new elections if the 179-seat Parliament threw out key elements of his austerity program.   His predecessor, the Social Democratic leader Anker Jorgensen, resigned last month after failing to win backing for similarly harsh measures.

headline: Burnup Reports a Loss
abstract: Burnup & Sims Inc., a cable communications concern, had a loss of $5.5 million in its second quarter, ended Oct. 31, on revenues of $51 million, compared with earnings of $2.5 million on revenues of $47 million a year earlier. Burnup attributed the loss in part to the impact of law suits between the company and Victor Posner, who has a 35 percent interest in Burnup.

headline: DURABLES ORDERS FALL STEEP 4.9%
abstract: In another discouraging sign for the economy, the Government reported today that orders to manufacturers for durable goods dropped 4.9 percent in October, the biggest decline in a year.   Such a steep decline in orders for cars, heavy machinery, furniture and other durable goods - those big-ticket items intended to last three years or more - indicated to analysts that overall industrial production would continue to decline, keeping unemployment high.  Industrial production has dropped in 13 of the last 15 months.

headline: Social Security
abstract: To the Business Editor: In ''Social Security's Overblown Problems (Nov.14), Barbara R.  Bergmann says that Social Security is a welfare program. But she still wants to keep it, even though at least half of our old people are wealthy enough to live comfortably without it, and the other half could go on welfare and get exactly the same money they're getting now - the only difference would be the name of the check.   Why does Professor Bergmann nevertheless want to keep it? I cannot read her mind, but my guess is that she believes that it is no good for people to save up their own money for their old age and that it is better for the Government to take care of you.  JESSE BRYANT    Manhattan, Nov.14, 1982

headline: Amway v. Canada
abstract: Canadian customs officials and the Amway Corporation are trying to settle $118 million in lawsuits out of court, a spokesman for the Canadian customs department said. The four lawsuits, filed in Canadian federal court in Toronto in 1980, accuse Amway and its Canadian subsidiary of providing false invoices to cover more than 1,700 shipments of products into Canada between Jan.  6, 1977, and Jan. 28, 1980. Canada is seeking $118 million in duties, taxes and penalties.

headline: British Trade Data
abstract: Record exports in November pushed Britain's visible trade surplus up to 470 million, or about $755 million, in November from 259 million, about $416 million, in October, the trade department said today.

headline: No Headline
abstract: MOSLEMS FAIL AGAIN TO END THE GULF WAR   NICOSIA, Cyprus, Oct. 23 (AP) - A 12-member peace commission representing the Islamic Conference opened talks in Teheran today in an attempt to end the two-year-old Iranian-Iraqi war, but the effort failed within hours, Iran's official press agency reported.   The Iraqi press agency said the Islamic peace mission had arrived in Baghdad, Iraq, from Teheran and had been met by the Iraqi Foreign Minister, Saadoun Hammadi, and members of the diplomatic corps.   (The mission returned to Saudi Arabia tonight, according to a Reuters dispatch from Bahrain. The Islamic Conference group immediately began briefing President Ahmed Sekou Toure of Guinea, the president of the Islamic Conference Organization's full peace committee, in Jidda about the trip, officials were quoted as saying.)

headline: POACHERS PUT INDIAN RHINO AT GREAT RISK
abstract: More than 1,050 great Indian one-horned rhinoceroses roam the Kaziranga preserve here in northeastern India, coexisting with tigers, elephants, buffalo and deer. But, although the rhinos' numbers have nearly tripled in a decade, conservation officials warn that they could join their two-horned African relatives as an endangered species.   For the Indian animals, like the African varieties, are coveted by poachers for their horn, which is widely regarded as an aphrodisiac as well as medicine especially helpful in bringing down fever.

headline: HARVESTER CONTINUES WAGE CUTBACK
abstract: The International Harvester Company disclosed today that it had sent letters to its 9,700 domestic salaried employees informing them that the company would not restore a 5 percent cut in their pay until at least January. The company had said it might restore the deleted wages in November.   Harvester, which has been facing serious financial difficulties all year, cut the pay of the 5,500 managers and 4,200 secretaries and clerks in March as part of an extensive cost-reduction program. It had said it would review its financial condition in November to determine whether to restore the salaries to their former levels.

headline: CANADA SEEKS ALLIES IN FIGHT ON ACID RAIN
abstract: Plastic Lake lay in stillness in this central Ontario region of heavy woods as a gentle shower fell from clouds that had picked up sulfuric pollutants from the smokestacks of the Ohio Valley.   Except for the drops bouncing on the clear surface, nothing moved.  There were no fish, no weeds, no crayfish. It was one of the thousands of dead or dying lakes of Canada.

headline: U.S. Truck Output
abstract: American auto makers will cut truck production in the fourth quarter by about 22 percent, Ward's Automotive Reports said today.

headline: E.E.C. ALSO PLANS CURB ON ITS IMPORTS OF STEEL
abstract: Western European nations will reduce their steel imports by more than 10 percent next year, it was announced today. The purpose is to permit the sale within Europe of Europeanmade steel that can no longer be exported to the United States.   Viscount Etienne Davignon, the Commissioner of Industry for the European Economic Community, said at a news conference that foreign suppliers would be asked to accept a smaller share of Europe's shrinking market, just as Americans had demanded that European producers reduce their share of the United States market.   Foreign ministers of the market's 10 members are expected to approve the reduction in imports at a meeting in Luxembourg Monday, Viscount Davignon said. It is a key element in the final decision, reached here today, to accept ceilings on European steel shipments to the United States in order to avoid the imposition of duties.

headline: TAX BENEFIT CARRIES CHRYSLER TO A PROFIT
abstract: The Chrysler Corporation, as expected, reported today that it earned a small profit of $9.4 million, or 3 cents a share, in the third quarter, giving it three consecutive profitable quarters for the first time since 1977. However, the No. 3 auto maker had an operating loss of $11.3 million in the period; and its earnings were generated by an extraordinary tax loss carryforward of $20.7 million.   A company spokesman, Baron K. Bates, said the operating loss was the result of the effect of the devaluation of the peso on the company's Mexican operations, an important Chrysler market. He said Chrysler had operating earnings in the United States in exess of $20 million, but would not specify the exact amount. The company's tax payment of $21.3 million, however, suggests domestic earnings of about $45 million.

headline: '82 Loss Seen By U.S. Steel
abstract: The United States Steel Corporation, the nation's largest steelmaker, will report a loss for the full year, David M. Roderick, chairman of the company, said yesterday at a meeting of the New York Society of Securities Analysts.   During the third quarter the company lost $82.4 million, and a further loss is expected in the fourth quarter, he said.

headline: BRITISH COMPANIES IN BUY-OUT TREND
abstract: Until a few months ago, the 250 workers at the Midlands British Road Services depot here labored in the shadow of a bustling elevated expressway on behalf of the British Government, owner of their parent company, the National Freight Consortium. Now they have new masters - themselves.   Eight months ago, employees at National Freight bought their company and became yet another example of the growing number of cases in Britain in which the workers or the managers have become the owners.   ''The feeling that you have actually got a piece of the action of this business is tremendous,'' said Peter Thompson, chairman of National Freight.

headline: EASING OF PRICES SEEN
abstract: The slowdown of inflation, after three years of double-digit growth rates in 1979-81, has been a bright spot in the midst of an economic recession. Producer prices, for example, rose at an annual rate of only 3.7 percent in the first seven months of this year, and are not expected to accelerate any time soon.

headline: LENOX INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: SETBACK HANDED TO AFGHAN REBELS
abstract: A Western diplomatic source said today that Soviet ground forces in Afghanistan had staged a four-day assault on a rebel stronghold 12 miles northwest of the capital and had then withdrawn, leaving it in the hands of Afghan troops.   The Soviet assault on the stronghold, in the township of Paghman, occurred between Oct. 5 and 9. Diplomatic sources said last week that the Soviet forces had used at least 200 tanks, armored personnel carriers and trucks in the attack, one of the largest drives against Moslem rebels in the area.

headline: PEKING IS TROUBLED BY RISE IN DEFECTIONS TO WEST
abstract: China's policy of sending students, scholars and others to the United States for extended visits has created tensions between the two Governments because of the large number of defections, according to American officials.   Peking officials are also reported to be troubled by what appears to them to be the beginning of dissident activities in the United States by some Chinese students.   As of the end of October, there were 1,030 pending applications for political asylum filed by Chinese in this country, a figure equal to roughly 10 percent of the estimated 10,000 to 11,000 Chinese who are on extended visits here, according to figures provided by the Immigration and Naturalization Service. Eight applicants for political asylum have been approved so far this year and 87 rejected.

headline: CASTING ABOUT FOR THE CORPORATE ELITE
abstract: NOT long ago, the story unfolds, a hot candidate who had almost c linched the presidency of a conglomerate made a costly gaffe.  T raveling to his final interview, he joined the pilot in the cockpit a nd started showing off with a series of disparaging cracks about t he company jet. A few hours later, the pilot told his next p assenger - the chief executive officer - that the prospect was a r eal wise guy.   The storyteller, a 51-year-old executive recruiter who has thrived with his knack for finding top-level corporate officers, leans forward in his chair and lowers his voice to a confidential whisper, ''Boom. It was all over.''   It was all over for that candidate, but not so for Gerard R. Roche, the chairman and top headhunter at Heidrick & Struggles, a major New York executive recruiting firm. With the nimbleness acquired in 20 years spent handling executive searches for Fortune 500 companies, he simply shipped over a candidate who proved to have ''stronger interpersonal skills.'' As a result, he pocketed his standard fee: one-third of the executive's first year total compensation, usually salary and bonus, paid even if a company does not hire one of his candidates. On to the next assignment.

headline: HERO'S SON QUESTIONS PILLAR OF YUGOSLAV STATE
abstract: Rade Koncar, the father, was a Yugoslav war hero whose name decorates factories, work brigades and streets in many a town and city. Now Rade Koncar, the son, has become a household word as a result of a political dispute he started four months ago.   The younger Koncar, born 40 years ago, just after his father was executed by Italian Fascist occupation forces, is a member of Yugoslavia's ruling Communist Party. Last summer, at the party's 12th congress, he gave a speech that appeared to challenge the very foundations of the party-state created under Marshal Tito.

headline: U.P.I. Wants a Splash From Lois, Pitts
abstract: ''We wanted someone who was splashy, exciting and aggressive,'' said William K. Adler, new director of information of United Press International, as he described the news service's selection of an ad agency. ''We knew we had to move fast and we couldn't have a stodgy, conservative approach. We had to show we were doing something exciting.''

headline: SHORTAGE OF CIGARETTES IS PLAGUING EGYPTIANS
abstract: Egyptians seem to have a nearly insatiable appetite for tobacco and tobacco products.  While cigarette consumption in many Western countries has declined amid concern about the damaging health effects associated with smoking, it increases here at a rate of nearly 8 percent a year, according to Government studies.   Last year, according to the Ministry of Industry and Mineral Resources, Egyptians smoked about 42 billion cigarettes, or 50 packs for every man, woman and child in the country. That is 6 billion more cigarettes than local factories were able to produce.

headline: 100 Nigeria Policemen Said to Be Riot Victims
abstract: The official Nigerian press agency reported today that about 100 police officers were apparently among more than 300 people killed or captured in four days of fighting with Moslem militants 750 miles northeast of here.

headline: BRITAIN SEEKS TO KEEP ISRAEL IN A U.N. AGENCY
abstract: Britain, attempting to forestall a threatened United States withdrawal from the International Telecommunications Union, proposed today that the agency express alarm over the invasion of Lebanon but not vote to oust Israel.   The amendment was proposed after the chief American delegate, Michael Gardner, told the 157-member United Naions agency that the United States would ''immediately and permamently'' resign if an Algerian-sponsored resolution to bar Israel was passed. He said the United States would also withhold its annual contribution to the agency of $3.2 million, or 7 percent of the budget.

headline: Icahn-Dan River
abstract: The Icahn Group, which had offered to buy two million shares of Dan River Inc. for $18 each, lowered the minimum number of shares to one million.

headline: Shamir Denies Making Argentine Arms Deal
abstract: Foreign Minister Yitzhak Shamir denied today that he had negotiated a new arms agreement with Argentina during his current visit there.   Mr. Shamir made his comments in a telephone interview from Buenos Aires on the Israeli Army radio station.

headline: South Africa Temporarily Lifts Ban on 'Master Harold' Play
abstract: The ban on ''Master Harold ... and the Boys,'' the play about South African race problems, has been temporarily lifted five days after it was imposed.

headline: WHEN MONEY DOESN'T MATTER IN JAPAN
abstract: The late Kurt Singer, a German sociologist and economist, once observed that the reason Japan was so efficient, so smooth-working ''does not reside in the rationalized perfection of its mammoth organizations, but in the dense tissue of small society relationships.''   At this time of year, prime examples of these small family-like groups can be seen in abundance each night, filling the sidewalks and streets of such entertainment districts in Tokyo as Ginza, Akasaka, Shimbashi and Roppongi.   In collections of two, three, four or a few more, they roam to Tokyo's hundreds of thousands of small restaurants, bars and other nightspots. Sometimes they are singing, often they walk arm-in-arm, not infrequently they are drunk. They are almost exclusively Japanese businessmen. They give Tokyo's night life the look and feel of one big, sprawling fraternity party. In unliberated Japan, few women are included.

headline: Interpublic's Earnings Fell 11.9% in Quarter
abstract: The Interpublic Group of Companies would have turned in attractive third-quarter results yesterday if it weren't for exchange and foreign currency translation losses, which collectively came to about $1.5 million for the period.   That wiped out the gains made by the acquisition of the international Lintas operation, which helped raise revenue for the quarter 25.3 percent, to $130.98 million, from $104.5 million in the corresponding quarter last year.

headline: Consolidated Foods Loses a Top Officer
abstract: John J. Cardwell, the 51-year-old president and chief operating officer of the Chicago-based Consolidated Foods Corporation, abruptly resigned yesterday, citing ''differences over policy and management style'' with the chairman and chief executive officer, John H. Bryan Jr.   Some analysts said they believed that Mr. Cardwell, who joined Consolidated as president six years ago, refused to go along with a new managerial reorganization that left him with a diminished role.

headline: NATO URGES SOVIET TO REBUILD TRUST
abstract: The United States and its European allies, stressing their willingness to develop trade and human relations, told the new Soviet leadership today that a chance was at hand to rebuild a climate of international trust.   In a communique that stressed openness toward the Government of Yuri V. Andropov, the new Soviet party leader, and avoided confrontational language, the foreign ministers of the 16 members of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization called on the Soviet Union for tangible signs that it is seeking a better climate after two years of deteriorated East-West relations.   ''The allies are open for all opportunities for dialogue,'' the statement said. ''They will welcome any positive move to reduce tension, and desire, if Soviet attitudes allow, to cooperate in rebuilding international trust.''

headline: Suburban Propane
abstract: The Suburban Propane Gas Corporation of Morristown, N.J., said it had rejected a proposal from a major industrial company, which it did not identify, to acquire the company for about $51 a share, or a total of $268 million.

headline: Top St. Joe Minerals Post Is Changing
abstract: John C. Duncan, chairman and chief executive officer of the St. Joe Minerals Corporation, will retire at the end of the year, and John A. Wright, president, has been elected to the additional posts of chairman and chief executive.   Mr. Duncan, 62, has been St. Joe's chief executive since 1972. He said he thought it was time to ''get out of the day-to-day operations and turn it over to the younger generation - John Wright.''

headline: BRIEFS

headline: Daughter of an Ulster Judge Escapes Death in Bomb Blast
abstract: The daughter of a leading judge in Northern Ireland narrowly escaped death today when a bomb planted by guerrillas exploded under her car outside a Belfast court, the police said.

Heileman Brewing Company and the Pabst Brewing Company said they had brought suit in Federal District Court in Delaware in an attempt to block a tender offer for Pabst by Paul Kalmanovitz, a West Coast brewery owner.   The suit charged that Mr. Kalmanovitz and his associates had violated Federal securities laws in connection with the offer, the companies said.

headline: Norstar to Buy Nassau Trust
abstract: Norstar Bancorp, a statewide bank holding company based in Albany, said it had agreed to acquire the Nassau Trust Company, which has 11 bank branches in Nassau and Suffolk Counties and had assets of $170 million as of Sept. 30.   Under the agreement, Norstar will offer to buy all 832,048 common shares of Nassau Trust.

headline: NICARAGUAN, SUING U.S., TELLS OF EXILE ATTACK
abstract: A Nicaraguan health official who said she was attacked by a group of anti-Sandinists on her country's border with Honduras last year has been brought to the United States to publicize a suit filed by seven Nicaraguans against the Reagan Administration. The suit seeks to challenge American support for such paramilitary groups.   The official, Dr. Myrna K. Cunningham, who works for the Nicaraguan Ministry of Health, and the other plaintiffs are represented by the Center for Constitutional Rights, a New York-based public interest legal group.

headline: Your Money; Withholding On Pensions
abstract: MILLIONS of Americans are aware by now that withholding on interest and dividends will begin next July 1. But less known to the public is the fact that there will also be withholding on pensions and annuities - and that, in many instances, this withholding will start next Jan. 1.   Many major payers of pensions and annuities, such as banks and insurance companies, have opposed the January deadline established in the 1982 tax law as unrealistic and unworkable. Perhaps as a result, the Internal Revenue Service released new regulations yesterday providing for a postponement on a case-by-case basis until April 1 or July 1, depending on whether the original target causes undue hardship to payers.

headline: DOW DROPS 16.74 MORE, TO 992.64
abstract: The Dow Jones industrial average dropped 16.74 points yesterday as bank trust departments and other large institutional investors continued to lighten their stock portfolios in profit taking.   Closing at 992.64, its low for the day, the Dow has plunged 64 points in the last six sessions. Yesterday's market setback was broadly based. Declining issues on the New York Stock Exchange outnumbered gainers by almost a 4-to-1 ratio.   Volume contracted to 81 million shares from 98.4 million on Tuesday, when stock prices abruptly turned lower after a strong opening.
