headline: McNamara Urges Shift In U.S. Atomic Strategy
abstract: Former Defense Secretary Robert S. McNamara suggested a shift in United States military strategy today in which Atlantic alliance and Warsaw Pact nations would renounce the use of a nuclear response to an attack ''until it has been determined beyond any reasonable doubt'' that the assault was intentional.   Mr. McNamara made his comments after receiving a $50,000 prize with Gerard C. Smith, former director of the Arms Control and Disarmament Agency, and McGeorge Bundy, national security adviser to Presidents Kennedy and Johnson.

headline: NICARAGUAN EXILE LIMITS ROLE OF U.S.
abstract: The top commander of exile forces seeking to overthrow the leftist Government in Nicaragua said today that the aims and operations of his troops were not subject to control by the United States.   Enrique Bermudez, a former colonel in the Nicaraguan National Guard who now commands 3,000 to 6,000 irregular troops in Honduras and Nicaragua, said in a interview: ''We would never accept the role of American mercenary. It is not acceptable to us to carry out missions to interdict Cuban and Russian supply lines to El Salvador. We are Nicaraguans and our objective is to overthrow the Communists and install a democratic government in our country.''

headline: ETHIOPIAN DRIVE AGAINST SOMALIA BOGS DOWN
abstract: An Ethiopian-sponsored military campaign to overthrow Somalia's leader, Gen. Mohammed Siad Barre, seems to be bogged down.   Soviet-armed invaders still hold some Somali territory and President Siad Barre's United States-supplied forces are unable to dislodge them. But with the campaign just over three months old, Western and Somali sources said, the invaders have failed to achieve a decisive success and General Siad Barre appears to have weathered yet another threat to his 13-year-old presidency.   The effort to bring down the general's autocratic, pro-Western Government began on June 30, when Somali dissidents in the Somali Democratic Salvation Front, backed by a strong, mechanized force of Ethiopian troops, crossed the long-disputed Somali-Ethiopian border and seized two small towns, Galdogob and Balanballe.

headline: CHRISTIANS ARE TORN IN THE LAND OF DR. LIVINGSTON
abstract: This is the land where David Livingstone lies buried and where, too, the great evangelical effort of the Scottish missionary and his peers has stamped itself indelibly on a nation once steeped in Africa's animism.   Three out of every four of Zambia's six million people profess adherence to one Christian church or another, and Livingstone is still venerated in the town named after him, at the Victoria Falls on the Zambezi River, and in the modest shrine to the north where he finally succumbed to disease, thousands of miles from home.   But the legacy, these days, of the early evangelists is tainted by schisms and debates among their successors that have pitted, in one case, a black laity against white clerics, and, in others, have brought allegations of misdeeds, sorcery and illicit liaisons among the priesthood.   The divisions are such, according to an analyst of church affairs, that a threat has arisen of a formal schism between Zambia's Roman Catholics and the Vatican that would add to the ranks of southern Africa's 2,000 separatist churches. Africa's Spiritual Realities   The debate has also evoked the wider conflict between the forms of religion imposed by outsiders and an African desire to remodel the church in a manner perceived as more suited to the continent's spiritual realities.

headline: INCO LOSS IN QUARTER A RECORD
abstract: Even before Charles F. Baird, chairman of Inco Ltd., told his board of directors today that he had sold Inco's two corporate jets, it was clear that the world's largest nickel company had seen better weeks.   Inco began the week by announcing that its giant nickel mine in Sudbury, Ontario, would remain closed three months longer than planned because of sagging worldwide metals demand, and today it reported the worst operating results of any quarter in the company's history, a loss of $66.4 million. Persistent labor and political critics again called for the company's nationalization.

headline: Edward Teller in Israel To Advise on a Reactor
abstract: Edward Teller is in Israel to advise the Government on building a nuclear reactor for peaceful purposes, a spokesman for the Ministry of Science said today.   Dr. Teller, a Hungarian-born American now 74 years old, worked on the Manhattan Project that resulted in the development of the atomic bomb in World War II.

headline: METROPOLITAN LIFE FILLS TWO TOP POSTS
abstract: The Metropolitan Life Insurance Company announced yesterday that John J. Creedon had been designated chief executive officer and Robert G. Schwartz chairman.   The changes will come about with the retirement Feb.3 of Richard R. Shinn, 64 years old, the current chairman and chief executive officer.   Mr. Creedon, 58, has been president and will retain that title. Mr. Schwartz, 54, has been vice chairman. Both men were promoted to those positions two years ago, when Mr. Shinn became chairman and chief executive officer. At the time, Mr. Shinn said they were being groomed as candidates for advancement when he retired.

headline: QUEUING UP FOR CODFISH ROE
abstract: A man was getting prunes with Armagnac as a present - $23. For one of her gifts, a woman was getting Perugina chocolates contained in a china violin - $25. Cima alla Genovese was moving. Torta Trevigiana was moving. Pagnotta Pugliese was moving.   ''Do you know what a Scotch bun is?'' a moon-faced man wanted to know.  ''It's a very, very heavy fruit cake,'' a salesman informed him.  ''Tastes like Scotch?'' ''I'm not sure. It's very, very heavy.'' It was Christmas time at DDL Foodshow, up on Columbus Avenue and 81st Street. People queued up, wanting their finnan haddie, wanting their smoked English codfish roe, wanting their Tsar Nickolai whitefish caviar.

headline: PANHANDLE EASTERN CORP reports earnings for QTr to Sept 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: BRITISH STOCK TENDER
abstract: The Bank of England announced the tender of $250 million of 2 1/2 percent index-linked Treasury stock maturing in 2003.

headline: Cardinal of Florence Has a Heart Attack
abstract: Giovanni Cardinal Benelli of Florence, one of the most influential Roman Catholic prelates, was in critical condition today after an acute heart attack, doctors said.   The 61-year-old Cardinal, Deputy Secretary of State at the Vatican under Pope Paul VI and once considered a leading candidate for the papacy, was taken to the hospital on Friday night after he was discovered unconscious in bed, his office said.

headline: A SLIMMER CADILLAC FAIRVIEW
abstract: The Cadillac Fairview Corporation drew attention in the 1970's by putting together dramatic real estate deals that changed skylines from Calgary to California. In these less buoyant times, it is attracting even more attention through a strategy of becoming stronger by becoming smaller.   In October, Cadillac forfeited a $21 million downpayment on property at Third Avenue and 53d Street in New York that it viewed as uneconomical. The property, which was to have been the site of a major office tower, had been purchased for $105 million, or an astronomical $1,900 a square foot.

headline: MIDLAND RESOURCES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Settlements by Hyatt
abstract: More than half the claims filed on behalf of victims of the Hyatt Regency skywalk collapse have been settled out of court, the hotel's lawyers reported. Michael Waldeck, who represents the Hyatt Hotels Corportion, operator of the Regency, and Lawrence Berkowitz, who represents the Crown Center Redevelopment Corporation, the owners, said insurers had settled 190 of 334 lawsuits and other claims, paying out more than $29 million.  Two suspended walkways in the hotel collapsed on July 17, 1981, killing 114 persons and injuring 200.

headline: WALTER, JIM, CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Moscow Is Said to Bar Jewish Chess Players
abstract: Dissident sources said today that the Soviet police had barred a group of Jewish chess players from visiting the former Soviet chess champion, Boris Gulko, who is on hunger strike to support his demand to be allowed to emigrate to Israel.   The dissidents said the players had planned to play a ''blitz tournament'' at Mr. Gulko's Moscow apartment as a gesture of support for his campaign.

headline: Tosco-AZL Link
abstract: The $95 million takeover of AZL Resources by the Tosco Corporation has been approved by directors of both companies, and AZL shareholders are expected to vote on it later this year, officials said.

headline: EPIDEMIC OF DENGUE FEVER SWEEPS NEW DELHI
abstract: Health officials here say that the capital has been swept by an especially virulent epidemic of dengue fever, a mosquito-borne disease that produces symptoms comparable to severe influenza.   Dr. Mahendra Dutta of the National Institute of Communicable Diseases said the epidemic, which began to develop two months ago, was the worst since 1970. While no deaths from the dengue virus have been reported here, thousands of people have come down with the disease, officials say.

headline: Exxon Price Cuts
abstract: Exxon U.S.A. announced additional price cuts for barge-load quantities of heating oil in New York Harbor, effective immediately.

headline: Altman, Stoller, Weiss Expands Mead Account
abstract: Altman, Stoller, Weiss has obviously been giving good service to the Mead Corporation, because the client has sent new business its way.

headline: I.M.F. Plan For Mexico
abstract: The International Monetary Fund is expected to approve a loan of nearly $3.9 billion for Mexico on Thursday, monetary sources said today.   The sources said the agency would impose strict conditions on the loan, which will run for three years, in an attempt to bring Mexico back from the brink of insolvency.

headline: System Down
abstract: To The Business Editor: When I was shopping for my word processor, I had even more trouble getting the Digital Equipment Corporation's attention than Stanley Klein did in ''Reprogramming at Digital'' (Sept.26).

headline: Western Airlines Chief Says He'll Stay in Post
abstract: Neil G. Bergt, the chairman and chief executive officer of Western Airlines, told the company's directors today that he has ''no immediate plans'' to leave Western, the company said.   Speculation about Mr. Bergt's future with the airline mounted after his plan to acquire Wien Air Alaska through his privately owned Eagle International Corporation was abandoned last Friday, reportedly because the Civil Aeronautics Board had attached conditions to the transaction.   Mr. Bergt, who was named to Western's top post last Dec. 8, had intended to merge Wien into Western in exchange for stock after Eagle reached an agreement last May to acquire Wien from the Household International Corporation for $50 million.

headline: FLORIDA POWER & LIGHT CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: PARIS AIDE OFFERS VIEWS ON MIDEAST
abstract: Foreign Minister Claude Cheysson of France says that a combination of political guarantees and border surveillance using advanced detection equipment could go far to break the impasse on achieving an overall broad Middle East peace.   Mr. Cheysson, interviewed Saturday morning in his office at the Quai d'Orsay, said the basic problem lay in assuring the security of all governments in the region. A solution could be found, he said, only when all interested parties began to redefine the question of security.   ''What does security mean?'' he asked. ''Does it mean territories when it's a difference of only 50 miles? This makes no sense.'' Security, Mr. Cheysson said, constitutes recognized borders and political settlements by all parties concerned.

headline: SHELL OIL COMPANIES reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: NORDSTROM INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Lloyd's Begins Inquiry
abstract: Lloyd's of London said it had appointed Anthony Colman, a lawyer, and Stephen Hailey of accountants Arthur Andersen & Company as a committee of inquiry to take control of the investigation into the involvement of any Lloyd's person, firm or company with the Fidentia Marine Insurance Company. last week Lloyd's announced it was investigating relationships with Fidentia, which was formerly a subsidiary of Brookgate Investments, the holding company of Brooks & Dooley Underwriting Ltd., managing agents at Lloyd's.

headline: WEINBERGER MEETS THAI OFFICIALS ON SECOND STOP OF 5-NATION TOUR
abstract: Secretary of Defense Caspar W.  Weinberger met with Thai leaders here today on a tour designed to show American support for friendly nations in Southeast Asia and the Pacific.   High on the region's security agenda are Vietnam's occupation of Cambodia, the buildup of the Soviet Navy in the Pacific, the desire of some nations for a larger American naval presence and the desire of others for more arms aid.   Mr. Weinberger told reporters this morning in Singapore, where he talked with Prime Minister Lee Kuan Yew, that what he sees as a Soviet threat ''is clearly increasing in the Pacific and it is obviously the thing we discuss with each of the countries.''

headline: PUSH BY BANKS TO SELL ACCOUNT
abstract: In a rush of jostling, posturing and redesigning, banks and savings institutions are concocting their plans for tomorrow's debut of the new money market fund accounts.   The financial marketers have taken the guidelines - no interest rate ceiling on a minimum deposit of $2,500 and only six preauthorized withdrawals - and dressed them up to compete for the estimated $100 billion at stake. Some are offering interest rates on the savings accounts above 11 percent, while others are trying cash bonuses.   In the midst of their planning last week, bankers and thrift institution executives received word that, on Jan. 5, they would also be permitted to offer a checking account with unrestricted interest rates and a $2,500 minimum deposit.

headline: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
abstract: * Alpha Microsystems, Irvine, Calif., has elected Richard A.  Cortese president and chief executive officer, succeeding Robert E.  Hitchcock, who is assuming the new positions of vice chairman and director of research.   * American Telephone and Telegraph Co. has named Morris Tanenbaum chairman and chief executive of its proposed Interexchange Organization, the new name for its expanded long-distance phone system. Robert W. Kleinert was named president and chief operating officer of the system, and Sam R. Willcoxon executive vice president, marketing.

headline: Toys R Us
abstract: The Canadian Government has given permission to Toys R Us to open stores in Canada, the company said.

headline: MIDDLE WEST
abstract: BECAUSE of the recession and rising unemployment - up 2 to 3 percent over last year in Middle Western states - it ish ard to forecast industry's need for workers in the region. Certain i ndustries, such as retailing and construction, are stalled but are e xpected to eventually make a moderate to strong comeback. The impacto f the recession and a switch in emphasis from manufacturing to s ervice industries is expected to have a greater effect on heavy i ndustrial states such as Illinois, Michigan and Ohio, than on o thers, such as Wisconsin.

headline: SmithKline Net Up 10%
abstract: The SmithKline Beckman Corporation announced today that its third-quarter net earnings were $118.8 million, or $1.44 a share, up 10 percent, from $108 million, or $1.31, a year earlier. Third-quarter sales rose 13 percent, to $762.1 million, from $674.3 million in the same period last year. ''Strong performance in the company's ethical pharmaceuticals business in the United States and continued growth in eye and skin care operations were the key factors in our progress during the quarter,'' Henry Wendt, president, said

headline: Miami Bootleg Market Found in Haitian Aid
abstract: Food sent to Haiti through the United States foreign aid program is routinely smuggled back to the United States and sold at a profit to the Haitian exile community in Miami, The Miami Herald reported today.   United States-donated food intended for malnourished Haitians is also routinely sold on the black market in Port-au-Prince and other Haitian cities, The Herald said in an article based on a four-month investigation.

headline: Coast Federal Sale
abstract: Coast Federal Savings and Loan Association said it has sold securities backed by $350 million of mortgages on California properties to the California State Retirement Fund. The sale, which was arranged with the help of two national secondary market agencies, is believed to be the largest single sale to a state pension fund. Coast Federal said it had used $158 million of securities guaranteed by the Federal National Mortgage Association and $92 million guaranteed by the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation in the sale.

headline: BODY OF ULSTER MILITIAMAN SOUGHT
abstract: Security forces on both sides of the Northern Ireland border mounted major searches today for the body of a Protestant militia sergeant killed by Irish Republican Army guerrillas.   A caller to a Belfast radio station said the I.R.A. had ''executed'' Thomas Cochrane, a sergeant in the Ulster Defense Regiment, for involvement in groups responsible for ''a number of serious crimes'' against Catholics.

headline: SCOT LAD FOODS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: MITTERRAND NOW FAVORS A MISSILE COMPROMISE
abstract: President Francois Mitterrand, who will meet here Tuesday with Secretary of State George P. Shultz, has modified his support for the American negotiating position in the talks with the Soviet Union on medium-range missiles in Europe.   While continuing to stress that the Soviet Union has an advantage in these missiles and that the decision of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization to counter them with the new American missiles is justified, Mr. Mitterrand is now also saying that the solution may be in a compromise.   Until recently, France had given no indication that its attitude varied from the Atlantic alliance position supporting the ''zero solution'' advanced by the Reagan Administration. Mr. Reagan offered to forgo plans to deploy 572 Pershing 2 and cruise missiles in Western Europe starting at the end of 1983 if the Soviet Union would scrap its more than 300 SS-20 missiles.

headline: EUROPEANS PRESS MOSCOW ON 2 ISSUES
abstract: The leaders of the 10 Common Market countries called on the Soviet Government today for initiatives on Afghanistan and disarmament and said such steps would meet with a positive response in Western Europe.   The chiefs of state and government, ending a two-day European council meeting here, avoided any assessment of the new Soviet leadership, however, and made clear that their policy, described as being based on ''principles of firmness and dialogue,'' would not change.   At the same time, and in preparation for talks between United States and Common Market officials next week on political, financial and trade matters, the European leaders said they were determined to insure ''solid and confident relations between the community and the United States.'' 2 Declarations Issued   The European Economic Community's positions were set out in two declarations. The statements covered a wide range of international and economic issues, but dealt only in passing with the question of protectionism, which dominated most of the private exchanges between the leaders and will be at the center of the United States-European meetings next week.

headline: GERBER SCIENTIFIC INSTRUMENT CO reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Executive Named To New Conoco Job
abstract: E.I. du Pont de Nemours & Company announced yesterday that Wilfred P. Schmoe would become chief operating officer of its Conoco Inc.  subsidiary, a newly created position, in May.   Du Pont took over Conoco a year ago and paid $7.5 billion for the company, winning out over Joseph E. Seagrams & Sons and the Mobil Corporation.

headline: Harvester Sale By Teledyne
abstract: Teledyne Inc. sold 1.5 million common shares of its 5.5 million shares of the International Harvester Company in the open market from Dec.1 through Dec. 10, according to a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission. Prices ranged from $2.95 to $3.95 a share.

headline: SENATE VOTES TO EXTEND COMMODITIES COMMISSION
abstract: The Senate today approved legislation extending the life of the Commodity Futures Trading Commission for two years. At the same time it defeated an Administration proposal to levy a fee on all commodity futures transactions that was intended to finance most of the agency's operations.   The authorization bill passed by a vote of 91 to 0.  The agency's authority technically expired at midnight Thursday, but the commission can remain in business under the continuing funding resolution that is expected to win Senate and House approval before Congress recesses this weekend.

headline: Military Analysis
abstract: Israel's Army and Air Force have emerged from the campaign in Lebanon triumphant but troubled. Victories over the Syrian Army and Air Force and the virtual elimination of the Palestine Liberation   Organization as a military threat appear to be modified by doubts about the wisdom of the last phases of the military operation and their effect upon American public opinion.   Recent conversations with junior Israeli officers at the front in Lebanon and with senior officers in Israel and elsewhere indicate that there was enough questioning among officers and men about a final and probably costly thrust into West Beirut to affect the command decision not to make such an attack while the guerrillas were still there in force. Sources at a command level say they do not think American pressure for an agreement for the departure of the P.L.O. fighters had anything to do with the decision not to mount an all-out attack.

headline: MILITARY SHAKE-UP IS REPORTED IN CHINA
abstract: Major changes in China's armed forces appear to be under way with the replacement of the commanders of three strategic military regions.   The changes are expected to signal a wider reorganization of the leadership of the Chinese Army, which has 4.23 million men and women under arms.   The shuffle is clearly part of the Chinese leader Deng Xiaoping's drive to weed out overage and leftist officials from posts of influence.   The changes reported so far involve the Nanjing, Canton and Chengdu military regions. There are rumors that as many as six to eight of China's 11 military regions could end up with new commanders.

headline: Chevron Venture
abstract: Chevron U.S.A. and Arco Alaska Inc.  plan to drill exploratory wells in Alaskan waters, spokesmen for the two companies said.

headline: Economic Scene; Stock Market As Forecaster
abstract: PRESIDENT REAGAN has hailed the surge of the stock market as evidence of public confidence that his policies are working and that the economy is about to swing into a healthy recovery. But is the stock market a reliable forecaster?   Prof. Paul A. Samuelson of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, a winner of the Nobel Memorial Prize in Economic Science, is responsible for the celebrated observation that the stock market ''had forecast nine of the last five recessions.'' That was not an idle joke but was based on empirical evidence, as of the time it was made in 1962.

headline: ECONOMIC AFFAIRS; POLITICAL BUBBLE, TOIL AND TROUBLE
abstract: IN economic policy making, Holloween is now celebrated on Election D ay. The magic potions promised to cure the nation's economic ills a re brought to the ballot box. The new governor or senator h enceforth promises to use them to create jobs, prevent inflation, a nd restore this nation's deserved position of leadership.  What are the potions that will do all this? Most are common patent medicines, some are even placebos, and all except a few will evaporate by the first of next year. The Food and Drug Administration never inspects any of them because they are harmless.

headline: NIGERIANS PREPARE FOR 1983 ELECTION
abstract: Next year Nigeria will stop doing most other things for a month, and the nation's attention will be focused exclusively on a series of state and national elections.   The elections, officials here believe, will devour energies, consume passions and put to the test a tangled democracy that sees itself as a model for black-ruled Africa and proof to the world of a continent's political maturity.   The elections are still nine months away, but the visitor to this torrid capital of five million people might think they were under way now, so intense is Nigeria's perennial political fervor.   Through the magnifying prism of the nation's self-perception, the voting will encompass forces and emotions on the grand scale. Roughly one-quarter of sub-Saharan Africa's 350 million people will somehow or other be touched by the national vote, and the victor will control black-ruled Africa's greatest wealth.

headline: U.N. FIGHT OVER PRESS FREEDOM: THE NEXT ROUND
abstract: The Western press is preparing for another confrontation with the developing countries and the Soviet bloc over questions of press freedom.   In this round, it has strong support from the Reagan Administration and Congress, which are disturbed by what they see as the implications of a proposed ''new world information and communication order.'' And, to counter what has been an ideological debate over what some critics see as imbalance in news coverage, the press has taken some practical initiatives recently to improve third-world communications and to increase Western awareness of events in the developing nations.   Once again, the forum for the debate is the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization, which will convene its 157 member nations in a general session tomorrow in Paris. The session is to set an agenda called the ''medium-term plan'' for Unesco activities during the rest of the decade.

headline: SUPER VALU STORES INC reports earnings for 12 weeks to Dec 4
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: EXCERPTS FROM MINISTERIAL DECLARATION AT GATT CONFERENCE
abstract: Following are excerpts from the ministerial declaration adopted today at the conference of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade:   The contracting parties recognize that the interdependence of national economies means that no country can solve its trade problems in isolation and also that solutions would be greatly facilitated by parallel efforts in the financial and monetary fields.   In this light, they commit themselves to reduce trade frictions, overcome protectionist pressures, avoid using export subsidies inconsistent with Article XVI of the GATT and promote the liberalization and expansion of trade.   They are therefore determined to create, through concerted action, a renewed consensus in support of the GATT system, so as to restore and reinforce confidence in its capacity to provide a stable and predictable trading environment and respond to new challenges. Commitment Is Reaffirmed   The contracting parties have accordingly decided: To reaffirm their commitment to abide by their GATT obligations and to support and improve the GATT trading system, so that it may contribute vigorously to the further liberalization and expansion of trade based on mutual commitment, mutual advantage and overall reciprocity and the most-favored-nation clause.

headline: LEUCADIA NATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Economic Scene; How to Make 1983 Happier
abstract: NEW YEAR'S EVE is a time for nostalgia and looking ahead. But the nostalgia over 1982 is curdled: The year turned out much worse than expected. Last February, the President's Council of Economic Advisers said in its annual report: ''The current recession is expected to end early in 1982.'' It has still not ended. And a major worry for the coming year is that unemployment, now close to 11 percent, will hang on near that level as employers continue to keep payrolls lean in an effort to operate profitably.   Anxieties are rife - among concerned employers as well as among workers - that technology is making a growing number of people with low skills and inadequate education unemployable.

headline: BURGER BATTLE SHIFTS TO COURT
abstract: The battle of the burger has moved from the television screens to the courtrooms.  The fight began with an advertising offensive by Burger King, the No.2 fast-hamburger chain, which has been losing its share of the market to McDonald's, the sales leader, and Wendy's, the fastexpanding No.3 chain.   Taking its cue from other second choices, notably Pepsi-Cola, Burger King, a Pillsbury susidiary, ordered a taste test. Saying the results showed that its burgers were favored over those of its two rivals, Burger King started a $20 million national advertising campaign based on the findings.

headline: MOST FARES RAISED 5% BY AIRLINES
abstract: Most of the nation's major airlines quietly put into effect yesterday a 5 percent increase in fares on most of their domestic routes in hopes of increasing profitability.   The fare increases, which were not announced, were in sharp contrast to the highly publicized discounts on some transcontinental and New York-to-Florida fares that also went into effect this week.  The discounts reduce the one-way fares on these routes to $99 for short periods before and after the Christmas holiday.   The 5 percent increase, which applies to the overwhelming majority of the nation's routes, is the third across-the-board fare rise this year: In July, fares rose $10, and in September, there was a 5 percent increase. Under current deregulation rules, the airlines are able to put increases into effect after notifying the Civil Aeronautics Board.

headline: U.S. WELCOMES SEOUL'S MOVE TO RELEASE 1,200 PRISONERS
abstract: The State Department welcomed the release of 1,200 prisoners today by the South Korean Government, saying it ''will make a further contribution to political harmony in Korea.''   Officials were hopeful that the amnesty, combined with the earlier release of Kim Dae Jung, South Korea's leading opposition figure, who arrived in the United States Thursday night, signified the start of political liberalization in South Korea.   Officials said the recent actions by Seoul at the very least appeared designed to improve the political atmosphere when Secretary of State George P. Shultz visits South Korea Feb. 6 through Feb. 8.   Seoul's latest action granted amnesty to 1,200 prisoners including 48 political detainees, seven of whom had been jailed with Mr. Kim.

headline: KROEHLER MANUFACTURING CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: WALESA ASKS WARSAW TO FREE DETAINEES AND RESTORE UNIONS
abstract: Lech Walesa, leader of the outlawed Solidarity trade union, has asked Poland's martial law ruler to restore the legal status of free labor unions and grant amnesty to all internees.    Mr. Walesa said in a letter to Gen. Wojciech Jaruzelski that was made available to news organizations today that the two actions could be the basis for a national reconciliation in Poland, where martial law has been in force for a year.   ''The deep and prolonged crisis can be overcome, primarily by the efforts of the whole society,'' Mr. Walesa wrote. ''I am ready to take part in work leading to this aim.''

headline: GENERAL ENERGY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: COURT TO DECIDE I.R.S.-BANKRUPTCY ISSUE
abstract: The Supreme Court agreed today to decide whether the Internal Revenue Service can be required to return property it has seized from a company that later seeks reorganization under the Federal bankruptcy law.   In order to help troubled companies reorganize and continue operating, bankruptcy courts are empowered to prevent ordinary commercial creditors from disposing of the bankrupt company's assets to which they might otherwise be entitled. Under this so-called turn-over authority, the creditors must return certain assets to the bankrupt company for its use during the reorganization.   But various Federal courts have disagreed over whether this provision also applies to the Internal Revenue Service, which is often a major creditor of a company that is on the verge of bankruptcy. The case the Court accepted today is an appeal by the Internal Revenue Service from a decision by the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit, in New York.

headline: OWENS & MINOR INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: THOMSON MAY GET GRUNDIG
abstract: Thomson-Brandt, a nationalized French electronics group, is close to an agreement to acquire control of Grundig A.G., a major West German electrical concern that is partly owned by N.V.  Philips of the Netherlands, corporate sources said today.   The merger would create a European electronics giant, closely linked to Philips and able to compete with Japanese electronics companies, both in Europe and other markets. Based on 1981 figures, the new company would have annual sales equivalent to about $4.6 billion.   The group would concentrate initially on the radio, television and video recorder field, the sources said.  A Grundig spokesman confirmed that talks were under way but emphasized that no agreement had yet been reached. No estimate was offered as to the price that Thomson would pay for Grundig.

headline: China Plans to Start Building Its First Atomic Power Plant
abstract: China will break ground early next year for its first nuclear power station and expects to complete it in seven years, the official New China News Agency reported today.   The agency said crews would start this month laying out roads, water and power lines and the foundation of the 300-megawatt plant at Hangzhou Bay about 80 miles southwest of Shanghai.   The station will serve the heavily industrialized Shanghai area, which is far from China's coal and hydroelectric energy sources.

headline: JAPAN EASES TARIFFS ON SOME IMPORTS
abstract: The Japanese Government said today that it planned to cut import tariffs on more than 70 items in another effort to ease the mounting friction with its Western trading partners. The list of items includes tobacco products, chocolate, biscuits and 40 other agricultural goods, and 28 manufactured items.   The tariff reductions are to become effective in April.  The effect the move will have on increasing imports will probably be comparatively slight - about $380 million a year, according to an unofficial Government estimate. By comparison, the United States trade defict with Japan is expected to reach a record $19 billion this year.

headline: NATIONAL CONTROLS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: RELATIVE OF SADAT INDICTED IN EGYPT
abstract: The Egyptian prosecutor's office indicted the half brother of Anwar el-Sadat today on charges that included influence peddling, the unlawful seizure of Government and private property, black marketeering and the import and sale of ''rotten'' food.   The case of the half brother, Esmat Sadat, and his two sons goes to trial Saturday. Publishing pictures of the voluminous stacks of documents the prosecution plans to use against Mr. Sadat, semiofficial newspapers said today that the charges referred to the acquisition of ''fortunes through pillage, usurpation and by using their influence as relatives of the late President in their dealings with the ministries of housing, communications, supply, agriculture and public health.''

headline: PRODUCTION NOW FOCUS OF OPEC
abstract: Ministers of the 13 OPEC countries adjourned today the first round of formal talks that have so far failed to yield an effective agreement on how much oil each member should produce. The meetings resume Monday.   Marc S.N. Nguema of Gabon, the Secretary General of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries, told reporters at the conclusion of today's meeting that ''most ministers are amenable to the idea that we must have a ceiling.'' Production Limit Sought   Fixing a maximum production goal and allocating individual national ceilings have become the foremost goals of the conference, after the ministers agreed during informal talks Friday and Saturday to maintain OPEC's current oil price of $34 for a barrel of Arabia Light crude. There are 42 gallons in a barrel.

headline: NEW BONN BUDGET CUTS MILITARY OUTLAY
abstract: West Germany's new conservative Government offered a 1983 budget today that foresees a drop in military spending from the level previously set by the Social Democratic Government of Chancellor Helmut Schmidt.   Gerhard Stoltenberg, the Finance Minister in the new Government headed by Chancellor Helmut Kohl, said at a news conference that the budget provided for 2.9 percent growth and would amount to total Government spending of 253.8 billion marks, or $99.5 billion.   Mr. Stoltenberg said the budget was based on ''economic assumptions that are serious and, for the moment, realistic.'' He said Bonn faced an acute rise in joblessness in coming months that would cut tax revenues and increase welfare costs. Despite an austerity package including higher taxes, welfare payment cuts and reduced subsidies to ailing industries, he said, public borrowing is expected to rise to the equivalent of $16.2 billion from $15.6 billion this year. In July, the former Government, figuring on a brighter economy next year, projected a net credit need of $11.1 billion in 1983.

headline: 5 WAYS TO TRY TO AVERT TAMPERING WITH DRUGS
abstract: Five main packaging techniques are available to manufacturers of over-the-counter drugs to make their products more nearly tamperproof, a packaging expert said yesterday.   the expert, Ben Miyares, who is executive editor of Food and Drug Packaging, a monthly trade journal owned by Harcourt Brace Jovanovich, said, "Starting with the individual capsule itself, there are some capsule designes which lock so that once they are closed, they cannot be pulled apart" without leaving easily visible signs.  Packaging experts said that Tylenol has been packaged in a conventional two-part capsule in unsealed bottles. Some samples of Tylenol sold in the Chicago area had been poisoned with cyanide, leading to seven deaths.

headline: FINANCE BRIEFS
abstract: * Becton Dickinson & Co. filed a shelf registration statement with the S.E.C. for up to $150 million of debt securities, with terms to be set at the time of sale.   * Commodore Corp. said it plans to file in the near future for an offering of at least 2.75 million common shares; the company currently has about 3.1 million shares outstanding.

headline: FED VOTED FOR FASTER MONEY RISE
abstract: The Federal Reserve System, clearly concerned about continuing weakness in the econony, voted last month to accept growth in its broadest meaasures of the money supply at rates above the targets originally established for 1982.   The central bank reported yesterday that, at a meeting in mid-November, the Federal Open Market Committee, its key policy group, had continued to shift its focus at least temporarily to controlling interest rates rather than managing the money supply. The record of the committee's discussions is normally released with a delay of about six weeks, although most of what was released yesterday had been widely assumed by credit market participants.

headline: Libyan Oil Output Up
abstract: Libya has increased its crude oil production to more than 1.7 million barrels a day, the Middle East Economic Survey said today. The country's output, which had averaged 747,000 barrels a day in the second quarter, rose to 1.5 million a day in September.

headline: Kidnappers Thwarted in Italy
abstract: Fifty paramilitary policemen stormed an apartment in a town north of Rome Thursday night and freed the kidnapped 19-year-old daughter of a wealthy businessman. Eight Sardinians were arrested, officers reported. Maria Luisa Achille, who was abducted near her family's villa on the outskirts of Rome Sept.  22, was reported in good condition.

headline: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
abstract: * American Hoist and Derrick Co., St. Paul, has named Charles G.  Truzinski chief financial officer.

headline: THE MX'S ECONOMIC IMPACT
abstract: The Congressional battle this week over the MX missile is likely to have an economic impact far beyond the 20 square miles of southeastern Wyoming ranch country that the Reagan Administration has chosen for its 100 missile silos.   Thirteen major military contractors and 135,000 workers in plants across the nation have a huge stake in the House of Representatives vote on whether to produce the MX, the missile that President Reagan considers one of the pillars of his Administration's strategic policy.   The Air Force has already spent $4.5 billion on research and development for the MX, which stands for missile experimental, and expects ultimately to spend $26 billion if Congress approves President Reagan's ''dense pack'' basing system. Floor Fight Expected   Nearly $2 billion was directed to the 13 contractors and to scores of subcontractors in the last fiscal year alone. Although Mr.  Reagan's proposal was jeopardized last Thursday when the House Appropriations Committee narrowly defeated an attempt to delete $988 million in MX production money from the military appropriations bill, a floor fight on the missile and its basing mode is expected this week.

headline: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
abstract: * Allied Chemical Co., Morris Township, N.J., has appointed Robert F. Traflet executive vice president.   * Aminoil USA Inc., Houston, has elected John P. McCloskey executive vice president, marketing.

headline: Merger Defense
abstract: To the Business Editor: In his article, ''The Vanity of the Takeover Game'' (Oct.3), William Nordhaus lumps the recent Bendix mess, ''conglomerate'' mergers and ''major'' mergers, together in one big counterproductive heap. Neglecting any and all benefits of mergers, he hastens toward his inevitable call for legal restrictions on mergers.   Lest his indiscriminate analysis cast suspicion on mergers in general, we would like to set the merger record straight.  Because there is no significant antitrust overlap in ''specific markets,'' Mr. Nordhaus reasons that the Bendix merger is a pure ''conglomerate'' merger. All pure conglomerate mergers fall outside antitrust overlap areas. But it does not follow that all mergers that fall outside such areas are pure conglomerate mergers. By making this argument, Mr. Nordhaus effectively ignores the thousands of mergers every year that neither achieve significant gain in market concentration nor fall within the pure conglomerate category.

headline: Polaroid Net Up in Quarter
abstract: The Polaroid Corporation reported yesterday that net earnings for the third quarter rose 29.7 percent, to $8.3 million, or 26 cents a share, from $6.4 million, or 19 cents a share, a year earlier, although worldwide sales sank 11.8 percent, to $316.8 million, from $359 million.   In a statement, William J. McCune Jr., Polariod's chief executive officer, said the improved earnings picture during the third quarter reflected continued efforts to control costs.

headline: JEWS SETTLE ON A 'VOLCANO' IN THE CENTER OF HEBRON
abstract: Occupied West Bank - The muezzins were summoning the faithful to prayer from mosques all over Hebron, a conservative Moslem town under Israeli occupation since 1967.   For a few minutes, they all but drowned out the voice of Miriam Levinger, a member of the militant Jewish group called Gush Emunim, or Bloc of the Faithful.   Mrs. Levinger, the wife of Rabbi Moshe Levinger, a leader of Gush EmuEmuher husband and 9 of their 11 children had chosen to move into the old abandoned Jewish quarter of Hebron. The district is in the densely populated center of this ancient town just behind a teeming marketplace.

headline: VATICAN AIDE DEFENDS POPE'S MEETING WITH ARAFAT
abstract: The Vatican has formally responded to protests by American Jews over the recent meeting between Pope John Paul II and Yasir Arafat, the leader of the Palestine Liberation Organization.   In a letter to a prominent American Jew, the Vatican defended the meeting as consistent with the Pope's efforts to promote peace and understanding. It said the act of receiving an individual in no way implied approval of his ideas and actions.   The recipient of the letter, Julius Berman, chairman of the Conference of Presidents of Major American Jewish Organizations, criticized the Vatican's position, saying it offered Jews ''no comfort.''

headline: Accounts
abstract: * SCI-COM Computer Systems Inc., Bridgewater, N.J., to AC&R Advertising Inc.   * Benzel-Busch Motor Corp., Englewood, N.J., to Keyes Martin, Springfield, N.J.

headline: BOY, 2, IS KILLED AND 34 ARE HURT
abstract: Unidentified gunmen threw hand grenades and fired submachine guns at worshipers leaving the Rome synagogue today at the conclusion of Sabbath services.   A 2-year-old boy was killed and 34 people were wounded, some seriously.  Witnesses gave differing accounts of the attack, but most said it was carried out by two men with dark complexions.  Some witnesses said the men fled on foot; others reported that they escaped in a car in which two accomplices were waiting.

headline: Hoechst Talks With Kuwait
abstract: The Hoechst chemical group is discussing industrial cooperation with the Kuwait National Petroleum Corporation, which has acquired nearly 25 percent of the German company.   Rolf Sammet, Hoechst's chairman, said at a news conference Wednesday that the state-owned Kuwait company had acquired ''more than 24 percent, but certainly less than 25 percent'' of Hoechst.   He said Kuwait viewed the stake as more than a capital investment and sought active cooperation with Hoechst ''to combine its strength in raw materials with Hoechst's know-how in chemicals and our distribution possibilities.''

headline: SOUTH AFRICA REACTOR DELAYED
abstract: The Government acknowledged today that the completion of South Africa's first nuclear power plant would be delayed as a result of a series of bombings over the weekend.   Responsibility for the four explosions, which extended over a period of nearly 12 hours Saturday and early Sunday, was taken by the underground African National Congress, the main movement of resistance to white rule.

headline: ALEXANDER WRITE-OFF INCREASED
abstract: Alexander & Alexander Services Inc. announced today that it would take a further $15 million write-off in the value of the Alexander Howden Group, which it purchased earlier this year.   Alexander & Alexander, a major New York-based insurance brokerage, said that the reduction in the value of Howden's assets, which comes on top of an earlier $25 million reduction, was necessary because insufficient reserves existed to cover liabilities at its Bermuda insurance subsidiaries.   The surprise disclosure here today was the latest in a controversy that has seen four former executives and a leading underwriter leave the London-based Howden unit after charges that they had defrauded their former employer of some $55 million.

headline: THE 'RICHEST MAN' IN AUSTRALIA
abstract: LANGLEY GEORGE HANCOCK must have seen the documentary ''Dig a Million, Make a Million'' at least 100 times since it was made in the late 1960's. It stars a much younger, stockier Lang Hancock as himself, a tough talking Australian prospector; the late Tom Price, the right-hand man of the late industralist Henry Kaiser, as the prospector's American sidekick, and A.W. Clausen, then a Bank of America vice president, as the banker who helps the prospector and Kaiser Steel strike a deal to explore and mine the prospector's iron ore El Dorado in the Hamersley Range. The film ends happily with the prospector flying off into the Australian sunset.   Mr. Hancock has reason to get great satisfaction from the film. It depicts his home state of Western Australia as Australia's Texas, a state of open spaces, mineral wealth and unlimited opportunity. It shows an independent, resourceful and unorthodox Lang Hancock demonstrating the John Wayne-like qualities that have made him a business legend in Australia. And it is a testament, in somewhat faded hues, to the legend of the ''lucky country,'' which holds that people e who live here are lucky. Mr. Hancock has reason to believe in that luck.

headline: Weinberger Sees Australian
abstract: Defense Secretary Caspar W.  Weinberger met here today with the Australian Defense Minister, Ian Sinclair, to discuss cooperation in what the United States and Australia view as a Soviet military buildup in the Pacific. ''The Soviet threat can only be described as very large and growing very rapidly and becoming increasingly dangerous,'' Mr. Weinberger said in a speech later at the National Press Club.

headline: BIG MOVERS IN STOCK MARKET
abstract: Blue-chip stocks such as General Electric and International Business Machines scored solid gains in the stock market's spectacular summer rally. But the best performers on the New York Stock Exchange for the first nine months of 1982 were typically much smaller companies that are unfamiliar to most investors.   Leading the list was Borman's Inc., a company that operates supermarkets under the name Farmer Jack, mainly in metropolitan Detroit. The No.2 spot went to the Vendo Company, which makes coinoperated vending machines for the soft-drink industry.

headline: No Headline
abstract: SHARON SAYS U.S. IDEAS ARE REASONABLE   JERUSALEM, Dec. 12 (UPI) - Defense Minister Ariel Sharon said today that new American ideas on how to break the impasse on the withdrawal of foreign troops from Lebanon was ''a reasonable solution'' for getting negotiations under way.   United States officials traveling with Secretary of State George P. Shultz in Rome said Saturday that the United States hoped to have two American mediators handle the troop withdrawal negotiations by traveling between Jerusalem and Beirut, thus avoiding direct Israeli-Lebanese talks.   ''As for the subject of the withdrawal of foreign forces, the subject of American shuttles seems to me to be a reasonable solution,'' Mr. Sharon said.   But he also said Israel and Lebanon must eventually hold face-toface negotiations on ''security arrangements and a normalization agreement'' between the two countries.

headline: OM A STILL FRONT, IRAQ LIES IN WAIT FOR THE IRANIAN MILITARY MACHINE
abstract: Seen from this Iraqi border command post 170 miles southeast of Baghdad, the front was mostly quiet. A small wood that was said to shelter Iranian troops two and a half miles away could be seen through field glasses.   There had been some sporadic fighting to the north in the morning, and an occasional shell was still being fired by Iraqi gunners. There was no reply from the Iranians, who, according to Iraqi officers, were short of ammunition.

headline: ARGENTINES SPLIT OVER RALLY VIOLENCE
abstract: An anti-Government demonstration that ended in violence Thursday left Government and opposition leaders united in sorrow today but divided over who was responsible.   The sorrow was that there was any violence at all after the police and organizers of the protest had worked closely together to avoid it.   ''The excesses on the one side and the indiscriminate represssion on the other tarnished a magnificent expression of the populace,'' Antonio Troccoli, a Radical Party leader, said.

headline: Market Place; Tax Strategies At Year's End
abstract: THE securities markets have their own version of last-minute Christmas shopping - a process that, in this case, can involve selling as well as buying.   In past years shareholders had to be especially vigilant about when they took gains, to make sure they were reflected in the desired tax return. Internal Revenue Service regulations had set the fifth business day before year-end as the deadline for stockholders to establish profits on a regular-way basis for their 1982 tax returns.   Now, however, a new ruling by the I.R.S. allows stockholders the option of establishing profits up to year-end that could be taxed in either the current or the coming year. In making this change the I.R.S decided that sales of stock in the last week of a year come under the installment sales law, because payment is made in the later year.

headline: A REPORTER'S NOTEBOOK: BEHIND THE SCENES AT THE GATT TRADE TALKS IN GENEVA
abstract: GENEVA W hile his countrymen were enjoying a long Thanksgiving weekend, Bill Brock, representing the United States at a world trade conference here, talked and listened, argued and cajoled. And by Monday morning of that over-extended weekend, he was saying that he had not slept in three nights. He wasn't the only one.   In all, more than 3,000 people -delegates from the 88 nations of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade as well as aides, reporters and camera crews - converged on Geneva Wednesday, Nov. 24, for a meeting scheduled to end by noon Saturday. They expected that the talks aimed at mending the world's battered trade system would be tough - but not as tough as they proved to be. Meetings were held day and night - in full sessions or in subcommittees, in coalition groups or in secretive twosomes - and continued well past Saturday's scheduled close and into Monday's dawn.   The exhaustion was spread all over town. One key set of meetings was held at GATT headquarters, an 18th century-styled chateau, built in the 1920's, overlooking Lake Geneva. In one corner, in a suite of offices with olive green walls, members of the high-powered ''chairman's group'' held 24-hour vigils and were dubbed the ''boys in the green room.''

headline: Princess Stephanie Appears in Public Again
abstract: Princess Stephanie of Monaco made her first public appearance today since being injured in an automobile crash. She attended a memorial service here for her mother, Princess Grace, who died after the accident.   Princess Stephanie, 17 years old, wearing a neck brace, accompanied other members of Monaco's royal family to the principality's cathedral for a requiem mass for Princess Grace.

headline: U.S. REBUTS SOVIET ON MX DEPLOYMENT
abstract: The Reagan Administration rejected today assertions made by Pravda, the Soviet party newspaper, that American deployment of the MX missile would violate the accords limiting strategic arms.   John Hughes, the State Department spokesman, issued a detailed rebuttal to the charge, saying it remained the policy of the United States to ''take no action which would undercut existing arms control agreements as long as the Soviets show equal restraint.''   ''Moscow is wrong,'' said Richard N. Perle, Assistant Secretary of Defense for International Security Policy, also disputing the allegation.

headline: PALESTINIANS IN LEBANON ALARMED BY ARRESTS AND RUMORS OF TRANSFER
abstract: Still shaken and fearful in the aftermath of the massacres at two refugee camps here, many of Lebanon's Palestinians are wondering what will become of them under the Government of President Amin Gemayel.   Their apprehension has been heightened by a number of reports circulating in Beirut and other parts of the country that the Government is considering a plan to oust all but 50,000 of the more than half a million Palestinians in the country.   Mr. Gemayel, who is allied with the Lebanese Christian forces that have been blamed for the massacres, is still forming his Government, so no action has been taken. But Palestinian civilians, ranging from laborers to skilled professionals, have become alarmed in recent days because hundreds of them have been picked up, by the Lebanese Army for interrogation and identity checks.   Some of those released after questioning are saying they have been verbally and physically abused by soldiers of the Lebanese Army, who are stationed at points all over this scarred city.

headline: ELECTION RESULTS IN GREECE REFLECT DISCONTENT WITH SOCIALIST REGIME
abstract: Greece's governing Socialist party appeared to have lost ground to the right and to the left in urban areas in the first round of municipal elections Sunday.   Substantial but incomplete returns in Athens and other major cities seemed to reflect some voter disenchantment with the Government of Prime Minister Andreas Papandreou.   The losses for the Socialists mean that they will be forced to depend heavily on Communist support in a runoff poll next Sunday since most of the candidates in urban areas did not win the required 51 percent. Athens Mayor Falls Behind   In Athens, generally a mirror of nationwide opinion, the conservative candidate, Tzanis Tzannetakis, took an early lead over the incumbent Socialist Mayor, Dimitrios Beis, with the Communists running third. If the Communists support the Socialist candidate in the second round, as has been the practice, Mayor Beis would be reelected.

headline: U.S. OFFICER HURT IN BLAST IN GERMANY
abstract: A United States Army officer was wounded today when a powerful bomb destroyed his car at an Army housing area near the south German city of Darmstadt, an Army spokesman said.   The police said it was the third terrorist attack against American soldiers in West Germany in two days.  A second American soldier was said to be in satisfactory condition in an Army hospital in Frankfurt with serious wounds suffered Tuesday when a bomb destroyed his car at a housing area in the town of Butzbach, near Frankfurt. Another soldier from the Frankfurt area escaped unharmed Tuesday when he discovered a bomb in his car and alerted the police.

headline: Pabst Rejects Takeover Bid
abstract: The Pabst Brewing Company said it had rejected a $32-a-share offer from a California brewer, Paul Kalmanovitz, for 4.2 million of its shares and said it would honor an earlier deal to be acquired by the G. Heileman Brewing Company.   Heileman announced on Nov. 26 that it had reached an agreement with a Minneapolis businessman, Irwin L. Jacobs, who had also sought to take over Pabst, under which Mr. Jacobs and his associates would tender their 1.14 million Pabst shares to Heileman and drop their bid for Pabst.

headline: SWEDEN TIGHTENS SUBMARINE RULES
abstract: The Swedish Government, angered and embarrassed by what it believes have been repeated incursions by foreign submarines, has ordered its navy to change tactics and seek to capture and humiliate future intruders, military specialists here said today.   The new rules of engagement are to become effective next July 1, when a new antisubmarine weapon, being developed in Sweden, will be ready, the specialists said. The Swedes would like to employ the new rules now but lack the weapons, they said.   But the specialists asserted that, even with a new weapon, the Swedish Navy would have to improve its ability to detect and then to locate precisely an intruding submarine and to prevent it from escaping, as they think one and possibly two did earlier this month.

headline: 4 Hall of Fame Entries At Art Directors Club
abstract: The four newest members of the Art Directors Club Hall of Fame will be formally inducted Friday at a dinner at the Pierre Hotel.  They are Amil Gargano, the strong-willed preident and chief executive officer of Ally & Gargano, who started in the agency business with Campbell-Ewald in Detroit; Richard Avedon, the famed photographer who the club described as ''one of the most important innovators in our profession''; Massimo Vignelli, architect and designer, and the late Jerome Snyder, who was the first art dirctor of both Sports Illustrated and Scientific American.

headline: Iran and Iraq Report Ground and Air Clashes
abstract: Iran and Iraq reported heavy ground and air fighting today along their battlefront.  Iraq said its forces had killed 111 Iranian soldiers and shot down an Iranian jet fighter.

headline: Seoul Sentences Critic Over Labor Comments
abstract: The Seoul District Criminal Court has sentenced the secretary of a Christian youth organization to 18 months in prison on charges of using the foreign press to defame the state.   The secretary, Kim Chul Kee, was convicted on the basis of a statement distributed June 23 to foreign reporters in which he criticized the Government's stand on a labor dispute at Control Data Korea, an affiliate of the Minneapolis computer parts producer.

headline: Ramada Debt Is Restructured
abstract: Ramada Inns said its lenders had agreed to restructure their existing debt agreement with the company, subject to final execution of documents.   The agreement was disclosed in testimony to the New Jersey Casino Control Commission by Thomas E. Martin, the company's chief financial officer.

headline: U.S. MOVE DISTURBS JAPANESE
abstract: What seemed to be a narrowly focused resolution adopted Tuesday by the United States Senate urging President Reagan to deny investment tax credits for the purchase of certain Japanese machine tools is being viewed here as a broadside aimed at Japanese industrial policy, the centerpiece of its successful system of economic management.   In addition, the resolution has again focused attention on Washington's approach to Japan's industrial policy and on economic policy in the United States.   The Senate backed a petition by Houdaille Industries, a producer of machine tools based in Florida, requesting that a 15 percent investment tax credit for two types of Japanese machine tools be denied. The company's case is an extensively researched argument that the Japanese Government has given its manufacturers an unfair advantage in international markets by forming a domestic cartel and funneling public funds into the industry, and by other measures.

headline: A HEART DOCTOR WINS A ROUND IN THE SPIRITED FIGHT OVER CHOCK FULL O'NUTS
abstract: ''Y OU'RE out of order,'' Leon Pordy shouted, a surprising outburst for a 63-year old cardiologist, whose monogrammed shirts and thin, silver mustache give him the appearance of a dapper Englishman.   ''You will be out of order when this meeting is over and we count the votes,'' Jerry Finkelstein, his 66-year-old adversary in a proxy fight, roared back.   The outburst came during the recent annual meeting of Chock Full o'Nuts, a New York-based company that sells a premuium brand coffee and whose restaurants, where a lunch of coffee and a nutted cheese sandwich costs $1.50, have been a fixture in New York City since the Depression -when that lunch cost 10 cents.   Well, the votes have been counted, and the incumbents won. Thus, Dr. Pordy, who is on the cardiology staff at Mt. Sinai hospital, will also be able to continue his career as the president of Chock Full.

headline: COMMON MARKET SEEKS U.S. TRADE TALKS
abstract: The European Common Market, alarmed at a split in the North Atlantic Treaty Organization over the Soviet natural gas pipeline to Western Europe, plans to press Washington for an urgent resumption of talks on trade with Eastern bloc countries, British Foreign Secretary Francis Pym said today.   Mr. Pym also said after an informal two-day meeting of Common Market foreign ministers that he was dismayed by the lack of followup on talks on East-West trade among NATO ministers in Canada earlier this month.   The 10 foreign ministers ended their meeting today with expressions of deep concern at the lack of consultation with the United States.  They also expressed concern at the latest crackdown in Poland but said they would not join Washington in new sanctions against Warsaw.

headline: Bull Moose Bid
abstract: The Bull Moose Tube Company, the St. Louis-based subsidiary of the National Steel Corporation, announced that it has signed a letter of intent for the purchase of all the outstanding stock of the Vulcan Tube and Metals Company of Chicago for an undisclosed amount of cash. Bull Moose produces mechanical, structural, sprinkler and pressure tubing.

headline: East German Guard Defects
abstract: A 22-year-old former East German border guard dodged mines and self-firing pistols mounted on frontier fences and crossed into West Germany early today, the authorities said. The defector, who was not identified, said he had left because he was dissatisfied with economic conditions in East Germany.

headline: PATENTS; Patenting Appearance, Not Structure
abstract: Design patents, of which 85 were issued this week for terms of 14 years, protect only the appearance of an article, not its structure or utilitarian features. But some of the concepts are intriguing.

headline: Lloyd's of London
abstract: Lloyd's of London said it had suspended W.M.D. Underwriting Agencies Ltd. and an underwriter, Colin Davies, as part of its continuing inquiry into reinsurance transactions at P.C.W.  Underwriting Agencies Ltd. and at W.D.M., a 40 percent owned associate agency. P.C.W. is owned by Minet Holdings P.L.C., an insurance broker that is held 20 percent each by the St. Paul Companies of St. Paul and the Corroon & Black Corporation of New York. Lloyd's would not give specific reasons for the latest suspension.

headline: Midland Bank Picks U.S. Branch Officer
abstract: The Midland Bank of London has named Harry P. Abplanalp executive vice president and chief manager of a New York branch of the bank that opens Monday.   The branch will be the only one operating under the bank's name in the United States. It will also be the largest foreign branch for Midland, one of Britain's top four banks and the 10th-largest bank in the world in deposits. In terms of United States presence, Midland last year bought a 51 percent interest in the Crocker National Corporation, the California bank, and is a member of a European consortium that owns the European Bank and Trust Company of New York.

headline: Stock-Index Futures Post Trading Advances
abstract: Stock-index futures trading continues to grow faster than any other sector of the commodity market, outpacing even the rising turnover in interest rate and precious metals contracts. The growth is considered extraordinary because the oldest index futures contract has been traded for only eight months; in the commodities industry, it normally takes several years for a new contract to achieve investor acceptance.   Also notable is that brokerage houses have discovered that much of the volume is being generated by their equities departments, rather than their commodities divisions.

headline: War in Gulf Centers On South Iraq Pocket
abstract: Air and ground fighting raged along the Iran-Iraq battlefront today and the ruling Islamic Republican Party in Iran called on Iraqi citizens to overthrow the Government in Baghdad.   War communiques carried by the official press and radio in both Iran and Iraq, monitored in Nicosia, indicated that most of the fighting was within a 180-square-mile pocket the Iranians hold in Iraq's southern area of Missan.

headline: No Headline
abstract: 2 NOMINATIONS LEFT HANGING   WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 (UPI) - The Senate, in the final hours of the 97th Congress, today approved a group of nominations, including those of two actresses and an actor, to national commissions, but it left two State Department nominations hanging.   Republicans refused to call up the nomination of Richard Burt, a former New York Times correspondent, as Assistant Secretary of State for European Affairs.

headline: ZIMBABWE PEASENTS GET A SHARE OF THE LAND
abstract: As revolutions go, the one that is taking place here, in countryside still dominated by brick tobacco barns built by former white owners, has a sluggish and even inconsequential look.   But as far as a peasant farmer named Mabewu Mpabwa is concerned, the Government of Prime Minister Robert Mugabe has delivered on the most emotionally charged promise made to the black majority during the long and costly struggle against white rule in what used to be called Rhodesia. That was the promise to begin reclaiming some of the vast expanse of cultivable land that whites took over in the early decades of this century and then claimed for their own exclusive use.    So far this ambitious land transfer program has taken place without displacing a single white farmer who wanted to stay on the land.

headline: Genentech Sees Loss in Quarter
abstract: Genentech Inc. said today that it expects to report a third-quarter loss but that it still planned to break even by the end of the year.   Genentech said that quarterly results could fluctuate widely but that ''these fluctuations, including this quarter's results, have no significance on the long-term growth and earnings of the company.''   In 1981 Genentech's net income, including tax credits, was $503,010, or 6 cents a share.

headline: RAGAN, BRAD, INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31

headline: Dow Will Abandon Big Saudi Venture
abstract: The Dow Chemical Company said yesterday that it would withdraw from a $1.5 billion joint-venture agreement with the Saudi Basic Industries Corporation to build a huge petrochemical complex in Jubail.   Dow, based in Midland, Mich., said it would take a write-off of $26 million, or 7 cents a share after taxes, in the fourth quarter to account for the termination.

headline: HOME STARTS ROSE SCANT 1% IN OCTOBER
abstract: Builders started work on new houses at an annual rate of 1.12 million units in October, up a modest 1 percent from September, the Government reported today. But permits for future construction were up sharply.   Spurred by falling interest rates, building permits were taken out in October at an annual rate of 1.18 million, up 17.7 percent from September's annual rate of just over 1 million. Permits rose 13 percent in September.

headline: Soviet and Finland Appealing For Arms Curbs and Detente
abstract: Finland and the Soviet Union appealed strongly today for detente and a curb to the nuclear arms race.

headline: New Fujitsu Computer
abstract: Fujitsu Ltd. said today that it would enter the American market with a personal business computer, the Micro 16S, priced below $4,000.

headline: BRANIFF FAILS IN ITS BID TO FORM A JOINT VENTURE
abstract: An attempt by Braniff International to begin flying again and put about 1,500 of its employees back to work foundered yesterday when it could not reach a seniority agreement with its pilots that would have been acceptable to Pacific Southwest Airlines.   The two carriers announced on Oct. 18 a plan that would have put 25 to 30 of Braniff's planes back in the air, flying for Pacific Southwest, if Braniff were able to obtain wage and benefit concessions from its five unions.   Some analysts saw the breakdown as increasing the likelihood that Braniff would have to liquidate, making it the first major domestic airline to go out of business as a result of a bankruptcy.

headline: People
abstract: * Jay Beckerman, Michael J. Drake, Charles J. Hasser, Larry Hoffner and William Wiener have been elected senior vice presidents of Batten, Barton, Durstine & Osborn.   * Richard A. Joslin, Charles W. Healy, Mark B. Itkowitz, Reinhold Schwenk, Alexander Ross, Martin J. Waters Jr. and Norman R. Goldstein have been promoted to senior vice president at Jordan, Case & McGrath.

headline: MRS. THATCHER FIRM ON HER AUSTERITY POLICIES
abstract: At the end of the annual Conservative Party conference here, Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher pledged on Friday not to waver in her tough economic policies, despite the severe recession and rising unemployment.   Standing beneath the conference slogan, ''The Resolute Approach,'' she told several hundred delegates that ''people in Britain have grown to understand that this Government will make no false promises nor will it fail in its resolve.''   The speech had been eagerly awaited as the weeklong gathering became increasingly divided over the Government's austerity approach.  On Thursday Agriculture Minister Peter Walker broke from the Government position and called for an expansionary economic policy coupled with limits on pay rises.

headline: Canadian Truck Rift
abstract: American truckers face difficulties in attempting to enter the Canadian market, but no proof exists that they are being discriminated against by the Canadian regulatory authorities, the Interstate Commerce Commission has concluded in a special report.   The report, released here late Monday, also opposes taking retaliatory action against Canadian truckers operating in the United States. American truckers, with some Congressional support, have campaigned to bar Canadian trucks from the United States until the Canadian market is made as accessible to Americans as the American market is to Canadians.

headline: Feldstein Warning On Budget Deficit
abstract: Large budget deficits facing the Government could delay recovery from the recession, Martin S.  Feldstein, chairman of the Council of Economic Advisers, said this evening.

headline: Loan Defaults At Richmond
abstract: The Richmond Tank Car Company, a Houston-based railroad car maker, said that it is in technical default on certain of its loan agreements and that it does not expect to be able to make a $2 million payment due this month on its $32 million revolving credit.  But it said that none of the defaults so far had involved actual failure to make payment of either principal or interest on its debt.

headline: Matsushita Deal With I.B.M. Japan
abstract: Matsushita, one of the world's leading makers of electric appliances, has signed a contract to make small computers for the Japanese subsidiary of the International Business Machines Corporation, according to the newspaper Asahi Shimbun.   Yoshiaki Toyama, a spokesman for I.B.M. Japan, declined to comment on the report, but said negotiations were under way between the two companies.

headline: CANNED CABERNET AND PINOT NOIR IN PLASTIC?
abstract: After long years of being put up mostly in glass bottles, wine is increasingly being sold in cans and plastic containers.  Geyser Peak, a California winery that prides itself on being an innovator in packaging, sells wine on the West Coast in 187-milliliter cans, which contain 6.3-ounce servings. Around the spring of 1983, the company plans to offer its wine in cans on the East Coast.

headline: Cambodian Rebel Arrives in Peking
abstract: Son Sann, a leader in the Cambodian rebel coalition formed to drive Vietnamese troops out of Cambodia, arrived in Peking today for a state visit, the official New China News Agency reported.   Both Prince Norodom Sihanouk, the coalition's president, and Khieu Samphan, its vice president, have been in Peking recently.

headline: SHIPYARD WORKERS DEFY THE REGIME IN GDANSK STRIKE
abstract: Workers at the Lenin Shipyard, the birthplace of the independent trade union Solidarity, struck early today to protest legislation outlawing the union. The protest spread to other factories and to the streets of this Baltic port city.   Clashes between demonstrators and the riot police broke out in midafternoon and continued until at least 11 o'clock tonight, with protesters building and setting fire to barricades and the police hurling volleys of tear gas and concussion grenades.   The strike was the first defiance of labor legislation enacted by Parliament on Friday dissolving the union that was formed in 1980 and that for a time claimed the loyalty of nearly 10 million people in this nation of 36 million. Before it was outlawed, the union had been suspended with the declaration of martial law last Dec. 13.

headline: Nicaragua Says Envoy To U.S. Has Not Quit
abstract: A spokesman for the Nicaraguan Embassy here said today that Nicaragua's Ambassador to Washington, Francisco Fiallos Navarro, had not resigned from his post here and was ''working with the revolution.''   In an interview with an opposition newspaper in Managua, Mr.  Fiallos called for a ''dramatic change'' in the direction of the Sandinist Government, and urged ''free, just and honest elections.''

headline: Woolco Move Is Defended
abstract: The president of the F.W. Woolworth Company yesterday defended the struggling retailer's decision to close its Woolco discount store chain and sell its British subsidiary.   ''Simultaneously and almost instantaneously, these two transactions have improved our current and projected profitability, cash flow and financial condition,'' Richard L. Anderson, president of the nation's fourth-largest retailer, told security industry analysts.

headline: 5 Shot in Italian Prison
abstract: Three inmates were shot and wounded today by a member of a rival Mafia-style gang in the prison of this southern Italian town, the authorities reported. Prison officials said two guards also were wounded.

headline: Guatemala-Mexico Deal
abstract: A senior Guatemalan official said today that Guatemala and Mexico could begin a barter trade system between the two countries but that the decision was in ''Mexico's hands.'' Deputy Agriculture Minister Luis Humberto Figueroa said at a news conference that the Governments of both countries, in view of a scarcity of dollars, were ready to put into effect a barter system in which Guatemala would trade meat products to Mexico for oil.

headline: Zionist Group Opposes Israel Settlement Policy
abstract: The World Zionist Congress, a powerful opinion-maker in Jewish affairs, voted today to condemn the Israeli Government's policy of establishing settlements in occupied Arab territories.   But the organization's chairman, Arye Dultzin, overruled the action on the ground that the delegates had no right to oppose Israeli policies.

headline: LITTLE JOY FOR BUSINESS LEADERS
abstract: This looks like any number of old Northeastern factory towns. The only employer of any consequence is represented by a sprawling brick edifice of little architectural note beyond its sheer bulk, but the employer in this case is a hotel, the Homestead.   Unlike most old factories, everything works at the Homestead, from the four-sided clock just under the thumb-like dome to the doors of the generous veranda, which are opened and closed, not by some electronic wizardry, but by green-uniformed floor men who align themselves almost invisibly with the hinges. Countless Amenities   The Homestead offers countless amenities for the protection and enjoyment of those who can pay its princely prices, enough even to satisfy men who travel by corporate jet and bring home, many of them, a million dollars a year. One hundred of those men, current and retired chief executives of many of the country's biggest companies, have just spent three days here, each day threatened by rain that they had the luck or authority to defer until most had departed.  Twice a year these men, members of the Business Council, make a pilgrimage here with their wives to ponder the world beyond them in private meetings with high Government officials.
