headline: THE NEW MEN WHO RUN THE INTERIOR MINISTRY AND THE K.G.B.
abstract: Vitaly V. Fedorchuk   For the first time since the early 1950's, the Soviet Ministry of Internal Affairs came under the control of a career K.G.B. officer yesterday with the appointment of Vitaly V. Fedorchuk to head it.   Since the end of May, Mr. Fedorchuk, 64 years old, had been chief of the K.G.B., rising to that post after more than four decades in internal security work. The appointment as K.B.G. chief also seemed to be a departure, for he was the first professional to head the organization since 1958.   The ruling Politburo had decided against a political appointment in May, a time when events in Poland seemed alarming and a power struggle to succeed the ailing party chief, Leonid I. Brezhnev, appeared to be approaching. Mr. Fedorchuk had headed the K.G.B. in his native Ukraine for 12 years, since July 1970, and the Politburo selected him to take over as chairman at the national organization.

headline: WEEK IN BUSINESS
abstract: The leading economic indicators fell 0.9 percent in August after four monthly rises, the Commerce Department said. The drop prompted the Administration to say that recovery would be slower than anticipated. The Labor Department, meanwhile, said initial claims for unemployment insurance rose to 703,000 in the week ended Sept.  18, suggesting a 10 percent unemployment rate could be possible for the month.

headline: S.E.C. Disclosure Plan
abstract: In the face of stiff protests from big business, the Securities and Exchange Commission agreed today to scale back a proposed rule that would have required public disclosure of transactions between officers of a publicly held company and some members of their families.   The commission voted unanimously to adopt the proposal after limiting its scope to transactions involving members of a corporate officer's immediate family. The original proposal would have extended the nepotism rule as far as first cousins.

headline: Market Place; Oil and Gas Income Funds
abstract: OIL and gas properties, decidedly out of favor as tax shelters, may offer investors satisfactory income prospects even so. That's the argument put forth by companies that specialize in limited partnerships - groups that buy producing oil properties for income purposes. Petro Lewis and Damson are the leaders in oil and gas income plans, and Morgan Petroleum Inc.  is a relative newcomer.   Morgan Petroleum's Garry E. Stelow, president of the general partner behind the Morgan income funds, reasons that large, older companies have concentrated on large properties. He thinks competition for these properties has left smaller ones in a pricing trough.

headline: Japan's Premier to Visit U.S.
abstract: Prime Minister Yasuhiro Nakasone today accepted an invitation from President Reagan to confer in Washington on Jan. 18, the Japanese Foreign Ministry said today.

headline: U.S. PLANS WAR HEADQUARTERS IN BRITAIN
abstract: The Reagan Administration plans to build a $13 million support headquarters in Britain, into which 1,000 staff officers of the United States European Command would move if war began in Europe, senior Administration officials said today.   The officials said the support center in High Wycombe, west of London, scheduled to be completed by 1986, would accommodate intelligence, operations, personnel, and logistics officers from the peacetime headquarters in Stuttgart, West Germany, and from the United States.   The main mission of the wartime support headquarters would be to assist American commanders on the Continent but not to run the war.  The support center would be particularly charged with moving troop reinforcements and supplies from the United States to the battle front.

headline: Kroger Elects President And Adds New Position
abstract: The Kroger Company, Cincinnati, announced the election yesterday of William G. Kagler as president and John A. Cornett as vice chairman, a new position. Kroger is the nation's second-largest supermarket chain after Safeway Stores Inc.

headline: Senate Panel Backs Nomination of Douglas to F.T.C.
abstract: The Senate Commerce Committee today unanimously approved the nomination of George W. Douglas, an economist, to the Federal Trade Commission.

headline: Chief to Step Down At Applied Digital
abstract: William J. Catacosinos, a co-founder and chief executive of Applied Digital Data Systems Inc. of Hauppauge, L.I., plans to step down after 13 years at the helm.   In the early days, Mr. Catacosinos pledged his home and cars to guarantee a $350,000 loan to the struggling company.

headline: IN RIO, AN OLD ENEMY IRKS THE ARMY
abstract: With less than a week to go in the campaigning for the first free municipal, legislative and gubernatorial elections in Brazil in 17 years, attention has focused on the race in Rio de Janeiro State, where a candidate for governor who is widely resented by the armed forces is leading.   The sudden emergence of Leonel Brizola in the polls is putting to its severest test the military-run Government's decision to hold elections and its pledge to guarantee that all winners take office.   The men in uniform who took over Brazil in 1964 viewed Mr. Brizola as the most provocative figure in the country's public life. After failing in efforts to set off mutiny in the military ranks and rouse his followers to armed resistence, he fled the country and remained in exile for 15 years.

headline: SOUTH AFRICA PUTS NEW 3-YEAR BAN ON AN AFRIKANER FOE OF APARTHEID
abstract: The Rev. Beyers Naude, a dissident Afrikaner churchman who broke with his church and people in order to make common cause with blacks in opposition to apartheid, was placed under a new three-year ban today that makes it a crime for him to attend meetings, write for publication or be quoted anywhere in South Africa.   The notification was delivered to him this morning at his home in Johannesburg, just three days before the expiration of a five-year ban that he received when the Government clamped down on white as well as black opposition in 1977 after the death in detention of the prominent black nationalist Steve Biko. An interracial organization that Dr. Naude founded and headed, the Christian Institute, which was designed to mobilize opposition to the racial system within South African churches, was declared illegal at that time.

headline: Nixon and Kissinger Visit Zia at Waldorf
abstract: President Mohammad Zia ul-Haq of Pakistan was visited yesterday at the Waldorf Towers by former President Richard M. Nixon and former Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger.   Mr. Nixon was President and Mr. Kissinger was his assistant for national security when Washington's policy ''tilted'' toward Pakistan during the war between India and Pakistan in December 1971.

headline: 6 ISRAELI SOLDIERS KILLED IN AMBUSH ON LEBANON ROAD
abstract: Six Israeli soldiers were killed and 22 others were wounded today in an ambush six miles east of Lebanon's capital on the Beirut-Damascus highway, the Israeli military command said. Military officials said the attackers were not identified.   The officials said the attackers had apparently infiltrated Israeli lines near Aleih, a mountain town less than two miles from the ceasefire line separating the Israeli Army and forces of the Syrian Army and the guerrilla forces of the Palestine Liberation Organization.   The ambush was the second attack in three days on Israeli troops in the Aleih area. An attack on Israelis Friday night resulted in an exchange of fire but no reported casualties.

headline: Publishers Honor Heiskell
abstract: The executive committee of the Magazine Publishers Association has named Andrew Heiskell, retired chairman of Time Inc., to receive the 1982 Henry John Fisher Award, which in the magazine business makes him ''Publisher of the Year.''   The 67-year-old executive, whose activities include the chairmanship of the New York Public Library, was with Time from 1937 until he left in 1980, having served as chief executive since the summer of 1969.

headline: ANDROPOV IS ADDED TO TOP STATE BODY
abstract: Yuri V. Andropov, the new Soviet party leader, was named today to membership in the Presidium of the Supreme Soviet, but he was not immediately named chairman, or chief of state, an office left vacant by the death of Leonid I. Brezhnev .   Western diplomats thought Mr. Andropov's selection to the Presidium was possibly the first step toward being named President. The Supreme Soviet, which is the nominal Soviet legislature, meets again tomorrow, and the Presidium may then propose its new member as its chairman. In any event, few doubt Mr. Andropov's power to give or take the office as he chooses.

headline: 2 LEADERS VIE FOR POWER IN EL SALVADOR
abstract: A bitter conflict between two of the most powerful figures in the Salvadoran Government has flared in recent weeks and left American officials increasingly concerned about the stability of the political system here.   The conflict pits the Minister of Defense and Public Security, Gen. Jose Guillermo Garcia, against Roberto d'Aubuisson, a former national guard intelligence officer and leader of the ultraright National Republican Alliance. At issue, according to foreign diplomats and Salvadoran officials, are attempts by Mr. d'Aubuisson to encourage opposition to General Garcia among army officers and the public in the hope of unseating him,   Such a step would create serious problems for the United States because General Garcia has largely supported American efforts here and has placed the Salvadoran Army behind land redistribution. Mr.  d'Aubuisson, who is president of the Constituent Assembly elected in March, opposes social reform and has been accused of having ties to rightist terrorism here. Western diplomats say Mr. d'Aubuisson's efforts to extend his power and dominate the military would severely weaken, perhaps crush, United States-supported efforts to shape a democratic government.

headline: 5,000 Demonstrate in Rome For Lebanese and the P.L.O.
abstract: About 5,000 students marched through the center of Rome today in what was billed as a ''day of solidarity'' with the Palestinian and Lebanese people.

headline: ISRAEL TO HELP HOUSE PALESTINIAN REFUGEES IN LEBANON
abstract: The Israeli Government, reversing a longstanding policy, said today that it would take an active role in housing and protecting the Palestinian refugees in southern Lebanon this winter.   Israel's previous position was to avoid participating in any semipermanent resettlement of the 30,000 to 60,000 refugees in camps that had once been centers of Palestinian guerrilla activity against Israel.   The Lebanese Government, once also a target of the Palestinians, had a policy similar to Israel's old one. The Lebanese told the United Nations Relief and Works Agency, which is directly responsible for the camps, that only tents could be erected for the homeless refugees.

headline: SAVINGS INSTITUTIONS ARE HEALTHIER BUT NOW FACE FURTHER CHALLENGES
abstract: The nation's thrift institutions, which only a year ago were facing the prospect of collapse, are in stronger shape now, thanks largely to the sharp decline in interest rates. But they still face a difficult future as banking practices grow more and more competitive.    Even now, most savings banks and savings and loan associations are continuing to lose money. But, with the lower interest rates, the majority are expected to return to profitability in the new year.   ''The worst is over, there's no doubt about that,'' said Senator Jake Garn, the Utah Republican who is chairman of the Senate Banking Committee.

headline: Needham, Harper Adds Anheuser-Busch Parks
abstract: Needham, Harper & Steers, Chicago, which has been grabbing up new accounts to make up for the McDonald's loss, has still another new assignment - promoting the three theme parks that Anheuser-Busch operates in its Busch Entertainment Corporation.

headline: THURSDAY, DECEMBER 30, 1982; The Economy
abstract: The merchandise trade gap narrowed to $4.1 billion in November but the deficit for the entire year is expected to surpass the 1978 record of $42.4 billion, the Commerce Department reported. It assumes a December deficit of about $5 billion. Economic weakness among some of America's biggest customers, notably Mexico, and the competitive disadvantage of the strong dollar were blamed for this year's worsening in the balance of trade. (Page D1.)

headline: TERRORIST SUSPECT REPORTED SEIZED IN BOLIVIA AND FLOWN OUT ON A JET
abstract: A suspect in a 1980 right-wing bombing that killed 85 people in Bolgona, Italy, was wounded and captured in a gun battle in Bolivia and placed on a secret Alitalia flight to Rome, Bolivian officials said.   They said an Alitalia DC-10 jetliner left La Paz Airport about 8 P.M. tonight headed for San Juan, Puerto Rico. They said the plane would continue to Rome.

headline: Socal Finds 'Giant' Field
abstract: The Standard Oil Company of California said today that it believed it had located a ''giant oil field'' off the coast of southern California. Socal said it based its report on wells drilled by its Chevron U.S.A. subsidiary and Phillips Petroleum around a jointly held tract off Point Conception. The tract was leased by the companies in May 1981 for $333.6 million, one of the most expensive offshore tracts obtained from the Federal Government.

headline: Hospital Chief To Lead Shared Medical Systems
abstract: If Mark S. Levitan were a physician, it might be said that he is going into private practice. As it is, the 48-year-old executive director of the Hospital of the University of Pennsylvania, in Philadelphia, is merely going private.

headline: HARD TIMES FOR CATERPILLAR
abstract: It was never supposed to happen in this prosperous company town. The Caterpillar Tractor Company - known for good management and efficient plants - had been one of the success stories among American heavy manufacturers.   But the company's good fortune, which was barely disturbed by the 1974-75 recession, has ended.  As a result of the current recession, Caterpillar has been forced to lay off 17,400 workers. And since Oct. 1, the company has been the target of a strike by the United Automobile Workers that has idled another 22,600 nationwide.

headline: JAPAN PLANS MILD ECONOMIC STIMULUS
abstract: The Japanese Government today adopted a package of mildly stimulative measures to increase the growth of its sluggish economy.   The new program calls for additional spending of $7.7 billion, mostly on public works, disaster aid and residential construction financing. The steps are intended to raise Japan's real economic growth to 3.4 percent in the current fiscal year, ending next March, up from the 2.7 percent increase the Government expects without growth-enhancing measures.

headline: G.M. Financing Rate Cut
abstract: The General Motors Corporation announced yesterday that its General Motors Acceptance Corporation unit would offer a 10.9 percent financing rate for new 1982 G.M. automobiles, beginning today. The program will result in savings of $1,300 to $2,125 for customers who finance their car purchases through G.M.A.C., the company said. The new rate, which General Motors said was below its previous financing offers, affects automobiles and trucks delivered through Dec. 31.

headline: Japan Vehicle Output
abstract: Japan's production of cars, trucks and buses edged down 1.8 percent in September from a year earlier, to 968,161 vehicles, according to the Japan Automobile Manufacturers Association.

headline: B.B.D.O. Is Assigned Stroh TV Account
abstract: Batten, Barton, Durstine & Osborn might have missed out the other day when the Stroh Brewery Company of Detroit, one of its clients, decided to assign its newly acquired Schlitz and Schlitz Light brands to MCA Advertising, but it did not miss out completely.   Yesterday Stroh named it the agency of record for all network television buying for all Stroh brands.  While only a few of them are national brands - Old Milwaukee and Old Milwaukee Light, which B.B.D.O., handles on a full-service basis; both Schlitz brands, and Schlitz Malt Liquor - the agency will additionally make network buys to fit the needs of the regional brands, which are Piels, Schaefer, Stroh and Stroh Light, Signature and Goebels.

It said, however, that Odyssey, which owns or has rights to 5.2 percent of Trans World, intended to approach the company to discuss its views about such a breakup.

''Many American journalists cry from the housetops that Peking is now bound by promises to effect unification peacefully,'' the Soviet author who defected in 1974 said.

headline: PROSPECTS
abstract: Trade Hopes Dim   The outlook for world trade can be summarized in a single word: gloomy. The International Monetary Fund, in a Dec.6 announcement that went virtually unnoticed, reported that industrial world exports had dropped a stunning 10.9 percent between the second and third quarters of the year, far greater than the 2 to 3 percent decline that had been predicted by prominent economists.   Those figures helped to convince Paul A. Volcker, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, that the Reagan Administration had to change its posture and support an increase in the I.M.F.'s lending resources.   That policy switch, European officials say, was set in motion last month, when Mr. Volcker asked Lamberto Dini, second in command at the Italian Central Bank, to visit him in Washington. Mr. Dini is chairman of the ''Group of Ten,'' the covey of financial officials that oversees the international monetary system. Mr. Volcker told Mr. Dini that he was worried that private banks were hurriedly cutting back their lending to developing nations. That, he said, could further reduce trade and worsen an already severe recession.

headline: EUROPEAN PUSH BY G.M., FORD
abstract: The European subsidiaries of America's two largest auto makers, attempting to reverse their flagging fortunes, have introduced new models this autumn that highlight broad changes in the European production and marketing strategies of both companies.   Both Adam Opel, the General Motors Corporation's West German unit, and Ford Europe are rebuilding their product lines to meet the challenge posed by fuel-efficient European and Japanese cars.   At the Paris auto show last month, Ford introduced its new Sierra model, a medium-sized car for Europe designed to replace the bestselling but 20-year-old Taunus, known as the Cortina in Britain.   At the same time, General Motors released details of the Corsa, a subcompact ''S'' car designed by Opel that will be assembled in Spain. The Corsa is slightly more than 12 feet long, the smallest car General Motors has ever built.

headline: BOND SURGE HELPS DOW GAIN 25.75
abstract: A late rally enabled the Dow Jones industrial average yesterday to soar by 25.75 points, to 1,030.26.   Analysts said the upswing was sparked mainly by the strong performance of the bond market, where long-term Treasury securities rose in price by more than $20 for every $1,000 in face value and yields fell. The bond price rally came after the Federal funds rate, the rate for overnight loans that banks make to each other, dropped early in the day.   ''Helping the rally was the report in the afternoon by the Commerce Department that durable goods orders placed with American factories last month rose 1.9 percent, or more than expected,'' said Leonard Siegel, vice president of investments of Josephthal & Company. The rise was viewed as an indication that an economic recovery might start soon.

headline: FINANCE BRIEFS
abstract: * Avon Capital Corp.'s $100 million issue of guaranteed notes due in 1990 was assigned an 11 3/4 percent coupon and priced at par, through Morgan Stanley & Co.   * Emhart Corp. filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission an offering of $75 million principal amount of senior debt notes, with terms decided at time of sale, through E.F. Hutton & Co.

headline: FINANCIAL FUTURES SET BRISK PACE IN LONDON
abstract: The London International Financial Futures Exchange has briskly entered the raucous world of currency and interest rate trading. In the new market's first three sessions, volume has climbed from a vigorous 3,243 contracts on opening day last Thursday to well over 4,000.   As traders in brightly colored jackets gesture and shout in a refurbished cavernous room of the 138-year-old building, analysts are closely studying the new exchange's activity. They are eager to see if London, with its staid financial traditions, will support a Chicago style of trading.

headline: Bomb in Frankfurt Destroys Cars at U.S. Housing Center
abstract: A bomb exploded at an American housing complex here early today, destroying four cars owned by United States servicemen but causing no casualties, the West German police said.

headline: No Headline
abstract: MRS. WALESA PROTESTS 'HORRIBLE' SEARCH   WARSAW, Oct. 24 (AP) - Danuta Walesa, wife of the interned union leader Lech Walesa, has said that Polish security agents took her to a police station, stripped her and searched her. She said the incident occurred as she was returning home from a visit to her husband.   Mrs. Walesa, in an interview over the weekend, said she believed the female security agents had been looking for a smuggled appeal or statement from her husband so they could charge him with a crime and place him under formal arrest.

headline: TYLENOL RECALL EXPENSE IS PUT AT $100 MILLION
abstract: Johnson & Johnson said yesterday that it would spend $100 million to withdraw Tylenol capsules from the market and cover the other expenses arising from the contamination of some capsules.   The estimate was part of the big pharmaceutical company's thirdquarter earnings report. The company said the costs connected with the Tylenol capsule poisoning had reduced net income for the quarter by 25.7 percent, to $96.5 million, or 61 cents a share.

abstract: Munsingwear Inc. of Minneapolis said yesterday that its chairman and chief executive, Raymond F. Good, 54 years old, had resigned.

headline: Stock Index Futures Off; Two End at Discounts
abstract: Not surprisingly, prices of all three stock index futures plunged yesterday along with the four actual market indexes. But two of the three index futures closed at discounts to the actual indexes and thus afforded traders a further insight into the behavior of these new markets, particularly the role played by dividend dates.   For example, the spot December Value Line index futures closed at 145.80, down the daily permissiblelimit of 500 basis points, or $5.  This left the December futures at a discount of 131 basis points to the actual Value Line index, which closed at 147.11, down 460 points on the day.

headline: 12 REPORTED HELD IN BEIRUT MASSACRE
abstract: A report that Lebanese authorities have made their first arrests in their investigation of the massacre of Palestinian civilians here in September was distributed today by a local news agency close to the militias of the Lebanese Christian Phalange Party of President Amin Gemayel.   The report, which was circulated by the Lebanese Central Information Agency but not supported by any other source, said that 12 suspects had been seized and that most of them were Moslem Shiites from southern Lebanon. The suspects were also said to include some southern Christians and one person who carried a Jordanian passport.   Israel has said that Phalangists were responsible for the massacre, but the Phalangist-dominated militias known as the Lebanese Forces have repeatedly denied involvement. Maj. Saad Haddad, commander of an Israeli-supported militia in southern Lebanon consisting of both Christians and Moslems, testified at the official inquiry earlier this week that none of his troops had been involved in the killings.

headline: REPAYMENT BY BANK
abstract: Nuovo Banco Ambrosiano, the successor bank to the one that collapsed, has repaid about $910 million of Euromarket borrowings, Giovanni Bazoli, president of Nuovo Ambrosiano, said today.   Nuovo Banco "has repaid with extreme punctuality the deposits taken by the former bank from the international market," he added at a meeting with foreign bankers.   He said deposits had risen to the equivalent of $1.5 billion, from a low of $1.2 billion in August, when Ambrosiano was liquidated and the successor bank was set up.

headline: Universal Pictures Replaces President
abstract: Ned Tanen, the president of the Universal Pictures division of MCA Inc. since 1978, is leaving to become an independent producer, the diversified entertainment company announced yesterday. He will be succeeded by Robert Rehme, head of Universal's marketing and distribution arm, who joined the company in 1981.   Led by its hugely successful feature film ''E.T.: The Extra Terrestrial,'' Universal is expected to take in more than $400 million at the box office this year, breaking the record of $290 million it set for major Hollywood studios in 1980.

headline: CLEANING HOUSE AT WOOLWORTH'S
abstract: FOUR years ago, when John W.  Lynn was chairman of the domestic Woolworth and Woolco units of t he F.W. Woolworth Company, he visited a Woolworth's variety store inM anhattan and was shocked by its shabby condition and unattractive m erchandise.   Somehow, that store had fallen between the cracks of Woolworth's multilayered supervision. The store manager explained that he had been too involved in too many duties to pay more attention to the store's housekeeping. As to the merchandise, he conceded that he had been ordering what he ''thought'' his customers wanted rather than trying to learn if they really wanted it. Put on notice to correct the situation, he cleaned up the store, stripped the stock of goods that were not selling and, with the help of Woolworth's central staff, added more desirable merchandise.   Within two years, that store delivered a net profit of $100,000, in contrast to its previous annual net incomes of between $7,000 and $8,000. ''All we did,'' said Mr. Lynn, ''was to clean up the place and give it basic merchandise. Today, that manager runs a bigger store. He's happier. And he even dresses better.''

headline: U.S. ENVOY AND BEGIN DISCUSS TROOP PULLOUT FROM LEBANON
abstract: Morris Draper, the special American envoy, met with Prime Minister Menachem Begin and other key Israeli officials today in his continuing effort to find an acceptable formula for the withdrawal of Israeli, Syrian and Palestinian forces from Lebanon.   Foreign Ministry officials said Mr. Draper, who arrived here from Beirut, discussed his recent meetings with the Lebanese President, Amin Gemayel, and Prime Minister Shafik al-Wazzan. The officials said he expressed the hope that negotiations between the Lebanese and the Israelis could start soon.

headline: Mind Boggling
abstract: To the Business Editor: I find it mind boggling, as noted in William Safire's ''The Meddler on The Roof'' (Sept.26), that grown men in this time of a disastrous national and world economy can involve themselves and their resources in something like the Bendix/Marietta et al. imbroglio, and frightening to realize that it is from such men that presidents and other politicians choose advisers. Do they really believe that they are doing serious work?   The vision of Nero fiddling while Rome burns comes more readily to mind than the fiddler on the roof.  JANET C. SHAHAN Tully, N.Y., Sept.30, 1982

headline: PHILADELPHIA ELECTRIC CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30

headline: BRAZILIANS JAM POLLING PLACES IN FIRST FREE VOTE IN 17 YEARS
abstract: Brazilians voted today in the first free municipal, legislative and gubernatorial elections in 17 years.  Lines had formed by the 8 A.M. opening hour and continued lengthy until the 5 P.M. close as the estimated 58.5 million voters participated in the latest stage in the gradual liberalization program under which President Joao Baptista Figueiredo has promised to return the country to democracy.   They were choosing 22 governors, 25 senators, all 479 members of congress, 947 state assemblymen, 3,857 mayors and some 60,000 city councilmen. They were also determining the makeup of the electoral college that will formally select Mr. Figueiredo's successor in 1985. The body will be composed of the members of the Senate and the House and six representatives of the majority party in each state assembly.

headline: Rights Protesters March In Buenos Aires
abstract: A 24-hour human-rights demonstration swelled today into a march through the city center by 6,000 people who chanted that the rally was ''the beginning of the end of the dictatorship.''   Organizations representing relatives of people who disappeared after being picked up by security agents of the military Government sponsored the March of Resistance that began Thursday afternoon at a downtown intersection.

headline: GENERAL AMERICAN COUNTERBID
abstract: The General American Oil Company of Texas, fighting a $520 million takeover bid by the Mesa Petroleum Company, disclosed last night a counteroffer for its own stock in a move that could start a bidding war.   General American said that it would buy up to 8 million of its own shares, or 31 percent of those outstanding, for $50 each. It also reserved the right to purchase an additional 5 million shares.

headline: Tibetans Are Said to Return
abstract: About 1,000 Tibetans living abroad returned to visit relatives or to settle in Tibet in the first 11 months of the year, the official New China News Agency said today.

headline: LOWER RATES STIR HOPE OF DEFICIT CUT
abstract: The abrupt decline of short-term interest rates in recent days, apparently the mainspring of the stock market rally, is being cheered by Administration officials who hope that it portends a smaller budget deficit.   Lower interest rates reduce the cost of carrying the Federal debt, which is now above $1,000 billion. More significantly, officials say, they are necessary for a stronger economy, which would do far more to shrink the deficit by producing additional tax revenues and reduced outlays for unemployment benefits.

headline: COPRPORATE PHILANTHROPY; A CASE FOR GIVING 2% OF PRETAX INCOME
abstract: CORPORATE profits continue to decline, unemployment is still on the i ncrease and legislative budget-cutting has affected a wide range of s ocial and public services.  At the same time, the President's Task Force on Private Sector Initiatives is asking corporations to double public involvement activities (including cash giving) over the next four years. And the Business Roundtable, composed of the chief executives of the nation's 200 largest corporations, has exhorted its members to offer their personal support for the principle of corporate involvement and provide leadership in helping local communities solve problems.  Is it realistic to expect the business sector to increase its level of public involvement in such times? Should a corporation limit its outreach to periods of high profits and prosperity? Some are still asking a more basic question: Is it legitimate for a business to be an active participant in its community, to give money, to lend its people and facilities, to invest in the revitalization of inner cities?

Rather, traders said, the heavy buying was partly attributed to the short covering that normally precedes bank and market closings and partly to the bullish mood that precedes a Treasury refunding.

headline: SECURITY BEGUN FOR LEBANON TALKS
abstract: Israeli and Lebanese Army soldiers set up a security cordon today around a beach hotel in this troubled town south of Beirut where talks are to open Tuesday on Israeli demands for security arrangements and a normalizing of relations.   Col. Fawzi abi-Farhat, security coordinator for the talks, said Israel moved tanks and armor into the hills overlooking Khalde to prevent any outbreak of fighting between rival Lebanese militiamen.

headline: SWEDES PRESS THEIR SEARCH FOR TRAPPED SUB
abstract: The hunt for a submarine presumed trapped near a naval base in the Stockholm archipelago entered its second week today as ships and helicopters continued their sweeps of the area.   Late in the day the Swedish Navy said there had been a new contact with the intruder, indicating that it was still cornered in a bay adjoining the Musko base, about 20 miles south of Stockholm.   Several small depth charges were exploded on Thursday when the submarine apparently tried to slide through a narrow channel leading to the open waters of the Baltic Sea before running into a steel net that had been deployed to block its passage. A naval spokesman, Capt. Sven Carlsson, said a second submarine was detected outside the bay Thursday.

headline: Technology; Binding Books With Adhesive
abstract: THE craft of bookbinding came into existence some time before A.D.  400, when the papyrus roll began to be supplanted by the handmade codex - what is now known as the book -with pages made from animal skins and bound by threads along one side.   In the mid-20th century, sewing was still the chief method of binding pages together. Until about 10 years ago, the Book Manufacturers Institute estimates, 80 percent of the hard-cover general interest books manufactured in the United States had their pages sewn.   But now, the institute's executive vice president, Douglas E.  Horner, said this week, roughly 80 percent of the books in this category are bound with liquid adhesive. Most paperback books are adhesive-bound, too.

headline: U.S ENVOY BERATES MOSCOW AND DRAWS A BARBED REBUTTAL
abstract: The American Ambassador to the Soviet Union and the Kremlin's principal expert on American affairs engaged in a sharp debate today on the issue of Soviet-American trade, with the Ambassador telling an audience of Americans and Russians that the United States would not relent in its determination to link trade to ''our overall principal relationship.''   The Ambassador, Arthur A. Hartman, who spoke at the U.S.-U.S.S.R.  Trade and Economic Council, also seemed to be rebuking American participants in the conference. Some of the 200 American business leaders here for the meeting have criticized the Administration's restrictions on trade with the Soviet Union.   In his policy statement, Mr. Hartman said the Soviet military buildup and the Kremlin's record in Afghanistan and Poland and on human rights were part of the ''reality'' that dictated official American attitudes toward trade.

headline: HEILEMAN WINS THE BATTLE FOR PABST
abstract: The year-and-a-half battle for the Pabst Brewing Company, the nation's fifth largest brewer, was finally settled yesterday with the G. Heileman Brewing Company, the fourth-largest brewer, winning control.   Under the merger agreement, Heileman will acquire certain assets of Pabst and the Olympia Brewing Company of Tumwater, Wash., which Pabst acquired last summer. Partly to resolve antitrust problems, the remaining assets will be spun off to Pabst shareholders as a ''new'' Pabst Brewing Company.

headline: A SURGE OF VANDALISM IN WARSAW BRINGS FEAR TO WESTERN DIPLOMATS
abstract: A wave of vandalism and break-ins has strirred fears among Western diplomats here of a campaign of harassment against representatives of countries seen as unfriendly to Poland's martial-law administration.   The embassies of both the United States and France, the nations that have borne the brunt of the incidents, have filed formal complaints with the Polish Foreign Ministry.   The incidents, which began last summer and have markedly increased in the last week, include mysterious burglaries at the houses of diplomats and other foreigners and the splashing of paint on cars and buildings. Pink Paint on French Embassy   On Monday night bottles of pink paint were thrown against the walls of the French Embassy and on a car belonging to the French cultural center. On Wednesday night three cars at the United States Embassy - clearly identifiable, as are all diplomatic vehicles, by their special plates - were smeared with yellow paint and a fourth had its tires slashed outside an apartment block used by embassy personnel.  Two offices housing agriculture and trade missions were also daubed with painted swastikas and the letters P L O.

headline: ISRAEL PUTS PALESTINIAN INFILTRATORS IN BEKAA VALLEY AT 2,000 TO 3,000
abstract: An Israeli Foreign Ministry official said today that 2,000 to 3,000 Palestinian guerrillas had infiltrated the Bekaa Valley of eastern Lebanon since they were evacuated from West Beirut to Syria in August.   They are said to be in encampments in parts of the valley under Syrian control. In all, Israeli Foreign Ministry and military spokesmen say, there are 7,000 Palestinian guerrillas still in Lebanon, the others being in encampments in the north around Tripoli.

headline: Talking Business with Silas of Phillips Petroleum; Oil Reserves Off California
abstract: People in the oil industry are speculating these days about the significance of a new oil discovery in the Santa Maria Basin, part of the continental shelf off Santa Barbara, Calif. The companies holding the most leases for drilling in the area are Texaco Inc., the Standard Oil Company of California and the Phillips Petroleum Company.   Although the size of the new reserves is not yet known, all the companies have said there are more than 100 million barrels of oil in the area, making it the largest oil find since the rich Prudhoe Bay field of northern Alaska was discovered in 1968. Many analysts believe the new reserves will total more than 500 million barrels.

headline: U.N. CHIEF TO HOLD INQUIRY ON RIGHTS IN POLAND
abstract: Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar, over protests from the Polish Government, will begin an inquiry into human rights in Poland on Tuesday, United Nations officials said today.   Mr. Perez de Cuellar is expected to appoint as head of the investigation Hugo J. Gobbi, a former Argentine diplomat and now the United Nations special representative in Cyprus. The decision comes after months of fruitless negotiations here between Polish diplomats and the Secretary General, who has sought Warsaw's cooperation with the inquiry.   In private, according to diplomats familiar with the talks, the Poles gave what were described as evasive answers, neither accepting the examination nor rejecting it out of hand. Above all, Mr. Perez de Cuellar sought permission for Mr. Gobbi to visit Poland and conduct his inquiry there. Polish envoys said today that Mr. Gobbi will not be allowed in.

headline: France Will Sign U.N. Sea-Bed Treaty
abstract: France will sign the United Nations Law of the Sea Treaty when the international convention is open for signature at Kingston, Jamaica, next week, a Government spokesman said today.   The United States has tried to persuade allied nations to reject the treaty, arguing that it will restrict sea-bed mining by private companies.

headline: U.N. Panel Asks Study On Chemical Warfare
abstract: The General Assembly's Political Committee has overwhelmingly approved a resolution calling on Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar to investigate the illegal use of chemical weapons in warfare.   The resolution was adopted on Monday, 70 to 18, with 31 abstentions, as the United States made public what it called additional evidence to document the use of Soviet-supplied lethal chemical and toxic weapons in Afghanistan and Southeast Asia.   The resolution is expected to be adopted by the General Assembly by an equal margin.

headline: U.S. to Allow Ward Plan
abstract: A proposal by Montgomery Ward Enterprises, a subsidiary of Montgomery Ward & Company, to provide prepaid legal services for customers will not be challenged, the Justice Department has announced. Under the plan a nonprofit foundation would be set up to offer prepaid legal services for Montgomery Ward customers.  Subscribers, for a monthly fee, would receive a number of services at no extra charge and would be entitled to additional services for specified charges.

headline: U.S. Regrets U.N.'s Election Of Nicaragua to the Council
abstract: The State Department expressed regret today over the decision of the United Nations General Assembly to elect Nicaragua to fill the Latin American seat on the Security Council.   Nicaragua won 104 votes on the third ballot Tuesday, compared with 50 for the Dominican Republic.

headline: BACKS RISE ON GAS
abstract: Paul A. Volcker, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, today opposed acceleration of the July 1 tax cut, now under consideration by the White House, but endorsed an increase in the gasoline tax to finance a highway repair program.   One effect of Mr. Volcker's comments was to strengthen the move already afoot in Congress to approve, at the special session beginning Monday, an increase in the gasoline tax equal to 5 cents a gallon, bringing the total tax to 9 cents.  President Reagan endorsed the increase yesterday.   But Mr. Volcker's remarks added to the already stiff opposition in Congress to making the scheduled 10 percent cut in personal income taxes effective Jan. 1 instead of July 1. Although Mr. Volcker is often criticized in Congress for thwarting economic recovery by rigid adherence to his anti-inflation program, his views on economic policy carry considerable weight on Capitol Hill.

headline: Steel Imports Up Last Month
abstract: Steel imports in November totaled 1.26 million tons, an increase of 9 percent from October, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported today. The imports accounted for 23.8 percent of the steel supply in the United States last month.

headline: CONTINUED RATE DROP EXPECTED
abstract: Government securities dealers meeting here expressed optimism today that the combination of a weak economy and a Federal Reserve policy aimed at pushing more money and credit into the financial system would continue to bring interest rates down for months to come.   Among the representatives of major securities firms attending the annual meeting of the Public Securities Association, there was general approval of recent Federal Reserve monetary policy. There was, however, much uncertainty about exactly what changes had occurred in that policy.

headline: AIDE AT 10 DOWNING STREET IS HURT BY A BOMB SENT TO MRS. THATCHER
abstract: A package addressed to Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher containing an incendiary device ignited this afternoon inside her official residence at 10 Downing Street, slightly injuring an official who checks all suspicious mail.   Similar packages were sent to the House of Commons, the police said, bearing the names of Michael Foot, leader of the opposition Labor Party; David Steel, the Liberal leader; Roy Jenkins, the Social Democratic leader, and Timothy Raison, a junior minister at the Home Office whose responsibilities include legislation concerning animals. None of those packages ignited.

headline: New Accounting Standards Board Advances
abstract: An organization to set accounting standards for state and local governments came a step nearer to reality this week with an announcement by the Financial Accounting Foundation that it planned to set up a Government Accounting Standards Board.   The new board would be the public-sector counterpart of the Financial Accounting Standards Board, which sets rules for business.

headline: UNRELENTING REBELS BEFOG THE 'PEACE' IN COLOMBIA
abstract: The suburban setting did not look like a place one would go looking for a leftist rebel. Two young girls in white communion dresses skipped down the street past well-tended lawns and two-story homes, and a delivery boy was busy at the corner tying a boxed pizza to the back of his scooter.   In a driveway midway along the block, a man in sneakers and blue jeans helped his 2-year-old daughter right herself on top of wildly disobedient roller skates. Here, it developed, was the insurgent, 41-year-old Carlos Duplat Sanjuan, home from prison because of a broad amnesty proposed by Colombia's new President, Belisario Betancur.

headline: RATES UP A BIT IN QUIET DAY
abstract: Interest rates rose slightly yesterday in quiet trading as securities dealers cut prices in advance of Treasury sales of shortterm bills and long-term bonds.   Yesterday's modest price declines were attributed to a lack of good news and not to any developments that would change the widespread forecasts of lower interest rates in coming weeks and months.   ''Everybody is in love with what they own,'' one trader of Government agency securities said, ''and there has been no significant selling.''   About the worst that could be said of the credit markets at this time is that ''there is some disquietitude that the outlook is so one-sided,'' said Maury Harris, an economist at Paine Webber Inc. He also expects yields to come down further, but he noted that some investors and traders get nervous when ''everybody starts saying the same thing.''

headline: FED IS TOLD TO KEEP ITS RATES LOW
abstract: In an unusual step, the House of Representatives has directed the Federal Reserve Board to establish a level of interest rates low enough to stimulate economic recovery.   The directive, approved by the House as part of an appropriations bill, was opposed by the Federal Reserve, which has a long tradition of resistance to periodic attempts by Congress to limit its autonomy in managing monetary policy.   ''It comes pretty close to interest-rate targeting,'' a House staff aide declared. The House did not vote on the directive, but passed it as part of an omnibus spending bill that authorizes funds needed to keep the Government operating past Friday. The vote Tuesday night was 204 to 200.

headline: M.T.A. Cancels Japanese Loan
abstract: The Metropolitan Transportation Authority has canceled plans to borrow $126 million from Japan to help finance its purchase of 325 subway cars from Kawasaki Heavy Industries Ltd.   Richard Ravitch, chairman of the M.T.A., said yesterday that, instead, the authority would finance the purchase through the sale of bonds because of the successful rate at which its bonds sold last week.

headline: Indiana Standard In Emirates Deal
abstract: The Standard Oil Company (Indiana) said it had signed an agreement with the United Arab Emirates to sell more than 1.5 trillion cubic feet of natural gas over a 20-year period.   The contract requires Amoco to provide the Emirates' Governmentowned distribution company with a minimum 200 million cubic feet of natural gas a day by mid-1984, increasing to 300 million cubic feet a day by mid-1986.

headline: ARMY RECRUITING THRIVES AS ECONOMY FALTERS
abstract: On the new downtown brick mall, between two empty shops and across the street from a shuttered department store, is one of Youngstown's most successful enterprises, the Armed Forces Recruiting Station.   ''We've gone double in terms of quality,'' said Sgt. 1st Class Joe W. Jenkins, the chief Army recruiter here, sitting at his desk, his green tunic, resplendent with ribbons and badges, hanging on a nearby coat hanger. ''Numbers are up, too.''   For the fiscal year 1982, which ended Sept. 30, Sergeant Jenkins said he was authorized to recruit 95 regular Army soldiers and 41 Army reservists. He said he was able to recruit 107 people for the regular Army and 52 reservists and added that if he had accepted all those who wanted to join, he probably could have enlisted more than 700 men and women.

headline: SAVINGS BOND TIED TO MARKET
abstract: President Reagan announced today that starting Nov. 1, the Treasury will offer United States Savings Bonds whose return is tied - for the first time - to market interest rates.    Also, if the bonds are held for five years or more, they will pay a minimum rate - 7.5 percent - which will not go down if market rates fall below that level.   Under authority requested by the Administration and given by Congress in the 1982 tax act, the President disclosed these details of a major change in the Savings Bonds program intended to make it more attractive to savers.   The variable rate bonds are also meant to counter criticism that people who buy Savings Bonds for small sums fail to get as good a return as they could realize if they could afford marketable Treasury securities that require a minimum purchase of $1,000.

headline: Some Bus Stops
abstract: To the Business Editor: As chairman of the not-for-profit Scarsdale/Hartsdale V.I.P.  Commuter (Bus) Association, I was interested in your article, ''And Now It's the Buses' Turn'' (Oct.3), which discussed the move to deregulate bus routes in the nation.   Based on my recent experiences, I hope that all levels of government will reduce the degree of regulation of bus routes. During the past year I have been involved in obtaining permission to establish a not-for-profit (not subsidized by government) commuter bus service in Westchester County. This service, which is designed for commuters who are fed up with commuter trains to New York City, has received wide support from the public. However, we have been constantly bogged down by government regulation and politics.

headline: Money Fund Assets Still Off
abstract: Assets of the nation's money market funds dropped by $168 million, to $224.6 billion, in the week ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute reported yesterday.   It was the fourth week in a row that the funds' total assets have declined. indicating that investors have apparently been moving money into the stock market and into Government securities and commercial paper as yields in money market funds declined.

headline: MARION CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: SOVIET INFLUENCE IN IRAN SHOWS A SHARP DECLINE
abstract: The influence of the Soviet Union, which saw in the Iranian revolution an opportunity to win a significant role in the Persian Gulf region, has apparently undergone a sharp decline here in the last year.   At the same time, the standing of France, which sheltered Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini and his aides in the final stage of their exile, has also deteriorated.   Ayatollah Khomeini, the leader of the revolution and the dominant figure in the Islamic republic of Iran, has prescribed a foreign policy with the slogan ''Neither East nor West.'' At first it appeared that the East was considered less bad than the West, but lately, in the words of an ambassador from a Western country, ''a balance of negatives has emerged.''

headline: EX-PAN AM OFFICER AT CANADIAN AIRLINE
abstract: Dan A. Colussy, a former president and chief operating officer of Pan American World Airways, has been named to similar posts at CP Air, formerly Canadian Pacific Air Lines.   Mr. Colussy, 51 years old, left Pan Am unexpectedly in 1980. He was seen as a successor to Pan Am's then-chairman, William T. Seawell.  When he left Pan Am, Mr. Colussy said he wanted to pursue a business project. Soon after, he was involved in an unsuccessful attempt by UNC Resources to take over Western Airlines, and in June 1981 announced that he was forming a regional airline that would operate out of Baltimore and be known as Columbia Air.

headline: Rodino Assails Inaction On Bankruptcy Courts
abstract: Representative Peter W. Rodino Jr., chairman of the House Judiciary Committee, today assailed the failure of Congress to meet the Supreme Court's Dec. 24 deadline for restructuring the nation's bankruptcy courts.   Meanwhile, the Justice Department said it would seek an extension of the deadline on Wednesday if it is requested by Congressional leaders, who have said bankruptcy legislation for this session is dead.   Representative Rodino, a New Jersey Democrat, said that the failure of Congress to cure constitutional defects found by the Supreme Court almost six months ago ''blatantly ignored ''a constitutional mandate handed down by the highest court in the land.''

headline: Gas Bills' Benefits Held Small
abstract: Various proposals before Congress to hold down sharply rising prices of natural gas would at best cut consumers' monthly bills by no more than 4 percent, Energy Secretary Donald P. Hodel said today.   That would seem considerably less than the savings held out by sponsors of bills to freeze wellhead prices or override so-called take-or-pay pipeline contracts.   ''Maybe these two things that are being talked about ''would have a 2 to 4 percent impact'' in reducing current bills, Mr. Hodel said.  ''I don't think that's the kind of protection, or help, that is needed.'' He said passage of the legislation could result in ''terribly disappointed'' consumers.

headline: NATIONAL GYPSUM CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30

headline: Real Estate; British Methods in Manhattan
abstract: IT was the fall of 1980, the commercial real estate market was booming and Brian Rainbow bought the first piece of Manhattan property for his company, Royco Development. Mr. Rainbow, president of Royco, was one of many new foreigners in a hot market. Royco was founded in Britain in the 1960's by Roy Strudwick, and the company does both commercial and residential development.   Mr. Rainbow spent a year traveling across America looking for opportunities to invest before deciding on New York City.  Now the company has a $60 million, 270,000-square-foot luxury office building under construction on 52d Street between Lexington and Third Avenues. It will be finished about June, but by many accounts the market for new office buildings has begun to wither. Mr. Rainbow shows no signs of being worried even though the building, like other new midtown projects, has no tenant yet.

headline: Midlantic Banks
abstract: Midlantic Banks Inc. said its board had agreed in principle to acquire the Greater Jersey Bancorp for $36 a share in cash and stock, creating New Jersey's largest commercial banking corporation, with assets exceeding $5.35 billion. Based on 2,202,000 Greater Jersey shares outstanding, the transaction would be worth $72.8 million.

headline: SEOUL OPPOSITION LEADER ASKS END OF BAN ON 580 POLITICIANS
abstract: A prominent opposition leader has urged that the South Korean Government lift a ban on some 580 politicians at once to restore ''elementary freedoms and democracy to the people of South Korea.''  The head of the banned New Democratic Party, Kim Young Sam, who was reached by telephone at his home where he has been under house arrest for the last seven months, also urged that President Chun Doo Hwan restore freedom of the press.  ''That is fundamental,'' he said. ''We have to have a free press in my country. That is where everything begins. It is an essential of any democracy.''

headline: THE SQUEEZE FACING INSURERS
abstract: The old saw about the business that lost money on every sale but made it up on volume has had a bitter ring for the property and casualty insurance industry in recent years.   For as a result of severe price cutting since 1978 - especially in commercial, rather than personal, lines where corporate buyers have economic muscle - insurance companies as a group have been reporting steady underwriting losses, or losses from the sale of insurance products. But the earnings from the investments in their portfolios have far surpassed the deficits from price cutting, thereby enabling the industry to post overall profits.   Now the nation's insurers are concerned that the sharp drop in interest rates that began last August will cut their investment income substantially. And without this protective cushion, there is widespread fear that the overall profitability of insurers, which are regulated by the states, will be significantly reduced unless premiums are immediately increased.

headline: Quake Kills 6 Afghan Miners
abstract: Afghanistan's state radio said today that at least six people were killed in a mine by an earthquake that jolted the northern part of the country. The Kabul radio said the quake was felt in Kabul, the capital, and areas as far north as Baghlan, about 120 miles away.

headline: Mexican Refinery Blows Up
abstract: Two explosions at a natural gas refinery in this Texas-Mexico border town early today sent flames into the air and illuminated the sky. An official at the Progreso International Bridge said there were two explosions, the first at about 3:15 A.M., Eastern standard time, and the second 15 minutes later. Initial accounts said no one was believed injured.

headline: Executive Resumes Career at Warner
abstract: Ted Ashley has decided to chuck retirement and go back to work full time. Warner Communications Inc., the entertainment giant, announced yesterday that he had joined the company as vice chairman.

headline: PARKWAY VILLAGE IN QUEENS GOING CO-OP
abstract: The people who opened a garden apartment development for United Nations personnel in the Kew Gardens Hills section of Queens 35 years ago probably considered it only logical to name the community Parkway Village.   The Grand Central Parkway is at the southern boundary of the site, which runs from Main Street to Parsons Boulevard. And the word village is appropriate because of a community-like quality achieved in the site planning. The 109 two- and three-story buildings surround a road network that moves through expanses of lawn and mature trees. Gateposts at the entrances and exits to the 37-acre site give the development a sense of privacy.

headline: After-Death Tax Planning
abstract: ESTATE planning does not have to end with the death of an individual. His or her executor, as well the beneficiaries, can often undertake a number of steps that might also reduce taxes.   After-death tax planning encompasses a careful look at potential Federal estate and state inheritance taxes, fiduciary income taxes on the estate and any trusts and the decedent's final income tax return. Savings can be made in all of these areas by investigating possible alternatives and selecting the option that calls for the lowest tax.

headline: KNOTTY ISSUE FOR CENTRAL BANKS
abstract: In 1974, during a banking crisis brought on by the collapse of a small West German bank, central bankers met in Switzerland and decided they could provide sufficient assistance to the world's banking system, should the need arise.   Western commercial bankers saw the decision as a sign of official support in case of troubles in unregulated banking centers, such as the Bahamas or Luxembourg, where the banks were expanding rapidly.   Then, after eight years of headway into the unregulated centers, came the collapse last summer of Banco Ambrosiano of Milan, Italy.  The glaring lesson to bankers came when Italy's central bank failed to bail out Ambrosiano's Luxembourg subsidiary, which owed some $400 million to other banks. With that, the bankers' perceptions of official support shattered.

headline: P.L.O. USED SCHOOL RUN BY U.N. AGENCY
abstract: A trade school near Beirut run by a United Nations relief agency was used by the Palestine Liberation Organization for military courses for 781 students over two years, according to a report by the agency.   The report by the United Nations Relief and Works Agency, which has been caring for Palestinians since 1950, said the Siblin Training Center allowed armed P.L.O. instructors to live in the camp, store arms in a basement that was barred to United Nations employees and send radio messages from it and conduct military classes for young men and women studying trades. Diplomas were withheld from vocational graduates until they had served a year with the guerrilla organization, the report said.   ''The center's premises were evidently used to provide systematic military training to the center's students,'' the report on an internal inquiry said.

headline: PATENTS; A Way of Repairing Space Shuttle Tiles
abstract: An invention that has been used effectively in repairing damage to the delicate tiles on the surface of the space shuttle Columbia was patented this week for the National Aeronautics and Space Administration. Glenn M. Icord and Calvin Schomburg, aerospace engineers at the Johnson Space Center in Houston, obtained patent 4,358,480 for the materials and process.  Patent 4,358,486 was also issued to the two engineers this week for a method that may be used to pad the under surface of the tiles.

headline: PLANT USE SET A LOW LAST MONTH
abstract: With nearly a third of production lines idle, the nation's factories operated last month at their lowest levels of capacity since the Government began keeping records in 1948, the Federal Reserve reported today.   Capacity utilization now stands at only 68.4 percent, below the 69 percent rate posted during March 1975, the final month of the 1973-75 recession.   This latest piece of grim industrial news means not only that a major part of the economy continued to decline in October but also, according to some economists, that when recovery comes, many American factories may not be equipped to meet it.   Another troubled sector, the construction industry, took some comfort from a report today showing that while October home starts were up only 1 percent from September, permits for future construction, spurred by lower interest rates, were up 17.7 percent.  (Page D11.)

headline: Israel Thanks the U.S.
abstract: Foreign Minister Yitzhak Shamir has thanked the United States for helping defeat an Iranian motion to expel Israel from the United Nations General Assembly, the Foreign Ministry said today. A spokesman said Mr. Shamir wrote to Secretary of State George P. Shultz thanking him ''for all the effort the United States put into insuring the failure of the Iranian motion.''

headline: IN METRIC FIGHT, CANADA M.P.'S TURN TO GALLON
abstract: The Government threatened this week to begin prosecuting merchants who have not adopted the metric standard, and 26 opposition Members of Parliament promptly challenged the move by taking over a filling station for the purpose of selling gasoline by the gallon.   Andre Ouellet, the Minister of Consumer and Corporate Affairs, announced an imminent crackdown on businesses that have ignored his ministry's earlier orders to stop selling by the gallon, pound, ounce or foot.   ''This is the last warning that I want to give on behalf of the Government,'' Mr. Ouellet said. He added that action against offenders would begin in a few days and that offenders faced fines of up to $1,000 for each day's delay in switching to liters, kilograms, grams and meters.

headline: Israelis Withhold Data on War
abstract: Israel is withholding information from the United States about military lessons gained from its invasion of Lebanon until Washington agrees to certain conditions demanded by Israel, according to officials in Jerusalem.   Israeli sources said a stumbling block was a clause in the agreement requiring Israeli consent before Washington passes on information to North Atlantic Treaty Organization countries or other third parties.

headline: SOVIET SAYS SANCTIONS MUST END
abstract: Senior Soviet trade officials told a group of American businessmen convening here today for the first time in four years that Washington would have to renounce trade sanctions if United States-Soviet trade were to revive. But they appeared eager for a resumption.   In the opening Soviet address to some 250 American executives gathered for a four-day trade conference, the Soviet Minister for Foreign Trade, Nikolai S. Patolichev, said: ''It is necessary for the United States to renounce once and for all the doctrine of using trade as a weapon against our country.''   Without the confidence that agreements would not be broken, Mr.  Patolichev declared, ''no businessman will sign a deal.'' Since 1979, the last year before economic sanctions of one sort or another were imposed, the American share of Soviet machinery imports had dropped to 3 percent from 7 percent, and the United States share of grain imports fell to 17 percent from 71 percent, the minister said. He added that only eight-tenths of 1 percent of Soviet equipment purchases now come from the United States.

headline: News Analysis
abstract: The campaign for the parliamentary elections in March has started, and the battered and demoralized Free Democrats appear to be stumbling.   Rarely has such uncertainty enveloped a West German election. The voting, promised for March 6 by Chancellor Helmut Kohl, could fundamentally alter the nation's political landscape, but some politicians have mounted a rear-guard action to prevent the election from taking place.   Not surprisingly, reluctance to face the voters is strongest among the small Free Democratic Party, which in September brought down Helmut Schmidt's Social Democratic Government by throwing its parliamentary support behind Mr. Kohl's conservative Christian Democrats.

headline: S.E.C. STAFF FAULTS BROKERS IN REPORT ON '80 SILVER CRISIS
abstract: Six major stock brokerage firms risked losing hundreds of millions of dollars two years ago because they gave excessive credit to the Hunt family of Texas for silver speculation, according to a staff report of the Securities and Exchange Commission that was released today.   The report also criticized the New York Stock Exchange for failing to detect the extent of the potential crisis as it developed.  In the months following the collapse of silver prices in the spring of 1980, regulators and the financial community were generally led to believe that Bache Halsey Stuart Shields Inc. had borne the greatest losses by extending credit to the Hunts.   But the S.E.C. said that five other firms - Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner & Smith Inc.; Dean Witter Reynolds Inc.; E.F. Hutton & Company; A.G. Edwards & Sons Inc., and Paine, Webber, Jackson & Curtis Inc. -faced potentially damaging losses.

headline: Israeli Minister in Argentina At Start of a Four-Day Visit
abstract: Foreign Minister Yitzhak Shamir of Israel arrived today for a four-day official visit to Argentina that will include a meeting with President Reynaldo Bignone, the Foreign Ministry said.   Mr. Shamir told reporters he would raise questions with Argentine officials about the thousands of people who disappeared in the military crackdown against leftist guerrillas in the late 1970's.

headline: BRIEFS
abstract: * American Telephone and Telegraph Co. said its Advanced Mobile Phone Service subsidiary had given the F.C.C. the details of its agreements with 18 other telephone companies on providing mobile telephone service in 13 areas.   * Asarco Inc. said it would lower its base spot price on refined lead by one cent, to 22 cents a pound, for delivered carload lots.   * Combustion Engineering Inc. said its Vetco Offshore subsidiary had sold a complete offshore drilling system to China; terms were not disclosed.

headline: GROWING UNREST SETS OFF ALARM BELLS IN ARGENTINA
abstract: Three days after thousands of anti-Government demonstrators were dispersed with tear gas and gunfire, Argentina's Roman Catholic Church declared today a ''Day of National Reconciliation'' and, in sermons throughout the nation, priests read a statement pleading for social peace.   The time has come, the statement said, for Argentines to stop ''blaming each other'' and ''for each person to accept his part of the responsibility for the grave mistakes and blunders of the past.''    It was a plea that reflected a fear shared by many Argentines: as the military Government of President Reynaldo B. Bignone is moving under pressure to return the country to democracy, many here sense a growing danger that the country will slide into anarchy during the transition.   The country is still mostly peaceful, but adding to Argentines' fears is an awareness that the country has broken down into violence many times in the last 50 years. In the 1970's more than 10,000 people reportedly died or disappeared in political terrorism and military actions to counter the terrorism.

headline: Key Rates
abstract: Previous   Year

headline: Real Estate; Shift Seen In Housing Outlook
abstract: THE tide is changing in real estate, according to Herve A.  Kevenides, vice president and director of real estate economics and market research at the Chemical Bank. New growth in residential construction is expected, he says, at a time of decline for commercial real estate.   His conclusions are based on results of a computerized real estate forecasting model that analyzes trends in 15 major metropolitan areas of the country.   ''All of the $25 billion increase in construction contracts forecasted for 1983 will occur in the residential sector,'' Mr.  Kevenides said in his report of the study. ''The key factors behind this outlook is a significant amount of overbuilding in most commercial markets accompanied on the residential side by a continued high level of demand, lower interest rates, a decline in consumer debt burden, improved consumer confidence backed by higher income and availability of mortgage funds.''

headline: Money Fund Assets Drop
abstract: Assets of the nation's 268 money market funds dropped $469 million, to $230.5 billlion, in the week ended Wednesday, following a decline of $309 million the week before, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday.   The 70 broker-dealer funds dropped $126 million in assets, to $113.7 billion; the 46 institutional funds, used by large investors, declined $822 million, to $43.4 billion.

headline: ISRAELI PARATROOPS ACCUSE SHARON OF SLANDER AND DEMAND APOLOGY
abstract: Veterans in an elite reserve paratroop brigade signed a petition today that accused Defense Minister Ariel Sharon of slandering them and that demanded a public apology.   They said Mr. Sharon had accused the unit in a television interview on Sept. 24 of refusing to fight during the invasion of Lebanon.  Mr. Sharon said in the interview that ''a certain reserve brigade'' had not been mobilized because of morale problems stemming from criticism within the unit of the invasion.   The unit fought 25 days in the opening stages of the invasion, with 10 of its members killed and 70 wounded. It was called up again on Aug. 8 for 21 days for an assault on West Beirut that did not materialize.

headline: MITTERRAND VISITING MUBARAK
abstract: President Francois Mitterrand of France arrived in Egypt today for three days of talks with President Hosni Mubarak aimed at strengthening the ''special relationship'' between the two countries.   The streets were lines with French and Egyptian flags, a television program depicted the life of the French President and radio programs played French songs.

headline: Hilton Hotels' Net Off by 27%
abstract: The Hilton Hotels Corporation reported yesterday that its net income for the fiscal third quarter fell 27 percent, to $19.3 million, or 73 cents a share, from $26.4 million, or 99 cents a share, in the corresponding quarter of 1981. Revenue dropped 29.1 percent, to $30.9 million from $43.6 million.

headline: Chrysler Office In Japan Reported
abstract: The Chrysler Corporation is planning to open an office here early next year to procure parts for its plants, according to a spokesman for Mitsubishi Motors, of which Chrysler owns 15 percent.   Commenting on a report that Chrysler is considering buying $1.9 billion worth of parts from Japan between 1983 and 1987, the spokesman said, ''We have no information to confirm the reported procurement except the setting up of a procurement office.''

headline: Building Index Rises
abstract: Contracting for new construction rose a seasonally adjusted 4 percent in September, extending a six-month upward trend, the F.W.  Dodge division of the McGraw-Hill Information Systems Company said.  Construction contracting is a leading indicator of future spending for on-site construction and building materials manufacturing. Newly started construction of all kinds totaled $14.2 billion.

headline: ON THE FRONTIER OF A NEW ECONOMICS
abstract: ELECTION day, November 1932.  America's economic problems were the dominant issue - the only issue - in the landslide Presidential victory of Franklin Delano Roosevelt. The economy was in collapse and F.D.R. had pledged to create jobs for the nation's 12 million unemployed - while somehow managing to balance the Federal budget. Little did he know then that eventually he would embrace the radical ideas of a Briton named John Maynard Keynes, who advocated huge deficit spending to bring the United States out of its depression.   Now it is election day, 1982. The shattered economy is once again the dominant issue of a national political campaign. Unemployment is at 10.1 percent, not the 24 percent of Roosevelt's era - thanks in large part to the adoption since then of Keynesian policies to cushion an economic decline. Still, hopes for recovery keep moving further into the future, notwithstanding the President's insistence on the campaign trail this fall that his policies will soon restore the economy to buoyant, noninflationary growth.   There are some who share this belief, who think the economy's vitality can be restored by shrinking the relative size of Government and lowering tax rates. And there are others who, doubting this, still think that Keynesian policies remain the basic solution to the nation's economic problems, with some minor modifications to avoid a revival of inflation.

headline: ARGENTINA INVESTIGATING SECRET ITALIAN LODGE
abstract: Reports that prominent Argentines have been members of a secret Italian lodge called Propaganda 2 are being investigated here after the recent arrest in Switzerland of the Italian industrialist who headed it.   The industrialist, Licio Gelli, who was seized with a fraudulent Argentine passport in mid-September, was said to have disappeared from Italy 18 months ago and to have been in hiding here and in Uruguay under the protection of military leaders. Among the charges filed against him in Italy were swindling and espionage.

headline: Vice Chairman Named At Chase Manhattan
abstract: John A. Hooper has been named vice chairman of the Chase Manhattan Bank, the bank said yesterday.  Mr. Hooper, 60, has been senior executive vice president and is the bank's chief credit officer. He has responsibility for credit policy, country risk policy, real estate finance and lending services.   He also plays a mean jazz piano. Mr. Hooper has been known to play at meetings of the American Bankers Association and to sit in now and then with professional musicians.

headline: MOBIL HOMES GAINING
abstract: For the past three years, the effect of high prices and mortgage rates has taken a toll on all home builders. Some have fared better than others, however, and manufacturers of mobile homes have weathered the industry's depression quite well. Since 1979, mobile homes have captured an increasingly bigger share of the shrinking new single-family home market.
